From alan at clueserver.org  Tue Oct  1 00:02:44 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 01 Oct 2002 00:02:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] More on UT 2003
Message-ID: <1033455764.7592.5.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

The discs are mislabeled in the installer. disc 1 is actually the "play
disc". Disc 2 is actually disc 1. Disc 3 is actually disc 2.  The
installer for Linux is on the last disc. (Marked disc 3, but the
installer calls it disc 2.)

The controls are not what I am used to. It is going to take some time. 
High resolutions are not always the best as the deatil can overwhelm
your targets.

You will probably need an nVidia AGP card as well as the closed source
nVidia drivers to play the game.  (Along with a big beefy machine.)

So far, I can play the game with full detail cranked up and it works
fine.  But I am using a dual Athalon 2100+ MP system with 512M and an
nVidia card with 64 megs of ram. Your millage may vary.


-- 
Alan <alan at clueserver.org>

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Oct  1 00:16:53 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 00:16:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] time-based rule
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEIPCAAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210010008350.1177-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, BMDimaculangan wrote:

> hello to all folks,
>
> we have a rule in our company that permits corporate IT departments full use
> and access of precious corporate bandwidth for critical mission activities.
> As well as key managers and top management may enjoy the same access
> benefits.  However, some employees are not included to this kind of benefit.
> According to the rule, access to the Internet is made possible only during
> noontime break, from 12:00 noon to 1:00 in the afternoon only but corporate
> email exchange is available throughout the working day.  My problem is, how
> can I apply and implement this rule in our Linux Server. Any idea?

Though it has been giving me some headaches, the newer 2.4 kernels include
some complex facilities for bandwidth management.  Using these along with
iptables (for selection of traffic types and/or machines whose bandwidth
you want to regulate), you should be able to setup pretty much anything
you like, then just run a shell script from a crontab at 12:00 and 1:00 to
make the necessary policy changes.  These facilities are part of the
current iproute software package in recent versions of linux, the
"tc" and "ip" commands are the primary ones of interest, but be warned
that the documentation sucks, and much is not documented at all.
There is however a web site which provides a great deal more info,
though it still hasn't solved my problems :-(   See:

   www.lartc.org

for more information.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

"Kenneth G. Stephens" wrote:
Tried this too, but all I got when selecting Linux from the Windows
boot process was an 'L' on a frozen screen. In reading other HOWTOs,
others have gotten as far as "LI" before their screen freezes.
Apparently the boot record is not being written correctly by LILO,
so when I "dd if=/dev/hdb2 of=/mnt/floppy/linux.bin bs=512 count=1"
that file linux.bin is no good for booting. I even tried running
LILO pointed to a floppy and dd'ing the boot record from that. This
time I got the 'L' and a screen full of 00's.


> The next step is to dd if=<linux boot partition> of=bootsect.lnx bs=512
> count=1.
> 
> This gives you your boot sector to load into windows 2000.  Put this file on a
> dos floppy.
> 
> Boot <shudder>Windows</shudder> and copy this file to C:/.  The edit boot.ini.
> It is normally read-only so you may have to play with permissions and add the
> following line to the bottom of the file:  C:/bootsect.lnx="Linux"
> 
> The next time you boot windows you will have a choice of
> <shudder>Windows</shudder> or <hooray>Linux</hooray>
> --

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Oct  1 06:41:47 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 06:41:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] uppercase email attachments extension
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEINCAAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210010640440.1848-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, BMD wrote:

> anyone who can tell me how deal with filtering email attachments with
> uppercase extensions?

  In postfix's header_checks, you can use 'i' after the final slash in the
regex. This changes the default, case-sensitive checks to case insensitive.

Rich




From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Oct  1 07:26:15 2002

Here's a review with a nice tip.

http://www.osnews.com/story.php?news_id=1842&page=all

"There is this new feature coming with RH8 that you create a directory
called ~/.fonts and you throw in all your TTF fonts in there, and they get
recognized automatically from the system!......Too bad that
OOo(OpenOffice.org) does not recognize the TTF fonts I installed on my
~/.fonts dir, though. Other GTK+ application can't see them either, eg.
gedit, while other can (eg.  Gnome2 Terminal). This is an incosintency
issue and, in my opinion, it should be fixed."

I'll have to see how well it works.

Keith

From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Oct  1 10:27:06 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 10:27:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011022210.4597-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

I just found one of my servers infected with the Slapper.C(Cinik) worm. 
This machine is totally up to date as far as Red Hat Network, which means 
openssl-0.9.6b-28.

I have read most of the threads in here on Slapper and I surmised that RH 
back-ported the appropriate fix. Apparently I was wrong, and now all my 
machines are exposed.

For more info:
http://isc.incidents.org/analysis.html?id=173
http://isc.incidents.org/analysis.html?id=167

Now, on to damage control mode :-/

Keith




From mikeraz at patch.com  Tue Oct  1 08:30:55 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 08:30:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] time-based rule
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEIPCAAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>; from bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph on Tue, Oct 01, 2002 at 02:53:00PM +0800
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEIPCAAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20021001083055.G19981@patch.com>

On Tue, Oct 01, 2002 at 02:53:00PM +0800, BMDimaculangan typed:
> hello to all folks,
> According to the rule, access to the Internet is made possible only during
> noontime break, from 12:00 noon to 1:00 in the afternoon only but corporate
> email exchange is available throughout the working day.  My problem is, how
> can I apply and implement this rule in our Linux Server. Any idea?

<rant>that rule sucks</rant>

>From the question, I'm assuming that "our Linux Server" is "our Linux Firewall".

You'll need to/could:

	segregate the people allowed full access and noon-time access into
	  differing IP address pools

	have a rule early in the FORWARD set that defines access for the 
	  group with limited access

	use cron to modify the rule at noon and 1:00pm


This could be as simple as

	iptables -R FORWARD <RULENUM> <RULESPEC> {-j ALLOW or DENY depending on time}

-- 
      Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz
    Be appropriate && Follow your curiosity
 http://www.patch.com/ http://wiki.patch.com/
       http://blog.patch.com/sandbox/

   The fortune cookie says:
I have hardly ever known a mathematician who was capable of reasoning.
		-- Plato



From ziggy at anodizing.com  Tue Oct  1 08:28:27 2002
From: ziggy at anodizing.com (Abraham Zwygart)
Date: Tue, 01 Oct 2002 08:28:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209271518500.9177-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <1033253151.1223.26.camel@laptop> <3D98725F.2C3E9404@gisnet.com> <200209302054.14125.kens@cad2cam.com>
Message-ID: <3D99BF1B.BA84832C@anodizing.com>

This is how I got it to work.  When installing Linux I used grub as the boot
loader.
Let every thing go by default except that you have to put a label on the nt
partition
or grub will not see it.  To do this at install time when it shows the boot loader
options
at the bottom of the screen it will list the different partitions and a check mark
on the
default boot partition.  Select the nt/dos partition and the above this line you
can
put in the label name.

Hope this helps
Abraham Zwygart

"Kenneth G. Stephens" wrote:

> On Monday 30 September 2002 08:48 am, Bill Thoen wrote:
> > Thanks for all the help, folks! I did get Linux loaded into the
> > 2nd partition of my 2nd disk, but dual-booting won't work with
> > this set-up. I had to use fdisk set up swap and native Linux
> > partitions (Disk Druid would allow it) and the RedHat 7.1 install
> > process took a couple of tries (it locked up just prior to
> > actually loading files.)
> >
> > The dual boot did not work I think because I couldn't get LILO to
> > write a proper boot record into the Linux partition (which starts
> > at the 21st GB of that 40GB disk.) It kept giving me a warning
> > that the boot area was not on the first disk, but otherwise
> > seemed to work. However, when I tried to copy the boot record
> > into a file with dd, the resulting file would not boot Linux when
> > used with Win2K's boot loader.
> >
> > Anyway I can boot Linux from a floppy when I need it, so at least
> > my first objective (to load Linux without hosing Windows2000) has
> > been achieved. Someday when I'm smarter I'll tackle the dual-boot
> > problem again. Setting up a dual boot machine seems very simple
> > in theory, but in practice there's a lot of variables among the
> > infinite number of configurations and one needs some genreal
> > experience to recognize problems.
> The next step is to dd if=<linux boot partition> of=bootsect.lnx bs=512
> count=1.
>
> This gives you your boot sector to load into windows 2000.  Put this file on a
> dos floppy.
>
> Boot <shudder>Windows</shudder> and copy this file to C:/.  The edit boot.ini.
> It is normally read-only so you may have to play with permissions and add the
> following line to the bottom of the file:  C:/bootsect.lnx="Linux"
>
> The next time you boot windows you will have a choice of
> <shudder>Windows</shudder> or <hooray>Linux</hooray>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Oct  1 10:50:58 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 10:50:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011022210.4597-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011048070.11689-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> I just found one of my servers infected with the Slapper.C(Cinik)
> worm.  This machine is totally up to date as far as Red Hat Network,
> which means openssl-0.9.6b-28.
> 
> I have read most of the threads in here on Slapper and I surmised
> that RH back-ported the appropriate fix. Apparently I was wrong, and
> now all my machines are exposed.

OK, so before I scouring my systems, could you just assure me that

a) you don't have any services running that were statically linked 
   against older, vulnerable openssl libs

b) that you restarted all ssl-enabled services (web, mail, whatever) 
   after you updated to the latest openssl rpm

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Oct  1 09:17:54 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 09:17:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re wget
In-Reply-To: <3D98FFD0.4050102@attbi.com>
References: <3D98FFD0.4050102@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021001161754.GB14971@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

wget is a handy tool to know of. The -m switch makes it mirror the site you
specify, following links. This doesn't work with many dynamic-content sites
however (wget sees the page "hey, this is a new version!" grabs it,
eventually finds a link back to the top, queries the server for the page,
sees it, "Hey, this is a new version!" grabs it...")

Just doing wget <url> will pull just that url down the pipe. 

A useful thing to do would be to bind a key to a script that cd's to a
predefined downloads dir and runs wget on whatever is in the clipboard.

-Rogan


On Mon, Sep 30, 2002 at 06:52:16PM -0700, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> Thanks Rogan and Russ. Never used wget, and it seems to be working.
> Dirk
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug



From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Oct  1 11:06:48 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 11:06:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re wget
In-Reply-To: <20021001161754.GB14971@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011102030.11689-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, Rogan Creswick wrote:

> wget is a handy tool to know of.

As is curl, which supports a ton of protocols: http, https, ftp, 
gopher, dict, telnet (!), ldap, or even file. It even can handle 
cookies. Sadly, however, I don't think it has the equivalent of wget's 
--mirror option.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

where firewalls come in very handy. I made the usual modifications to 
httpd.conf and checked /tmp for signs, then made changes to my 
firewall (appliance) configuration. Closed ALL incoming UDP ports,

security." I love my Netscreen(s), but I'm going to use iptables as 
well, when I finish my server upgrades in a couple of weeks.

damage control process. I can say that I've been there with similar 
issues in the past. I got suckered into trying WireX's "Immunix 7"

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Tue Oct  1 11:50:55 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Tue, 01 Oct 2002 12:50:55 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011022210.4597-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <3D99EE8F.BF8F7022@gisnet.com>

My server got slapped silly with the A variant about two weeks
ago, so I fixed it and updated my openssl RPM then. Since then my
server's logs show about 3-4 attacks per night -- but none have
got through since. A friend down the hall upgraded in time too,
but he forgot to restart httpd and he got "slapped" with the B
version the very next day. 

Seems to me, given the numerous (failed) attempts for slapper to
get into my machine lately, that the current RPM is okay as long
as you restart httpd. At least I hope so.

Here's what a successful attack looks like (in
/var/log/httpd/error_log):
[Thu Sep 12 15:43:11 2002] [error] [client 12.163.231.102] client
sent HTTP/1.1 request without hostname (see RFC2616 section
14.23): /
[Thu Sep 12 15:43:16 2002] [error] mod_ssl: SSL handshake failed
(server www.gisnet.com:443, client 12.163.231.102) (OpenSSL
library error follows)
[Thu Sep 12 15:48:13 2002] [error] mod_ssl: SSL handshake timed
out (client 12.163.231.102, server www.gisnet.com:443)
[Thu Sep 12 15:48:13 2002] [error] mod_ssl: SSL handshake timed
out (client 12.163.231.102, server www.gisnet.com:443)

(lots of SSL handshake timeout messages follow)

After the upgrade, here's what a failed attack looks like:
[Mon Sep 30 20:35:53 2002] [error] [client 211.133.188.52] client
sent HTTP/1.1 request without hostname (see RFC2616 section
14.23): /
[Mon Sep 30 20:36:03 2002] [error] mod_ssl: SSL handshake failed
(server www.gisnet.com:443, client 211.133.188.52) (OpenSSL
library error follows)
[Mon Sep 30 20:36:03 2002] [error] OpenSSL: error:1406B458:SSL
routines:GET_CLIENT_MASTER_KEY:key arg too long

(No SSL handshake messages follow.)

- Bill Thoen

>>  where firewalls come in very handy. I made the usual modifications to

>>  firewall (appliance) configuration. Closed ALL incoming UDP ports,
>>  except 2.
>>
>
>Please, rub my nose, I have to learn it :-) Before I turn off all UDP,
>which ports have to be open? DNS needs 53, right?



	Don't know for YOU, ... but for ME, I closed all UDP ports 
except DNS (53) and SMTP (25). I don't know what services you run on 
your box(-es), so I can't suggest anything - YMMV. At least one 
version of Slapper likes UDP port 2002. That door - and nearly 
everything else - is closed on my system(s).

	I've check /tmp several times. Grepped /var/log/messages(*) 
and so forth. I'm clean (knock wood).

	FWIW, I highly recommend Netscreen firewall appliances. I'm 
sure that some hard-core Linux heads will say that IPtables work just 
fine, and more power to them. I like a box OUTSIDE of my server(s) 
and the Netscreen(s) work just great - VPN, IPSec, etc. They're a 
bear to configure, but worth it!

	Hope that this helps.   ;-)




Patrick Beart

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Tue Oct  1 12:58:00 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Tue, 01 Oct 2002 13:58:00 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011213590.4702-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <3D99FE48.8273649A@gisnet.com>

Keith Nasman wrote:
> I know the recommended cure is a total rebuild but what are the steps to
> purge the system of this worm? I'll be pouring over the RPM verify output
> pretty quick here. I've deleted the files in /tmp and of course killed the
> .cinik process.

Because it's a complete compromise (i.e. they can run any code
they like on your system) the only sure cure is a complete
rebuild. But I think the risk vs cost to rebuild equation differs
depending on what's at risk. To me, I can afford to shut off my
one server for a few days while I scream and kick and chew the
rug trying to figure out how to repair the mess. Others may not
have that luxury and need to be able to show due diligence
towards their company's internet security. So I just pulled the
obvious teeth from the beastie and now watch my logs closer. So
far so good.

Here's some tips I collected for dealing with the A version (UDP
ports are different for the different versions, but for A they
are 2002.):

To look for your own IP in other people's firewall logs:
	http://dshield.org/warning_explanation.php
To check what other ports are open:
        $ netstat -an | grep -v ^unix
To see what process is bound to each port:
        # /usr/sbin/lsof -i -P |more
To check for a listening port 2002
        # netstat -an | grep 2002
To check for activity on a port (2002 in this case):
        # tcpdump -n udp port 2002

URLs:
http://online.securityfocus.com/

After de-fanging slapper, I had a lot of traffic on port 2002 at
first but it died off rapidly after I wasn't responding to the
infected zombie peers. AS long as you don't see your IP send out
messages (use tcpdump), you're okay and they'll leave you alone
in a few days.

- Bill Thoen



From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Oct  1 12:57:18 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)

As was discussed earlier, what probably happened is that I didn't restart 
the apache service after the RPM upgrade. Below is the response I got as 
well as a file to compile to test for the vulnerability.

Thanks for all the hints/tips/cluesticks.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 01 Oct 2002 15:17:14 -0400
From: Ken Snider <ksnider at flarn.com>
Reply-To: rhn-users at redhat.com
To: rhn-users at redhat.com
Subject: Re: [rhn-users] Slapper.C/ OpenSSL

Keith Nasman wrote:
> Found the below article in the archives from 17Sep02. I'm a new subscriber 
> (as of a few minutes ago), so please let me know if I've missed some 
> appropriate discussion in viewing the archines.
> 
> I just found one of my servers infected with the Slapper.C (Cinik) worm. 
> The machine in question is managed with RHN and is fully up to date. I am 
> concerned that the openssl that is current in RHN is not fully patched. I 
> have looked at: 
> 
> http://isc.incidents.org/analysis.html?id=167
> http://isc.incidents.org/analysis.html?id=173
> 
> I am taking the precautionary measures listed on my other servers and
> would like to know when a correctly patched version will be available.

Simply, this is completely untrue.

The most logical explanation as to the cause of the problem is that the 
server was not rebooted (as was suggested in the errata) or your apache 
otherwise restarted, and the ssl libraries unloaded. If you do not do this, 
simply updating on rhn will *not* secure your system.

Here's a file you can compile to test your servers for the vulnerability. 
Every one of our servers, from RH 6.2 to 7.3, was not vulnerable after 
adding the errata and rebooting to clear the libraries.

--
Ken Snider

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Oct  1 14:54:55 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 14:54:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011153220.4702-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011449360.15301-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> > b) that you restarted all ssl-enabled services (web, mail,
> >    whatever) after you updated to the latest openssl rpm
> > 
> That I did not. I guess that is a standard procedure that I didn't
> know about. Does that mean that these other services keep a running
> copy for themselves, rather than hitting the (updated) library each
> time? Enlighten me on this :-)

A competent C programmer could give you a more complete explanation...

What seems to happen is that when a process (e.g., httpd) is started, 
the linker maps into memory any dynamic libraries against which the 
process is linked (e.g., libssl.so) and then does magic so that the 
main process can find the library's routines in memory.

Once started, the process typically doesn't have anything to do with
the disk-based copy of itself or the libraries against which it's
linked.

So you can delete a program or its libraries out from underneath 
itself without affecting the running process.

The only way to pick up new, patched libraries it to restart the 
process.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From brmiller at kudzuforest.com  Tue Oct  1 16:53:03 2002
From: brmiller at kudzuforest.com (Brendan Miller)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 16:53:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with Sparc kernel recompile
In-Reply-To: <200209281204.40653.aschlemm@attbi.com>; from aschlemm@attbi.com on Sat, Sep 28, 2002 at 12:04:40PM -0700
References: <017401c2670c$3a0d16c0$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> <200209281204.40653.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021001165303.E23221@kudzuforest.com>

> > I'm attempting to recompile the kernel for my Sparc20.  I picked
> > 2.4.9 because, well, it's listed at the bottom (vs. 2.4.19 which are
> > listed near the top) ;-)
> >
> > When it comes to the actual compile, 'make bzImage' and 'make zImage'
> > fail.  In my research this appears to be because I dont have x86
> > architecture.  I have seen suggestions for both 'make boot' and 'make
> > vmlinux'.  Both seem to do the same thing (fail at the end because
> > 2.4.9's vt.c header is broken for Sparc).

The ultralinux.org link will give you pointers on the proper way to build
kernels on a sparc.  I don't think you use the make lilo/boot/zImage/bzImage
that you use on x86.  I think just "make" is all, and then copy the kernel
to the Right Place for silo to find it.  (It's been awhile.)

But does anyone know if they ever fixed the 2.4 kernel series to build on
sparc?  For ahwhile it was broke, and the vt.c header problem seems 
indicative of a generic kernel source for sparc issue as opposed to the
proper make incantation.

Check some spark lists and see if they ever got 2.4 properly ported to 
sparc.  I ran 2.2.18 'cause 2.4.x was broke so long.

Brendan

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Tue Oct  1 19:27:10 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 19:27:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <3D9A543C.6020300@sun.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011232590.3030-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
 <3D9A543C.6020300@sun.com>
Message-ID: <p0510031cb9c007f5f3d5@[192.168.3.1]>

At 7:04 PM -0700 10/1/02, Richard Langis wrote:
>While that may be true with RH-derivitives, Debian restarts just 
>about everything (even pcmcia on a laptop getting sources from the 
>network, grrr) when it upgrades.
>
>IMHO, that's the way it SHOULD be, anyway.  Why upgrade if you're 
>not going to start using the upgraded packages?


	You answered your own question with your "pcmcia" (sic) comment.  ;-)

	If the upgrade (process) only restarted daemons from upgraded 
applications, that would be fine and certainly prevent absent-minded 
omissions such as the one that Keith experienced. OTOH, if the 
upgrade ALWAYS restarted the entire box (server, workstation, 
whatever), then you'd have a Windows-like process that reboots every 
time you breath on it.

	Some people set up cron to run (Red Hat's) "up2date" at 
regular intervals (e.g. weekly). That kind of down time (for weekly 
reboots) would adversely impact a commercial server unless the admin 
was very careful about the timing of the upgrade. A 5 minute reboot, 
once a week, drops a server's uptime to less than 99%, annually (over 
4 hours/yr).




Patrick Beart


>
>Rich Shepard wrote:
>>  Keith,
>>
>>   While I don't run httpd, I don't know of any package that restarts the
>>running daemon upon upgrade or freshen. I've always done this manually.
>>
>>Rich
>

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Tue Oct  1 22:28:29 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Tue, 01 Oct 2002 22:28:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS question
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021002131905.0301bc78@pop.net-yan.com>

use 'dig'

for example to check a dns server for foo.com with the IP of 127.0.0.1
do the following...

dig @127.0.0.1 foo.com ANY

should dump foo.com's info....

root 2775 2729 0 16:21 pts/1 00:00:00 grep bind

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Oct  2 06:44:11 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 06:44:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <3D9A543C.6020300@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020618040.16190-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 1 Oct 2002, Richard Langis wrote:

> While that may be true with RH-derivitives, Debian restarts just
> about everything (even pcmcia on a laptop getting sources from the
> network, grrr) when it upgrades.
> 
> IMHO, that's the way it SHOULD be, anyway.  Why upgrade if you're
> not going to start using the upgraded packages?

I, for one, think it ought to be up to the admin, not the 
package-management system, as to when applications are forced into 
using the upgraded packages.

Take, for instance, the openssl package update. On our main Linux
login server at work (Red Hat 7.3), 136 separate packages require the
openssl dynamic libraries:

  [heinlein]$ rpm -q --whatrequires libssl.so.2 | wc -l
      136

Among them are

* mail clients: balsa, evolution, mutt, pine
* web browers: galeon, lynx
* service daemons: apache, openldap, postgresql, sendmail, squid

I like to be able to upgrade libraries as soon as the update is posted 
so that, on the one hand, clients like pine or galeon pick up the 
upgrade the next time someone launches them.

But...

But I certainly don't want mail or database access disrupted 
willy-nilly at the same time. That's silly: "I'm sorry, everyone, but 
we have to schedule a service downtime because our package manager 
wants to install some bugfixes and who knows what applications it 
will automatically choose to restart."

True, Red Hat's notice could have said something to the effect of

  You can easily discover which packages are affected by the upgrade
  to this package by querying the RPM database:

     rpm -q --whatrequires libssl.so.2
     rpm -q --whatrequires libcrypto.so.2

  As soon as possible, you'll want to restart long-running processes 
  associated with the list of packages returned by your queries.

That completely different, however, than putting such restarts into 
the hands of the package-management system. I shudder to think about 
the service disruptions...

At some point, you face two choices:

* dumb things down like Microsoft has so that every update tells the 
  admin s/he should reboot the system

* rely on the admin to know what's running on the system and what will 
  be affected by a library upgrade.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct  2 06:50:15 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 06:50:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Log rotation: almost, but not quite
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020632410.6640-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Progress is being made, but I'm still not where I want to be.

  The logs were rotated again this morning, according to
/etc/cron.daily/logrotate's report mailed to root (and forwarded to me).
However, /var/log/maillog was _not_ rotated.

  I took /var/log/maillog out of /etc/logrotate.d/syslog, but it remains as
a separate script in that directory.

  Let me see if I have this correct:
	cron calls /etc/cron.daily
	/etc/cron.daily includes both 1postfix (the mail log analyzer) and
		logrotate. So the mail log is analyzed before it's
		rotated. That's fine; should be only the previous 24 hrs.
	/etc/cron.daily/logrotate is a shell script that invokes
		/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf
	/etc/logrotate.conf includes /etc/logrotate.d
	/etc/logrotate.d/ is a directory that contains scripts for:
		junkbuster  maillog  mgetty  psacct  rpm  samba  snmpd  syslog  uucp

  And we've come full circle: the /etc/logrotate.d/maillog script is not being
called, apparently. That script calls for daily rotation of
/var/log/maillog.

  If I have this correct, then I'm at a complete loss to understand why the
last step is not taken. Can someone nudge me in the right direction, please?

Thanks,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct  2 08:15:38 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 08:15:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210020746110.6683-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020813460.6640-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> > openssl dynamic libraries:
> > 
> >   [heinlein]$ rpm -q --whatrequires libssl.so.2 | wc -l
                                               ^^ 
> Paul, is there anyway to determine which of these or other applications
> are, or might be, statically linked?  Or is that even an issue?  My guess
> is the rpm database wouldn't know.

  I do believe, Rod, that static libraries end in .a and all .so are
shared/dynamic libs.

  You could run `rpm -q --whatrequires libssl.a`; on my system there are no
such packages.

Rich
	




From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Oct  2 08:15:03 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 08:15:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Slapper.C
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210020746110.6683-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020809170.16190-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> Paul, is there anyway to determine which of these or other
> applications are, or might be, statically linked?  Or is that even
> an issue?  My guess is the rpm database wouldn't know.

It is an issue, but, no, rpm doesn't keep track of static linking.  
You'd have to run nm or objdump against all your binaries to check for
the presence of the old library routines.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From chrisolds at kidmillennium.net  Wed Oct  2 08:38:51 2002
From: chrisolds at kidmillennium.net (Chris)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 08:38:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021002164705.02a91410@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <000201c26a29$d22727a0$1200a8c0@kidmillennium.net>

Stephen,

It sounds like a DNS issue definitely, but I'm a bit a novice at
"setting up" named on a server, I recently began to try and get my
webserver to handle DNS.  It's a bit of a brain cell killer...so I pay a
local hosting company to do DNS for this web-server, until I can get
some reading material on DNS--

On my system, Running Mandrake...

In 

/var/named

theres a file <domainame>.<suffix>

it's what I know as the "zone" file.  It's where the IP and reverse IP
info. resides.  For this machine, although I'm just now getting into
doing DNS with this machine.

Here's what it looks like, I know it's a little messy...but notice the
how the names are correlated to the IP of the machine.


@               IN      SOA     superhero.kidmillennium.net.
root at kidmillennium.net. (
                        2002090202 ; serial
                        1H ; refresh
                        15 ; retry
                        14D ; expire
                        12H ; default_ttl
                        )
webmail         IN      A       198.88.146.58
@               IN      MX      5       superhero.kidmillennium.net.
@               IN      NS      superhero.kidmillennium.net.
@               IN      A       198.88.146.58
mail            IN      A       198.88.146.58
superhero       IN      A       198.88.146.58


I don't know that this is actually functional...I pay a local hosting
company (www.kattare.com) to do DNS for this web-server, and I can just
edit it on-line...I think his server even updates the "serial number"
automagically if I forget.  You must update the serial number for your
changes to the zone file to take affect, and replicate/propagate
properly.   

Hope this points you in the right direction.

Chris Olds

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Oct  2 09:26:23 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 02 Oct 2002 09:26:23 -0700
Subject: Updating Packages (was: [PLUG] Slapper.C)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011232590.3030-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <3D9A543C.6020300@sun.com> <p0510031cb9c007f5f3d5@[192.168.3.1]>
Message-ID: <3D9B1E2F.80200@sun.com>

Who said anything about rebooting?  I meant stopping and restarting 
running processes, like the original thread complained about when 
Apache/SSL was upgrade - but not restarted - and the system was 
subsequently hacked.

Also, the downtime during a Debian upgrade is nil to none - the packages 
are updated, reconfigured, stopped and then immediately restarted.  Only 
if a user just *happened* to connect to said application during the 
second or two that the process is restarting would they see any 
problems.  They would probably attribute it to a timeout somewhere, and 
try again.

For those of us who covet our precious uptime, but want to keep things 
updated - and that doesn't necessarily mean the kernel - this is STILL 
the way to do things.  Even my aforementioned pcmcia upgrade worked fine 
after I realized what it did and restarted it manually after everything 
else was completed.

-R

Patrick Beart wrote:
> 
>     If the upgrade (process) only restarted daemons from upgraded 
> applications, that would be fine and certainly prevent absent-minded 
> omissions such as the one that Keith experienced. OTOH, if the upgrade 
> ALWAYS restarted the entire box (server, workstation, whatever), then 
> you'd have a Windows-like process that reboots every time you breath on it.
> 
>     Some people set up cron to run (Red Hat's) "up2date" at regular 
> intervals (e.g. weekly). That kind of down time (for weekly reboots) 
> would adversely impact a commercial server unless the admin was very 
> careful about the timing of the upgrade. A 5 minute reboot, once a week, 
> drops a server's uptime to less than 99%, annually (over 4 hours/yr).

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Oct  2 10:09:01 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 10:09:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Log rotation: almost, but not quite
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020632410.6640-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020632410.6640-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200210021009.01530.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Now that you removed the duplicate entry that was causing that error, 
did you rerun "logrotate" in debug mode and to see if it reported 
anything interesting?

Also I went back and looked at your original posting with your logrotate 
configuration for your maillog:

> In /etc/logrotate.d/maillog I have:
>
> /var/log/maillog {
>    daily
>    rotate 4
>    copytruncate
>    compress
>    size=+1024k
>    notifempty
>    missingok
>    postrotate
>        /usr/bin/killall -HUP syslogd
>    endscript
> }

Does it make sense to have a "size" directive when you're rotating the 
log on a daily basis? I have a daily rotation for my "MySQL" log that 
does not specify a "size". In your case you don't care about the file 
size just that the file is rotated on a daily basis.

The other thing you might try is removing the "copytruncate" and add a 
"create 640 root root" directive instead. This will cause the existing 
log file to be compressed and a new, empty file is created in its 
place. On my system my logfiles have root both as owner and group so 
that's why I supplied the "create" sample I did. You can omit any of 
the attributes for "create" and logrotate will use the attributes from 
the original file.

Tony

On Wednesday 02 October 2002 06:50 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Progress is being made, but I'm still not where I want to be.
>
>   The logs were rotated again this morning, according to
> /etc/cron.daily/logrotate's report mailed to root (and forwarded to
> me). However, /var/log/maillog was _not_ rotated.
>
>   I took /var/log/maillog out of /etc/logrotate.d/syslog, but it
> remains as a separate script in that directory.
>
>   Let me see if I have this correct:
> 	cron calls /etc/cron.daily
> 	/etc/cron.daily includes both 1postfix (the mail log analyzer) and
> 		logrotate. So the mail log is analyzed before it's
> 		rotated. That's fine; should be only the previous 24 hrs.
> 	/etc/cron.daily/logrotate is a shell script that invokes
> 		/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf
> 	/etc/logrotate.conf includes /etc/logrotate.d
> 	/etc/logrotate.d/ is a directory that contains scripts for:
> 		junkbuster  maillog  mgetty  psacct  rpm  samba  snmpd  syslog 
> uucp
>
>   And we've come full circle: the /etc/logrotate.d/maillog script is
> not being called, apparently. That script calls for daily rotation of
> /var/log/maillog.
>
>   If I have this correct, then I'm at a complete loss to understand
> why the last step is not taken. Can someone nudge me in the right
> direction, please?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Rich

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Oct  2 10:32:03 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 02 Oct 2002 10:32:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021002164705.02a91410@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021002131905.0301bc78@pop.net-yan.com> 
	<5.1.1.6.0.20021002164705.02a91410@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1033579923.31793.40.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Stephen,

The best source of troubleshooting DNS problems is the syslog.  Each
time the DNS server starts, it logs what zones were loaded and what
zones were not loaded (as well as what line in the zone file it didn't
like).  It also tells you what ip address it is listening on.

The best advice I've heard is to never create your zone files from
scratch, always copy a zone file that you know works and make changes to
that.

HTH

Derek Loree

Hi all!

A success story! (so far...)

I am about 1 year into using Linux (Mandrake 8.1)
I live in rural them-thar hills (dial-up connection, discussions about public 
trans. are a joke to me) and after a SEVEN HOUR download, I installed Open 
Office all by myself!

This is a 'thank-you' and tribute all the folk on this list who have helped 
me with newbie questions so far, and also a great deal of credit goes to the 
Open Office folks for creating a program and an instructional web page so 
that just about anyone can install it.

I was pleased to find that it opened some 'test' Microsoft documents I had. 
Not perfectly though - fonts look 'clunky' (no improvement over Star Office 
5.2) but it doesn't FLOOD your desktop, at least.

Next tests for me are:

1) Let's see how it handles check-boxes in Word, and
2) Let's see if the people I work with over the Internet (who are all 
IE/Outlook sheep) see in THEIR copy of a .doc file I created, everything that 
I see. (Is it WYSIWYG in -both- directions.)
3) Oh yeah - printing...


I'll let you know how it goes...

GLL

                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                     7 PM Thursday Oct 3, 2002
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                             Room 294/296
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)


      **********************************************************

			     PRESENTATION

			   Overview of LVM
		       (Logical Volume Manager)

				  by
			   Cooper Stevenson
		    <cooper at linux-enterprise.net>


      Logical Volume Manager (LVM) is a system for handling disks
      and disk partitions.  It enables one to "glue" two or more
      disks or partitions together to form a larger virtual
      disk which can then be logically partitioned and used like
      a normal disk, only with extra features.  For example, one
      can resize LVM based file systems.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects
                   including the monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for
                   Education, etc.

              7:30 - 8:30  Presentation

                   See above

              9:00 - ...  Beer
                                  The Lucky Labrador Brewing Company
                                  915 SE Hawthorne



                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell
                                          dmandel at pdxLinux.org


          P.S.  The Mid Willamette Valley Linux Users Group needs to
                change meeting locations.  I haven't heard anything
                about the next meeting.
                See http://lug.peak.org/ for details.

          P.S.  The Eugene Linux Users Group meets regularly.
                See http://www.euglug.org for details.

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Oct  2 11:50:15 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 11:50:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Log rotation: almost, but not quite
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210020314040.17755-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210021144450.10121-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, alan wrote:

> Well, if it did not solve his problem, it may have solved mine.

Serendipity!

> Logrotate was going out and trying to read about 10,000 bogus error 
> messages in a directory that no longer existed.  Hopefully nuking the 
> status file will end that behaviour.  (The process would wedge with 99% 
> cpu usage.)

This file is only used to keep track of the last (successful?) rotation to
the best of my knowledge.  You should also look at all the files
associated with logrotate to make sure those bogus entries (non-existent
directories ) aren't in one of them.
   I do vaguely remember problems with entries in 
/var/lib/logrotate.status but that has been years ago.  Let me know if you 
_don't_ find the bogus directories in the other logrotate files.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, alan wrote:

> cpu usage.)

  Wow! All of a sudden there are a lot of us with log rotation problems (or
"quirks"). I don't feel bad that I'm the only one suffering from
cluelessness.

Rich




From mikel at quantecllc.com  Wed Oct  2 13:06:54 2002

	Personalities : [raid0] [raid1]
	read_ahead 1024 sectors
	md2 : active raid1 md/1[1] md/0[0]
	      156301248 blocks [2/2] [UU]
	      [>....................]  resync =  0.1% (171864/156301248)
finish=11895.5min speed=217K/sec
	md1 : active raid0 ide/host3/bus0/target1/lun0/disc[1]
ide/host3/bus0/target0/lun0/disc[0]
	      156301312 blocks 8k chunks

	md0 : active raid0 ide/host2/bus0/target1/lun0/disc[1]
ide/host2/bus0/target0/lun0/disc[0]
	      156301312 blocks 8k chunks

	unused devices: <none>

My only question is this:  how the heck do I mount the RAID?

and I get the same error each time:

From jimwebb at charter.net  Wed Oct  2 13:48:18 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (Jim Webb)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 16:48:18 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Booting of multiple OS
Message-ID: <003b01c26a55$09a0e920$02a8a8c0@Jim>

What is the best way to install multiple OS's on a pc?  System commander
still around?  I'm looking at building a box with BSD, RH linux, and
windoze.  I know that most of us don't like windoze, but in the healthcare
arena, they are the major player unless you are playing with AIX, AS400,
etc.  Nobody builds information systems for pathology on BSD or Linux that
I'm aware of.  If you know of anybody, please let me know.

Thanks,

Jim Webb




From cschluti at pdx.edu  Wed Oct  2 14:16:53 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (charlieS)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 14:16:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Booting of multiple OS
In-Reply-To: <003b01c26a55$09a0e920$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <000101c26a59$081fca90$4500000a@SERVANYA>

 
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Install windows first, then install linux. Use Lilo (or grub - if you
must). Fancy crap like "system commander" is a waste of space.
Also, google is a good place to look.
Also, this question is asked in here about once a month, so the
archives would be a good place to look.

- -Charlie

     (Source: PC World.com) Can a frustrated Windows user dump
Microsoft? Even with lots of improvements, Linux is still no
cakewalk.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741073

CHINESE RESEARCHERS DEVELOP CPU FOR LINUX SERVERS
     (Source: ITworld.com) The Institute of Computing Technology
at the Chinese Academy of Science in Beijing took the wraps off
the prototype of a homegrown MIPS-compatible microprocessor, the
266-MHz Godson-1A, that researchers said can be used in routers
and Linux servers.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741075

GSA UNVEILS LIST OF TOP 20 VULNERABILITIES
     (Source: InfoWorld.com) The Top 20 list of Internet security
vulnerabilities unveiled Wednesday by the U.S. GSA includes those
affecting Microsoft's IE and IIS as well as the Apache Web
server, which was identified as a source of problems for Unix and
Linux.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741076

Speaking as a Linux newbie, I'd have to agree with that. I've
installed Linux on three machines already and after each effort I
felt like I'd been rode hard and put away wet. But with a little
help from friends and allies, all my machines are working. And I
think it's good that learning Linux is hard. There's value in a bit
of struggle.

Me, I'll use both systems as long as they butter my bread and don't
eat my lunch.

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Wed Oct  2 20:21:44 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 20:21:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard advice
In-Reply-To: <3D9BA73E.DA651A50@computer-arts.net>
References: <3D9BA73E.DA651A50@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <p05100302b9c1664f7925@[192.168.3.1]>

At 7:11 PM -0700 10/2/02, Mike Witt wrote:
>I'm having problems with the motherboard on one of my systems and
>I'm planning to go to Fry's this weekend and buy a new one. I'm
>poor right now, so it will be whatever is the current low-end for
>ATX form factor boards. ...snip...
>
>I'd appreciate any advice on specific boards that are known to either
>have problems, or known to work well (linux wise) or if someone can
>point me to a place that has that kind of info.


	I had a real bad experience with an ASUS (CL2) motherboard. 
Seems that ASUS tweaks their boards, some. They HATE Micron RAM!

	Let me repeat that:  NEVER use an ASUS motherboard with Micron RAM!

	... Weird, almost impossible-to-diagnose problems appear and 
cause numerous kernel panics while the motherboard EATS the RAMM.

	Had an older (abt 3 years) Intel 810 board go bad, AND the 
Intel 815 that replaced it. Turned out to be a bad CD-ROM drive 
(according to Pacific Solutions) that killed the secondary IDE 
controller on the brand new (815) board. Probably a combination of 
heat and the bad CD-ROM drive that caused the original 810 board to 
go, as well.
	Overall, I stick with Intel boards, myself. The built-in NICs 
are better than on some boards.

	I see Soyo all over at Fry's. Very few Intel boards. Maybe it 
was just their inventory that day, or something.  Dunno.




Patrick Beart

From revans at e-z.net  Wed Oct  2 20:30:16 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed,  2 Oct 2002 20:30:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard advice
In-Reply-To: <3D9BA73E.DA651A50@computer-arts.net>
References: <3D9BA73E.DA651A50@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <20021003032955.YUTY22381.sccrmhc03.attbi.com@linux>

POOR = ECS K7S5A + Duron  lan/audio in MB

Watch the ads and you can pick up the MB and 1.2 Duron for $79, Fry's had some
$30 32M TNT video cards with $20 mail in. With 256 Mb DDR ( no name Fry's  ) at
$42, $79 Samsung 48x12x48 ( CompUSA ) with $50 mail in and $35 case from ENU, I
put together a couple of boxes for ~$281. I had some 265 DRAM I wanted to use
in the MB but couldn't get to work. I don't know if it was me, the MB or the
RAM. 

Watch the ads and you can pick up the MB for $49 and put whatever AMD you want
with it. I think this is the cheapest board in town but a friend is using the
MSI KLE133 Audio Video LAN ATA100 from ENU $62 for Windows systems. With the
savings of video card this might be a better deal.

He was able to put together a Athlon 1700+ XP with 256 Mb Ram, 40G drive, cheap
cdrom ( can't remember the spec ) for, I think he said ~$245. The video is
NVidia so it should work with Linux but I can't say for sure this MB works with
Linux.

Those are the cheapest systems I know of.

If you have the cash the 7200 RPM 80G Western digital with 8M buffer is really
fast. $120 ( ENU ) and 1.5 times faster than the 7200 40G Western Digital it
replaced. ( I used the 40G in the new box ) Fry's was selling the 80G for $139
with $40 mail in. $99 pug $.34 is pretty nice ( I remember paying more than I
could spare at the time, for a 230M disk, so if this doesn't seem all that
great please take into account my being around when 8M ram was something I
thought I would buy after I won the lottery. )

Thank you
Russell

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Oct  2 20:49:11 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 02 Oct 2002 20:49:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Log rotation: almost, but not quite
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210021144450.10121-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210021144450.10121-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1033616951.1360.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 11:50, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, alan wrote:
> 
> > Well, if it did not solve his problem, it may have solved mine.
> 
> Serendipity!
> 
> > Logrotate was going out and trying to read about 10,000 bogus error 
> > messages in a directory that no longer existed.  Hopefully nuking the 
> > status file will end that behaviour.  (The process would wedge with 99% 
> > cpu usage.)
> 
> This file is only used to keep track of the last (successful?) rotation to
> the best of my knowledge.  You should also look at all the files
> associated with logrotate to make sure those bogus entries (non-existent
> directories ) aren't in one of them.
>    I do vaguely remember problems with entries in 
> /var/lib/logrotate.status but that has been years ago.  Let me know if you 
> _don't_ find the bogus directories in the other logrotate files.

That file was the cause of the problem.  The bogus entries were from
someone trying to hack mailman on my server.  (The script just dumped a
bunch of crap in the log.)  I need to investigate this farther. There
may be a race condition in logrotate that is causing the problem.  (If
you have more than 10,000 files in a directory, ext2 slows down a GREAT
deal.  If logrotate has a file in logstatus that suddenly disappears, it
seems to go out to lunch for a very long time.  (Like until killed.)


-- 
Alan <alan at clueserver.org>




From kens at cad2cam.com  Wed Oct  2 20:59:59 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 20:59:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
In-Reply-To: <3D999E1A.3F6795C1@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209271518500.9177-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200209302054.14125.kens@cad2cam.com> <3D999E1A.3F6795C1@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <200210022059.59701.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Tuesday 01 October 2002 06:07 am, Bill Thoen wrote:
> "Kenneth G. Stephens" wrote:
> Tried this too, but all I got when selecting Linux from the Windows
> boot process was an 'L' on a frozen screen. In reading other HOWTOs,
> others have gotten as far as "LI" before their screen freezes.
> Apparently the boot record is not being written correctly by LILO,
> so when I "dd if=/dev/hdb2 of=/mnt/floppy/linux.bin bs=512 count=1"
> that file linux.bin is no good for booting. I even tried running
> LILO pointed to a floppy and dd'ing the boot record from that. This
> time I got the 'L' and a screen full of 00's.
>
> > The next step is to dd if=<linux boot partition> of=bootsect.lnx bs=512
> > count=1.
> >
> > This gives you your boot sector to load into windows 2000.  Put this file
> > on a dos floppy.
> >
> > Boot <shudder>Windows</shudder> and copy this file to C:/.  The edit
> > boot.ini. It is normally read-only so you may have to play with
> > permissions and add the following line to the bottom of the file: 
> > C:/bootsect.lnx="Linux"
> >
> > The next time you boot windows you will have a choice of
> > <shudder>Windows</shudder> or <hooray>Linux</hooray>
> > --
> > Ken Stephens
> > CAD2CAM.COM
> > CADtoCAM.COM

Did you issue a lilo after building your system?

There is discription on the web somewhere what each letter in LILO means when 
booting.  Any case says that lilo cannot read the boot sector completely.  
There is a second and third part of lilo that is read from the disk 
partition.  This is what gets updated when you run lilo after configuring 
lilo.conf.  There is sometimes mention of adding a linear parameter, but 
first try coordinating your boot sector with your current configuration.  
Boot into that configuration using your boot floppy.  Then run lilo.  The 
copy you boot sector as before and complete the process.  Then try again to 
boot from the ntldr and choose Linux.

Good Luck.

-- 
Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM
CADtoCAM.COM

revans at e-z.net said:
> POOR = ECS K7S5A + Duron  lan/audio in MB 

I'll second the K7S5A recommendation.  We are using it in our fileserver
at the office with no problems.  Since it is a server, the onboard sound
doesn't get used.  As you are doing sound work, you might want to confirm
that the onboard sound will work for you.

galen





From smathews at pcez.com  Wed Oct  2 22:26:26 2002

My two Linux boxes beat me up from time to time as well.  But I also use new
whiz-bang PCs running XP at work and at home, and I still get the same old crummy
problems I had  w/Windows 95a and NT.  Linux vs Windows, from from a pure desktop
user point of view? It's like having to chose between cream and suppositories.


But at least Linux is fun to tinker around with, turns an old PC into a nice
workstation, has compilers and such, etc., whereas Windoze is just a pain in
the ass and requires more and more money with every application you want.

>of struggle.

From alex at daniloff.com  Wed Oct  2 22:25:53 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)

Subject: [PLUG] Linux vs. Windows: The rematch
In-Reply-To: <3d9bc6f2.5459.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d9bc6f2.5459.0@pcez.com>

Well,
It took two months to convince my colleagues in our eng. dept.
to switch our operations and process data analysis into Linux environment. 
It happened almost two years ago. Up to the present moment our dept. is 
running only on SuSE Linux. Totally M$ free environment! 
All my colleagues are running Linux on their home computers and don't
wan't even hear about Winbloze. 
In the last year we had company wide M$ OS/software license audit. 
You should have seen those M$ auditors who tried to check M$ registration 
numbers on our Linux boxes!  We didn't say to them that we 're running on 
Linux. That was an unforgettable entertaining show!
These dorks tried to contact M$ tech support in order to determine what 
version of winbloze we're running, why it doesn't look like it and where to 
find reg. number. We were laughing like crazy.
Our manager screwed our entertainment by telling them that it's not a Winblows 
but Linux - Miky$oft killer. 
Auditors went away all red faced.  
Other departments started to express their interest in Linux as well. 

Alex

From sean at fork.com  Wed Oct  2 22:33:09 2002

Message-ID: <1033623190.23445.9.camel@einstein>

Actually I was doing this today.

Now try to make a filesystem on the raid partition (if that's the right
word)

Something like 

mkfs.ext3 /dev/md0

then try to mount it with

mount /dev/md0 /mnt

This should work.


Sean

Hash: SHA1

Well, lessening the filtering shouldn't affect mail retrieval, since
the filters are applied when mail is received.

Are these users using outlook? I've noticed that with outlook mail
retrieval is very slow, but with say, the mozilla mail client, it
works as excepted.

BTW: Postfix is an MTA. There is something else allowing you to
retrieve your mail - a separate pop or imap server. The problem may
be there.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Oct  3 08:47:24 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 08:47:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Parable of Free Air
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210030843430.23071-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Plug seemed a bit slow this morning, so here's a story to read.

 -----------------------------------------

 The Parable of Free Air
 http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=33949&cid=3674122

 Once upon a time, some people lived in a cave, and no one knew that
 there was a world outside of the cave. The cave provided everything
 they needed, with plenty of fish and water. Luminous mushrooms
 provided both food and light. The only thing in short supply was
 air. All air came through a small shaft connected to the outside
 world. The shaft was controlled by a single company, Microshaft,
 which carefully rationed its flow to maximize demand and collected
 breathing license fees from everyone who had to breath. To save money
 the company hired cheap labor to operate the valves, but these
 laborers were often barely competent, and the air supply was
 unreliable. The shaft was poorly maintained, the air was often stale
 and laden with viruses. By selling a product that cost them
 essentially nothing to produce, Microshaft's profits were enormous
 and they became rich and powerful.

 One day, a group of daring young renegades discovered that there were
 other ways to get air, just by moving some rocks that blocked
 openings to the outside. And they offered their air free. At first
 people were hesitant to use Free Air, thinking something must be
 wrong with it since it was free. Initially Microshaft ignored the
 renegades, dismissing them as a fringe movement and minor
 nuisance. But eventually Microshaft saw them as a threat. They
 started a major marketing campaign to convince people that the Free
 Air was bad for their health. But people found that they actually
 felt better and healthier breathing the free, fresh air. Microshaft
 added more and more features to their air, perfuming it and coloring
 it with smoke to give it "added value". Many people started to
 dislike Microshaft's heavy, bloated air that was hard to breath and
 began flocking in droves to the sources of Free Air.

 About this time, after some years of hard volunteer work, Open Air
 developers finally increased the size of a Free Air portal so that a
 person could actually squeeze through to the outside. The first brave
 individuals who ventured through it discovered that not only was
 there an unlimited supply of air in the outside world, there was no
 way you could harness and control its supply.

 Alarmed, Microshaft sought to have the government declare Free Air
 illegal since it threatened their business model, which they had
 developed and rightfully earned through many years of hard work. They
 called the use of Free Air "theft" and claimed that the "viral"
 nature of the Public Breathing License advocated by many Open Air
 rebels would threaten the livelihood of Microshaft's suppliers and
 distributors. Indeed, the whole economy of the cave would collapse,
 they said. Laws were quickly passed and the portals of Free Air were
 sealed off.

 A charitable organization called the Business Air Alliance was formed
 to help protect businesses against the threat of Free Air portals. By
 proving that it was theoretically possible to fund terrorist
 organizations with the money saved by breathing Free Air, the BAA
 successfully lobbied to strengthen the laws so that any attempt to
 make an opening to the outside became punishable by death. Possession
 of shovels and picks became a criminal offense, and the BAA performed
 random audits to help citizens comply with the law. For their
 protection, everyone was required to wear an Air Rights Management
 security device, which would send an alarm to the authorities if it
 didn't detect a secret mix of fumes found only in Microshaft air.

 As time passed, Microshaft and the government became
 indistinguishable. To prevent future uprisings, a new feature was
 added to the air to keep the people sedated happily ever after.

 --------------------------------




From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Thu Oct  3 09:18:19 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 09:18:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Booting of multiple OS
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014D5C@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Jim wrote:
>do you know whether I can create 3 partitions and install Windows first and
>then Linux and BSD on the other 2 partitions?

Short answer: Yes.

Longer answer: I would create more than 3 partitions.  First, I've never done anything with the BSDs so I'm not sure what an optimal partitioning scheme would look like to them.  But here is what I would do for the windows/linux partitions: First, I would make small /boot partitions (one for linux and one for the BSD) close to the beginning of the drive (under the 1024 cylinder limit).  While this isn't absolutely necessary with newer BIOSes, it eliminates the possibility of a problem.  Next I would make sure that my Windows partition starts under the 1024 cylinder limit. Then I would create a swap partition for linux and perhaps for the BSD (I don't know whether BSD does swap files, or whatever.  Like I said, I'm not familiar with it). Finally I would make my / partitions for linux and BSD.  Depending on what you are planning on using linux for and how many different distros you'll want to try, you might think about making a separate partition for /home.  Up to you though.  I hope that this helped.


John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com

1, i 1), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.0 to /var/log/maillog.1 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 0), 
copying /var/log/maillog to /var/log/maillog.1
truncating /var/log/maillog
running postrotate script
running script with arg /var/log/maillog: "
        /usr/bin/killall -HUP syslogd
"
removing old log /var/log/maillog.5

  <more lines clipped>

  Two things here: first, in /etc/logrotate.conf I had inadvertently included
logrotate.d twice. When I removed one of those statements the output changed
to include the above. For some reason, this didn't show up yesterday (or
Tuesday, whenever it was that I ran logrotate with the debug option).

  Second, while /var/log/maillog was just rotated, it still is 970K in size
and includes records back to 9/30.

  I also just removed (before running logrotate -d) the line in
/etc/logrotate.d/maillog that specified rotation when the log file was > 1M.
If it's rotated daily it should not be greater than 1M anyway. Here's
/etc/logrotate.d/maillog:

/var/log/maillog {
    daily
    rotate 4
    copytruncate
    notifempty
    missingok
    postrotate
        /usr/bin/killall -HUP syslogd
    endscript
}

  Is there something here that needs correcting?

Thanks, Russ,

Rich

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Thu Oct  3 11:02:08 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 03 Oct 2002 11:02:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Booting of multiple OS
In-Reply-To: <004001c26a8c$6a74cb40$02a8a8c0@Jim>
References: <004001c26a8c$6a74cb40$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <1033668128.1004.10.camel@coyote>

Linux likes a separate partition for swap, so I would use 4 partitions.
A windows partition, a Linux swap, a Linux root, a BSD.  ( think the
winblows partition has to be the first one on the disk)

that has restrictions.  BSD "partitions" its partition so it doe snot
require a separate partition for swap.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct  3 13:19:39 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 03 Oct 2002 13:19:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210030953090.11064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D9CA65B.3050306@dimstar.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>[root at salmo /etc]# /usr/sbin/logrotate -d /etc/logrotate.conf 
>
...much output deleted...

>reading config file maillog
>reading config info for /var/log/maillog 
>
There's the important part. And no reported errors..

>truncating /var/log/maillog
>
It says it's truncating... Were you running as root so that it would 
have permission to do so?

>/var/log/maillog {
>    daily
>    rotate 4
>    copytruncate
>    notifempty
>    missingok
>    postrotate
>        /usr/bin/killall -HUP syslogd
>    endscript
>}
>
>  Is there something here that needs correcting?
>
See what happens when you simplify this. The syslog logrotate 
configuration file only has

/var/log/messages /var/log/secure /var/log/maillog /var/log/spooler 
/var/log/boot.log /var/log/cron {
    sharedscripts
    postrotate
    /bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null` 2> /dev/null 
|| true
    endscript
}

in it. Put this in your maillog stanza:

/var/log/maillog {
    daily
    sharedscripts
    postrotate
    /bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null` 2> /dev/null 
|| true
    endscript
}

I believe it should inherit the rotate 4 from /etc/logrotate.conf, and 
I'm not sure the rest is needed.


-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #11 (Collect all 17)
"Every year, back comes Spring, with nasty little birds yapping their fool heads off and the ground all mucked up with plants." - Dorothy Parker

so I took out the reference in /etc/logrotate.d/syslog.
 
> in it. Put this in your maillog stanza:
> 
> /var/log/maillog {
>     daily

>     /bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null` 2> /dev/null

  I'm not sure either. I _think_ I got this from the postfix installation,
but I'm not sure who put it there.

  Well, I just made your recommended changes and re-ran logrotate with debug
on. According to the output:

rotating pattern: /var/log/maillog  after 1 days (4 rotations)
empty log files are rotated, old logs are removed
considering log /var/log/maillog
  log needs rotating
rotating log /var/log/maillog
renaming /var/log/maillog.5 to /var/log/maillog.5 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 5), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.4 to /var/log/maillog.5 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 4), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.3 to /var/log/maillog.4 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 3), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.2 to /var/log/maillog.3 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 2), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.1 to /var/log/maillog.2 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 1), 
renaming /var/log/maillog.0 to /var/log/maillog.1 (rotatecount 4, logstart
1, i 0), 
renaming /var/log/maillog to /var/log/maillog.1
creating new log mode = 0600 uid = 0 gid = 0
removing old log /var/log/maillog.5
running shared postrotate script
running script with arg /var/log/maillog : "   
    /bin/kill -HUP at /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null 2> /dev/null
  || true
"
  Looks great, eh? But, ls -la /var/log shows:

-rw-------    1 root     root      1046804 Oct  3 13:38 maillog
-rw-------    1 root     root       938543 Sep  8 01:02 maillog.2

  No maillog.1, no new maillog, existing maillog still has records from 30
September.

  The logrotate debug output reports all these changes, but they are not
seen in /var/log. Is this user error some place? I'm really puzzled now.

Thanks,

Rich

Rich,

When running "logrotate" in debug mode it only "tells" you what it's 
going to do but it doesn't actually do anything. Run it without the 
debug argument and it should actually to what it says its gonna do.

Tony

  Sonofagun! So it's trying to attach to the nntp port (I didn't pick up on
the port number) and that's where 'scroll text' comes from? Huh!

  And I use slrn for Usenet, not pine. Guess I'll take that out again.

Thanks, Paul,

Rich

Actually I was doing this today.

Now try to make a filesystem on the raid partition (if that's the right
word)

Something like

mkfs.ext3 /dev/md0

then try to mount it with

mount /dev/md0 /mnt

This should work.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct  3 14:48:44 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 03 Oct 2002 14:48:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: PLUG digest, Vol 1 #822 - 10 msgs
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOAEOHLGAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <3D9CBB3C.7060104@dimstar.net>

Michael Luevane wrote:

>that said it WAS possible to use software raid with the Promise
>controllers.
>  
>
That was never in question, and I'm sorry if my answers gave the 
impression that I said that.

My point was that if you are using the hardware raid features of the 
Promise card, then you don't need the software raid features of the kernel.

If you are using the software raid features of the kernel, then you are 
using the Promise card as a standard EIDE controller, and not a raid 
controller. You may or may not see a performance hit by doing it this way.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #11 (Collect all 17)
"Every year, back comes Spring, with nasty little birds yapping their fool heads off and the ground all mucked up with plants." - Dorothy Parker

>    SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)
> 
> 
>       **********************************************************
> 
> 			     PRESENTATION
> 
> 			   Overview of LVM
> 		       (Logical Volume Manager)
> 
> 				  by
> 			   Cooper Stevenson
> 		    <cooper at linux-enterprise.net>
> 
> 
>       Logical Volume Manager (LVM) is a system for handling disks
>       and disk partitions.  It enables one to "glue" two or more
>       disks or partitions together to form a larger virtual
>       disk which can then be logically partitioned and used like
>       a normal disk, only with extra features.  For example, one
>       can resize LVM based file systems.
> 
>       **********************************************************
> 
>           Agenda:
> 
>               7:00 - 7:30  Business

>                    Education, etc.
>

>

instant messenger.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Oct  3 18:01:10 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu, 03 Oct 2002 18:01:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT - Cisco 678 Password Reset
References: <20021003102124.A8983@patch.com>
Message-ID: <3D9CE856.8010307@pacifier.com>

mikeraz at patch.com wrote:
> If you know how to reset the password on a Cisco 678 please email me off list.
> 
> It's OK if the config is lost in the process.
> 

Try this
http://www.herbighouse.com/cisco/ciscofaqs.html#Option2NoPasswordHowto

I think it's for a 675, but is probably the same.

--
Kyle Accardi




From colin at dabritz.org  Thu Oct  3 19:30:14 2002
From: colin at dabritz.org (Colin Dabritz)
Date: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 19:30:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT - Cisco 678 Password Reset
References: <20021003102124.A8983@patch.com> <3D9CE856.8010307@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <003301c26b4d$f8ac4b10$73c8a8c0@CDnforce>

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&q=cisco+678+password+re
covery
produces
http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/474/pswdrec_6xx.html
the official cisco process for password recovery, which also works for the
675 etc

The first option gets the current password out of NVRAM, the second blasts
the entire configuration, resetting the password.
I have had to do this more than once, and its a bit of a pain, but much
better than having a $100+ paperweight.

Most QWEST DSL users have a 675 or 678 dsl router, incase anyone was
wondering.

> mikeraz at patch.com wrote:
> > If you know how to reset the password on a Cisco 678 please email me off
list.
> >
> > It's OK if the config is lost in the process.

From mike at computer-arts.net  Fri Oct  4 07:46:02 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 07:46:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New motherboard: Do I need to re-install?
Message-ID: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net>

Running RH 7.2. I just replaced my old Gigabyte GA-6BX7+ motherboard
which used an Intel PII with an ECS K7S5A (recommended in the previous

"Motherboard advice" thread.) The new board has and AMD Duron processor
on it.

All I did was swap the motherboards and then boot it up. In other
words, I didn't do anything Linux-wise to configure for the new
type of processor. Everything basically came up okay. But, as you 
would expect, there are a few "oddities."

Before I start to debug what's left, it occurred to me to ask if
I should really have re-installed Linux. For example could some
libraries or other code have been loaded or built that depend on
the processor type?

Along the same lines (and I realize that this is probably a pretty
open ended question without a "real" answer) how common it is for
mainstream Linux applications to build code that is dependent on
processor type? 

-Mike

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Fri Oct  4 08:40:09 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 08:40:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2.4.19 + RAID was: RE: PLUG digest, Vol 1 #822 - 10 msgs
In-Reply-To: <20021004023002.4929.83908.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOGEAHLHAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Ah, then we'll just call it a misunderstanding on my part :)

I wasn't interested in hardware raid because everything I'd read said that
you'd be stuck with the 2.4.18 until Promise came out with a new driver and
things that I had read made it look like it might be a while for a new
driver.

Anyway, it's working, I'm logging in. Next step... LDAP!

-----Original Message-----
From: Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net>
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] RE: PLUG digest, Vol 1 #822 - 10 msgs
Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

Michael Luevane wrote:

>that said it WAS possible to use software raid with the Promise
>controllers.
>
>
That was never in question, and I'm sorry if my answers gave the
impression that I said that.

My point was that if you are using the hardware raid features of the
Promise card, then you don't need the software raid features of the kernel.

If you are using the software raid features of the kernel, then you are
using the Promise card as a standard EIDE controller, and not a raid
controller. You may or may not see a performance hit by doing it this way.

--
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Oct  4 08:54:18 2002

On Fri, Oct 04, 2002 at 07:49:59AM -0700, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> I want to convert my Perl code into 
> compiled Linux executable binary file.
> Generally I need to do this to speed up
> my program by skipping interpretation and
> compilation phase when it's executed.
> Could somebody please advise where should 
> I look for the information on this subject.
> Or should I convert my Perl script into C/C++
> and compile it?

This is a Perl FAQ.  Check out:

http://perldoc.com/perl5.8.0/pod/perlfaq3.html#How-can-I-compile-my-Perl-program-into-byte-code-or-C-

The short answer is that it won't help very much.  You can learn a lot
about the subject by using Google to search through the archives of
comp.lang.perl.misc, or try searching Perlmonks.com

Colin



From eric at ejahn.net  Fri Oct  4 09:40:48 2002
From: eric at ejahn.net (root)
Date: 04 Oct 2002 09:40:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RedHat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <1033744935.1316.5.camel@linux>
References: <3D9DA893.8000007@attbi.com> <1033742645.1320.2.camel@linux> 
	<3D9DAACC.9EC13640@anodizing.com>  <1033744935.1316.5.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <1033749661.2247.8.camel@localhost>

Just backup the subfolders inside
/home/YOUR_OLD_SYSTEM'S_USER_NAME/evolution/local.  When you get RH 8.0
up and running, just copy the contents into the new
/home/YOUR_NEW_SYSTEM'S_USER_NAME/evolution/local.  I've done this many
times with evolution, and it's always worked, even going from later
versions of evolution back to earlier (don't ask me why, it's
embarrassing) :)
