From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri Oct  4 10:24:50 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 10:24:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Binary compiled Perl =?iso-8859-1?q?code=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <200210041449.g94Enx908234@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210041016010.14218-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Fri, 4 Oct 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Hello Linux folkz,
> I want to convert my Perl code into
> compiled Linux executable binary file.
> Generally I need to do this to speed up
> my program by skipping interpretation and
> compilation phase when it's executed.
> Could somebody please advise where should
> I look for the information on this subject.
> Or should I convert my Perl script into C/C++
> and compile it?
> What is the better approach to achieve this goal?
> Thank you in advance for any advise or sources of
> information.
>

There was some kind of perl2exe tool that used to be advertised in he Perl
Journal as I recall...

But first consider:
If your Perl script is mostly doing text processing (which is common
for Perl scripts) then it's not likely that you'll speed it up much at all
by converting to C++ and compiling.  Perl's regex engine is highly
optimized already.

Perhaps you should figure out which parts of the script might be sped up
by moving to C and rewrite only those parts and create an extension that
is callable from C (Use the Inline::C module for this).  For example, if
you're doing some kind of matrix
multiplication (something that you _could_ speed up in C) Inline::C let's
you insert the C code for doing this into your Perl code.  It takes care
of compiling and creating an extenstion from the C code.

So it's likely that you won't be able to speed up things too much by
moving to C/C++ (in the case of text processing), but for other cases
where things can be sped up in C try using the Inline::C module to rewrite
those parts instead of rewriting everything in C/C++.

Phil




From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct  4 12:40:01 2002

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Oct  4 11:20:27 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 04 Oct 2002 11:20:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [Fwd: New sig line quote]
In-Reply-To: <1033715266.1359.1.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
References: <1033715266.1359.1.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <1033755626.2417.16.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

True Story:

A friend, Wayne, built his own Airplane.  It *mostly* works.  The latest
adventure was a cooling problem.  He was messing with oil coolers to fix
it, and therefore leaking a lot of oil.  He put an old ripped up carpet
on the ground under the engine to catch the leaking oil.

When he went to test the new cooling engine, it works, but the prop
snagged a loose end of the carpet and wound it around itself until the
prop snapped.

My Comment:

Wayne failed to build a thread-safe engine........

[Ducking]

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct  4 12:50:51 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 12:50:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Promise RAID on 2.4.19 - update

> 
> 	unused devices: <none>

Just curious, but why did you go with a raid1 of two raid0s instead of a
great big raid5?

Seems to me that you'd get just as much redundancy and 50% more drive
capacity out of a raid5 array of the four disks you've got.

> My only question is this:  how the heck do I mount the RAID?

Did you put a filesystem on the device?

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct  4 13:01:07 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 13:01:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux vs. Windows: The rematch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210021555281.7606-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210041253190.7729-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 2 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> LINUX VS. WINDOWS: THE REMATCH
>      (Source: PC World.com) Can a frustrated Windows user dump
> Microsoft? Even with lots of improvements, Linux is still no
> cakewalk.
> http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741073

Even with lots of (mostly superficial) improvements, Windows is still no
cakewalk.  So what's the point?

Computers are complex devices and expecting them to operate smoothly with
absolutely no specialized knowledge on the part of the user is absurd.  
Reviewers and most users are familiar with the methods and terminology
that Microsoft uses and therefore are confused by anything that is
different.  I would say that in the modern age, a wholly new computer user
would have more difficulty and frustration taking a Windows CD and bare
hardware to a working internet-connected workstation than a Debian
GNU/Linux CD and bare hardware to the same end point.  And in the end, the
Debian GNU/Linux system would be more stable, more secure, and have more
available software.  Hence, the longer the system is used, the lower the
pain and frustration regardless of learning.  You can know everything
there is to know about Windows and still have to reboot regularly and
experience occasional lock-ups.  Knowledge doesn't decrease your pain
(though knowing WHY you locked up might alleviate some of the
frustration... or it could make it worse.  Depends on your personality
type, I guess).

Anyway, I just woke up.
J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Oct  4 11:39:54 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 11:39:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] K7S5A Sound Hardware
References: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net> <3D9DDC7C.853BAA06@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <3D9DE07A.8040302@sun.com>

One thing I DO like about current iterations of Linux over M$ is that 
there is a LOT of hardware that Linux just works with, and M$ requires 
driver cds, disks, or trips to the 3rd party vendor webpages to find 
drivers for.

IE Win98 NEVER saw my nVidia graphics cards (not even TNT1!) nor my 
Diamond audio card.  I don't think w2k was much better.  Starting up 
windows in 640x480x16 is a painful experience on a 19" monitor.

I have a development board that drivers do _not_ exist for M$ on the 
web, yet I'm positive that Knoppix would see everything just *fine* and 
it'd work flawlessly.  Well, just as soon as I get it to POST again. 
(grumble grumble)

-R

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Oct  4 11:54:35 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 11:54:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] K7S5A Sound Hardware
In-Reply-To: <3D9DDC7C.853BAA06@computer-arts.net>
References: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net>
        <3D9DDC7C.853BAA06@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <39329.192.168.1.2.1033757675.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

Mike;

I have the K7SEM. It uses the SIS 7018 Codec Sound chipset.

This is listed as the ``Trident 4DWave DX/NS, SIS 7018 or ALi 5451 PCI
Audio Core'' option in the 2.4.18 kernel.

If your sound chipset is the same then this is the way to go. It works
great for me.


-Cooper

From Allen.Russell at kpchr.org  Fri Oct  4 11:51:58 2002

Subject: [PLUG] K7S5A Sound Hardware
References: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net> <3D9DDC7C.853BAA06@computer-arts.net> <mailman.1033757585.14646.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>

> Mike;
> 
> I have the K7SEM. It uses the SIS 7018 Codec Sound chipset.

> This is listed as the ``Trident 4DWave DX/NS, SIS 7018 or ALi 5451 PCI
> Audio Core'' option in the 2.4.18 kernel.
> 
> If your sound chipset is the same then this is the way to go. It works
> great for me.
> 
> -Cooper

Hmmm... Mine doesn't appear to be using the same chipset:

  kernel: Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.21, 06:29:46 Jun  1 2002
  kernel: PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
  kernel: i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
  kernel: i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
  kernel: ac97_codec: AC97  codec, id: 0x434d:0x4941 (Unknown)
  kernel: i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
  kernel: i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 Unable to map surround DAC's (or DAC's not present), total
channels = 2
  modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module sound-service-0-0

Google reveals that there are various drivers available, but I haven't
figured out whether any of them solves the "only 48Khz" problem. This
does appear to be an issue for the sound software I'm using, which
wants to do 44.1

Anyway, the search continues...

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Oct  4 13:07:29 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 13:07:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] K7S5A Sound Hardware
In-Reply-To: <3D9DEA02.69B57BE0@computer-arts.net>

Message-ID: <41400.192.168.1.2.1033762049.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

Mike;

The best answer I can give you from here is to compile ``Intel ICH (i8xx)
support in a new kernel. The help section for this option states that it
includes support for your sound chipset.

Modules have gotten a lot better with recent kernels in my opinion. If you
would rather eliminate *any* chance for hassle then simply compile it in.


-Cooper

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Oct  4 13:07:56 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 04 Oct 2002 13:07:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New motherboard: Do I need to re-install?
In-Reply-To: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net>
References: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <1033762077.31793.107.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-10-04 at 07:46, Mike Witt wrote:
> Running RH 7.2. I just replaced my old Gigabyte GA-6BX7+ motherboard
> which used an Intel PII with an ECS K7S5A (recommended in the previous
> 
> "Motherboard advice" thread.) The new board has and AMD Duron processor
> on it.
> 
> All I did was swap the motherboards and then boot it up. In other
> words, I didn't do anything Linux-wise to configure for the new
> type of processor. Everything basically came up okay. But, as you 
> would expect, there are a few "oddities."
> 
> Before I start to debug what's left, it occurred to me to ask if
> I should really have re-installed Linux. For example could some
> libraries or other code have been loaded or built that depend on
> the processor type?

Are the oddities related to peripheral devices (like sound card), or
core devices (like harddrive)? The only distribution that I know of that
would require a complete reinstall because of this change is Gentoo.
(Does Linux-From-Scratch count as a distribution?)  The other
distributions compile their packages to run on as little hardware as
possible.  About the only exception is the kernel, where you can choose
a precompiled version for your architecture.  The most common problem
I've seen with trying to change architecture out from under an OS is
failure to mount the root partition (even though the drive could be read
well enough to load the kernel), but it sounds like you have gotten past
that hurdle.  This doesn't mean that your kernel is optimized for the
Duron, or the chipset on your new motherboard, just that it is generic
enough not to choke on your hardware.  For optimization, I recommend
configuring and compiling your own kernel.

HTH

Derek Loree

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Oct  4 15:30:32 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 15:30:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [rhn-users] Slapper.C/ OpenSSL (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011253140.5221-200000@skua.ahapala.net>; from keith@ahapala.net on Tue, Oct 01, 2002 at 12:57:18PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210011253140.5221-200000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <20021004153032.A23772@kippered.herring.org>

On Tue, 01 Oct 2002, Keith Nasman wrote: 
> 
> As was discussed earlier, what probably happened is that I didn't restart 
> the apache service after the RPM upgrade. Below is the response I got as 
> well as a file to compile to test for the vulnerability.
[...]

And if you want to see what servers are attempting to exploit the
vulnerability on *your* Apache web server (and notify the owner or upstream
provider)...


-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-==-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
#! /usr/bin/perl -w
#
# Look for "request without hostname" in Apache error_log
# and print summary report of infected hosts attempting
# to exploit Apache SSL vulnerability
#
# Usage: findSSL.pl /path/to/error/log(s.*)

use strict;

my $identstr = "request without hostname";
my $host;
my $first = "";
my $cnt;
my %probes;
my %lastprobe;
my $timedate;

# parse all files specified on stdin
while (<>) {
    chomp;
    # only report Apache SSL exploits
    next unless /$identstr/;
    ($timedate, $host) = (split(/\[/, $_))[1,3];
    $timedate =~ s/\]//;
    $host =~ s/\].*//;
    $host =~ s/.* //;
    $first = "$host at $timedate" if ($first eq "");
    $probes{$host}++;
    $lastprobe{$host} = $timedate;
}

printf "First probe was from $first\n\n";

foreach $host (sort keys(%probes)) {
    $cnt = $probes{$host};
    $timedate = $lastprobe{$host};
    write;
}

format STDOUT_TOP =
Count  Host name / IP address  Time and date of last probe
-----  ----------------------  ---------------------------
.

format STDOUT =
@>>>>  @<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<  @<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
$cnt, $host, $timedate
.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-==-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-


bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ findSSL.pl /var/log/httpd/error_log
First probe was from 213.17.88.105 at Thu Oct  3 04:09:10 2002 

Count  Host name / IP address  Time and date of last probe
-----  ----------------------  ---------------------------
    1  200.168.170.235         Thu Oct  3 17:32:56 2002
    1  213.17.88.105           Thu Oct  3 04:09:10 2002


Sandy

From sjm at mccrew.com  Thu Oct  3 21:47:49 2002
From: sjm at mccrew.com (sjm at mccrew.com)
Date: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 21:47:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] squid and non-browser access
In-Reply-To: <20021003174431.A4834@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210032135380.24729-100000@pook.mccrew.com>

On Thu, 3 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> Howdy!
> 
> I finally figgered out how to get pppd to dial out, persistently, and
> on demand. And I got squid to let the demand come from a different
> server. However, I haven't figgered out what to set to let the demand
> on the different server be from a non-browser app.


How did you do it?  Are you just using pppd settings?  While it has been a
while since I have messed with pppd, it can be set to bring the link to the
internet up on demand, and for any kind of traffic, not just HTTP.

On auger, you can just set up a default route to dax, and on dax have pppd
configured to be its default route.  Any traffic on auger for the 'net, be
it HTTP, ssh, telnet, anything, should cause dax to bring the link up, and
dax should forward packets for auger and the laptop.

Check The Fine Manual as to whether you need to set up dax as a router.  If
you do, then adding the following to your /etc/rc.d/rc.local should fix
that:
    echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward

One thing to watch out for: you would likely want to set up sendmail (or
whatever MTA you are using) to queue up mail rather than trying to deliver
straightaway, otherwise every e-mail you send will cause the link to come
up.

You do not need to set up pppd for each application.

> 
> Konqueror and Netscape have a proxy setup page. I haven't found that
> setup in lynx or mutt or fetchmail or sendmail.
> 
> The network:
> 
> dax:
>  modem
>  pppd
>  squid
>  nic
> 
> auger:
>  browser
>  nic
> 

<snip>

Cheers,
-- 
-- Steve McCarthy                     Current wind and temp at my house
   sjm at mccrew.com                    http://www.mccrew.com/apps/Latest.jsp

Just curious, but why did you go with a raid1 of two raid0s instead of a
great big raid5?

Seems to me that you'd get just as much redundancy and 50% more drive
capacity out of a raid5 array of the four disks you've got.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Oct  4 16:56:49 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 16:56:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm
References: <3D9E293F.5000903@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D9E2AC1.6080809@dimstar.net>

Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> If I run #rpm -Uvh when I'm installing RH 8.0 rpms over RH 7.3 , will 
> all of the rpms be installed or just the updated versions of 7.3 that 
> Ialready have?  Does this question make sense?

If you run #rpm -Uvh * on a directory that contains all of the rpms on 
the 3 RH 8.0 disks, you will indeed install EVERYTHING in that directory.

If, however, you run #rpm -Fvh on that same directory, you will only 
upgrade (RH calls it "freshen") those RPMS that already exist on your 
system.

One thing about this. If they've packaged things differently, then you 
may end up with dependencies that require you to install (rpm -i) 
certain rpms.

It's much easier to use the installer that comes with the distribution 
and choose the "Upgrade" option. Make a backup of your existing system 
first.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #11 (Collect all 17)
"Every year, back comes Spring, with nasty little birds yapping their fool heads off and the ground all mucked up with plants." - Dorothy Parker





From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Oct  4 16:57:47 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 04 Oct 2002 16:57:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] K7S5A Sound Hardware
In-Reply-To: <3D9DEA02.69B57BE0@computer-arts.net>
References: <3D9DA9AA.9C59373E@computer-arts.net>
	 <3D9DDC7C.853BAA06@computer-arts.net>
	 <mailman.1033757585.14646.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	 <3D9DEA02.69B57BE0@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <1033775867.2417.43.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

I have a similar board.  You amy need "noathalon" in the kernel command
line.

/etc/lilo.conf
image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.18
        label=18
        root=/dev/hda6
        append="hdb=scsi noathlon mem=nopentium"
        read-only
        initrd=/boot/initrd-2.4.18.img


lsmod
via82cxxx_audio        17952   2  (autoclean)
uart401                 6208   0  (autoclean) [via82cxxx_audio]
sound                  54284   0  (autoclean) [via82cxxx_audio uart401]

/var/log/messages:

kernel: Via 686a audio driver 1.9.1
kernel: ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x4943:0x4511 (ICE1232)
kernel: via82cxxx: board #1 at 0xDC00, IRQ 9

/etc/modules.conf
alias sound-slot-0 via82cxxx_audio
post-install sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -L >/dev/null 2>&1 || :
pre-remove sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -S >/dev/null 2>&1 || :


On Fri, 2002-10-04 at 12:20, Mike Witt wrote:
> Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > 
> > Mike;
> > 
> > I have the K7SEM. It uses the SIS 7018 Codec Sound chipset.
> > 
> > This is listed as the ``Trident 4DWave DX/NS, SIS 7018 or ALi 5451 PCI
> > Audio Core'' option in the 2.4.18 kernel.
> > 
> > If your sound chipset is the same then this is the way to go. It works
> > great for me.
> > 
> > -Cooper
> 
> Hmmm... Mine doesn't appear to be using the same chipset:

From alan at clueserver.org  Fri Oct  4 08:51:16 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 08:51:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm
In-Reply-To: <3D9E293F.5000903@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210040846100.29615-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Fri, 4 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> If I run #rpm -Uvh when I'm installing RH 8.0 rpms over RH 7.3 , will 
> all of the rpms be installed or just the updated versions of 7.3 that 
> Ialready have?  Does this question make sense?

First of all, you would want to use "-Fvh", not "-Uvh".  There is another 
reason why you don't want to do this...

If Redhat has changed how the package works, or the packages have picked 
up new dependancies, you will not get them.  Using upgrade will take care 
of these sort of things.  (Freshen does not look for changes in the 
required dependancies.)

> good mid priced sound and video card for Red Hat 7.3

> Sed Quis Custodiet Ipsos Custodes?

Do you just want the sound card to play CDs, or will you be using
software to generate sounds (and possibly Midi) that you want to
play?  My experience has been that getting an all-around working
sound card is probably more difficult than most of the other common
cards.

I'm currently using a Sound Blaster Live card. But I think this
is probably somewhat "old" technology at this point.

So far, I've never been totally happy with any sound chipset that
came on a motherboard that I've had. Just today I gave up on using
the on-board sound on my new motheboard (in the previous threads
you might have seen) and put in the old Sound Blaster.

-Mike

PS... I'm pretty much of a novice with audio hardware and the
associated drivers. So take the above with a grain of salt.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Oct  4 21:02:52 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 21:02:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Druid?
In-Reply-To: <3D9E61EA.5A6DFCD8@computer-arts.net>

On Fri, 4 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> When you install Red Had, it provides a program to partition the hard
> drives. I *think* it's called "Disk Druid" (or something like that)

  Yes, it's called Disk Druid.
 
> Can anyone tell me if there's a way to invoke this particular program to
> partition a new disk, when your not doing an install? I can't find any
> reference to anything that appears to be it using "apropos" or just
> looking through the normal "bin" directories.

  There's the old fashioned way: fdisk and, perhaps, cfdisk. The former is
installed on your system and you can invoke it to see what you have without
trashing anything. man fdisk

Rich

From raanders at acm.org  Sat Oct  5 04:54:42 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 04:54:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Druid?
In-Reply-To: <3D9EA772.5F0F0EAC@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210050449360.24143-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sat, 5 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> Rich Shepard wrote:
> >  
> >   There's the old fashioned way: fdisk and, perhaps, cfdisk. The former is
> > installed on your system and you can invoke it to see what you have without
> > trashing anything. man fdisk
> 
> Well... I guess the honest response to that is, I can't figure out
> how to use it :-)  I used to use it, once upon a time. But, for 
> example, how do you tell it that you're using "ext2" or "ext3" file
> systems?  It doesn't *seem* to be there in the known partition types.
> (Or maybe that's not the right place to look)

Partition types and filesystem types are two different things.  Fdisk is 
for creating and modifing partitions and to a certain extent the type of 
filesystem you can place in the partition.  The filesystem utils are for 
creating/formatting the different types of filesystems; ext2, minix, 
ext3, etc.
   Disk Druid is a fancy front end to handle both things at once.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Oct  5 08:54:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 08:54:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Druid?
In-Reply-To: <3D9EA772.5F0F0EAC@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210050832400.18540-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 5 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> Well... I guess the honest response to that is, I can't figure out how to
> use it :-) I used to use it, once upon a time. But, for example, how do
> you tell it that you're using "ext2" or "ext3" file systems?  It doesn't
> *seem* to be there in the known partition types. (Or maybe that's not the
> right place to look)

  Try, as root, `/sbin/fdisk /dev/hda` (or whatever hard drive you want to
partition). You'll be prompted to enter "m for help". That gives you a menu
of options. The 'l' option lists all available filesystem types; the 'p'
option prints the existing partition table, and so on.

  The tune2fs tool permits you to turn on and off the journaling option.
That is how you can switch between ext2 and ext3.

Rich




From mike at computer-arts.net  Sat Oct  5 09:06:43 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Sat, 05 Oct 2002 09:06:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Druid?

> creating/formatting the different types of filesystems; ext2, minix,
> ext3, etc.
>    Disk Druid is a fancy front end to handle both things at once.

Okay, well I had a go at this. The utilities I've got don't seem
to be able to create ext3 filesystems, but I did this:

(1) created a partition with fdisk
(2) used mkfs to make an ext2 filesystem
   (the details of these two commands are below the dotted line)

(3) using the Gnome "hardware browser" hdc1 *appears* to look
    like it should.

(4) the command:  mount -t ext2 /dev/hdc1 /data
    gives the following error msg:

    mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/hdc1,
    or too many mounted file systems

    Rebooting doesn't make any difference.

Can anyone help me out with what I'm doing wrong here?
(Or tell me how to run Disk Druid?)

-Mike

PS... I also tried "parted" with similar results.

From brucek at kingkon.com  Sat Oct  5 10:27:50 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 10:27:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mutt (re)formatting command
Message-ID: <20021005102750.A9354@defiant.ncplus.net>

In a previous version of mutt (redhat 6.x), there was a formatting
command that would take long-line paragraphs and 'fix' them - quoting
included. I used it for awhile, and then noticed that any editing in
the paragraph 'fix'ed it, even without the special command.

All I can remember of that command was that it was not intuitive,
and use a { in the command sequence .... I first discovered it in a
magazine article somewhere.

However, in my current version of mutt (I have always used vi as my
editor) that auto-fixing of edited long-line paragraphs is disabled,
and I don't know how to re-enable it; nor can I recall what that cool
re-formatting command is.

Any of you folks have a clue - that you could pass along?

TIA!
-bk

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Oct  5 10:37:13 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 10:37:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Druid?
In-Reply-To: <3D9F0E13.5C5AE040@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210051015090.16307-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> The utilities I've got don't seem
> to be able to create ext3 filesystems

Create a journal on the filesystem using tune2fs and remount it as ext3:

$    tune2fs -j /dev/hdaX

Journal option info is available in the tune2fs manual. For info on
mounting in "writeback" or "ordered"  mode (ext3 v.2 features) see the
ext3 faq:

http://batleth.sapienti-sat.org/projects/FAQs/ext3-faq.html

I believe the syntax would be something like this to first convert to
version 2:

    mount /dev/hdaX /mnt -o journal=update

with 'ordered' as the default, writeback mode could be obtained with:

    mount -o data=writeback

> Can anyone help me out with what I'm doing wrong here?
> (Or tell me how to run Disk Druid?)

Did you remember to create the mount point, ie "mkdir /data" ? That's
the thing I always forget... Otherwise, no clue.

g'luck,

Tyler




On Sat, 5 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> "Roderick A. Anderson" wrote:
> >
> > Partition types and filesystem types are two different things.  Fdisk is
> > for creating and modifing partitions and to a certain extent the type of
> > filesystem you can place in the partition.  The filesystem utils are for
> > creating/formatting the different types of filesystems; ext2, minix,
> > ext3, etc.
> >    Disk Druid is a fancy front end to handle both things at once.
>

>

>     like it should.
>

>     gives the following error msg:
>
>     mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/hdc1,

>
>     Rebooting doesn't make any difference.

> Can anyone help me out with what I'm doing wrong here?
> (Or tell me how to run Disk Druid?)

From rob at euglug.net  Sat Oct  5 10:46:39 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 10:46:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mutt (re)formatting command
In-Reply-To: <20021005102750.A9354@defiant.ncplus.net>; from brucek@kingkon.com on Sat, Oct 05, 2002 at 10:27:50AM -0700
References: <20021005102750.A9354@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <20021005104639.A18030@cogit8.org>

The one you're describing sounds like a vi command (or vim?).  I use vim
with mutt... If, in command mode, you press 'gq}', it will reformat from the
cursor to the end of the paragraph.  Similarly, 'gqj' will reformat the
current line.  And you can highlight area (vim only) using Shift-V, then
press 'gq' will reformat the whole area.

-Rob

> On 20021005.1027, Bruce Kingsland said ...
>
> In a previous version of mutt (redhat 6.x), there was a formatting
> command that would take long-line paragraphs and 'fix' them - quoting
> included. I used it for awhile, and then noticed that any editing in
> the paragraph 'fix'ed it, even without the special command.
> 
> All I can remember of that command was that it was not intuitive,
> and use a { in the command sequence .... I first discovered it in a
> magazine article somewhere.
> 
> However, in my current version of mutt (I have always used vi as my
> editor) that auto-fixing of edited long-line paragraphs is disabled,
> and I don't know how to re-enable it; nor can I recall what that cool
> re-formatting command is.
> 
> Any of you folks have a clue - that you could pass along?
> 
> TIA!
> -bk
> -- 
> Bruce Kingsland
> Kingsland Konsulting
> brucek at kingkon.com

From raanders at acm.org  Sat Oct  5 12:01:22 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 12:01:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Disk Druid?
In-Reply-To: <3D9F2EE1.6B3B2330@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210051156220.30420-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sat, 5 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> Okay, well it *appears* that the disk I've been trying to partition
> may actually have been bad. I swapped in another hard drive and was
> able to format and mount it, using fdisk and mkfs.

Find someone with a copy of spinrite if you want to take the time (10-20
hours) and install the possibly bad HD in a system, boot to DOS then use
spinwrite.  I've had it fix a couple of 'bad' drives that went on for
years.  I've also had then go down again in short order.
   When building a new system I always try to run spinrite on the hard 
drives is I have the time.  It will look for an correct errors that most 
other HD software just faints on.  Also a good way to burn-in the hard 
drives.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From sandy at herring.org  Sat Oct  5 12:42:47 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 12:42:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mutt (re)formatting command
In-Reply-To: <20021005104639.A18030@cogit8.org>; from rob@euglug.net on Sat, Oct 05, 2002 at 10:46:39AM -0700
References: <20021005102750.A9354@defiant.ncplus.net> <20021005104639.A18030@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <20021005124247.A31192@kippered.herring.org>

On Sat, 05 Oct 2002, Rob Hudson wrote: 
> The one you're describing sounds like a vi command (or vim?).  I use vim
> with mutt... If, in command mode, you press 'gq}', it will reformat from the
> cursor to the end of the paragraph.  Similarly, 'gqj' will reformat the
> current line.  And you can highlight area (vim only) using Shift-V, then
> press 'gq' will reformat the whole area.

This is true. It's a function of what you've set as your editor... in my
case:

    [from .muttrc]
    set   editor="/usr/local/bin/gvim '+/^$' -f -c 'colo elflord' -c noh"

You can also map the reformat commands to something a bit easier to remember
and key, like...

    [from .vimrc]
    nmap <C-J>      gq}
    vmap <C-J>      gq

...to map them to ^J (the vmap is for visual mode, and maps the selected
area rather than the current paragraph).

Also of interest is how you've set formatoptions. Try `help formatoptions'
from within `vim' for the details.

Happy Vimming (as Bram would say :)
Sandy
--

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Sat Oct  5 14:03:21 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 14:03:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210040846100.29615-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
References: <3D9E293F.5000903@attbi.com>
        <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210040846100.29615-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <64529.12.231.181.15.1033851801.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

alan said:
> If Redhat has changed how the package works, or the packages have picked
>  up new dependancies, you will not get them.  Using upgrade will take
> care  of these sort of things.  (Freshen does not look for changes in
> the  required dependancies.)

Bzzzt. Sorry, thank you for playing. Freshen _does_ check do a dependency
check before installing packages. The only difference between -U (upgrade)
and -F (freshen) is that -F "will upgrade packages, but only if an earlier
version currently exists" as per the RPM man page.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

Subject: [PLUG] Help with PCMCIA tulip module for 2.4.19
References: <010d01c26ced$226e5420$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> <20021006052456.BZXT17535.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux>

Unfortunartely I am having trouble finding tulip in the kernel tree.

make menuconfig

Network device support --->

[*] PCMCIA network device support --->
< > 3Com 3c589 PCMCIA support
< > 3Com 3c574 PCMCIA support
< > Fujitsu FMV-J18x PCMCIA support
< > NE2000 compatible PCMCIA support
< > Asix AX88190 PCMCIA support
< > New Media PCMCIA support
< > SMC 91Cxx PCMCIA support
< > Xircom 16-bit PCMCIA support
< > Xircom Cardbus support (new driver)
<*> Xircom Tulip-like Cardbus support (old driver)
[ ] Pcmcia Wireless LAN

I have the Tulip-like driver selected, but I cannot find tulip itself.  I
feel there's something fundamental I'm missing but I haven't found docs to
help me out.

Todd

From lemming at attbi.com  Sun Oct  6 12:27:38 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Help with PCMCIA tulip module for 2.4.19

DECchip Tulip (dc21x4x) PCI support
is under the PCI section.

http://www.geocrawler.com/archives/3/201/2001/8/0/6478677/
shows how to edit your config for a 2.4.9 kernel.  May help your
current situation.

From revans at e-z.net  Sun Oct  6 12:30:05 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun,  6 Oct 2002 12:30:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with PCMCIA tulip module for 2.4.19
In-Reply-To: <001601c26d67$ca701f80$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
References: <010d01c26ced$226e5420$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
    <20021006052456.BZXT17535.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux>
    <001601c26d67$ca701f80$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
Message-ID: <20021006192945.GALH6431.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>

You might want tp try the one right above what you selected, if Xircom
Tulip-like Cardbus support (old driver) didn't work.

< > Xircom Cardbus support (new driver)

This driver is for the Digital "Tulip" Ethernet CardBus adapters. 
 It should work with most DEC 21*4*-based chips/ethercards, as well 
 as with work-alike chips from Lite-On (PNIC) and Macronix (MXIC) and  
 ASIX

I was wrong about tulip_cb as part of the kernel  pcmcia tree. I think now, the
doc I read, meant tulip kernel suppport was from the two Xircon drivers, hey
what do I know?  tulip_cb is part of the pcmcia_cs external drivers so you can
go get the tar ball and compile it. 

You might want to get the updated pcmcia_cs source, if	"(Did 3.1.22 really
ship with RH7.3?)" is true.
http://www.tux.org/hypermail/linux-tulip-bug/2002-May/0007.html


Thank you
Russell

From bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us  Mon Oct  7 09:12:51 2002
From: bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us (Ben Mabbott)
Date: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 09:12:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba and WinXP connection problem
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021005103023.00b4f750@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021005103023.00b4f750@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021007232557.00b51c28@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <00df01c26e1c$62dee670$e001ab0a@admin>

For WinXP and 2000, you have to add a machine account to samba in order to
connect.

First, you need to add a machine account that matches the computer name you
plan to use:

"useradd -d /dev/null -s /bin/false M40G$"

The home folder is set to /dev/null since this account won't need to store
any files, and the shell is set to /bin/false for security purposes. The
trailing $ signifies that this is a machine account. Now that you have that
done, you need to add it to the smbpasswd file:

"smbpasswd -a -m M40G"

-a for adding an account, -m to signify it's a machine account.

That's it. Restart Samba and the WinXP box for good measure, and you should
be in business.

-Ben

> Hi Russell,
>
> Thanks for your response.
>
> At 10:10 PM 10/5/2002 -0700, you wrote:

> again. Any suggestions?

Sorry for the standard questions:

* what video chipset are you running?

* is gpm running?

* in /etc/X11/XF86Config, does the CoreKeyboard device defined in the 
  ServerLayout section match the keyboard InputDevice defined later 
  in the file? If so, does the keyboard definition look reasonable?


--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct  7 12:24:10 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 07 Oct 2002 12:24:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] VPN needed for other OS
Message-ID: <1034018651.31782.126.camel@dereklinux>

Hi all,

I need some advise about secure tunnels.  I've been trying for the last
week to get a win2k machine to tunnel into an IPSEC deamon running on a
test box (configured for x509 certs).  This has been a very frustrating
experience, particularly since it still doesn't work, connection logging
on the client box shows nothing, and all the server says is "connection
not authorized".

First question, does anyone know of an alternative with about the same
level of security?

Second Question, can anyone give a short run down of how the ipsec
tunneling is supposed to work?  In particular, the documentation doesn't
say anything about iptables rules, yet ipsec looks for kernel support
for iptable, ipchains and ipfwd (or whatever that old one is).  Does
there need to be NAT rules in place for the tunnel, or does ipsec take
care of that?

I eagerly await your words of wisdom.

Derek Loree






From m at netpro.to  Mon Oct  7 13:52:24 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 13:52:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Keyboard stops working in X under RH 8
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210071102090.25150-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210071341310.15169-100000@lukem.com>

On Mon, 7 Oct 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On Mon, 7 Oct 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
> > Installed RedHat 8...  keyboard works fine up until X starts, then
> > it's completely unresponsive.  When I shutdown X, the keyboard works
> > again. Any suggestions?
>
> Sorry for the standard questions:
>
> * what video chipset are you running?

i815, although RedHat thinks it's an ATI Rage 128.  If I boot into
runlevel 3, I can then run startx and run Gnome.  Xconfigurator is
apparently no longer around, so I used the RedHat Display tool to change
to the i815 (i810 driver), but then X wouldn't start at all after that and
I got "No devices detected" and "no screens found".  I did a "rmmod r128"
and then "insmod i810", but it still didn't work.  Under the Section
"Device" in XF86Config, the RedHat Display tool changed the Driver to
"i810" and the BoardName to "Intel 815", but left Identifier, VendorName,
and Device set to "ATI Rage 128".

> * is gpm running?

No.  If I turn on gpm, I can't use the keyboard in runlevel 3 either.

> * in /etc/X11/XF86Config, does the CoreKeyboard device defined in the
>   ServerLayout section match the keyboard InputDevice defined later
>   in the file? If so, does the keyboard definition look reasonable?

Here's the original XF86Config, before I ran the RedHat Display tool:

# File generated by anaconda.

Section "ServerLayout"
	Identifier     "Anaconda Configured"
	Screen      0  "Screen0" 0 0
	InputDevice    "Mouse0" "CorePointer"
	InputDevice    "Mouse1" "SendCoreEvents"
	InputDevice    "Keyboard0" "CoreKeyboard"
EndSection

Section "Files"
# The location of the RGB database.  Note, this is the name of the
# file minus the extension (like ".txt" or ".db").  There is normally
# no need to change the default.
# Multiple FontPath entries are allowed (they are concatenated together)
# By default, Red Hat 6.0 and later now use a font server independent of
# the X server to render fonts.
	RgbPath      "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/rgb"
	FontPath     "unix/:7100"
EndSection

Section "Module"
	Load  "dbe"
	Load  "extmod"
	Load  "fbdevhw"
	Load  "dri"
	Load  "glx"
	Load  "record"
	Load  "freetype"
	Load  "type1"
EndSection

Section "InputDevice"
#	Option	"AutoRepeat"	"500 5"
# when using XQUEUE, comment out the above line, and uncomment the
# following line
#	Option	"Protocol"	"Xqueue"
# Specify which keyboard LEDs can be user-controlled (eg, with xset(1))
#	Option	"Xleds"		"1 2 3"
# To disable the XKEYBOARD extension, uncomment XkbDisable.
#	Option	"XkbDisable"
# To customise the XKB settings to suit your keyboard, modify the
# lines below (which are the defaults).  For example, for a non-U.S.
# keyboard, you will probably want to use:
#	Option	"XkbModel"	"pc102"
# If you have a US Microsoft Natural keyboard, you can use:
# Then to change the language, change the Layout setting.
# For example, a german layout can be obtained with:
#	Option	"XkbLayout"	"de"
# or:
#	Option	"XkbLayout"	"de"
#	Option	"XkbVariant"	"nodeadkeys"
#
# If you'd like to switch the positions of your capslock and
# control keys, use:
#	Option	"XkbOptions"	"ctrl:swapcaps"
	#Option	"XkbOptions"	""
	Identifier  "Keyboard0"
	Driver      "keyboard"
	Option	    "XkbModel" "pc105"#
	Option	    "XkbRules" "xfree86"
	Option	    "XkbLayout" "us"	#Option	"XkbVariant"	""
EndSection

Section "InputDevice"
	Identifier  "Mouse0"
	Driver      "mouse"
	Option	    "Protocol" "IMPS/2"
	Option	    "Device" "/dev/psaux"
	Option	    "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
	Option	    "Emulate3Buttons" "no"
EndSection

Section "InputDevice"
	Identifier  "Mouse1"
	Driver      "mouse"
	Option	    "Device" "/dev/input/mice"
	Option	    "Protocol" "IMPS/2"
	Option	    "Emulate3Buttons" "no"
	Option	    "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
EndSection

Section "Monitor"
	Identifier   "Monitor0"
	VendorName   "Monitor Vendor"
	ModelName    "Generic Laptop Display Panel 1280x1024"
	HorizSync    31.5 - 67.0
	VertRefresh  50.0 - 75.0
	Option	    "dpms"
EndSection

Section "Device"
	# no known options
        #BusID
	Identifier  "ATI Rage 128"
	Driver      "r128"
	VendorName  "ATI Rage 128"
	BoardName   "ATI Rage 128"
EndSection

Section "Screen"
	Identifier "Screen0"
	Device     "ATI Rage 128"
	Monitor    "Monitor0"
	DefaultDepth     16
	SubSection "Display"
		Depth     16
		Modes    "1024x768" "800x600" "640x480"
	EndSubSection
EndSection

Section "DRI"
	Mode         0666
EndSection





From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Oct  7 14:29:07 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 14:29:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Keyboard stops working in X under RH 8
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210071341310.15169-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210071412050.25150-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 7 Oct 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> > * what video chipset are you running?
> 
> i815, although RedHat thinks it's an ATI Rage 128.

<grumble>
  bleepin' Intel, altering chipsets every three weeks whether
  they need it or not. i8<week number of year here>. feh.
</grumble>

> Xconfigurator is apparently no longer around, so I used the RedHat
> Display tool...

By 'RedHat Display tool,' do you mean /usr/bin/redhat-config-xfree86?
That seems to be the blest successor to Xconfigurator.

If you've got your hand on all the relevant specs for your monitor and 
video subsystem, you can always try the canonical XFree86 tool: 
/usr/X11R6/bin/xf86config.

> I did a "rmmod r128" and then "insmod i810", but it still didn't
> work.

That's a different set of modules entirely. The Linux frame buffer 
device is a stab at abstracting graphics hardware in order to allow 
Linux graphics software to run on a wider variety of platforms. IOW, 
that's kernel code, not XFree86 stuff.

M understanding is that there are relatively few occasions when you'd
need the fb abstraction on x86 hardware.

> > * is gpm running?
> 
> No.

Drats. That's the easy answer :-)

> Here's the original XF86Config, before I ran the RedHat Display tool:
>
> Section "InputDevice"
        [snip]
> 	Identifier  "Keyboard0"
> 	Driver      "keyboard"
> 	Option	    "XkbModel" "pc105"#
> 	Option	    "XkbRules" "xfree86"
> 	Option	    "XkbLayout" "us"	#Option	"XkbVariant"	""
> EndSection

The Xkb* options are not, as far as I can tell, very well documented, 
but this seems pretty sane to me.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Oct  7 15:20:00 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 15:20:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] VPN needed for other OS
In-Reply-To: <1034018651.31782.126.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210071514520.21971-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On 7 Oct 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

> Hi all,
> 
> I need some advise about secure tunnels.  I've been trying for the last
> week to get a win2k machine to tunnel into an IPSEC deamon running on a
> test box (configured for x509 certs).  This has been a very frustrating
> experience, particularly since it still doesn't work, connection logging
> on the client box shows nothing, and all the server says is "connection
> not authorized".
> 
> First question, does anyone know of an alternative with about the same
> level of security?
> 
> Second Question, can anyone give a short run down of how the ipsec
> tunneling is supposed to work?  In particular, the documentation doesn't
> say anything about iptables rules, yet ipsec looks for kernel support
> for iptable, ipchains and ipfwd (or whatever that old one is).  Does
> there need to be NAT rules in place for the tunnel, or does ipsec take
> care of that?
> 
> I eagerly await your words of wisdom.


Uh, yeah.  Well you didn't provide much info for what is a complex topic.  
And ipsec is a complex topic.  From what I know so far, the 
authenitacating part of ipsec, called isakmp, has problems with going thru 
NAT.  It stems from the fact that part of the authenciation mechanism uses 
the source ip address of the incoming packet, which is mangled during the 
NAT process.  Addressing freeswan specifically, there is  a patch out now 
called NAT-traversal which attempts to overcome this issue.  I'd refer you 
to the freeswan-users archives found at www.freeswan.org for further 
details about the patch.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Oct  7 16:28:51 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 07 Oct 2002 16:28:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Binary compiled Perl code?
References: <mailman.1033746487.26926.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <863crhvnf0.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> writes:

Alex> Hello Linux folkz,
Alex> I want to convert my Perl code into 
Alex> compiled Linux executable binary file.
Alex> Generally I need to do this to speed up
Alex> my program by skipping interpretation and
Alex> compilation phase when it's executed.
Alex> Could somebody please advise where should 
Alex> I look for the information on this subject.
Alex> Or should I convert my Perl script into C/C++
Alex> and compile it?
Alex> What is the better approach to achieve this goal?
Alex> Thank you in advance for any advise or sources of
Alex> information.

Put these as the last two lines of your program:

    BEGIN { warn sprintf "after compilation: %.2f %.2f\n", times }
    END { warn sprintf "after execution: %.2f %.2f\n", times }

That's the user/system cpu time (in seconds) after compilation and
after execution.

I bet if your program is of any significant size and purpose, the
compilation time will be a very small fraction of the execution time.
Now think of how much *human* time you'll be spending keeping a
"binary" up to date, and also realize that the time to load an
entirely separate unshared binary will probably be more than the time
for the already memory-paged-in Perl executable (on most systems :) to
simply read the source and compile it.

In short, Perl's compilation time is nearly always not the issue, once
you look at it.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

> Uh, yeah.  Well you didn't provide much info for what is a complex topic.

You're right, I didn't provide much info, mainly because there is so
much.  When I started, I used the instructions from:

http://www.natecarlson.com/include/showpage.php?cat=linux&page=ipsec-x509 
Nate claims that this works even with the client behind a masquerading
firewall.

What I'm fishing for with the second question is more like:

1) Server starts up, network interfaces start, ipsec interfaces start,
waiting for a connection.

2) Client starts a connection, sends initial packet (I think this is the
start of phase 1 using IKE).

3) Server responds to initiation, Phase 1 is successful if the client
replies back.  This establishes the tunnel (I think, I also assume this
is when the win2k client will start logging connection activity).

4) Client sends encryption needs back to server (initiation of Phase
2?).

5) Server generates encryption parameters (time of key rotation, etc.).

6) Client accepts encryption parameters and starts sending out encrypted
packets.  Now everything should work.

The part I don't get is how the packets go from the tunnel device
associated with eth0 (the internet side) to eth1 (the LAN side), Nate
says nothing about iptables rules, or special tunnels to the inside
interface.  He also has two seperate tunnels set up, one to the
interface with no subnet, and one to the LAN subnet, I don't understand
why.

Why am I fishing here?  Because I'm hoping for some real world
experience, not just a programmers version of what ought to happen.

Thanks

Derek Loree

From eric at ejahn.net  Mon Oct  7 18:32:29 2002
From: eric at ejahn.net (Eric Jahn)
Date: 07 Oct 2002 18:32:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Palm Conduit for RH 8.0 solved
Message-ID: <1034040756.15124.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Someone from the ximian evolution list helped me out with this one.  Run
this command as user (not root):

 gpilotd-control-applet --cap-id=1            

a GUI to configure conduits appears.  After configuring, your palm
should synch with evolution/whatever.





From kens at cad2cam.com  Mon Oct  7 21:09:37 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: 07 Oct 2002 21:09:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Installing OpenLDAP via RPMs
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEDNLHAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

On Mon, 2002-10-07 at 10:38, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Hi, listers.
> 
> I'm looking for some information on Installing OpenLDAP RPMs, specifically
> the Mandrake RPMs.
> 
> I've installed the RPM as follows:
> 
> 	rpm -Uvh openldap-2.0.25-7mdk.i586.rpm
> 
> and it looks like it installs.
> 
> Great.
> 
> Now, Where the heck are the fles that I need to configure in order to make
> it work???
> 
> I've searched for the slapd.conf file - not found
> 
> So, I scratches me head and I wonders - what did I miss?
> 
> TIA!
> 
> ======================================
> Michael Luevane, Analyst/Network Admin
> Quantec, LLC
> 6229 SE Milwaukie
> Portland, OR 97202
> 503.228.2992x28
> ======================================

Any time you want to find out where the files are loaded after
installing an RPM issue:

rpm -ql <package name>

Where package name is the short name of what you installed.  In this
case issue:

rpm -ql openldap
 
Ken

From m at netpro.to  Mon Oct  7 21:34:30 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)

On Mon, 2002-10-07 at 21:22, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:
> 
> >Since you are using a newer version of RedHat, do you suppose you are
> >using XF86Free 4.0.x?  Then you should look at the /etc/X11/XF86Config-4
> >configuration file for your settings
> >
> 
> If it's RH 8.0, then it's probably XFree86 4.2.0.
> 

Also, the reason 7.3 and below had a XF86Config-4 file was they shipped
with both 3.x.x and 4.x.x XFree and the XFree86 people added that
functionality for those people who needed one or the other or both.. 

Red Hat now only ships with 4.2.x and has moved back to just using
XF86Config as the configuration file.

Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/




From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Oct  7 22:05:28 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 22:05:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] VPN needed for other OS
In-Reply-To: <1034033389.31793.163.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210072140210.25571-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On 7 Oct 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

> You're right, I didn't provide much info, mainly because there is so
> much.  When I started, I used the instructions from:
> 
> http://www.natecarlson.com/include/showpage.php?cat=linux&page=ipsec-x509 
> Nate claims that this works even with the client behind a masquerading
> firewall.
> 
> What I'm fishing for with the second question is more like:
> 
> 1) Server starts up, network interfaces start, ipsec interfaces start,
> waiting for a connection.
> 
> 2) Client starts a connection, sends initial packet (I think this is the
> start of phase 1 using IKE).
> 
> 3) Server responds to initiation, Phase 1 is successful if the client
> replies back.  This establishes the tunnel (I think, I also assume this
> is when the win2k client will start logging connection activity).
> 
> 4) Client sends encryption needs back to server (initiation of Phase
> 2?).
> 
> 5) Server generates encryption parameters (time of key rotation, etc.).
> 
> 6) Client accepts encryption parameters and starts sending out encrypted
> packets.  Now everything should work.
> 
> The part I don't get is how the packets go from the tunnel device
> associated with eth0 (the internet side) to eth1 (the LAN side), Nate
> says nothing about iptables rules, or special tunnels to the inside
> interface.  He also has two seperate tunnels set up, one to the
> interface with no subnet, and one to the LAN subnet, I don't understand
> why.

when ipsec starts and ipsec interface is started with it, ipsec0 for 
example.  you can specify the name of the interface in ipsec.conf and bind 
it to specific interface like eth0.  when the tunnel is successfully 
created, ipsec should update the kernels routing table automagically so 
that packets destined for the far side of the tunnel will get routed to 
the appropriate ipsec0 interface.

I haven't read Nate's documentatiion (been meaning to) so I can't speak to 
it.  Two things I do recommend is going to either the www.freeswan.org or 
www.freeswan.ca website and rifling thru the documentation found there.  
And subscribe to the freeswan-users mail list.  It's probably the most 
free-form mail-list I've seen, definitely don't use a MS based MUA to 
peruse it.

> 
> Why am I fishing here?  Because I'm hoping for some real world
> experience, not just a programmers version of what ought to happen.

I just got done fight^H^H^H^H^Hbuilding a vpn using a package called 
SuperFreeswan (put together by a freeswan guru named Ken Bancroft) that 
included NAT-Traversal as well as x509 certificate support that looked 
something like...



RFC-1918 Network
    |
    |
Firewall (linux and freeswan, NAT)  <--------------------------+
    |                                                          |
    |                                                          |
Cable Modem Router                                             |
    |                                                          |
    |                                                          |
Internet                                                vpn tunnel
    |                                                          |
    |                                                          |
Firewall (linux and freeswan and doing NAT)                    |
    |                                                          |
    |                                                          |
RFC-1918 Network (wireless)                                    |
    |                                                          |
    |                                                          |
Firwall (linux and freeswan and doing NAT and wins, ick)  <----+
    |
    |
RFC-1918 Network (yet another)
 




From brucek at kingkon.com  Fri Oct  4 08:26:29 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Fri, 4 Oct 2002 08:26:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] squid and non-browser access
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210032135380.24729-100000@pook.mccrew.com>; from sjm@mccrew.com on Thu, Oct 03, 2002 at 09:47:49PM -0700
References: <20021003174431.A4834@defiant.ncplus.net> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210032135380.24729-100000@pook.mccrew.com>
Message-ID: <20021004082629.B6264@defiant.ncplus.net>

sjm at mccrew.com's Log: StarDate 1003.2147:
> On Thu, 3 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> > I finally figgered out how to get pppd to dial out, persistently, and
> > on demand. And I got squid to let the demand come from a different
> > server. However, I haven't figgered out what to set to let the demand
> > on the different server be from a non-browser app.
> 
> How did you do it?  Are you just using pppd settings?  While it has been a
> while since I have messed with pppd, it can be set to bring the link to the
> internet up on demand, and for any kind of traffic, not just HTTP.

The ppp options are: (/etc/ppp/options)

  lock
  crtscts
  defaultroute
  noauth
  noipdefault
  persist
  demand
  ipcp-accept-remote
  ipcp-accept-local

and the command string is:

 pppd /dev/ttyS1 115200 :$remoteIP remotename $isp user $user \
 connect "/usr/sbin/chat -v '' AT OK ATDT$phone CONNECT '\d\c'"

(yes, it's in a script so that I can use different isp's.) This is all
on dax, and anything I do on dax works just as advertised. ANY access
outside the local net causes the modem to dial (and to keep trying
until a connection is established); and once established, I can
browse, or ssh, or whatever I choose when at the dax console (or
logged into dax).

I also have squid running on dax, and the changes I made to the
squid.conf file are:

 http_port 80
 http_port 3128
 http_port 1080

 acl our_networks src 192.168.0.0/24
 http_access allow our_networks
 http_access deny all

 httpd_accel_host virtual
 httpd_accel_port 80
 httpd_accel_with_proxy on
 httpd_accel_uses_host_header on

My /etc/hosts file:

127.0.0.1	localhost.localdomain	localhost # LoopBack

192.168.0.1	tori.kingkon.com	tori	 # Al's Warp 5 System
192.168.0.2	winni.kingkon.com	winni	 # Al's Win95C System
192.168.0.7	dax.kingkon.com		dax	 # Dual P200 Server
192.168.0.17	picard.kingkon.com	picard	 # 486DX4-100 FireWall
192.168.0.77	auger.kingkon.com	auger	 # Athlon 800 DevStation
192.168.0.177	defiant.kingkon.com	defiant	 # 486DX2-50 360PE ThinkPad

64.40.40.51	ncplus.net		ncplus	 # Local Dialup
64.40.40.4	ncplus.net		ncplus	 # Local Dialup

199.2.117.161	pacifier.com		pacifier # Personal ISP space
199.2.117.164	mail.pacifier.com	mail	 # Personal Mail Host

> On auger, you can just set up a default route to dax, and on dax have pppd
> configured to be its default route.  Any traffic on auger for the 'net, be
> it HTTP, ssh, telnet, anything, should cause dax to bring the link up, and
> dax should forward packets for auger and the laptop.

auger's default route is dax on eth0, and dax's default route is
ncplus on ppp0. But the only traffic on auger that will bring up dax's
modem is http. ssh, telnet, ping don't..... same is true on defiant
(the laptop) and additionally includes fetchmail and lynx. However,
konqueror on auger will cause dax's modem to fire up; but only because
I set the proxy page in konqueror on auger (with the proxy disabled,
no access to the modem).

> Check The Fine Manual as to whether you need to set up dax as a router.  If
> you do, then adding the following to your /etc/rc.d/rc.local should fix
> that:
>     echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward

ummm, I did add run an iptables command: (from the squid HOWto)

 iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i eth0 -p tcp -d 80 -j REDIRECT --to-port 3128

is that a related step? where in the Fine manual do I look?

> One thing to watch out for: you would likely want to set up sendmail (or
> whatever MTA you are using) to queue up mail rather than trying to deliver
> straightaway, otherwise every e-mail you send will cause the link to come
> up.

I'm running mutt and sendmail (and fetchmail and procmail). I'm OK
with the link coming up alot - the fone line was installed primarily
for data comm.

> You do not need to set up pppd for each application.

I didn't think so. But the proxy question arises....

> > The network:
> > 
> > dax:
> >  modem
> >  pppd
> >  squid
> >  nic
> > 
> > auger:
> >  browser
> >  nic

-bk

From srau at rauhaus.org  Tue Oct  8 09:08:33 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 09:08:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] VPN needed for other OS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210072140210.25571-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
References: <1034033389.31793.163.camel@dereklinux> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210072140210.25571-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <20021008160832.GA28574@rauhaus.org>

I have a functioning VPN between a Linux/FreeSWAN firewall and a Cisco
VPN3005 Concentrator.

If anyone tries this particular combination, I found it necessary to add
"pfs=no" to my ipsec.conf for the tunnel to the VPN3000.

--Stafford

Remember, a mailing list like this is _not_ just for your own personal
gratification.  When you publicly ask a question, you are engaging the
minds of other people.  If you solve your own problem after you have
asked, both for those peoples curiosity and for posterity, I think it
is polite to outline what the solution was.  Think of it as the price
you pay for requesting free advice.  Just my opinion.

Russell> anything obvious, besides CONFIG_PROC_FS=y.

Ed> Linux.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Oct  8 11:44:09 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 11:44:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using a Netgear PS 110 print server device from Linux
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210081119410.1682-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

    I'm setting up a Netgear PS 110 print server device.
This is a device to put your printers on a LAN a bit like an HP Jet
Connect.

    The Netgear PS 110 print server has a network connection and two
parallel ports.  The network connection is connected to the LAN,
and each of the parallel ports is connected to a printer, P1 and P2.
Windows PCs on the LAN can print to either printer.  So far I
have NOT been able to print to either printer from a Linux box
on the LAN.

    I should be able to print via samba, lpd, or ftp according to the
manual and I think the Netgear configuration supports this, but ...

    (1)  I can use a command like:
              smbclient -L PS330444 -I 192.168.0.4
         to get information about the supported services, but
         I can not print using smbclient like I normally can.
         When I try this nothing happens at either printer.

    (2)  I can use ftp to get to the Netgear box, read and write
         the Netgear configuration file, reset the box and so on.
         But, I haven't been able to ftp a file to either printer.

    (3)  I don't remember what happened when I used cups (lpd), but
         as I recall nothing happened.  I think the files justed
         queued up with the first one being active.

    Does anyone have an idea about this situation?
If so, we advise me.

will be a regular occurrance here as well for the next couple of

advertised it seems to get.

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Tue Oct  8 12:16:33 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 12:16:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Thumbnail guidelines for when to convert a program from Perl to C? {Was: binary perl executable?)
In-Reply-To: <863crhvnf0.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <20021008191633.21480.qmail@web14403.mail.yahoo.com>

Can anyone give a thumbnail guideline for when someone might
want to prototype an application in perl, then rewrite it in
something faster for production use? Anyone have any examples
and real world speedups? Am I wrong in thinking that a lot
of the perl module functions are already written in C or other
compiled languages, so the performance gains in rewriting an 
application completely in C might not be worth it?

I'm asking this for the programmer neophytes among us,
myself included.

Thanks,

Sean Harbour

=====

Sean, Sharon & Kyle Harbour
www.seanharbour.homeip.net

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue Oct  8 12:47:55 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 12:47:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Thumbnail guidelines for when to convert a program from
 Perl to C? {Was: binary perl executable?)
In-Reply-To: <20021008191633.21480.qmail@web14403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210081218570.30907-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour wrote:

> Can anyone give a thumbnail guideline for when someone might
> want to prototype an application in perl, then rewrite it in
> something faster for production use? Anyone have any examples
> and real world speedups? Am I wrong in thinking that a lot
> of the perl module functions are already written in C or other
> compiled languages, so the performance gains in rewriting an
> application completely in C might not be worth it?
>
> I'm asking this for the programmer neophytes among us,
> myself included.
>

As always there are tradeoffs and it depends on your application.
As you implied, prototyping is generally a lot faster/easier in a
scripting language like Perl or Ruby than it is in C/C++ especially for
applications that include text processing(due to the ease of using regex's
in the scripting languages) and file access.  So using a scripting
language tends to minimize development time, but runtime may not be
optimal (again, depending on your application).

My understanding is that for text processing where regex's are used that
you are not likely to see much if any speedup by moving from Perl to C.
Other types of applications that might be mathematically intensive might
benefit from being rewritten in C.  However, in order to save development
time, you don't need to rewrite your whole Perl script in C, you can use
the Inline::C module (it's on CPAN) to rewrite the time consuming parts in
C.  Check out Inline::C, it's quite cool.  It allows you to basically
include C code in your Perl script.  The first time the C code is
encountered it is 'sent out' for compilation by gcc and then an extension
is created.  On subsequent runs compilation is not needed and the extension
code is called.  So Inline::C makes it easy to mix Perl and C to get the
best of both worlds - Perl for the things you wouldn't want to have to do
in C (like text processing and simple parsing) and C for the things that
are slow in Perl.  (there is also similar module for Ruby now called
RubyInline).

BTW: Another way to easily create extensions for scripting languages (most
of the well known ones are supported) is to use swig (simple wrapper
interface generator). (http://www.swig.org).  Swig is best for going the
other way: when you have a large C or C++ library around that you want to
be able to access from your scripting language.  I used swig to
generate extensions for Ruby (it'll work with Perl too) from a C++
class library when I was contracting at Intel and I cannot
recommend it highly enough. I also used it recently to create a Ruby
extension for a large public domain BDD library written in C - it
literally took about 15 minutes. Swig is a VERY slick tool and I'm always
surprised how well it does in 'guessing' what I wanted with minimal
intervention from me.  Anyway, with swig you can easily take an existing
C++ project, for example, and make all of your C++ classes available in
Ruby (or Perl, or Tcl, or even Java).  Swig is sooo much easier than the
traditional ways of creating extensions (like XSUBS in Perl) and you can
easily target multiple scripting languages mostly without changes.

...sorry for getting a bit off topic (I realize you're interested in going from
Perl -> C) but I just had to put in a good word for swig. ;-)


Phil






From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Tue Oct  8 12:51:02 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)

At 1:25 PM -0700 10/5/02, Russ Gilman-Hunt wrote:

>>projects to pay the rent?


>cowboyz.com is, for all intents and purposes, pushing up posies.
>russ gilman-hunt
>ex-cowboy
>


	I've been wanting to chime in on this kind of topic for 
awhile, now. So, please forgive the personal 
rant/musing/prognostications, but ...


	Web Development is DEAD, particularly in Portland. Business 
tends to have lousy Web sites. Too many "young turks" (names 
withheld, to avoid potential lawsuits) and opportunists that "took 
the money and ran" with no thought to proper construction or 
"Information Architecture" on the sites that they butchered.
	Business - particularly small business, which makes up nearly 
all of Oregon's offerings in this area - only cares that they HAVE a 
site, not how effective it is, how attractive and engaging it is, or 
how easy it is to navigate. I wrote an article about proper Web site 
design for ComputerBits magazine in November of 2000, and nearly all 
of that article is still applicable, today.

	With the IT crash about 2 years ago, nothing is going on in 
Web development - except falling salaries. What was paying decent 
money 2 years ago is now a secretarial position! Salaries are LESS 
THAN HALF (!!) of what they were in early 2000. With a Bachelor's 
degree in computer science and at least one major programming 
language (e.g. C, C++, Java, etc.) you MIGHT be able to get 40K a 
year ... maybe.
	My new motto is: "Friends don't let friends do Web development."


	Web site hosting is equally dead. With large NOC's like 
Exodus filing for bankruptcy, there is a tremendous GLUT of hardware, 
so hosting prices have fallen like a lead balloon. The hardware and 
infrastructure can't dissolve like wet toilet paper, so the companies 
that own it (or purchase at a deep discount) have to find a way to 
make their investment payoff.
	Whereas business Web site hosting used to command between $50 
and $100/month, it's now at $7.95!  ... That's right, you can now 
host a commercial Web site for about 1/3 of the cost of dialup - and 
get all of the "bells-n-whistles" (e.g. unlimited bandwidth, 
unlimited POP accounts, custom CGI, etc.)

	Programming is going overseas at a fast clip. U.S. 
programmers are about as "in demand" as stale potato chips. Most 
large-scale programming is going to India, Pakistan, or the former 
Soviet republics.

	There is some optimism about computer security positions as a 
growth market, but industry speculators aren't projecting this market 
to open up for about 18 months.

	http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,547669,00.asp

	My contact at the Portland Business Journal claims that she's 
having to work 10 times harder to get new advertising business, and 
is having trouble paying her bills as a result (she's obviously on 
commission).

	I think that it's very ironic that sales of computers 
continues to grow. MS viruses (and now Linux "Slapper") continue to 
proliferate at an alarming rate. However, no one seems to care about 
QUALITY or SECURITY in all but a few business sectors. Even the 
Oregon State Human Services department prefers to avoid spending any 
money on securing their (mostly Microsoft) system and ADMITS that the 
thing is WIDE OPEN.

	I keep wondering what it's going to take to wake these people 
up? ... some kind of high-tech "9/11" experience???

	:-(





Patrick Beart

as the economy continues to stagnant under the weight of the income

From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Tue Oct  8 13:58:51 2002
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Tue, 08 Oct 2002 20:58:51 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] networking stumper
Message-ID: <20021008205851.PUU18356.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>

Good afternoon.
I wrest your attention from your spleen-venting, ranting 
performances that belong on Plug-Talk (probably because I 
disagree with it, I want it stomped on. :) )

Anyhow. I've got a Linux box here, see? And it's running (no no 
don't leave!) Slackware version 8.1.  The card in is is from a 
disenfranchised macintosh; the //proc/pci lists it thusly: 

 Bus  0, device  16, function  0:
    Ethernet controller: Digital Equipment Corporation DECchip 
21140 [FasterNet] (rev 34).
      IRQ 10.
      Master Capable.  Latency=32.  Min Gnt=20.Max Lat=40.
      I/O at 0xe880 [0xe8ff].
      Non-prefetchable 32 bit memory at 0xfebffe80 [0xfebffeff].

It's running Sendmail (no no don't panic) version 
220 mail.hotp.com ESMTP Sendmail 8.12.4/8.12.4

It works OK, except for some of these, which come from some 
(sigh) macs: 

Sep 24 08:24:17 mail sendmail[21510]: g8OFJIQI021510: 
SYSERR(root): collect: I/O error on connection from 
tech.hotp.com, from=<s_cobb at hotp.com>

My solution has been a non-solution. IE, "bugger it, I don't have 
time to fix it- most people can set their outbound mail server to 
be my computer. Let's do that."  It's worked, in the sense that the 
underlying problem is not solved, but the sufferers can get on 
with their lives.   My presumption is that there's something 
wrong with the cabling on that floor (shrug) that causes some 
sort of latency. (the building could stand a good re-cabling).

However, now I am working on a perl script that downloads 
information from the web server. And I don't have log messages 
for this problem, but here's the symptoms. . . 
1)  Web server is IIS/Windows. Perl script uses Net::FTP and 
downloads a list of files in ascii mode. Random files seem to 
lose all line / file endings, generating an error.  When I say 
"random", I mean that there doesn't seem to be any coorelation 
between files that are selected for this mistreatment, but 
subsequent attempts to download the file are also bad. I don't 
mean that 4 our of 5 files download OK and the next day that 
last file has a 4 in 5 chance of downloading- it has 0 chance.

2) When it generates an error, the file is not removed from the 
server and not saved locally (I have a backlog of about 1300 
files).  However, viewing the file in Windows gives me proper 
line endings.

2a) I've tried using ncftp to download each file in binary / ascii. It 
does not help - the file comes down the way it decides to come 
down. This would lead me to believe that this is file-related; 
however, the files are created by two automatic processes (they 
are catalog requesting forms) and the process is identical.

3) Occasional ftp sessions "time out" for some unknown reason 
(it says the server has closed connection).

In other words- FTP has also a mysterious ailment. There's a 
subtle connection between FTP and Sendmail- they use the 
network card.

The network statistics look like this: (ifconfig eth0)
eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:00:94:AD:93:96  
          inet addr:10.10.10.45  Bcast:10.10.10.255  
Mask:255.255.255.0
          EtherTalk Phase 2 addr:65280/53
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  
Metric:1
          RX packets:31584334 errors:1 dropped:0 overruns:0 
frame:0
          TX packets:27420007 errors:90 dropped:0 overruns:0 
carrier:180
          collisions:0 
          RX bytes:3049054126 (2907.8 Mb)  TX 
bytes:1644590675 (1568.4 Mb)

I'm not that worried about the TX errors: the box has been up for 
76 days. Before I got this box switched to another network 
segment, this number was ... excessive (on the scale of multiple 
hundreds of collisions per hour).

--------------
So the question I have today is ...
Would replacing the card in the Mail server have a greater than 
50 percent chance of helping the problems with Mail and FTP- 
or do you suppose there's another underlying reason for this? 

The card in my linux box seems to work well. Maybe I should 
just swap cards temporarily?
----------------
Russ, mildly confused.

also don't tell my lawyer how to write a contract. By the same token, 
I don't accept a client's process or procedure. That's what they are 
paying ME for!

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Oct  8 14:27:51 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 14:27:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Researchers study Linux,Windows TCO
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210081403200.9890-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

[...]

"Linux, along with Solaris, also came out ahead of Windows in terms of
administration costs, despite the fact that it's less expensive to hire
Windows system administrators. The average Windows administrator in the
study earned $68,500 a year, while Linux sys admins took home $71,400, and
those with Solaris skills were paid $85,844. The Windows technicians,
however, only managed an average of 10 machines each, while Linux or
Solaris admins can generally handle several times that."

"There were other costs the study was not able to quantify, according to
Robinson, such as security. While study participants were reluctant to
provide hard figures on the costs of security breaches, it appears that
the "cost for handling security issues on Windows systems was very high,"
says Robinson. The study revealed that Windows administrators spent twice
as much time patching systems and dealing with other security-related
issues than did Solaris or Linux admins. "

http://linuxtoday.com/news_story.php3?ltsn=2002-10-08-016-26-NW-BZ-MR

This segment of the study also looked interesting:

"Windows owners are responsible for ensuring that they comply with
Microsoft's licensing policies by maintaining inventories of software
products installed. Microsoft has threatened audits and lawsuits where it
believes companies have violated those policies.

Partially out of a fear of such legal action and the penalties that they
may carry, many companies have implemented costly software inventory
products to perform these audits internally. These products may range from
$5 to $50 per seat, depending on their functionality. Because Linux and
Solaris are not licensed in this fashion, companies that use these
products do not need to fear such penalties."

	I've been wanting to chime in on this kind of topic for 
awhile, now. So, please forgive the personal 
rant/musing/prognostications, but ...


	Web Development is DEAD, particularly in Portland. Business 
tends to have lousy Web sites. Too many "young turks" (names 
withheld, to avoid potential lawsuits) and opportunists that "took 
the money and ran" with no thought to proper construction or 
"Information Architecture" on the sites that they butchered.
	Business - particularly small business, which makes up nearly 
all of Oregon's offerings in this area - only cares that they HAVE a 
site, not how effective it is, how attractive and engaging it is, or

design for ComputerBits magazine in November of 2000, and nearly all 
of that article is still applicable, today.
