Web development - except falling salaries. What was paying decent 
money 2 years ago is now a secretarial position! Salaries are LESS 
THAN HALF (!!) of what they were in early 2000. With a Bachelor's 
degree in computer science and at least one major programming 
language (e.g. C, C++, Java, etc.) you MIGHT be able to get 40K a 
year ... maybe.

	Web site hosting is equally dead. With large NOC's like 
Exodus filing for bankruptcy, there is a tremendous GLUT of hardware, 
so hosting prices have fallen like a lead balloon. The hardware and 
infrastructure can't dissolve like wet toilet paper, so the companies 
that own it (or purchase at a deep discount) have to find a way to 
make their investment payoff.
	Whereas business Web site hosting used to command between $50 
and $100/month, it's now at $7.95!  ... That's right, you can now 
host a commercial Web site for about 1/3 of the cost of dialup - and 
get all of the "bells-n-whistles" (e.g. unlimited bandwidth, 
unlimited POP accounts, custom CGI, etc.)

	Programming is going overseas at a fast clip. U.S. 
programmers are about as "in demand" as stale potato chips. Most 
large-scale programming is going to India, Pakistan, or the former 
Soviet republics.

	There is some optimism about computer security positions as a 
growth market, but industry speculators aren't projecting this market 
to open up for about 18 months.

	http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,547669,00.asp

	My contact at the Portland Business Journal claims that she's 
having to work 10 times harder to get new advertising business, and 
is having trouble paying her bills as a result (she's obviously on 
commission).

	I think that it's very ironic that sales of computers 
continues to grow. MS viruses (and now Linux "Slapper") continue to 
proliferate at an alarming rate. However, no one seems to care about 
QUALITY or SECURITY in all but a few business sectors. Even the 
Oregon State Human Services department prefers to avoid spending any 
money on securing their (mostly Microsoft) system and ADMITS that the 
thing is WIDE OPEN.

	I keep wondering what it's going to take to wake these people 
up? ... some kind of high-tech "9/11" experience???

	:-(





Patrick Beart

-- 
------------------------------------------------
Web Architecture  &  "iWeb4Biz"         503-774-8280       Portland, OR
Internet Consulting, Intelligent Web site Development & Secure site Hosting.
http://www.WebArchitecture.com/

"This is an era when nonsense has become acceptable and sanity is 
controversial."
                                      - Thomas Sowell

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Tue Oct  8 14:42:12 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 14:42:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Portland Internet industry
In-Reply-To: <p0510030cb9c8f8607c45@[192.168.3.1]>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210081427320.17132-100000@serpentor.cobrala>


On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Patrick Beart wrote:

> 	... and -- with respect -- you are pandering to that/them.    :-/
>
> 	My business morality says that a good consultant doesn't
> blindly accept the client's focus. My job, as a consultant, is to
> steer the client to the proper procedure and outcome. If the client
> knew best, they wouldn't NEED me.
> 	You, as a consultant, are supposed to be the brains, not just
> the brawn. If you take all of your direction from the client, then
> whose knowledge is being used? Aren't YOU being paid for YOUR
> knowledge and experience?

Two things.

First off, this depends in part on what kind of consultant you are. I've
worked since graduating from college in 97, for companies. I've never been
an independent consultant or even a terribly highly paid consultant with
lots of pull or influence. I make the right decisions technically, I try
as hard as I can to influence the clients my company works with to make
the right decisions, but in the end I only have so much power. I'm the one
being paid. They don't have to listen to me.

Which brings me to part 2. If someone makes triple or more than I do to
make business decisions and still doesn't listen to me (which happened to
many of us in the tech field) then how does that make it our fault? Should
we have quit our jobs in protest? I need to eat. So if my employer tells
me to go do some programming and I know their business plan sucks, I may
tell them so, but I still need to pick up a pay check so I won't push it
TOO hard, otherwise my family will end up poor and destitute.

This is what I don't get. If CEOs, managers and executives don't get paid
to make good business decisions, what the hell do they get paid so much
for?

> 	These situations - and my comments - aren't some kind of
> conspiratorial "class war", as your comments seem to suggest. Nor are
> my comments some personal poke at you. They are simply a commentary
> on the cluelessness of business, particularly local business.
>
> 	BTW, Web developers and programmers are separate fields,
> vis-a-vis my comments.

I understand. I just wanted to clarify that when talking about taking the
money and running there's a difference between the programmer picking up
his paycheck and the suits which lead the client astray because they want
the money. They generally run the show both for the client and the
consultancy (at least in most situations I've been involved with). Not the
programmer.

> >Nothing will wake them up, probably. It's all about the bottom line. It
> >will continue to be from here on out. Not that it wasn't before, by the
> >hyperspeed greed that took over in the 90s is here to stay.
>
>
> 	I'm sorry, but I just don't buy into the "as I'm just a lowly
> consultant, I'm powerless over this stuff" kind of mentality.

When you're a consultant that isn't independent, this has to be your
mentality. Remember, there's a difference between independent consultant
and someone working as a consultant for a company. In the latter position
you have suits above you who will often supercede your good advice with
their desire to please the client, even if it's not the best idea. You
either have to learn to live with bad choices or quit. I choose to feed my
family. My bad.

> 	My kind of consultant is not much different than a doctor or
> lawyer ... I don't let clients control every aspect of the process.
> For instance, I don't tell my doctor how to treat me, medically. I
> also don't tell my lawyer how to write a contract. By the same token,
> I don't accept a client's process or procedure. That's what they are
> paying ME for!
>
> 	Obviously, it's different for folks like you.

What does that mean? Folks like me? Folks who work for companies that pay
their salaries and don't want to lose their jobs by speaking out too much?

Preston




From jimwebb at charter.net  Tue Oct  8 14:58:12 2002

Has anybody else seen this problem while attempting to install RH Linux 8.0?

I am unable to install my RH 8.0 personal due to issues with anaconda.
There are a number of problems with anaconda that lead to a message that
states: "OSError: [Errno 12] Cannot allocate memory".  I'm unable to save
the complete error message to a floppy disk to submit to bugzilla or to
here.  My pc freezes at this point.

This error occurs after I've selected the packages that I want to install.
I'm not sure what's going on, but if any of you have seen this or heard
about it, please let me know.  The Red Hat site does not help at all.  In
fact, it's a piece of dung.  Everything that pertains to RH 8 leads to a
dead webpage.

TIA,

Jim

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Tue Oct  8 15:36:37 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 15:36:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] networking stumper
In-Reply-To: <20021008205851.PUU18356.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210081531550.937-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Tue, 8 Oct 2002 gilmanhunt at attbi.com wrote:

> The network statistics look like this: (ifconfig eth0)
> eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:00:94:AD:93:96  
>           inet addr:10.10.10.45  Bcast:10.10.10.255  
> Mask:255.255.255.0
>           EtherTalk Phase 2 addr:65280/53
>           UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  
> Metric:1
>           RX packets:31584334 errors:1 dropped:0 overruns:0 
> frame:0
>           TX packets:27420007 errors:90 dropped:0 overruns:0 
> carrier:180
>           collisions:0 
>           RX bytes:3049054126 (2907.8 Mb)  TX 
> bytes:1644590675 (1568.4 Mb)
> 
> I'm not that worried about the TX errors: the box has been up for 
> 76 days. Before I got this box switched to another network 
> segment, this number was ... excessive (on the scale of multiple 
> hundreds of collisions per hour).
> 
> --------------
> So the question I have today is ...
> Would replacing the card in the Mail server have a greater than 
> 50 percent chance of helping the problems with Mail and FTP- 
> or do you suppose there's another underlying reason for this? 
> 
> The card in my linux box seems to work well. Maybe I should 
> just swap cards temporarily?


Don't know the specific answer, but will offer this.  I've been 
configuring a replacement mail server just recently and was experiencing 
network outages of either painfully slow or out right dead.  When I 
finally got around to doing an ifconfig I noticed the RX errors.  Not 
many, but it would increment.  After too much troubleshooting I replaced 
the patch cable and that fixed the problem.  Overall I learned that RX 
errors are really hard on network performance and reliability.

On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> Even more humorous was when it was discovered that the employee that was
> canned happened to be the company's only resource for a product the
> they were making a lot of money on. Some of the company's executives
> were forced to eat crow when the axed employee was hired back as a
> highly paid contractor.

I once worked for a company where I was asked to hack into message boards
and find out the names of people who were posting messages about the
company to drive the stock down. I quit promptly and contacted the SEC.
However, part of the reason I quit, is because I knew in a showdown with
management I would be fired or worse. That's corporate America.

Preston

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Oct  8 17:24:09 2002
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)

Subject: [PLUG] Wheel mouse

This subject has probably been beaten to death before,
but if so, I missed it. My cockatiel chewed through
the cable of my primitive mouse, and I replaced it
with a Logitech optical wheel mouse. (I'm going to
keep the cockatiel away from this one.)

The new mouse works fine with Linux, despite the fact
that Logitech makes no mention of this OS. But it
doesn't support the wheel feature, just as the old one
did not. Is there a way to get such support with Linux?

Robert "Tim" Kopp

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Oct  8 17:51:54 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 08 Oct 2002 17:51:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Wheel mouse
In-Reply-To: <20021009002409.4127.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021009002409.4127.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1034124714.1042.180.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-10-08 at 17:24, Robert Kopp wrote:
> This subject has probably been beaten to death before,
> but if so, I missed it. My cockatiel chewed through
> the cable of my primitive mouse, and I replaced it
> with a Logitech optical wheel mouse. (I'm going to
> keep the cockatiel away from this one.)
> 
> The new mouse works fine with Linux, despite the fact
> that Logitech makes no mention of this OS. But it
> doesn't support the wheel feature, just as the old one
> did not. Is there a way to get such support with Linux?

I have a logitech mouse with a wheel.  To get it working, I just kept
trying different protocols in gpm until I found one that worked.

My gpm configuration is:


Current configuration: -m /dev/psaux -t fuimps2 -Rraw
Device: /dev/psaux
Type: fuimps2
Repeat_Type: raw

Here is the relevant section from XF86Config-4

Section
"InputDevice"                                                           
       Identifier "Configured
Mouse"                                      
        Driver         
"mouse"                                                 
        Option         
"CorePointer"                                           
        Option          "Device"               
"/dev/gpmdata"                  
        Option          "Protocol"             
"ImPS/2"                        
        Option          "ZAxisMapping"          "4
5"                           
EndSection                              

HTH

Derek Loree




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Oct  8 18:05:08 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 18:05:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Wheel mouse
In-Reply-To: <1034124714.1042.180.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: 16624-43349@sneakemail.com

On 8 Oct 2002, Derek Loree derek-at-infotects.com wrote:

> On Tue, 2002-10-08 at 17:24, Robert Kopp wrote:

> Here is the relevant section from XF86Config-4
> 
> Section
> "InputDevice"                                                           
>        Identifier "Configured
> Mouse"                                      
>         Driver         
> "mouse"                                                 
>         Option         
> "CorePointer"                                           
>         Option          "Device"               
> "/dev/gpmdata"                  
>         Option          "Protocol"             
> "ImPS/2"                        
>         Option          "ZAxisMapping"          "4 5"
> EndSection                              

The protocol change "IMPS/2" worked for me as well.  Most applications
seem to work with the mouse wheel.  (So far the only one I have that
doesn't is the Adobe Acrobat reader.)

Now my only problem is on my mouse the wheel serves as a third button so I
keep pasting things in by accident...

  -- Steve

Dilbert cartoons go back a number of years and were around when I worked 
at this company. We had a bulletin board in the coffee room and every 
morning someone would posted the absolute perfect Dilbert cartoon that 
had the same tone and "flavor" that the executives had sent out to the 
company employees for the previous day.

The cartoon was posted sometime between 0600-0700 and would be promptly 
removed by the first executive that entered the building. I was usually 
in the office by 0730 and got to see the daily cartoon board.

Tony

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Oct  8 21:08:56 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 21:08:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <20021008053645.A21586@defiant.ncplus.net>; from brucek@kingkon.com on Tue, Oct 08, 2002 at 05:36:45AM -0700
References: <20021008053645.A21586@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <20021008210856.A8418@kippered.herring.org>

Bruce,

I didn't see another reply, so I'll chime in. Change the value of QUEUE in
/etc/sysconfig/sendmail and then restart sendmail. The default is

    QUEUE=1h

You can change that to

    QUEUE=5m

to have it attempt to flush the queue every 5 minutes rather than once an
hour. See /etc/init.d/sendmail for how that value is put to use.

I leave it at the default and just `sendmail -q' as root from the command
line on the rare occasions that warrant some percussive persuasion :)

Sandy

On Tue, 08 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote: 
> I found in the sendmail faq (in the newsgroups) that you can get mail
> that is stuck in the mqueue to move by running "sendmail -q<time>".
> How do I put options on the commandline in the rc.d directories. Those
> all seem to be soft-links; but I haven't seen any instructions on how
> to add options to soft-links.
> 
> -bk

> Bruce Kingsland

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Oct  8 22:23:07 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 08 Oct 2002 22:23:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Thumbnail guidelines for when to convert a program from Perl to C? {Was: binary perl executable?)

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour <sharbours at yahoo.com> writes:

Sean> Can anyone give a thumbnail guideline for when someone might
Sean> want to prototype an application in perl, then rewrite it in
Sean> something faster for production use?

When programmers cost $5/hr and CPUs are $10 per mhz, it might
make sense to rewrite Perl into something else.

We crossed the line a long time ago where programmer time was a lot
more expensive than CPUs.

Stop looking for false economy.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Oct  9 00:04:49 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 00:04:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Thumbnail guidelines for when to convert a program from
 Perl to C? {Was: binary perl executable?)
In-Reply-To: <863crgnq2s.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: 5184-32184@sneakemail.com

On 8 Oct 2002, merlyn-at-stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz) |XXXXXXXXX| wrote:

> We crossed the line a long time ago where programmer time was a lot
> more expensive than CPUs.

I'll agree with this, and in fact I've often been impressed by perl's
speed.  More than once it's actually outperformed my C code just because
the perl developers have spent so much time tweaking and optimizing
things.  (especially the text parsing and regex bits)  The only real slow
part is the startup time, and that is quite bearable for anything with an
overall runtime over about 1 second.

However, if you have something that only runs for 100ms, then that perl
startup overhead becomes more critical.  I'm impatient, but even I can
wait 200-500ms for perl to load and compile.  ;-)

  -- Steve

Jeremy C. Reed's Log: StarDate 1008.1007:
> On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> 
> > I found in the sendmail faq (in the newsgroups) that you can get mail
> > that is stuck in the mqueue to move by running "sendmail -q<time>".
> > How do I put options on the commandline in the rc.d directories. Those
> > all seem to be soft-links; but I haven't seen any instructions on how
> > to add options to soft-links.
> 
> Just edit the original file (the file it links too).

I see now that the 'sendmail' in the rc.d tree is a script, rather
than an executable like the one in the /usr/sbin dir.

> Depending on the OS, you may see that the original SysV startup script
> gets its configs from another file.

two other files, it turns out....

> Every startup script for starting a sendmail daemon already has it run the
> queue at some set interval (like 30 minutes).

the interval defaults to 1 hour.... interesting value.

> On systems that don't have a listening mail server (no -bd), then I just
> do a "sendmail -q" (no time interval) via cron.

another intersting approach -- thanx.

> (I see that this is carbon-cpioed to a list I am not subscribed too. If it
> doesn't bounce: "hello Portland!")

yeah. I've found that the Portland group sometimes responds quicker,
or has different useful experience. So, now that I'm stuck over on the
peninsula - I go for all the experience I can get!  :)

>    Jeremy C. Reed
>    http://bsd.reedmedia.net/

From brucek at kingkon.com  Wed Oct  9 00:51:18 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 00:51:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <3DA35255.3030606@quiotix.com>; from jbs@quiotix.com on Tue, Oct 08, 2002 at 02:47:01PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0210081002340.6449-100000@pilchuck.reedmedia.net> <3DA35255.3030606@quiotix.com>
Message-ID: <20021009005117.D24087@defiant.ncplus.net>

Jeffrey Siegal's Log: StarDate 1008.1447:
> Jeremy C. Reed wrote:
> > On systems that don't have a listening mail server (no -bd), then I just
> > do a "sendmail -q" (no time interval) via cron.
> 
> You don't need -bd to have it run as a daemon and periodically run the 
> queue.  'sendmail -q<time>' will start still a deemon, even without -bd. 
>   If you also add -bd on the command line, it will listen in addition to 
> periodically running the queue; if not, it won't.

I think that's implied when you ask q to repeat every so often, altho
it's not specifically stated in the docs I read. Maybe I'll have to
get the bat book.

> If you're running the queue very often, you might want to take a look at 
> some sendmail options: persistant host status and single threaded delivery.

There are commands in the man page that describe how to list the
hosts, but I don't appear to have any. There are not commands
documented on how to change that. There was also a comment on the
single threaded issue related to small memory capacity. I should
probably use that, since all my mail is on my laptop, a 50 Mhz 486
with 20MB of ram.

> Persistent host status will prevent it from trying to connect to down 
> hosts every time it runs, and single thread delivery will keep multiple 
> simultaneous queue runs from competing with each other to talk to the 
> same host.  Both of these have issues though; review the sendmail docs 
> before trying to enable them.

Still looking for those expanded docs.

-bk

Kingsland Konsulting

Hi Ben,

I have no luck.  Problem still remains

At 09:12 AM 10/7/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>"useradd -d /dev/null -s /bin/false M40G$"

It went through without complaint.

>"smbpasswd -a -m M40G"

It went through without complaint, not requesting for adding password

stop ipchains and restart  Samba

# mount
/dev/hde2 on / type ext3 (rw)
none on /proc type proc (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
/dev/hde1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
none on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)

//M40G/Shared on /mnt/WinXP type smbfs (0)

One thing I could not understand.  It seems mounted but with a (0) content.


Backside Story
===========
Previously this hard drive ran RH7.3 with Samba server installed also 
having problem in connecting WinXP (the same WinXP under this test).  Samba 
server could see WinXP and its shared folder for file transfer without any 
problem.  But WinXP could not see Samba server.  The smb.conf file was a 
basic Samba config file similar to this one now used.  Unfortunately I have 
not saved the original file for future use.  After installing Samba-2.2.31 
coming with RH7.3 CDs, the setup was quite simple without much work, no 
password requested, no Administrator added to Samba, etc.   But It worked 
one-way only.  Later I made a fresh installation of RH7.3 erasing the old 
one. Now both ways are blocked.

Thanks

Stephen Liu

From brucek at kingkon.com  Wed Oct  9 02:05:10 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 02:05:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <006301c26efa$a6032ae0$666beecc@LAPTOP>; from ralphs@accelnet.net on Tue, Oct 08, 2002 at 11:43:41AM -0700
References: <20021008053645.A21586@defiant.ncplus.net> <006301c26efa$a6032ae0$666beecc@LAPTOP>
Message-ID: <20021009020510.G24087@defiant.ncplus.net>

Ok. the reference - I'm running RedHat 7.2

What I found, after all those nice hints came in.

/usr/sbin/sendmail is the main executable.
/etc/rc.d/init.d/sendmail is a script that runs at boot.
/etc/sysconfig/sendmail contains two envars:
	DAEMON=yes
	QUEUE=1h
/etc/mail/sendmail.mc contains directives for updates to ....
/etc/sendmail.cf contains the specific local instructions; among which is:
	MinQueueAge=30m meaning a msg must stay in the queue for 30m.

This implies to me that if I send a message, it will first go to the
queue and wait for a half hour. This would explain why, when I wait
for mutt to say "message sent" and then immediately drop pppd, that
the message doesn't get sent until the next time that I start pppd;
but then only actually gets sent if I keep pppd up for at least an
hour (or a multiple of an hour from when sendmail was started).

Because of that (I think), I found some messages still in the queue
after several days, which is what initiated this dialogue. I originally
set the queue.warn to 4 days (up from 4 hours) and the queue.return
to 35 days (up from 5 days) due to the fact that I was having to find
someone elses DSL pipe or dialtone to collect my email. I would then
answer and reply between visits, and it was typical to be several days
before I could reconnect to the internet. Even tho I have dialtone in
my house now, I haven't reverted those settings yet -- incase I take my
laptop somewhere else on a vacation (a what?).

I added "sendmail -q15m" to my ppp dialer script after the actual dial
command. perhaps that should be moved to ip-up? or maybe it's moot on
my next reboot, since I changed the /etc/sysconfig/sendmail QUEUE
value to 15m.

I haven't found any instructions for m4 on how to address sendmail.cf
settings that aren't included in the default sendmail.mc file. I just
perused the "info m4" doc, but found nothing specific to sendmail. It
was interesting to learn that 'dnl' means 'delete to newline'.

I haven't found the command that tells me which version of sendmail
I'm running. I know I updated it in April 2002 to whatever was latest
at that time, but I can't remember the syntax for learning that sort
of info.

Thanx again everybody!

-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

Sandy already showed how to get this information by telnet, so I will just
note that Sendmail stamps its version number in all outgoing mail:

Received: (from brucek at localhost)
        by defiant.kingkon.com (8.11.6/8.11.6) id g9995Dr24903;
        Wed, 9 Oct 2002 02:05:13 -0700

if I remember correctly, the format is
(sendmail.cf version/binary version)

From bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us  Wed Oct  9 11:24:32 2002
From: bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us (Ben Mabbott)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 11:24:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba and WinXP connection problem
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021005103023.00b4f750@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021005103023.00b4f750@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021007232557.00b51c28@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021009155708.02d81180@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <00b801c26fc1$1d1b60e0$e001ab0a@admin>

Hi Stephen,

I didn't catch that you were trying to mount a Windows share on the linux
box...I've never tried that so I won't be much help. However, maybe my
smb.conf can help you at least get the WinXP box access to the samba server.
This setup is currently running, and my WinXP box can connect to shares and
transfer files. I've made no modifications to the WinXP box other than
setting it's workgroup.

[global]

   workgroup = LAN
   netbios name = linux
   server string = Samba Server

   hosts allow = 192.168.1. 127.
   printcap name = /etc/printcap
   load printers = yes
   printing = lprng
   log file = /var/log/samba/%m.log
   max log size = 0

   security = user
   encrypt passwords = yes
   smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
   unix password sync = Yes
   passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
   passwd chat = *New*password* %n\n *Retype*new*password* %n\n
*passwd:*all*authentication*tokens*updated*successfully*
   pam password change = yes
   obey pam restrictions = yes

   socket options = TCP_NODELAY SO_RCVBUF=8192 SO_SNDBUF=8192
   dns proxy = no

From reed at reedmedia.net  Tue Oct  8 10:07:56 2002
From: reed at reedmedia.net (Jeremy C. Reed)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 10:07:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <20021008053645.A21586@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0210081002340.6449-100000@pilchuck.reedmedia.net>

On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> I found in the sendmail faq (in the newsgroups) that you can get mail
> that is stuck in the mqueue to move by running "sendmail -q<time>".
> How do I put options on the commandline in the rc.d directories. Those
> all seem to be soft-links; but I haven't seen any instructions on how
> to add options to soft-links.

Just edit the original file (the file it links too).

Depending on the OS, you may see that the original SysV startup script
gets its configs from another file.

Every startup script for starting a sendmail daemon already has it run the
queue at some set interval (like 30 minutes).

On systems that don't have a listening mail server (no -bd), then I just
do a "sendmail -q" (no time interval) via cron.

(I see that this is carbon-cpioed to a list I am not subscribed too. If it
doesn't bounce: "hello Portland!")

   Jeremy C. Reed
   http://bsd.reedmedia.net/

From jbs at quiotix.com  Tue Oct  8 14:47:01 2002
From: jbs at quiotix.com (Jeffrey Siegal)
Date: Tue, 08 Oct 2002 14:47:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0210081002340.6449-100000@pilchuck.reedmedia.net>
Message-ID: <3DA35255.3030606@quiotix.com>

Jeremy C. Reed wrote:
> On systems that don't have a listening mail server (no -bd), then I just
> do a "sendmail -q" (no time interval) via cron.

You don't need -bd to have it run as a daemon and periodically run the 
queue.  'sendmail -q<time>' will start still a deemon, even without -bd. 
  If you also add -bd on the command line, it will listen in addition to 
periodically running the queue; if not, it won't.

If you're running the queue very often, you might want to take a look at 
some sendmail options: persistant host status and single threaded delivery.

Persistent host status will prevent it from trying to connect to down 
hosts every time it runs, and single thread delivery will keep multiple 
simultaneous queue runs from competing with each other to talk to the 
same host.  Both of these have issues though; review the sendmail docs 
before trying to enable them.




From reed at reedmedia.net  Tue Oct  8 15:23:16 2002
From: reed at reedmedia.net (Jeremy C. Reed)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 15:23:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <3DA35255.3030606@quiotix.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0210081512060.6449-100000@pilchuck.reedmedia.net>

On Tue, 8 Oct 2002, Jeffrey Siegal wrote:

> Jeremy C. Reed wrote:
> > On systems that don't have a listening mail server (no -bd), then I just
> > do a "sendmail -q" (no time interval) via cron.
>
> You don't need -bd to have it run as a daemon and periodically run the
> queue.  'sendmail -q<time>' will start still a deemon, even without -bd.

I understand -- that is why I said "listening" and my example showed only
running queue a few times a day.

On some of my systems, I run a sendmail replacement (called mailout) which
I wrote. It can't listen for port 25 connections. It is a light-weight
replacement for a real smtp server which often is not even needed on most
systems.

> Persistent host status will prevent it from trying to connect to down
> hosts every time it runs, and single thread delivery will keep multiple
> simultaneous queue runs from competing with each other to talk to the
> same host.  Both of these have issues though; review the sendmail docs
> before trying to enable them.

Thanks for the info. Exim has similar features, such as queueing multiple
messages to particular domains so they can sent in a single connection.

These days, on my real mail servers, I use Exim and sometimes postfix.
(Although I continue to do work with sendmail and qmail when it comes
a long.)

It is great that there is such a variety of good software to choose from.

   Jeremy C. Reed
   http://bsd.reedmedia.net/




From reed at reedmedia.net  Wed Oct  9 09:23:49 2002
From: reed at reedmedia.net (Jeremy C. Reed)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 09:23:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Resolved: [SLL] sendmail -q5m (HOWto)
In-Reply-To: <20021009020510.G24087@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0210090916520.6449-100000@pilchuck.reedmedia.net>

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> 	MinQueueAge=30m meaning a msg must stay in the queue for 30m.
>
> This implies to me that if I send a message, it will first go to the
> queue and wait for a half hour. This would explain why, when I wait

The mail should be attempted to be sent immediately. Then if it
temporarily fails, then it will need to wait 30 minutes between queue
runs. Note: generally you do not need to ever have a -q queue run, unless
you have mail that couldn't successfully be sent in the first place.

You should look at your mail logs (/var/log/mail.log or /var/log/maillog
or similar) to see what is happening to your message. Each message can
have multiple log entries (lines).

> I added "sendmail -q15m" to my ppp dialer script after the actual dial

That will start a daemon each time. You don't need the "15m" time
interval.

> I haven't found the command that tells me which version of sendmail
> I'm running. I know I updated it in April 2002 to whatever was latest
> at that time, but I can't remember the syntax for learning that sort
> of info.

I use:

 sendmail -d0.1 -bp | head -1

Also see www.sendmail.org FAQ

   Jeremy C. Reed
   http://www.reedmedia.net/




From greg at maneuveringspeed.com  Tue Oct  8 17:04:52 2002
From: greg at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Tue, 8 Oct 2002 17:04:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 8.0 at a glance...NICE!
Message-ID: <005e01c26f27$7ed63390$6501a8c0@Endeavor>

There are surely tons of reviews, so I won't go into it much, but in a
word....NICE.

The new Gnome desktop is sharp.  On my IBM A30 all hardware except for
my PCMCIA wifi 802.11 wireless internet card was detected.

OpenOffice.org 1.0 is standard, as is Mozilla 1.0 (the latter is out in
1.1 as of this writing).  There are launcher ("shortcut" icons)" on the
lower left panel to launch the word processor, spreadsheet, and
presentation (like PowerPoint).  Ximian Evolution is an excellent mail
client similar to Outlook.  All have configured well right out of the
"box".

I do instant messaging, and gaim really delivers on a cross-database
level...ICQ and Yahoo configured well.  ICQ worked as is...uses the same
AOL network since they have owned it for about 4 years now.  Yahoo
required the loading of a simple plugin - which I found out with a quick
click on HELP and the FAQ.  Like Trillian has done for Windows, we have
it all in one package.  It's not my ideal client, but it's nice.

Mozilla continues to work well, as it does for me in Win.  I especially
like the ability under Advanced Options to DISABLE "open unrequested
windows."  Popups and those especially evil POPUNDERS...are GONE.  No
third party app to kill them.

I resented not having a terminal launcher on the panel, but that was
easily corrected.

A big music fan, XMMS does not play MP3's out of the box.  One fellow
suggested it's because Redhat does not want to get into the controversy
of supporting the mp3/CD piracy thing....I don't know, I'm an engineer,
not a lawyer or a politician. Regardless, www.xmms.org has an easy
update that will tackle the problem.  I should point out that I couldn't
find a launcher for XMMS, though it still launched from command line.

We still need to see a HIBERNATE feature...which is one of the most
wonderful features I have ever seen being a laptop user.

I run Linux mostly as a server...it chugs faithfully away when I leave
town and I don't worry about it much. After dual-booting my laptop
between WinXP and Redhat 8.0...I will run it a lot more.  Now if the
kernel developers can just get the extra mile and get us that hibernate
feature...


Greg Long
KLUG
Klamath Linux-Unix Group
http://www.maneuveringspeed.com/klug/index.html

LTSP SYSTEM ADMINISTRATION


WHY:  LTSP (Linux Terminal Server Project) might possibly be the

the Linux community with opportunities to learn more about LTSP
installation, configuration, and system administration, this course is
designed to provide hands-on practical LTSP lab/Linux server and networking
experience.

(Basically, this course is being coordinated by an individual disappointed
with the lack of currently available LTSP and advanced Linux hands-on
educational opportunities)

WHO: Created in response to the needs of college students, K-12 public
school educators/IT coordinators, and business sysadmins wishing to learn
more about the capabilities and administration of LTSP labs.

WHAT: Providing hands-on experience by building a working LTSP lab from
scratch.  The intent is to provide each participant with their own LTSP
computer/server and clients to set up and configure.  For a general course
outline (still considered a working document) and list of preferred course
prerequisites, see the following link:

http://www.mjsunderground.net/LTSPCourseOutline.htm

I recently picked up a used ThinkPad 560 cheaply (<$150) on Ebay, and 
I've managed to squeeze a minimal Debian setup on the hard drive by 
mounting it temporarily in an external FireWire case, and running the 
install from my desktop workstation. However, the machine did not come 
with the standard external floppy drive, and as far as I can tell from 
documentation searches and a day or so of experimentation, there's no 
way to install a bootloader on one machine, and then move the disk to 
another -- prob. something to do with the BIOS-based disk access code, 
but bootloaders and assembly at that level are all black magic hoodoo to me.

So, if anyone out there on the list has a ThinkPad 560/570/600/whatever 
with an external bootable floppy drive, and is willing to let me use the 
drive for an hour or so, I would be happy to buy you coffee/a beer/some 
lunch/etc. for the favor. The install really is done, and I just need to 
boot the machine once to finish getting the bootloader set up. 
Alternately, if anyone has a spare drive sitting around, I'd be more 
than willing to see if we can't negotiate a fair price (the guy who sold 
me this box wants $40, plus another $20 shipping and handling, which 
seems a bit steep for something I'm literally only going to need while 
re-installing the OS).

From alex at daniloff.com  Wed Oct  9 13:19:50 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 13:19:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk IO in =?iso-8859-1?q?Linux=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <1034018254.2749.86.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
Message-ID: <200210092019.g99KJo014184@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello Linux folkz,
I'm sorry for these strange questions

After reading 
"Web Performance Tuning"
2nd Edit. 2002 by Patrick Killelea 
Pub.O'Reily. ISBN 0-598-00172-x  

I have the following assumptions:

Linux kernel uses buffered IO file access 
when it's reading and writing to the physical 
partition/device with its native FS.

Linux kernel uses unbuffered IO file access 
if a program (e.g. DB engine) reads and writes 
to the raw partition/device.
I assume it's because DB engine handles its
data transaction on raw device/partition 
without going through the kernel IO calls.
 
Does all above apply to the case if drives 
support DMA?

Why it's nessesary to bind raw devices to block devices
( bind /dev/raw/raw1 to /dev/hdb1 )
if a database engine reads and writes to the raw partition
without such binding?

Will this binding improve performance of the DB engine or
this needs to be done only in order to read from Linux what
has been written on a raw device?

Thank you in advance for any answers or sources of further
information.

Alex

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Wed Oct  9 16:14:59 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 16:14:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual boot win 2000 and RH Linux 8
In-Reply-To: <002a01c26fe2$ce50f7a0$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0210091608270.21432-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

After you have shrunk the Win partition with PMagic, begin RH install
(don't create Linux partitions yet).
Use Disk Druid of fdisk to create Linux and swap partitions (don't tell it
to partition everything automatically, it'll wipe out the disk).
It'll want to install GRUB into MBR, let it. It probably won't recognize
NTFS, I think NTFS mounting is still experimental, unless RH enabled it in
their kernel (if it was FAT32 it would mount it).
It'll also give you an option to add the other OS to GRUB, tell it to do
it.
Then you choose which one to boot from GRUB and everything works fine.
That is, if your PC supports booting from second partition of the disk. If
it's a relatively old PC and the disk is IDE, it won't work because the
BIOS can't get to the disk above 1024 cylinders. Then what you do is this:
you move your Win partition with PMagic to open up a small partition at
the beginning of the disk, 10M is fine. Then in Disk Druid you tell RH to
mount the small partition as /boot and the big partition at the end of the
disk as /. The rest is the same, and it configures GRUB automatically to
deal with the /boot partition.

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Jim Webb wrote:

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct  9 17:01:29 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 17:01:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] MTA filtering good mail
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210091650550.13131-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I really need some help on this issue; I've been fighting it for several
weeks now without success. The problem is the reverse of spam blocking: it's
sending and receiving mail that should _not_ be blocked according to my
postfix filters.

  For example, here's one I just tried sending that bounced back to me:

Subject: Undelivered Mail Returned to Sender
----------------------------------------

This is the Postfix program at host salmo.

I'm sorry to have to inform you that the message returned
below could not be delivered to one or more destinations.

For further assistance, please send mail to <postmaster>

If you do so, please include this problem report. You can
delete your own text from the message returned below.

                        The Postfix program

<pjcogan1 at hotmail.com>: Domain.

  Now, much as I would love to reject hotmail.com and all the other no-cost
e-mailers, I cannot. The problem here is that 'hotmail.com' is not in any of
my recipient_check or sender_check map files. The only two records are:

[root at salmo /etc/postfix]# grep hotmail.com *
body_checks:/pleasestopsending at hotmail.com/ REJECT Spam rejected.
header_checks:/^From: <BeatriceTinsley at hotmail.com>/ REJECT Sender.

  In neither of these two instances, both with specific usernames, is the
reason the domain. The only instance of "Domain" is in header_checks, and
there's no instance there of hotmail.com! I'm totally bamboozled why postfix
is rejecting this message when I try to send it.

  I also have legitimate mail rejected when there is are question marks in
the subject, but not when there's a single question mark. That's another one
that has me completely baffled for there are no instances of question marks
in header_checks except at the end of specific subject lines.

  Some erroneous filtering I've finally figured out myself (the daily log
rotation of /var/log/maillog has _really_ helped me there). For example, I
was losing mail on a mail list from a user of the British ISP, virgin.net,
because 'virgin' is one of the postfix trigger words. I also had to
explicitly OK two ISPs in Nevada to prevent messages via their servers being
rejected.

  Help, please! :-)

TIA,

Rich




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Oct  9 18:24:46 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 18:24:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk IO in =?iso-8859-1?q?Linux=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <200210092019.g99KJo014184@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: 9427-10868@sneakemail.com

Disclaimer:  Some of this is based on general UNIX architecture and not
specifically on Linux.  I look to the others on the list to provide
gentle correction where needed.  ;-)

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Linux kernel uses unbuffered IO file access 
> if a program (e.g. DB engine) reads and writes 
> to the raw partition/device.

> I assume it's because DB engine handles its
> data transaction on raw device/partition 
> without going through the kernel IO calls.

No, the DB will still need to use kernel I/O calls.  (I.e read() or
write() system calls.)  Without those calls the DB would need to know how
to talk directly to the hardware, and that would defeat much of the
purpose of the OS.  ;-)  I.e. your database would need to know your disk
SCSI ID, drive type, SCSI card, etc. etc.

> Does all above apply to the case if drives support DMA?

This happens below the level at which an database interfaces with the
OS.  Databases have no knowledge of whether your drives use DMA or
not.  You can have both raw and block divices on any type of hard drive,
DMA or no DMA.

Here's a description of the data flow from your database to your disk, on
a sample disk write.  For you nitpickers, keep in mind this is appreviated
for clarity and is not 100% technically perfect.  ;-)

1) database
2) system call (i.e. "write()")
3) OS kernel system call interface
4) OS filesystem driver (unless DB is on raw/block disk, then skip this)
5) OS buffer cache (unless DB is on raw disk, then skip this)
6) OS block device driver [not sure if this is before or after RAID/LVM]
7) LVM driver (if used)
8) RAID device driver (if used)
9) SCSI/IDE driver
10) SCSI/IDE hardware (this is where DMA comes in)
11) hard drive firmware
12) bits on a platter

> Why it's nessesary to bind raw devices to block devices
> ( bind /dev/raw/raw1 to /dev/hdb1 )
> if a database engine reads and writes to the raw partition
> without such binding?

Linux doesn't bind a particular raw device to a particular block
device.  Most other unixes use something like /dev/dsk/<block> +
/dev/rdsk/<char> where the <block> and <char> device names are the same.

I think the actual command used is "raw /dev/raw/raw1 /dev/hdb1" based on
your example.

> Will this binding improve performance of the DB engine or
> this needs to be done only in order to read from Linux what
> has been written on a raw device?

This is needed to tell linux unambiguously where to find the data for that
raw device.  ;-)  Look at "man raw" for more info.  It does not appear to
be optional, so it's not a performance question.

My take on the raw interface is that it's kind of klugy.  Linux was built
with block devices from the beginning, and working around them is likely
to result in finding more bugs than you might find otherwise.  ;-)

  -- Steve




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Wed Oct  9 19:46:30 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 19:46:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual boot win 2000 and RH Linux 8
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210091534170.22236-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210091927550.22449-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> You could always remove the Win2K drive, pop in a fresh drive and install
> Linux on it too...

Indeed, if the intention is to compare performance, Apache would be at a
disadvantage on a second generation partition. Among other issues,
Apache's I/O will take much longer because it must read and write to the
center of the disk, whereas IIS will get the speedy outer rim.

The sad thing is, I think Apache would still come out ahead. :)

Tyler



On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> You could always remove the Win2K drive, pop in a fresh drive and install
> Linux on it too...
>
>
> On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Jim Webb wrote:
>
> > I've just been given a dell server at work to show them RH linux for an
> > intranet at the hospital that I work at. I'm trying to show them linux with
> > apache as opposed to windoze with IIS.  It has Windoze 2000 already
> > installed on it with one partition.  I'm going to use partition magic and
> > create two partitions.  How do I go about installing Red Hat at that point
> > in order to make it a dual boot machine.  I looked at the archives back
> > several months and saw that someone wanted to have linux in the MBR and
> > windows at hdb or something.
> >
> > I'm not really sure about this.  I understand that I'll have to load linux
> > in the second partition and also load the linux bootloader such as GRUB or
> > LILO.
> >
> > What will I see when I start the install of linux?  Will RH 8 see the ntfs
> > partition and then show the linux partitions?  Will I be booting up with
> > GRUB or the windows loader initially?

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Wed Oct  9 19:50:50 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 19:50:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk IO in Linux?
In-Reply-To: 9427-10868@sneakemail.com
References: 9427-10868@sneakemail.com
Message-ID: <200210091950.50638.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Wednesday 09 October 2002 18:24, Steve Bonds wrote:
> Disclaimer:  Some of this is based on general UNIX architecture and not
> specifically on Linux.  I look to the others on the list to provide
> gentle correction where needed.  ;-)

OK. I have a few minor corrections, but I am not a kernel developer either.

Well, I lied about minor correction.  This got long.  Sorry, I deal with 
databases and filesystems all day long as a systems architect, so it tends 
to leak over :-)

> On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > Linux kernel uses unbuffered IO file access
> > if a program (e.g. DB engine) reads and writes
> > to the raw partition/device.
> >
> > I assume it's because DB engine handles its
> > data transaction on raw device/partition
> > without going through the kernel IO calls.
>
> No, the DB will still need to use kernel I/O calls.  (I.e read() or
> write() system calls.)  Without those calls the DB would need to know
> how to talk directly to the hardware, and that would defeat much of the
> purpose of the OS.  ;-)  I.e. your database would need to know your disk
> SCSI ID, drive type, SCSI card, etc. etc.

Steve's got this right.

_All_ normal block device access goes through buffering.  This buffering 
has been called various things in Linux.  In 2.2 there were buffers for 
reading and writing.  In 2.4, that was unified to one cache.  In 2.5/6 
they're changing it again.

This makes database people unhappy because when the low level kernel 
routines tell the C library that they wrote the block to disk, it might 
not really be on disk, but could be in a buffer somewhere (yes, I'm 
simplifying).  There are system calls and special attributes and some ways 
around this (think fsync() and friends).  But, that's a pain.  And, it 
doesn't solve the whole problem (see later).

Hence, you get the raw devices.  These are special devices created on 
demand that give another interface to some existing block device.  This 
extra interface is outside the whole set of caching etc. that the kernel 
does.  It talks about as directly to the hardware as the kernel can do.  
If you write a block on that interface, when it's done, the drive has told 
it that it's done (it still could be in memory on the drive!  users of 
speedy IDE drives beware, I've lost data due to this).

> > Does all above apply to the case if drives support DMA?
>
> This happens below the level at which an database interfaces with the
> OS.  Databases have no knowledge of whether your drives use DMA or
> not.  You can have both raw and block divices on any type of hard drive,
> DMA or no DMA.
>
> Here's a description of the data flow from your database to your disk,
> on a sample disk write.  For you nitpickers, keep in mind this is
> appreviated for clarity and is not 100% technically perfect.  ;-)
>
> 1) database
> 2) system call (i.e. "write()")
> 3) OS kernel system call interface

3b) VFS call, this handles most of the high level filesystem stuff that is 
independent of the actual implementation of the filesystem.

> 4) OS filesystem driver (unless DB is on raw/block disk, then skip this)

I've never tried to mount a filesystem on a raw device.  Might be possible 
in which case this layer would get hit.

> 5) OS buffer cache (unless DB is on raw disk, then skip this)
> 7) LVM driver (if used)
> 8) RAID device driver (if used)

Are these before or after the buffer cache?  I can't for the life of me 
remember.

> 6) OS block device driver [not sure if this is before or after RAID/LVM]

this was out of order above.  There's not really much here other than a 
pseudo-vtable of file-ops.

> 9) SCSI/IDE driver
> 10) SCSI/IDE hardware (this is where DMA comes in)

Actually, there are a few more pieces to DMA. It is set up by the driver 
and other parts of the kernel (DMA requires locked pages etc., so the VM 
subsystem is involved partially).

> 11) hard drive firmware

11b) hard disk cache.  Modern drives have this.  You can turn it off and 
should if you really want high levels of data integrity.  There was a 
large discussion on the ReiserFS list and the MySQL list some time ago 
(two years?).  You write to the drive, it puts it into cache and tells you 
it's done.  The power goes out.  Some drives do not use rotational energy 
to write the cache to disk (because the cache is too big).  See the actual 
drive specs.  But, don't assume that because the drive told you that it 
wrote the data that the magnetic fields are changed on the platters.

> 12) bits on a platter
>
> > Why it's nessesary to bind raw devices to block devices
> > ( bind /dev/raw/raw1 to /dev/hdb1 )
> > if a database engine reads and writes to the raw partition
> > without such binding?
>
> Linux doesn't bind a particular raw device to a particular block
> device.  Most other unixes use something like /dev/dsk/<block> +
> /dev/rdsk/<char> where the <block> and <char> device names are the same.
>
> I think the actual command used is "raw /dev/raw/raw1 /dev/hdb1" based
> on your example.

Can't remember off the top of my head, but I remember the syntax being 
similar to that of the loop-back device.

> > Will this binding improve performance of the DB engine or
> > this needs to be done only in order to read from Linux what
> > has been written on a raw device?
>
> This is needed to tell linux unambiguously where to find the data for
> that raw device.  ;-)  Look at "man raw" for more info.  It does not
> appear to be optional, so it's not a performance question.
>
> My take on the raw interface is that it's kind of klugy.  Linux was
> built with block devices from the beginning, and working around them is
> likely to result in finding more bugs than you might find otherwise. 
> ;-)

Raw devices have been around on other forms of Unix for a long time.  The 
discussion of raw devices that worked just like those of other Unix 
variants ended with Linus saying "no way, I'm not going to clutter up my 
already full /dev with more cruft!".  Ok, I'm taking liberties with what 
he said, but that is the meat of the argument.  The device space was 
already nearly full (running out of major numbers) and the /dev tree is 
full of all kinds of things that aren't needed most of the time.  devfs 
solves some of the problems.

Raw devices allow specific block devices to have unbuffered access.  They 
do this without cluttering /dev and without overuse of major numbers.

I would not necessarily say that it was speed that the DB people were 
after.  That is a factor.  I think that one of the biggest things they 
wanted was to be able to ensure that blocks were written to disk in a 
specific order. 

With the OS doing one or more layers of caching, elevator algorithms etc. 
and the drives or disk controllers doing the same thing, it is very easy, 
often common, for blocks to be written out of order.  If you are doing a 
very important transaction into a fully ACID compliant DB and the part of 
the transaction that says "DONE!" is written to disk, but the previous two 
blocks aren't when the power goes out, you'll have a corrupt database.

Some kinds of disk controllers (SCSI??, FibreChannel??) can have "write 
barriers".  When the controller hits one of these in the list of commands, 
it makes sure that all writes before the barrier are flushed to disk 
before it does one past the barrier.  So, in my transaction example above, 
you'd put a write barrier just before the "DONE!" block (I think one is 
put after it too so that transactions don't get mixed).  All the blocks 
that were part of that transaction will be flushed to disk before the 
"DONE!" block.

By forcing the order of disk writes, you usually slow down disk access, not 
speed it up.  But, you make sure that you'll have a coherent DB after a 
sudden power failure.

I actually think that raw devices (as done on Linux) are a fairly elegant 
solution to the problem of having direct disk access.  However, I also 
think that a system that makes you need such access is definitely not that 
good.  Most Unix variants fall into that category.

Best,
Kyle




From m at netpro.to  Wed Oct  9 19:59:59 2002

Subject: [PLUG] What wrote this? It broke in pronto and I would like to post it
 to the pronto list
Message-ID: <20021010053714.FMJA6765.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Oct 10 01:23:41 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 01:23:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Disk IO in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200210091950.50638.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: 22337-92398@sneakemail.com

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> 11b) hard disk cache.  Modern drives have this.  You can turn it off
> and should if you really want high levels of data integrity.  There
> was a large discussion on the ReiserFS list and the MySQL list some
> time ago (two years?).  You write to the drive, it puts it into cache
> and tells you it's done.  The power goes out.  Some drives do not use
> rotational energy to write the cache to disk (because the cache is too
> big).  See the actual drive specs.  But, don't assume that because the
> drive told you that it wrote the data that the magnetic fields are
> changed on the platters.

Anyone using a hard disk write-back cache without a UPS and auto-flush on
power failure is begging for pain.  I've felt that pain and it's not
fun.  (Can you say 'fish out the backup tapes', boys and girls?)

I will freely admin to being behind the times on IDE technology, but all
my SCSI drives have write cache OFF even though the system is
UPSed.  Unless I'm running a benchmark to impress my friends. ;-)  Turning
it on gets that extra 20%, but is never appropriate for data that can't be
recreated easily.

> I would not necessarily say that it was speed that the DB people were
> after.  That is a factor.  I think that one of the biggest things they
> wanted was to be able to ensure that blocks were written to disk in a
> specific order.

My experience has been they're after the higher performance.  
Double-buffering by the OS is just wasting CPU cycles if you're already
using internal database caching as well as possibly caching at the
disk array level.

I think the reason you hear the "specific order" argument is because of
old-timers who learned to manage databases on JBODs (bare disks bereft of
caching/striping/RAID).

Those pesky database people-- always trying to get down into the meat of
the hardware to optimize the database layout for the current data
set.  Unfortunately, most of the databases I deal with have areas of
constantly moving "local busy-ness" which generally correspond to that
day/week/month's data.  Since (unfortunately) most databases have
archiving/data removal put in as an afterthought (if at all), this little
section of high I/O keeps creeping forward in the database over time.

The net result is all that careful tuning is completely useless after a
few weeks or months since the hotspot has moved.

(My solution: loads of battery-backed cache on the hardware (absorbs your
random I/O), and stripe* the fury out of everything (speeds the sequential
I/O).  This gets you 80% of the way there with 10% of the effort and it
works just as well on day 1 as on day 100.)

*I find that striping across hardware RAID-5 groups to be particularly
effective since many RAID-5 controllers are slow on sequential
writes.  Striping over them gives 'em a chance to catch up between I/Os.

> With the OS doing one or more layers of caching, elevator algorithms
> etc.  and the drives or disk controllers doing the same thing, it is
> very easy, often common, for blocks to be written out of order.  If
> you are doing a very important transaction into a fully ACID compliant
> DB and the part of the transaction that says "DONE!" is written to
> disk, but the previous two blocks aren't when the power goes out,
> you'll have a corrupt database.

Yeah, this is why any database worth anything does opens its files with
the O_SYNC option to ensure that the kernel doesn't return from the
write() until the hardware says the data is safe.  This option
periodically seems to break on linux.  Most UNIX variants have ways of
"translating" this safety feature to be faster and less safe.  Not
recommended.  ;-)

Writing data out of order isn't necessarily a problem if ALL I/O is going
through the buffer cache.  (And anyone mixing buffered and unbuffered I/O
is begging for lots of pain.)  The buffer cache need only ensure that
multiple writes to the *same data* arrive in order, which is usually not a
problem.  Reads to that data will come out of the most-recently-written
buffer so the application need never even know it wasn't on disk.

The power-lost/OS-crashed loss of data is a problem on any write-back
cache and a major reason to avoid them if there is no way to externally
recreate the lost/corrupt data.

> By forcing the order of disk writes, you usually slow down disk
> access, not speed it up.  But, you make sure that you'll have a
> coherent DB after a sudden power failure.

Just to beat the point some more, the coherency problem isn't necessarily
related to the ordering-- it's a risk of having data "in transit".

One of the main reasons raw is faster for big databases is they do their
own caching so the buffer does nothing but add a few milliseconds of
searching the buffer to each I/O for no net gain.

Wow.  That sure got long.  ;-)

  -- Steve




From brucek at kingkon.com  Thu Oct 10 06:54:41 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 06:54:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Any ThinkPad owners in the area?
In-Reply-To: <3DA49A00.3010602@day-reynolds.com>; from lennon@day-reynolds.com on Wed, Oct 09, 2002 at 02:05:04PM -0700
References: <3DA49A00.3010602@day-reynolds.com>

Lennon Day-Reynolds's Log: StarDate 1009.1405:
> I recently picked up a used ThinkPad 560 cheaply (<$150) on Ebay, and 
> I've managed to squeeze a minimal Debian setup on the hard drive by 
> mounting it temporarily in an external FireWire case, and running the 
> install from my desktop workstation. However, the machine did not come 
> with the standard external floppy drive, and as far as I can tell from 
> documentation searches and a day or so of experimentation, there's no 
> way to install a bootloader on one machine, and then move the disk to 
> another -- prob. something to do with the BIOS-based disk access code, 
> but bootloaders and assembly at that level are all black magic hoodoo to me.
> 
> So, if anyone out there on the list has a ThinkPad 560/570/600/whatever 
> with an external bootable floppy drive, and is willing to let me use the 
> drive for an hour or so, I would be happy to buy you coffee/a beer/some 
> lunch/etc. for the favor. The install really is done, and I just need to 
> boot the machine once to finish getting the bootloader set up. 
> Alternately, if anyone has a spare drive sitting around, I'd be more 
> than willing to see if we can't negotiate a fair price (the guy who sold 
> me this box wants $40, plus another $20 shipping and handling, which 
> seems a bit steep for something I'm literally only going to need while 
> re-installing the OS).

I have a ThinkPad 360PE. There is a feature that you have to set in
the lilo, or in the grub: floppy=thinkpad
This tells linux that you're running on a thinkpad, which as an
inverted floppy sense line. IBM decided to save some realestate on
this series, which requires the software to adjust.

I got RedHat 5.2 running by putting my drive into someone elses box,
and installing it all there, and then rebooting. I got RH7.2 installed
by connecting the laptop to another system which had a drive
containing _all_ the files from the two installation disks, and using
boot floppies made from disk1 to do an ftp install.

Maybe this is OT from what you are asking for, but I thot maybe there
might be some clues herein. As I read your question again, maybe
you're telling us that there is no floppy on your thinkpad...

ymmv,
-bk

From mike at computer-arts.net  Thu Oct 10 08:13:06 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 08:13:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Saving Gnome Session
Message-ID: <3DA59902.E29271BE@computer-arts.net>

When I check the "save session" box, when logging out of Gnome,
it appears to create the file $HOME/.gnome/session. In this file,
the apps that I'm running are saved, but no info about their
"geometry" appears to be saved.

It appears that I can edit the session file by hand, for example:
  6,Program=xterm
  6,CloneCommand=xterm +sb -geometry 80x24+6+356 
  6,RestartCommand=xterm +sb -geometry 80x24+6+356 
seems to do what I want, when I log off and on again.

However, Gnome periodically seems to want to change this file
when I DON'T do the "save session" thing. Also, of course, it would
be nice to have Gnome save the geometry info if possible.

Can anyone point me to documentation that addresses this?
When I open up "help" in Gnome is comes up with something that either
doesn't work very well, or that I don't understand :-)  It appears
that if If I knew exactly where I wanted to look, I might find
something, but I can't figure out any way to search through it.

-Mike

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Oct 10 09:41:34 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 09:41:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] html tag for image caption
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210100929320.19864-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210100929320.19864-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021010164134.GA19928@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Oct 10, 2002 at 09:30:54AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   According to my copy of ORA's "HTML", there is a <caption> tag associated
> with tables. Is there a way to associate a caption with an image?

The pages I design use tables for layout, so I usually just place text
above or below (as appropriate) the image in the same cell.  Use a <BR>
tag to force them onto different lines.

Colin

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Oct 10 10:15:52 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 10:15:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel build questions ...
In-Reply-To: <1034269523.31782.205.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0210101014001.24220-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

/usr/src/linux-2.4/configs/ contains configs for all kernel packages.
If you know which one you installed (i.e. smp or not, i686, athlon, etc),
you can find your config.
If you want to rebuild, this is a good starting point, too.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Oct 10 11:51:43 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 11:51:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] sparc
In-Reply-To: <200210101136.43677.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210101148420.12165-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, Marvin wrote:

> I have a chance to get a sparc10.
> 
> Not knowing about sparc is this something I can put Linux on???

Yep. Current versions of Debian and SuSE should run on it.

> err.... If I take this what would I do with it??

Nothing that requires huge amounts of speed :-)

Seriously, you could use it to host a variety of network services: 
web, light-duty RDBMS, dhcp, ntp, ldap. Unless your app is seriously 
CPU-intensive, it'll do just fine.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com  Thu Oct 10 11:51:23 2002
From: Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com (Mazhary-Clark, Ben)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 11:51:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] sparc
Message-ID: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B140893374289D@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>

Yep, I had odd issues with my SS5-110 and Debian Woody (3.0) which I was
never able to figure out.  Debian seems to be one of the best distros out
there for Sparc, or at least has the best support.  RedHat dropped sparc
support after 6.2 (however it worked great).  And of course since RH dropped
it Mandrake follows suit.  SuSe used to have a sparc release but it would
appear they do no longer.  

Your best starting point for Linux-Sparc resources should be:
www.ultralinux.org
They have a listing of supported distros and FAQs.
Have fun!
--ben

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Thu Oct 10 12:00:34 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 12:00:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] html tag for image caption
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210100929320.19864-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210100929320.19864-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <p05100300b9cb7ca35cda@[192.168.3.1]>

At 9:30 AM -0700 10/10/02, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   According to my copy of ORA's "HTML", there is a <caption> tag associated
>with tables. Is there a way to associate a caption with an image?


	The "caption" attribute of HTML Tables is "deprecated" 
(phased out, obsolete).

		http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/tables.html#h-11.2.2

	The "caption" attribute is NOT designed for images, nor is it 
a stable cross-browser tag attribute. Various non-standard browsers 
(i.e. MS Internet Explorer!) will render the attribute differently.

	... so many (HTML) problems, so little (customer) interest in 
fixing them.   ;-)




Patrick Beart

Internet Consulting, Intelligent Web site Development & Secure site Hosting.
http://www.WebArchitecture.com/

controversial."

(the luggable sun4m) in the not too distant past.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Oct 10 12:32:08 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 12:32:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
References: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
		<1021396697.17058.119.camel@dereklinux>  <3CE15308.1FF527B3@attbi.com>
		<1021418055.18186.189.camel@dereklinux>  <3CE1B6F3.28D1EE43@attbi.com> <1021483897.18186.274.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <3DA5D5B8.DBFD2B90@attbi.com>

Derek Loree wrote:

> I personally think (given that your grounding is good) that you should
> pursue this as a hardware problem (try changing the mouse or get an
> anti-static pad for the mouse), not an environmental condition that
> needs to be dealt with on a daily basis.
> 
> I hope that you will keep us updated on this issue.

Ok. This was the last posting of a thread from last spring when I first
brought up a problem I was having with my machine resetting itself on
occasion. There was much to think about in all the good ideas that came
from this list. There were also a lot of other things that came up to
get in the way of pursuing any of them. But just recently, the problem
resurfaced, so I went back and read all the old posts and have come up
with what I think is a working solution.

To review: I have two floor mats under my desk chair, a metal table with
the mouse on it, and a metal frame/laminate topped table with the
keyboard and monitor on it. The computer itself sits on a wooden box
under the metal table. If the chair bumps the metal table, the machine
resets. (Last spring, other static events were also causing the reset.)

In looking over the various recommendations, the point about the static
mats being a capacitor made good sense. Also, that just bolting a wire
to them wasn't going to do much to drain that charge, since they are
plastic, after all. It occurred to me that I could approximate a fancy
discharge mat if I could incorporate a metallic grid into the mat
system. I now have a piece of chicken wire sandwiched between the two
plastic mats, and a length of small chain draped around the chair
pedestal so that it drags on the mat. I crimped a piece of awg 20
stranded wire to one of the cut ends of the chicken wire and ran that
over to a leg of the metal table. I ran another piece of the same wire
from that point on the table leg to the screw of an outlet cover. Spade
lugs are crimped to the two wires where they are held under a screw on
the table leg. I tried to use a spade lug for the wire under the cover
plate screw, but the screw is too short, so I just went with wrapping
the stranded wire around the screw before tightening it.

I have tested the setup by rolling the chair across the mat and letting
it hit the table. It seems to work! The system did not reset. While
that's probably not a great test, it is a test using the original
parameters. Time will tell if I've really solved the problem.

So, thanks to all who offered advice back in May. If this turns out not
to work, I'll let you know.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From stever at woo-hoo.com  Thu Oct 10 13:32:42 2002
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 13:32:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Yet another RH8.0 failed install
In-Reply-To: <28533.209.210.3.17.1034117410.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <28533.209.210.3.17.1034117410.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <21963.209.210.3.17.1034281962.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

With help from Arjan van de Ven at Redhat, the solution to this problem
was the following:

"can you try putting

apm=idle_threshold=100

on the kernel commandline ? (eg type "e" in grub and then edit the line
with vmlinuz on it to add that)"

It fixed the problem.  Apparently I was the fifth person he helped with
this fix so it is not entirely uncommon.  The line has something to do
with power management for laptops which seems to break certain PCs.....




> I have this HP Vectra VL which, as long as I pass the "no-hlt" parameter
> to the kernal, worked perfectly using RH7.3.  I just tried the "upgrade"
> but then did a clean install of RH8.0 and it fails upon booting.  The
> last line output is:
>
> Freeing unused kernel memory: 212k freed
>
> It simply halts after this point and is unresponsive to any keys.
>
> Even when booting off of the boot floppy it stops in the same place.
>
> Any suggestions on what could be causing this type of failure?
>
> Thanks for your help.
>
>
>

Subject: [PLUG] sparc
In-Reply-To: <3DA5D071.2040005@parkrose.k12.or.us>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210101148420.12165-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <3DA5D071.2040005@parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <20021010211125.GA17500@wirex.net>

On Thu, Oct 10, 2002 at 12:09:37PM -0700, Dan Young wrote:
> Paul Heinlein wrote:
> >On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, Marvin wrote:
> >>I have a chance to get a sparc10.
> >>Not knowing about sparc is this something I can put Linux on???
> >
> >Yep. Current versions of Debian and SuSE should run on it.

I just set up Debian Woody on a sparc 10. It went pretty smoothly, other
than the debian installer not realizing that the few tasksel selections
I made would fill the (420MB) disk. 

I did have a problem with the debian sparc netboot image and an IPX (sun4c
class), where the kernel just seemed to hang on loading itself. I didn't
have a chance to diagnose it any further than that.

> You could give Gentoo a shot too.
> http://www.gentoo.org/doc/gentoo-sparc-install.html
> 
> It looks like sparc32 support is somewhat limited, so one of the other 
> distros might be better for a SS10. I've poked around on an Ultra 5 with 
> Gentoo a bit.

I don't wanna imagine how long it would take a sparc10 to bootstrap a
gentoo install.

> The BSDs are an option also, I had NetBSD running on a Sparc Voyager 
> (the luggable sun4m) in the not too distant past.

Yes, I installed NetBSD 1.6 on the IPX I mentioned above. Once I got the
darn thing to netboot properly (needed tftp, bootpd, bootparams, and
nfsd all working), it was a pretty straightforward install.

--

References: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>		<1021396697.17058.119.camel@dereklinux>  <3CE15308.1FF527B3@attbi.com>		<1021418055.18186.189.camel@dereklinux>  <3CE1B6F3.28D1EE43@attbi.com> <1021483897.18186.274.camel@dereklinux> <3DA5D5B8.DBFD2B90@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DA5F76D.5080905@pacifier.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:
> Derek Loree wrote:


> It occurred to me that I could approximate a fancy
> discharge mat if I could incorporate a metallic grid into the mat
> system. I now have a piece of chicken wire sandwiched between the two
> plastic mats, and a length of small chain draped around the chair
> pedestal so that it drags on the mat. I crimped a piece of awg 20
> stranded wire to one of the cut ends of the chicken wire and ran that
> over to a leg of the metal table. I ran another piece of the same wire
> from that point on the table leg to the screw of an outlet cover. 


I think you really want to add a resistor in series to prevent possible shock.

chicken wire -> desk -> 10M ohm/.25W restr -> outlet cover

(That's 10 Meg ohm)

--
Kyle Accardi

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu Oct 10 15:18:43 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 15:18:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] sparc
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210101508530.1896-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 10 Oct 2002 11:51:43 -0700 (PDT) Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, Marvin wrote:
>
> > I have a chance to get a sparc10.
> >
> > Not knowing about sparc is this something I can put Linux on???
>
> Yep. Current versions of Debian and SuSE should run on it.

There is also a RedHat-like distro that reportedly works, called
Aurora. I haven't played with it. See the Ultralinux home page
for further details.
>
> > err.... If I take this what would I do with it??
>
> Nothing that requires huge amounts of speed :-)
>
Two items to be aware of:

1) Make sure you have enough disk in the Sparc. The one I have has
two 400 MB drives -- not quite enough to load X using the latest
version of Debian. This can put a crimp on many uses for it.

2) SS10's do not have a built in CDROM. You'll have to either
scrounge a SCI external CDROM drive (I built one using an old 411
case & a 4x SCSI Plextor drive -- works fine) or set up an NFS
server & use the CDROM drive on that.

On the plus side, I find that my SS10 is clearly zippier than the
486 I've been using as a testbed, & from watching the listings on
ebay, I can attest that you can find lots of spare parts to beef
it up, if you so desire.

Geoff

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu Oct 10 15:47:48 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 15:47:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] sparc
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210101541210.1896-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 10 Oct 2002 15:18:59 -0700 Marvin wrote:

> On Thursday 10 October 2002 3:18 pm, Geoff Burling wrote:
>
> > 2) SS10's do not have a built in CDROM. You'll have to either
> > scrounge a SCI external CDROM drive (I built one using an old 411
> > case & a 4x SCSI Plextor drive -- works fine) or set up an NFS
> > server & use the CDROM drive on that.
>
> What type scsi would that be.. ???
>
UltraWide, or SCSI II. Since it's a generation back, they're
very inexpensive right now. (I just picked up a sparc-compatible
external SCSI cable at FreeGeek for $2.50 -- about a third of
the mail order price of $9-10, which is still a lot less than
what this stuff cost 5 to 7 years ago.)

If you poke around the Sun web site, you can find the field engineer
manual for the SS10. Lots of useful tips there. (And I wonder how
long before some PHB at Sun decides to remove them in order ``to
save money"?)

Geoff
