From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Thu Oct 10 17:41:05 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 17:41:05 -0700
Subject: Web site Images   (was Re: [PLUG] html tag for image caption)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210101201300.20189-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210101201300.20189-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <p05100302b9cbcde373e4@[192.168.3.1]>

At 12:02 PM -0700 10/10/02, Rich Shepard wrote:
>On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, Patrick Beart wrote:
>
>>	The "caption" attribute of HTML Tables is "deprecated"
>>  (phased out, obsolete).
>
>   Good to know, Patrick. Thanks. Wasn't going to use it anyway.
>
>>	The "caption" attribute is NOT designed for images, nor is it
>>  a stable cross-browser tag attribute. Various non-standard browsers
>>  (i.e. MS Internet Explorer!) will render the attribute differently.
>
>   Only 1 person has commented that she would like to see images on my Web
>site. I don't think I'll add any.



	Images could really be valuable - depends on the focus of the 
site. I'd counsel you not to dismiss the idea, without careful 
consideration of what you want to do with the site and WHO your 
audience is.
	While YOU might not see the need for images, your potential 
audience might. This woman's feedback could be a bellwether for you.




Patrick Beart

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu Oct 10 17:55:47 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 17:55:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: suspicious returned e-mails
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021010172235.00aa9008@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

Hi all,

The last week or so, I've gotten a handful of returned e-mails.

What's suspicious is that I'm certain I never sent them.  The accounts I 
supposedly sent from are aliases that are only used for inbound mail from 
web sites I host.

So something is obviously amiss.  I'm not sure what, exactly, one might 
stand to gain from spoofing real addresses to send mail to non-existent 
recipients, but I thought some of the more grizzled netizens among us might 
have an idea what kind of exploit is being attempted.

A copy of one such returned mail is copied below.  In this mail, 
ev at dylanreinhardt.com is an inbound alias.  My mail server 
is  www.digitaldrywall.com (yes, www... it's a RaQ).  A MIME header says it 
had a midi file attached, but the file type was exe.  I didn't try to make 
use of the large amount of gibberish data in the body of the message, so 
it's tough to say what the file might have been.

Should I be reporting abuse to postmaster at ooops.org, or is that what 
they're trying to trick me into doing?  Could this be some ultra-clever 
ruse to confirm webmaster addresses for a spam list?

TIA for any thoughts y'all might have... I don't imagine there's anything 
to be done... mostly I'm curious to keep up with what those crazy kids are 
doing these days.

Dylan

Return-Path: <MAILER-DAEMON>

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Oct 10 18:10:41 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 18:10:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: suspicious returned e-mails
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021010172235.00aa9008@www.dylanreinhardt.com>; from plug@dylanreinhardt.com on Thu, Oct 10, 2002 at 05:55:47PM -0700
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021010172235.00aa9008@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <20021010181041.A27534@kippered.herring.org>

It's the nasty Klez worm at work. See...

http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.klez.h at mm.html

...where you'll note...

Email:
This worm searches the Windows address book, the ICQ database, and local files
for email addresses. The worm sends an email message to these addresses with
itself as an attachment. The worm contains its own SMTP engine and attempts to
guess at available SMTP servers. For example, if the worm encounters the
address user at abc123.com it will attempt to send email via the server
smtp.abc123.com.

The subject line, message bodies, and attachment file names are random. The
From address is randomly-chosen from email addresses that the worm finds on the
infected computer.

Sandy

On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Oct 10 18:47:50 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 18:47:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Teeny H/D, Ancient Distro.
In-Reply-To: <20021010235546.F205D371B0@ados.com>
Message-ID: 14406-47637@sneakemail.com

On Thu, 10 Oct 2002, guy1656 guy1656-at-ados.com |XXXXXXXXX| wrote:

> OK, having fun here on a 'pounder' machine. (Not connected to network,
> no critical information stored on it.)
> 
> 266MHz, 1.2GB HD, installing Caldera 2.2
> 
> Anyways, the symptom I'm getting is that the installation won't
> "stick." If I shut down and reboot again the "LILO" only gets to "LI"
> and hangs.

Usually this is because the /boot area is not in the first 1024 cylinders
of the disk.  Try creating a 50MB /boot partition as the first primary
partition on the disk and reinstalling.

  -- Steve

At 06:10 PM 10/10/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>It's the nasty Klez worm at work. See...
>
>http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.klez.h at mm.html
>
>...where you'll note...
>
>Email:
>This worm searches the Windows address book, the ICQ database, and local files
>for email addresses. The worm sends an email message to these addresses with
>itself as an attachment. The worm contains its own SMTP engine and attempts to
>guess at available SMTP servers. For example, if the worm encounters the
>address user at abc123.com it will attempt to send email via the server
>smtp.abc123.com.
>
>The subject line, message bodies, and attachment file names are random. The
> From address is randomly-chosen from email addresses that the worm finds 
> on the
>infected computer.
>
>Sandy

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Oct 10 22:34:10 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 10 Oct 2002 22:34:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Thumbnail guidelines for when to convert a program from Perl to C? {Was: binary perl executable?)
References: <mailman.1034147167.25746.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86lm55fsj1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Steve" == Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> writes:

Steve> However, if you have something that only runs for 100ms, then that perl
Steve> startup overhead becomes more critical.  I'm impatient, but even I can
Steve> wait 200-500ms for perl to load and compile.  ;-)

Then stop compiling it repeatedly.

See PPerl, mod_perl, FastCGI, SOAP, POE, etc etc.

Many solutions to persist a Perl compilation or a Perl process.

From pem at nellump.net  Fri Oct 11 00:25:29 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 00:25:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PC Reboots As Kernel Loads
Message-ID: <20021011072528.GB418@nellump.net>

Strange. I recently replaced the aging P166 motherboard in my Linux
box with a second-hand (known good) MicronPC i810-based 700 MHz
Celeron mobo. Everything looks alright until the kernel attempts
to load, at which point the box spontaneously reboots.

I can just barely make out where the kernel message spew is when
it barfs: it appears to be just *after* the "calculating delay
loop" line, which judging by the dmesg output of my other systems
is when the kernel decides what it has to work with in the way of
RAM.

Is it possible for "bad" RAM to make the kernel barf? This RAM came
off of the P166 board (yes, it's compatible with the Celeron --
standard PC133 DIMMs), and was working just fine. Also, I had no
difficulties booting with a Win98 boot floppy (sigh).

The next step I had in mind was to run some sort of memory test
software. Any better ideas?


Paul

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Oct 11 07:39:29 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 07:39:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PC Reboots As Kernel Loads 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 11 Oct 2002 00:25:29 PDT."
             <20021011072528.GB418@nellump.net> 
Message-ID: <200210111439.g9BEdT210214@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> Strange. I recently replaced the aging P166 motherboard in my Linux
> box with a second-hand (known good) MicronPC i810-based 700 MHz
> Celeron mobo. Everything looks alright until the kernel attempts
> to load, at which point the box spontaneously reboots.
> 
> I can just barely make out where the kernel message spew is when
> it barfs: it appears to be just *after* the "calculating delay
> loop" line, which judging by the dmesg output of my other systems
> is when the kernel decides what it has to work with in the way of
> RAM.
> 
> Is it possible for "bad" RAM to make the kernel barf? This RAM came
> off of the P166 board (yes, it's compatible with the Celeron --
> standard PC133 DIMMs), and was working just fine. Also, I had no
> difficulties booting with a Win98 boot floppy (sigh).
> 
> The next step I had in mind was to run some sort of memory test
> software. Any better ideas?
> 

Are you still using the same power supply that came with the 166 MHz
board?  If so, I would suggest trying a newer, beefier supply.  It
has been my experience that right around the bogomips calculation is
where the kernel really starts working hard.  An embedded PowerPC
board that I've been working on will often reset at that spot if
the power supply isn't up to snuff.

The memory test is also a good idea.  You can download a free one
at memtest86.com.

galen






From jrosenbaum at ffadesign.com  Fri Oct 11 08:47:32 2002
From: jrosenbaum at ffadesign.com (josh rosenbaum)
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 08:47:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Teeny H/D, Ancient Distro.
In-Reply-To: <20021011020754.E180237344@ados.com>
Message-ID: <009601c2713d$837f58a0$a501a8c0@Josh2>

This'll wipe the information off your drive, but if you have any sort of
boot disk with fdisk on it, you can try fdisk /mbr
That resets the master boot record.  Then I would suggest what Steve
suggests and create a nice new partition.  Then reboot and all should be
good...

Good luck!
-Josh

		       ADVANCED TOPICS MEETINGS

      OGI wants people to register, so they know how many people to
      prepare for.  Since the talks are free you will not be ask
      to give a credit card number.  Register at http://cpd.ogi.edu/


      **********************************************************


      Linux Kernel 2.6:  New Features-I      Date:  October 1, 2002

      Linux Kernel 2.6:  New Features-II     Date:  October 15, 2002


      These are the first two in a series of three free seminars in
      which Dr. Jerry Cooperstein will outline the changes coming in
      the next major release of the Linux operating system kernel,
      due in early 2003. These include: a new optimized scheduler,
      kernel pre-emption, inclusion of the JFS and perhaps XFS
      journaling file systems, reverse-mapping enhancements to the
      virtual memory subsystem, inclusion of kernel support for the New
      Generation Posix Threads library, better support for NUMA,
      expansion to new architectures including AMD's x86-64 and Power
      PC 64 bit, rewrites of the device driver model, serial drivers,
      ACPI, IDE, the kernel building system, asynchronous I/O and the
      block device layer.

      For seminar details and registration information see:

      http://cpd.ogi.edu/

      go to   Public Seminars
             10/1/2002 Linux Kernel 2.6: New Features-I
        or   10/15/2002 Linux Kernel 2.6: New Features-II

      >>>>> Dr. Cooperstein will be in Beaverton to teach the
            five-day "Linux Kernel Internals" course, Sept. 30 -
            Oct. 4 at Axian.
            See http://www2.axian.com/training/course_calendar.php4
            and contact Kay Norin at kayn at axian.com for information.

From DVHoward at teleport.com  Sat Oct 12 01:37:03 2002
From: DVHoward at teleport.com (Douglas)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 01:37:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Null Modem
References: <1034322097.6526.10.camel@moochercrew.org>
Message-ID: <004001c271ca$8d84fa70$933c1ad8@k61800DVH>

Check out these HOWTOs
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Serial-HOWTO.html#toc18 
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Remote-Serial-Console-HOWTO/ 

Be aware that you may be trying out too many new unknowns all at once.
You could use a Linux box with two serial ports connected with a cable.
Have a minicom talking to each port. Then with two windows on the 
screen, type into one minicom, and see it received in the other minicom
in the other window.  Then you will know if you have your cables working
properly.
Then attach it to the Sun box.
You will also need the pinout of the Sun serial port.
Google is your friend here.




From sum at geekhouse.org  Sat Oct 12 08:22:29 2002
From: sum at geekhouse.org (Sum Wu)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 08:22:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Null Modem
In-Reply-To: <004001c271ca$8d84fa70$933c1ad8@k61800DVH> from "Douglas" at Oct 12, 2002 01:37:03 AM
Message-ID: <200210121522.g9CFMTf11651@yume.wella.org>

You only need regular modem cable... nothing special about it... and on
Minicom it will always say you are not connected even though you are
connected to a Sun... Make sure you are connected to the "Serial A"
port on a Sun.  Here is a config file for Minicom... save it as
"/etc/minirc.sun" and type "minicom -s sun" .... you are good to go!!!

############################################
# minirc.sun
# adjust your serial location as needed
############################################
pr port             /dev/ttyS0
pu baudrate         9600
pu minit            
pu mreset           
pu mdialpre         
pu mdialsuf         
pu mdialpre2        
pu mdialsuf2        
pu mdialpre3        
pu mdialsuf3        
pu mhangup          
pu mdialcan         
pu rtscts           No 
############################################

-- Sum
Solaris Freak


> Check out these HOWTOs
> http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Serial-HOWTO.html#toc18 
> http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Remote-Serial-Console-HOWTO/ 
> 
> Be aware that you may be trying out too many new unknowns all at once.
> You could use a Linux box with two serial ports connected with a cable.
> Have a minicom talking to each port. Then with two windows on the 
> screen, type into one minicom, and see it received in the other minicom
> in the other window.  Then you will know if you have your cables working
> properly.
> Then attach it to the Sun box.
> You will also need the pinout of the Sun serial port.
> Google is your friend here.
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 




From mike at computer-arts.net  Sat Oct 12 13:09:08 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 13:09:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Threading of messages
Message-ID: <3DA88164.8B170342@computer-arts.net>

Some people use this list via email, and some use it as a 
newsgroup. It appears that, if you use it via mail, the string
[PLUG] is prepended to the message. But [PLUG] is not prepended
if you post via NNTP.

If I'm understanding correctly, this results in two separate
"threads" (at least as parsed by my news reader) when people
respond both via mail and NNTP.

I post with NNTP, but in this post I have prepended the string
[PLUG] by hand. So, will this result in only a single "thread?"

-Mike


From sandy at herring.org  Sat Oct 12 13:26:13 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 13:26:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Threading of messages
In-Reply-To: <3DA88164.8B170342@computer-arts.net>; from mike@computer-arts.net on Sat, Oct 12, 2002 at 01:09:08PM -0700
References: <3DA88164.8B170342@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <20021012132613.B11258@kippered.herring.org>

On Sat, 12 Oct 2002, Mike Witt wrote: 
> Some people use this list via email, and some use it as a 
> newsgroup. It appears that, if you use it via mail, the string
> [PLUG] is prepended to the message. But [PLUG] is not prepended
> if you post via NNTP.
> 
> If I'm understanding correctly, this results in two separate
> "threads" (at least as parsed by my news reader) when people
> respond both via mail and NNTP.
> 
> I post with NNTP, but in this post I have prepended the string
> [PLUG] by hand. So, will this result in only a single "thread?"
> 
> -Mike

That depends upon how you (or your newsreader/MUA in particular) define
"thread". Mine (slrn and mutt) thread by References: rather than by Subject:
- which is a far better way to correlate, especially when someone alters the
subject.

Sandy

From sum at geekhouse.org  Sat Oct 12 17:23:53 2002
From: sum at geekhouse.org (Sum Wu)
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 17:23:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Null Modem
In-Reply-To: <200210121522.g9CFMTf11651@yume.wella.org> from "Sum Wu" at Oct 12, 2002 08:22:29 AM
Message-ID: <200210130023.g9D0Nrj12602@yume.wella.org>

Doh... I mean regular null modem cable will do :(... Double Doh!!
                      ^^^^

-- Sum

> You only need regular modem cable... nothing special about it... and on
> Minicom it will always say you are not connected even though you are
> connected to a Sun... Make sure you are connected to the "Serial A"
> port on a Sun.  Here is a config file for Minicom... save it as
> "/etc/minirc.sun" and type "minicom -s sun" .... you are good to go!!!
> 
> ############################################
> # minirc.sun
> # adjust your serial location as needed
> ############################################
> pr port             /dev/ttyS0
> pu baudrate         9600
> pu minit            
> pu mreset           
> pu mdialpre         
> pu mdialsuf         
> pu mdialpre2        
> pu mdialsuf2        
> pu mdialpre3        
> pu mdialsuf3        
> pu mhangup          
> pu mdialcan         
> pu rtscts           No 
> ############################################
> 
> -- Sum
> Solaris Freak

From judah at opusnet.com  Sun Oct 13 08:17:15 2002
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: 13 Oct 2002 08:17:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla and Flash Player
In-Reply-To: <1034467286.1953.5.camel@linux>
References: <20021011072528.GB418@nellump.net>
	<200210111439.g9BEdT210214@tinman.seitzassoc.com> 
	<20021012143429.A11674@kippered.herring.org> 
	<1034467286.1953.5.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <1034522237.19203.470.camel@laptop>

On Sat, 2002-10-12 at 17:01, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> Two questions.  Firs, how do I find what version of the flash player I
> have installed? 

In your location bar enter  about:plugins  
or 
Choose Help -> About Plug-ins  from the menu


 I'm using Mozilla on my system and a couple of flash
> games don't work on my linux machine.
> 
> Second, if I have an older version, how do I upgrade.  

Similarly as you would with netscape. Just substitute Mozilla like
replacements.

/usr/lib/mozilla-1.0.1/plugins

copy your new flash files into that directory. Your Mozilla version may
vary.

A-

-- 
----
Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun Oct 13 13:17:23 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 13:17:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla and Flash Player
In-Reply-To: <3DA8D1D3.3050603@anarchysoftware.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210131029570.13987-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> One nice feature of Mozilla is the ability to block images (ads) on a by
> server basis. This doesn't help with flash ads, which I am seeing more
> and more of. Is there a way to block flash content on a by server basis?

I looked into this a few days ago and found several solutions. One
approach is to use "jFlashmanager" [3] a java program that automates
turning flash on and off. You could also use a web proxy like privoxy [1],
or a bookmarklet that suppresses flash and iframes [2]. The approach I'm
taking is to block flash ad servers in my /etc/hosts file [4].


1. http://www.privoxy.org/

"Privoxy is a web proxy with advanced filtering capabilities for
 protecting privacy, filtering web page content, managing cookies,
 controlling access, and removing ads, banners, pop-ups and other
 obnoxious Internet junk... Privoxy has application for both
 stand-alone systems and multi-user networks."

 License: GNU GPL

2. http://www.squarefree.com/bookmarklets/zap.html

 "Removes java, flash, background music, and iframes from a page. (The
 HTML tags removed are object, embed, applet, and iframe.)"

 License: Free

3. http://www.jtedley.com./jtflashmanager/index.php

 "jTFlashManager gives you the capability to turn Flash on and off for all
of your browsers. "

License: Free

4. http://slack.net/~ads/

"You can put the list of servers above in your proxy machine's
/etc/hosts file and conveniently block ads for all your users. This
will also save you lots of bandwidth and help protect your users'
privacy. "

----------------

HTH,

Tyler

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Oct 13 20:54:37 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 20:54:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <1034564423.3910.0.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210132052550.5528-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 13 Oct 2002, eric wrote:
> when running the ./configure command for the oggtst source, the process
> runs well until I get the message: "configure: error: Cannot find
> ao/ao.h".  I have libao installed.

You probably have the dynamic library, but not the headers appropriate to
compile against the library.  This is one of the lame things about trying
to compile software on a binary distribution.

Perhaps you should check to see if your package repository contains a
libao development package, as opposed to a straight libao binary library
package.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sun Oct 13 21:02:23 2002

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Oct 13 21:13:07 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 21:13:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
References: <1034564423.3910.0.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3DAA4453.8070307@dimstar.net>

eric wrote:

>checking for ao/ao.h... no 
>configure: error: Cannot find ao/ao.h 
>
>Has anyone ran into this problem?  I'm using Redhat 8.0 and have tried
>all the included versions of automake.  Thanks in advance. 
>

Install the "devel" package that goes with the libao package. I don't

I concur with Jeme. You have the library, but not the headers. The

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Oct 13 21:35:18 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 21:35:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OO install
References: <3DAA41CF.2060609@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DAA4986.3080206@pacifier.com>

Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> What does this mean;
> # rpm -Uvh OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
> Preparing...                ########################################### 
> [100%]
> installing package OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3 needs 11Mb on the / filesystem
> 
> and what is the mount point /dev/shm on RedHat 7.3? I've got 440M and 
> it's empty.It says it is a tmpfs. A temp filesystem of 440M?!


It means you don't have 11Mb free on your root partition.
Type,
	$ df -h
to see what you have where.

Re: /dev/shm on RH 7.3, the relevant part of `mount` says
  none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)

probably similar to yours.  (Was surprised when the installer asked a bigger 
swapfile, I already had allocated a generous swap partition).  But I don't 
think this is your problem.  Open Office wants a permanent place to install
itself.

Type,
	$ rpm -qilp OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
you'll see where it wants to plant itself.  If it's /opt, then create a symlink
	$ln -s /home/on/the/range /opt

--
Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Oct 13 21:38:48 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 21:38:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OO install
References: <3DAA41CF.2060609@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DAA4A58.5000609@dimstar.net>

Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> What does this mean;
> # rpm -Uvh OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
> Preparing...                
> ########################################### [100%]
> installing package OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3 needs 11Mb on the / filesystem

That means it's not finding at least 11 megs available on the root ( / ) 
file system. What is the output of 'df'?

> and what is the mount point /dev/shm on RedHat 7.3? I've got 440M and 
> it's empty.It says it is a tmpfs. A temp filesystem of 440M?!

That's the device for the swap file. It's not unusual to have a swap 
partition that's 440 megs. I have a 1 gig swap partition. For no other 
reason than I have a 40 gig drive, and I'd rather not run out of memory. 
Even virtual memory.

Russ






From brucek at kingkon.com  Sun Oct 13 22:23:19 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 22:23:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <3DAA4453.8070307@dimstar.net>; from russj@dimstar.net on Sun, Oct 13, 2002 at 09:13:07PM -0700
References: <1034564423.3910.0.camel@localhost.localdomain> <3DAA4453.8070307@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20021013222319.A7760@defiant.ncplus.net>

Russ Johnson's Log: StarDate 1013.2113:
> eric wrote:
> 
> >checking for ao/ao.h... no 
> >configure: error: Cannot find ao/ao.h 
> >
> >Has anyone ran into this problem?  I'm using Redhat 8.0 and have tried
> >all the included versions of automake.  Thanks in advance. 
> >
> 
> Install the "devel" package that goes with the libao package. I don't 
> have a RH8 system handy, so I can't give you the exact name.
> 
> I concur with Jeme. You have the library, but not the headers. The 
> headers and source come in the devel rpms for that package.

This seems wrong to me. When I see devel in package names, I think of
me doing development work. I don't think of me just installing
software and using it.

I'd expect the devel package to have source for all the parts of the
program. If the headers of the binary libraries are necessary for
installing applications that must be compiled on your system, then why
can't the headers for that binary library be included in the
'non-devel' package; assuming that the headers are not the full
source.

I'm not sure I want full source of every tool on those systems where I
need to compile programs. Since all of my systems are unique (speaking
cpu's here), in order to have optimal compiles, I'd have to have all the
source on all of them; and there isn't necessarily enough disk space on
all the systems for that. As a developer, I'd want full source of only
those tools I'd be developing, or needing to view in order to complete
said development -- and then only on my development system. As a user,
I don't seen a need for any full source -- except those sources that I
choose for educational reasons.

my2sense.
-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Oct 13 23:01:55 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 23:01:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <20021013222319.A7760@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210132246560.6472-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 13 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> This seems wrong to me. When I see devel in package names, I think of
> me doing development work. I don't think of me just installing
> software and using it.

When "devel" is in a package name (nearly always a library package), it
just means the headers are there for compiling software that links against
the library.

It _IS_ super dumb.  I totally agree.  There is absolutely no reason to
equate 
./configure && make test install 
with software development.  I think that probably scares people that it
shouldn't.

> I'd expect the devel package to have source for all the parts of the
> program. If the headers of the binary libraries are necessary for
> installing applications that must be compiled on your system, then why
> can't the headers for that binary library be included in the
> 'non-devel' package; assuming that the headers are not the full
> source.

I'd like an answer to that, too, honestly.

Now, the headers are only required when you are going to compile software
and there is a method of moving binaries between machines and putting them
in the proper locations so that they work well enough to be called
"installed", so technically the headers aren't required to install
applications for which you have precompiled binaries.  But so what?

> I'm not sure I want full source of every tool on those systems where I
> need to compile programs.

The "devel" packages are usually just binary packages with headers, not
source packages.  Yeah, it's totally dumb.  But so is packaged binaries
for fast computers.

> Since all of my systems are unique (speaking cpu's here), in order to
> have optimal compiles, I'd have to have all the source on all of them;
> and there isn't necessarily enough disk space on all the systems for
> that.

Well, there _IS_ such a thing as cross-compiling.  You can build for other
architectures than the one running on your system.

> As a developer, I'd want full source of only those tools I'd be
> developing, or needing to view in order to complete said development
> -- and then only on my development system. As a user, I don't seen a
> need for any full source -- except those sources that I choose for
> educational reasons.

Right, so most package management systems have adopted the following
naming scheme:
(these may be rpm, deb, tgz, whatever)

foo:  The binary executables, libraries, stock
configuration, and (at least minimal) documentation files to use the
application.

foo-devel:  The same as the above, often compiled with debugging symbols
in the binaries, plus the header files for compiling new binaries against
any shared libraries in the package and (hopefully) some extra
documentation.

foo-src:  The full source for the package and documentation, usually
modified with special patches and configuration defaults to make it
compliant with the schemes and ideals of the package maintainer and the
distribution maintainer (rather than the software's official maintainer).

Dig?

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From revans at e-z.net  Sun Oct 13 23:58:33 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 23:58:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard disc re-partition question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021014141944.00b58070@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021014141944.00b58070@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <20021014065812.JJOX28253.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>

To list the partition table on a drive

fdisk -l  -u /dev/harddrive 

I only know of a utility for defragmenting a ext2 filesystem. since Linux has
support and patches for so many file systems you will have to look for
yourself.

You will need to specify what you mean by "safe and easy way". Are you talking
saving the data on the partition and resizing them, a wipe and repartition, or
are you looking for information on something like LVM?

Thank you
Russell

On Sun, 2002-10-13 at 20:54, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On 13 Oct 2002, eric wrote:

> > runs well until I get the message: "configure: error: Cannot find
> > ao/ao.h".  I have libao installed.
> 
> You probably have the dynamic library, but not the headers appropriate to
> compile against the library.  This is one of the lame things about trying
> to compile software on a binary distribution.
> 
> Perhaps you should check to see if your package repository contains a
> libao development package, as opposed to a straight libao binary library
> package.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Oct 14 08:53:59 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 08:53:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard disc re-partition question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021014141944.00b58070@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210140838010.1925-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> 2) What command shall issue to "defragment" the hard disc on Linux

What filesystem are you using? If ext2, defragmenting is not likely to
improve disk performance. This is because ext2 (unlike FAT and NTFS)
guarantees allocation of the closest free block even when contiguous
blocks are unavailable. While the files are still fragmented, the
discontiguous blocks are packed so closely that the effect of
fragmentation is minimal.

"Fragmentation on a typical ext2 disk is usually between zero and three
percent no matter how much file system activity occurs."

http://www.biznix.org/whylinux/windows/fragment.html

"The ext2 filesystem attempts to keep fragmentation at a minimum, by
keeping all blocks in a file close together, even if they can't be stored
in consecutive sectors. Ext2 effectively always allocates the free block
that is nearest to other blocks in a file. For ext2, it is therefore
seldom necessary to worry about fragmentation."

http://www.ecm.auckland.ac.nz/sag/node49.html


Tyler

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 14 10:21:29 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 10:21:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
References: <1034564423.3910.0.camel@localhost.localdomain> <3DAA4453.8070307@dimstar.net> <20021013222319.A7760@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <3DAAFD19.7070400@dimstar.net>

Bruce Kingsland wrote:

>Russ Johnson's Log: StarDate 1013.2113:
>  
>
>>eric wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>checking for ao/ao.h... no 
>>>configure: error: Cannot find ao/ao.h 
>>>
>>>Has anyone ran into this problem?  I'm using Redhat 8.0 and have tried
>>>all the included versions of automake.  Thanks in advance. 
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>Install the "devel" package that goes with the libao package. I don't 
>>have a RH8 system handy, so I can't give you the exact name.
>>
>>I concur with Jeme. You have the library, but not the headers. The 
>>headers and source come in the devel rpms for that package.
>>    
>>
>
>This seems wrong to me. When I see devel in package names, I think of
>me doing development work. I don't think of me just installing
>software and using it.
>

Ah, but you ARE doing development work. You are compiling software from 
source, which is development. You may not be editing the code, but you 
are compiling it. You'll only need those headers if you compile your 
programs. You'll never need them if you always install from a binary RPM.

You are only "installing software and using it" when you never 
"./configure", and always install the binary RPM. Of course, this is 
easier in theory than practice.

>I'd expect the devel package to have source for all the parts of the
>program. If the headers of the binary libraries are necessary for
>installing applications that must be compiled on your system, then why
>can't the headers for that binary library be included in the
>'non-devel' package; assuming that the headers are not the full
>source.
>
They're not required, unless you choose to install and "./configure" 
with the source.

--
Russ Johnson

http://www.dimstar.net

Freesco runs quite well but takes a bit to set up and configure.  But the
great thing about it is it runs off of a floppy.  You edit and configure
the disk image then write it and boot to the floppy.  Have it running on a
P133 just fine, all the moving parts are the floppy and PS fan; CPU
doesn't even have a fan...but the box is quite large.

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 14 10:37:14 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 10:37:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210132246560.6472-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3DAB00CA.1050703@dimstar.net>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>It _IS_ super dumb.  I totally agree.  There is absolutely no reason to
>equate 
>./configure && make test install 
>with software development.  I think that probably scares people that it
>shouldn't.
>
It's not editing the code, but it IS part of the developement process, 
and a vast step beyond what most computer users want to do with their 
computer.

*MOST* users simply want a computer that runs the programs they want, 
without any build environment at all. They just want it to work.

In that case, having the headers on the system would be wasted space, 
and could open up additional security holes.

For you and I, it's not a big deal to open the source tar ball, 
configure, test and install source. For Joe sixpack, he doesn't even 
want to know the capability is there. He doesn't care. He wants his 
computer to run, and that's it.

>Now, the headers are only required when you are going to compile software
>and there is a method of moving binaries between machines and putting them
>in the proper locations so that they work well enough to be called
>"installed", so technically the headers aren't required to install
>applications for which you have precompiled binaries.  But so what?
>
For the vast majority of computer users, there's no need for source, 
compilers, headers or any of this other stuff you and I like so much.

And there's nothing wrong with that. If they don't want to learn how to 
compile a program from source, they don't have to. The binary 
distributions do that for them, and that's what they get paid to do. 
That's also what makes America great. We each have our own choices to 
make. 

>>I'm not sure I want full source of every tool on those systems where I
>>need to compile programs.
>>    
>>
>
>The "devel" packages are usually just binary packages with headers, not
>source packages.  Yeah, it's totally dumb.  But so is packaged binaries
>for fast computers.
>
In your opinion. For you, it probably is dumb. For the guy down the 
street that just wants to pick up his mail, surf, and maybe chat, a 
full-on developement system that can compile anything is dumb. He 
doesn't need it, and doesn't want it.

Other folks have other needs, and what fits your style might be totally inappropriate for others. 

--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Oct 14 10:58:41 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 10:58:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
Message-ID: <3DAB05D0.9B9D45E7@attbi.com>

I'm using the network technique to install Debian on my Thinkpad 390X.
I've gotten to the "Select net modules" part where I'm supposed to
select a driver from a long list. I have a 3Com Model 3CXE589ET, 10 Mbps
PCMCIA card. I find a number of 3c--- drivers listed, but none of them
are specifically the one I have. Does anyone know if the model I have
works with one of these? I looked up the 589 on 3Com's site, but didn't
learn anything useful.

3c501		'EtherLink' support
3c503		'EtherLink II' support
3c505		'EtherLink Plus' support
3c507		'EtherLink 16' support
3c509		'EtherLink III' support
3c515		ISA Fast EtherLink
3c523		'EtherLinkMC' support
3c529-scyld	(No description available)
3c59x		'Vortex/Boomeran [that's all that's on the screen]

Thanks for any help.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Oct 14 11:13:37 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 11:13:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
In-Reply-To: <3DAB05D0.9B9D45E7@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141110170.14552-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I'm using the network technique to install Debian on my Thinkpad
> 390X. I've gotten to the "Select net modules" part where I'm
> supposed to select a driver from a long list. I have a 3Com Model
> 3CXE589ET, 10 Mbps PCMCIA card. I find a number of 3c--- drivers
> listed, but none of them are specifically the one I have. Does
> anyone know if the model I have works with one of these?

My general method for dealing with this sort of issue is to pop 
/proc/pci into less and try to figure out what the kernel sees.

Of course, it'd also be helpful to know what kernel you're installing 
(does Debian still install 2.2 by default/). In the 2.4 series, 
there's a module specifically for 3Com 3c589 PCMCIA support 
(3c589_cs.o).

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> > anyone know if the model I have works with one of these?

> My general method for dealing with this sort of issue is to pop
> /proc/pci into less and try to figure out what the kernel sees.

Not sure how I'd do that before the installation finishes.
 
> Of course, it'd also be helpful to know what kernel you're installing
> (does Debian still install 2.2 by default/). In the 2.4 series,
> there's a module specifically for 3Com 3c589 PCMCIA support
> (3c589_cs.o).

I'm working with the floppies from:

http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/3.0.23-2002-05-21/images-1.44/

It looks like it's 2.2.20, although some files are labeled 2.4.16...

From John at JohnTelford.com  Mon Oct 14 11:44:06 2002
From: John at JohnTelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 11:44:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Router/firewall w/gui distro needed
In-Reply-To: <MWMail.repspsjl@host.none>
References: <MWMail.repspsjl@host.none>
Message-ID: <20021014184406.GC17434@lnx2.labnet>

It would be nice if there were an easy way to set up effective firewall
rules using a command line or GUI.  Unfortunately there isn't.

The user interface isn't the problem.  Getting firewall rules correct is
difficult and error prone.  One must be intimate with how the firewall
processes rules, and understand in detail how IP protocols work.

Then the fun begins.  The firewall and the set of rules need to be
tested.  This step is difficult and requires experience using IP tool
sets.

My experience is the most effective firewall rule that requires the
lease amout of experience to setting up NAT.  This is what most off the
shelf consumer firewalls use by default.

...John


On Mon, Oct 14, 2002 at 07:59:26AM -0700, Dinsdale wrote:
> IPcop is a hearty firewall with a web interface. 
> www.ipcop.org
> 
> I am going to set up a router and firewall box for a Mac using friend of
> mine. He has never/nor ever wants to see a command line. Have any of you
> heard of a good R/F distro that includes an intuitive gui control panel,
> possibly web based? I am tempted to use SME 5.5, but that even seems WAY
> bloated at 300mb. The box will need to do no other work. Thanks mates.
> Theo

From lennon at day-reynolds.com  Mon Oct 14 12:00:49 2002
From: lennon at day-reynolds.com (Lennon Day-Reynolds)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 12:00:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141110170.14552-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <3DAB0BC5.6AD82527@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DAB1461.6010401@day-reynolds.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:

>Paul Heinlein wrote:
>
>  
>
>>>I'm using the network technique to install Debian on my Thinkpad
>>>390X. I've gotten to the "Select net modules" part where I'm
>>>supposed to select a driver from a long list. I have a 3Com Model
>>>3CXE589ET, 10 Mbps PCMCIA card. I find a number of 3c--- drivers
>>>listed, but none of them are specifically the one I have. Does
>>>anyone know if the model I have works with one of these?
>>>      
>>>
>>My general method for dealing with this sort of issue is to pop
>>/proc/pci into less and try to figure out what the kernel sees.
>>
Or even /proc/pcmcia?

>
>Not sure how I'd do that before the installation finishes.
>
IIRC, the Debian install kernel includes /proc filesystem support. You 
should be able to switch to the second virtual console any time after 
the "colorful" portion of the installer starts up, and check from there.

> 
>  
>
>>Of course, it'd also be helpful to know what kernel you're installing
>>(does Debian still install 2.2 by default/). In the 2.4 series,
>>there's a module specifically for 3Com 3c589 PCMCIA support
>>(3c589_cs.o).
>>    
>>
>
>I'm working with the floppies from:
>
>http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/3.0.23-2002-05-21/images-1.44/
>
>It looks like it's 2.2.20, although some files are labeled 2.4.16...
>
>  
>
The default Debian 3.0 install floppies do use 2.2.20, but there's 
another (fairly well-supported) set of disk images available from the 
same mirrors. Look for the 'bf-2.4' directory under 'images-1.44', and 
you should see 'rescue.bin', 'install.bin', and 'drivers-[1-4].bin'. I 
have a ThinkPad 560 which I recently finished a Debian/bf-2.4 install 
on, and the driver for the 3c589-based Farallon network card I have was 
in the standard driver collection.

Plus, if you use the bf-2.4 images, you have the option of using an Ext3 
root partition, which (for me, at least) is a major win. I've spent too 
much time watching fsck slowly fill the screen with a row of equals 
signs, only to stumble over some mess left by an inopportune power 
failure. I also like to live on the "bleeding edge," and the 'unstable' 
tree of Debian has lots of nice 2.4-kernel-specific goodies.

The only issue I've found with a 2.4-based Debian installation is that 
fewer module packages are available as binaries: for example, the 
'thinkpad' modules which tpctl uses to replication most of the Windows 
ThinkPad setup utility's functionality is only available as a source 
package, which is kind of a drag on my 560 (a 133Mhz machine with 40MB 
of RAM).

Good luck,

Lennon Day-Reynolds
lennon at day-reynolds.com




From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Oct 14 12:05:17 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 12:05:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
In-Reply-To: <3DAB0BC5.6AD82527@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141201020.14552-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Not sure how I'd do that before the installation finishes.

I've only done a couple Debian installations, and both have been over
serial consoles, so my memory may not count for much -- but I
*thought* you could get to a shell prompt during the installation. Or
maybe that's only an option after installation and before reboot.

The Red Hat installer gives you a shell on the second virtual terminal 
(Alt + F2), and it wouldn't surprise me at all to see that Debian 
did a similar thing.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org

Subject: Re: [PLUG] Router/firewall w/gui distro needed


Freesco runs quite well but takes a bit to set up and configure.  But
the great thing about it is it runs off of a floppy.  You edit and
configure the disk image then write it and boot to the floppy.  Have it
running on a P133 just fine, all the moving parts are the floppy and PS
fan; CPU doesn't even have a fan...but the box is quite large. 
http://www.freesco.org/

I think I have a pre-configured disk image laying around...

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 14 12:37:29 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 Oct 2002 12:37:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141110170.14552-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141110170.14552-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1034624252.3744.365.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2002-10-14 at 11:13, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
> > I'm using the network technique to install Debian on my Thinkpad
> > 390X. I've gotten to the "Select net modules" part where I'm
> > supposed to select a driver from a long list. I have a 3Com Model
> > 3CXE589ET, 10 Mbps PCMCIA card. I find a number of 3c--- drivers
> > listed, but none of them are specifically the one I have. Does
> > anyone know if the model I have works with one of these?
> 
> My general method for dealing with this sort of issue is to pop 
> /proc/pci into less and try to figure out what the kernel sees.
> 
> Of course, it'd also be helpful to know what kernel you're installing 
> (does Debian still install 2.2 by default/). In the 2.4 series, 
> there's a module specifically for 3Com 3c589 PCMCIA support 
> (3c589_cs.o).

IIRC, the module for your specific card will be detected when PCMCIA is
first configured.  It was a couple of months ago, but it seems like the
install procedure missed the "Configure PCMCIA" step, you just need to
select it from the long list.

I'm pretty sure you don't need to load any "drivers"; in other words,
you can skip the step that loads the modules.  You will know if the
PCMCIA stuff loaded properly if the step after you do the "Configure
PCMCIA" is "Configure Network".  If the "Configure Network" doesn't show
up next, you need to go back to the "Configure PCMCIA" and try again.

I was actually blown away by how simple the installation was for a
laptop.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 14 14:32:51 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 14:32:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the font order
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141429070.16105-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  One of the changes I notice between RH 6.2 and 7.3 is that there is no
longer a user-configurable list of fonts in the fontpath section of
/etc/X11/XF86Config. All it has now is "unix:7100".

  When I run /usr/sbin/chkfontpath I see that the unscaled fonts are on the
top of the heap and this suggests to me the reason why the mozilla fonts (as
evidenced when viewing a Google page) are so terrible.

  How do I alter the order in which the X server sees the fonts? I want to
make the 100 dpi/scaled fonts the default.

TIA,

Rich




From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 14 14:50:59 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 Oct 2002 14:50:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Disk image copy program
In-Reply-To: <3DAB38A8.79BCADD0@attbi.com>
References: <20021014141801.A11024@kudzuforest.com> 
	<3DAB38A8.79BCADD0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1034632259.28785.375.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2002-10-14 at 14:35, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Brendan Miller wrote:
> 
> > I have Windows 2000 on a 40GB drive in my _other_ computer....
> > But as long as it's been installed, I've never used but 4GB,
> > so that drive is going largely to waste.  I have a 9GB drive
> > I'd like to "move" my install to...  The disks are different
> > sizes, so whatever copy occurs can't copy the partition table,
> > 'cause it will be erroneous on the 9GB disk.
> 
> Could you use fdisk to resize the Windows partition? Then, "move" the
> now 9GB partition to the 9GB drive? 

This probably won't work with NTFS.

The best luck I've had with this issue is Norton Ghost.  They make a PE
version that came with the basic "SystemWorks 2000".  The PE version
won't do the network dumps, but can move a partition of one size to a
partition of another size on the local machine.  The drawback is that it
boots to DOS, so SCSI transfers are painfully slow (no drivers).

HTH

Derek Loree





From rzeller at efn.org  Mon Oct 14 15:07:02 2002

From plug at thedrew.net  Mon Oct 14 15:45:54 2002
From: plug at thedrew.net (plug at thedrew.net)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 15:45:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ftp and ssh
Message-ID: <000801c273d3$749216a0$0300a8c0@druidsgiant>

Hey all, I'm hoping someone has had better luck with this than I have. I
installed Redhat 8.0, then downloaded and installed the Pure-FTPd rpm. I
set this up as per the readme and had everything working satisfactorily,
other than the fact that it was plain ftp. (NOTE: I have been unable to
access the pure-ftpd site today, www.pureftpd.org, but google has the
site cached) SO, I tried to setup FTP with SSH. I followed the steps in
the faq, with a few differences. I've copied the pertinent faq section
below. I attempted to create a user of type 2, (encrypted access only)
but had to slightly modify the commands he used.

He used:
	useradd -u ftpuser -g ftpgroup -d /dev/null -s /usr/bin/false
customer2

I used
	useradd -u 600 -g 501 -d /dev/null -s /bin/false drewftp
He used:
	pure-pw useradd customer2 -m -d /home/customer2 -u ftpuser -r
127.0.0.1/32
I used:
	pure-pw useradd drewftp -m -d /home/customer2 -u 600 -g 501 -r
127.0.0.1/32

SO, now when I try to connect to the server over ssh using SecureFX
(http://www.vandyke.com/download/securefx/index.html) I get password
authentication failed while trying to use the drewftp user. However, I
can connect just fine using a regular user that I setup over regular ftp
(no ssh). Here's what SecureFX said:

* FTP over SSH.

-> How to run Pure-FTPd over SSH? I want to encrypt all connection data
(including passwords) .

FTP-over-SSH is a nice alternative over FTP-over-SSL (impossible to
securely
firewall) and SFTP (which is slower, but only uses one port) .

Customers using Windows can use FTP-over-SSH with the excellent Van
Dyke's
SecureFX client (http://www.vandyke.com) . It doesn't require any
special
knowledge : just tell your customer to check "FTP-over-SSH2" in the
"Protocol" listbox when creating an account for your FTP server.

On the server side, here's how to manage FTP-over-SSH accounts :

1) Add /usr/bin/false to your /etc/shells file (on some systems, it's
/bin/false) .

2) To create a FTP-over-SSH account, create a system account with
/dev/null
as a home directory, and /usr/bin/false as a shell. You don't need a
dedicated uid : the same uid can be reused for every FTP-over-SSH
account.

3) Create a virtual user account for that user (either with PureDB, SQL
or
LDAP) . Give that virtual user a real home directory, and only allow
connections coming from 127.0.0.1 (all FTP-over-SSH sessions will come
from
localhost, due to SSH tunneling) .

People with no home directory (/dev/null) and no valid shell
(/usr/bin/false) won't be able to get a shell nor to run any command on
your
server. But they will be granted FTP-over-SSH sessions.

Here are examples (Linux/OpenBSD commands, translate them if necessary)
.

1) Creating a regular FTP account :

pure-pw useradd customer1 -m -d /home/customer1 -u ftpuser

2) Creating a FTP-over-SSH account (non-encrypted sessions are denied) :

useradd -u ftpuser -g ftpgroup -d /dev/null -s /usr/bin/false customer2
pure-pw useradd customer2 -m -d /home/customer2 -u ftpuser -r
127.0.0.1/32

3) Creating an account who can use regular (unencrypted) FTP from the
internal network (192.168.1.x), but who must use FTP-over-SSH when
coming
from an external network (internet) :

useradd -u ftpuser -g ftpgroup -d /dev/null -s /usr/bin/false customer3
pure-pw useradd customer3 -m -d /home/customer3 -u ftpuser \
        -r 127.0.0.1/32,192.168.1.0/24



* Virtual users : /etc/pureftpd.pdb .

-> I made changes to /etc/pureftpd.passwd but the server doesn't
understand
them : I can't access any account I just created.

The server never reads /etc/pureftpd.passwd directly. Instead, it reads
/etc/pureftpd.pdb (or whatever file name you gave after -lpuredb:....) .

This file is a copy of /etc/pureftpd.passwd, but in a binary format,
optimized for fast lookups.

After having made a manual change to /etc/pureftpd.passwd, you must
rebuild
/etc/pureftpd.pdb with the following commands :

pure-pw mkdb

If you add/delete/modify user accounts with pure-pw
useradd/usermod/userdel/
passwd, don't forget the '-m' option to automatically rebuild
/etc/pureftpd.pdb and not only update /etc/pureftpd.passwd .






From rzeller at efn.org  Mon Oct 14 15:49:58 2002
From: rzeller at efn.org (Ralph Zeller)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 15:49:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the font order
In-Reply-To: <3DAB4547.8000204@pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210141429070.16105-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <20021014220702.GA6025@zellercpa.com> <3DAB4547.8000204@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20021014224958.GA9751@zellercpa.com>

On (10/14/02 15:29), Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Ralph Zeller wrote:
> >vim /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fs/config
> 
> 
> There's also /etc/X11/fs/config
> They are the same size and date on my system (not symlinked either).  Dunno 
> why there needs to be two.  Will the real config please stand up?
> 
> --
> Kyle Accardi

Oops, I gave a symlink.  /etc/X11/fs/config is the real file, and the other
is symlinked at fs: 

$ls /usr/X11R6/lib/X11 -l |grep fs
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           22 May 19 11:24 fs -> ../../../../etc/X11/fs

At any rate, you can usually tell where any file came from with: 
'rpm -q --whatprovides /my/file' but it's funny that 
'rpm -q --whatprovides /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fs/config' reports XFree86-xfs-4.2.0-8
but rpm -ql XFree86-xfs-4.2.0-8 reports /etc/X11/fs/config

Ralph



From m at netpro.to  Mon Oct 14 15:55:33 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 15:55:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the font order
In-Reply-To: <3DAB4547.8000204@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210141555030.12585-100000@lukem.com>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Ralph Zeller wrote:
> > vim /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fs/config
>
>
> There's also /etc/X11/fs/config
> They are the same size and date on my system (not symlinked either).  Dunno
> why there needs to be two.  Will the real config please stand up?

They're hardlinks.  Do an ls -li on each file and you'll see they have the
same inode number.
~M

From yrn4dsl at attbi.com  Mon Oct 14 17:07:42 2002
From: yrn4dsl at attbi.com (david)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 17:07:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up PostgreSQL on RedHat
In-Reply-To: <20021014204039.GE24821@dalsemi.com>
References: <20021014204039.GE24821@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <20021014170742.006cb7bf.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002 13:40:39 -0700
Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com> wrote:

> When I set up MySQL on my Red Hat server, I was shown by a frien who
> was knowledgeable in MySQL how to go in and change the root account
> from the default that was shipped with the distribution.
> 
> Now I'd like to install PostgreSQL, and my friend has never used it,
> and the docs talk about multiple methods of authenticating people
> trying to use the database.  Files, various tables, etc.
> 
> Can someone give me, in a nutshell, what I need to do to change all
> default passwords and accounts related to PostgreSQL on Red Hat
> so I don't leave any backdoors?
> 
> Thanks,
> Colin
> 

I've only installed Postgres on FreeBSD, but here's my $.02

The default install doesn't allow remote connections. Most of the connection and authentication settings are in data/pg_hba.conf or data/postgresql.conf relative to the postgresql user's home directory. FreeBSD sets up the user pgsql by default under the directory /usr/local/pgsql. My guess is that RedHat isn't far off. The docs at http://www.postgresql.org/idocs/index.php?installation.html may help.

Good luck.

> without any build environment at all. They just want it to work.

You're right Russ, it's just that a lot of times (as in the case of the
"oggtst" code which started this discussion) there isn't an rpm readily
available, forcing novice users like myself to delve deeper even though
they just want things to work out of the box.  I'm thinking about
devoting some time to understanding RPM-building so that I can package
for other novices readily installable rpms for certain really useful
applications on the distros I'm using.  Redhat is to blame for this
particular problem, because they dropped mpg support in RH 8.0, but
failed to more completely support an replacement media-type (ogg-vorbis
being the obvious candidate).

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Mon Oct 14 20:59:30 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 20:59:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA Driver for Debian Install
References: <3DAB05D0.9B9D45E7@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <00a401c273ff$43b9cce0$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

I've been attempting to upgrade the kernel on my laptop running woody for
about a week and I keep losing my ethernet card every time.  Finally, with
the (infinite) help (and patience) of another list user, I got it solved.

# apt-get install pcmcia-source

This put pcmcia-cs.tar.gz in my /usr/src/ directory.  Untarred it, went into
the new directory (/usr/src/modules/pcmcia-cs) and, of course, read the
README file.  Which told me to :

# make configure
# make all
# make install

When I rebooted the system, my ethernet card started blinking again.  This
was a 2.2.20 -> 2.2.21 upgrade.  The 2.4.19 attempt failed miserably, so I'm
taking baby steps...

Hope that helps.  If not you, then someone else with a Netgear FA511 card
and a laptop.

t

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 14 22:47:24 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 22:47:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210132246560.6472-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> 	<3DAB00CA.1050703@dimstar.net> <1034651419.28145.31.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3DABABEC.7030407@dimstar.net>

su -Eric Jahn wrote:

> 
>  
>
>>*MOST* users simply want a computer that runs the programs they want, 
>>without any build environment at all. They just want it to work.
>>    
>>
>
>You're right Russ, it's just that a lot of times (as in the case of the
>"oggtst" code which started this discussion) there isn't an rpm readily
>available, forcing novice users like myself to delve deeper even though
>they just want things to work out of the box.
>
And that's just ONE of the reasons that linux isn't quite ready for the 
masses.

Of course, there are two ways to think of this. One, the user that 
doesn't know how (or care to) compile his own programs probably doesn't 
need to be running that bleeding edge piece of software that's on 
version 0.04, or two, the package maintainers need to realize that not 
everyone knows how, or cares to know how, to roll their own, and they 
should provide the packages if they can. Otherwise, it's up to the 
distributions to do it, and they may not package it the way the 
maintainer wishes. There's a whole slew of reasons...

>I'm thinking about
>devoting some time to understanding RPM-building so that I can package
>for other novices readily installable rpms for certain really useful
>applications on the distros I'm using.
>
Check to see if some people are already doing this. In many cases, the 
maintainers of a package will readily accept help and put the packages 
up with the rest of their stuff.

>  Redhat is to blame for this
>particular problem, because they dropped mpg support in RH 8.0, but
>failed to more completely support an replacement media-type (ogg-vorbis
>being the obvious candidate).
>
Yeah. Damn patent holders. Redhat was stuck between a rock and a hard 
place. Being THE major distribution in North America, they are the 
obvious first target. I'm sure they couldn't afford to be sued over 
licensing fees for mp3 decoders. From what I understand, the fee is 
$.75, per decoder, wether it's sold or given away. So each ISO image, 
times the number of mp3 decoders, and you have a hefty chuck of change. 
I probably would have done the same thing given the same circumstances.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Developers:

My client is moving GUIs Xcommand, QCommand and Reo Voice Command to Sun
Netbeans specification.

Their environment for development is Sun Solaris with Forte Java IDE. They
use Mercury Loadrunner and Winrunner for QA, CVS and Bugzilla for code
Management. They use a form of Unified Process which is a variation of RUP
called XUP. They
must be familiar with Rational Unified Process.

Java People. MUST have extensive Swing experience preferably with Sun Open
Office, Netbeans and Forte Experience as well as Solaris and Linux
experience, to include CVS, Bugzilla and UML.

Software Assurance Engineer:

Must have extensive experience in Mercury Products including Winrunner for
GUIs and Loadrunner for load testing.
Must have Unix and Linux experience as well as CVS and Bugzilla.

These positions are based in Dallas and anyone interested may reach me at
the contact information below.

Sincerely,

Subject: [PLUG] ATT Cable Internet
Message-ID: <7B2F6EA5E35E214882CB9828962BC3CF01D82519@corvallis.summit.fiserv.com>

Hi all.

I just got ATT Cable installed yesterday and am building a box to use with
it right now. My question , and I hope some of you who have already done
this will know, is that in order to get the box I want to use as my gateway
installed I have been told that I need to "register the MAC address" in
order to get DHCP working. The guy who installed it, he was very good about
sharing what knowledge he had, gave me a account number, registration code,
and a web site https://sas.r1.attbi.com to "register the MAC address" with.
(Note the parts in quotes are his words) So my question is I have to
register the MAC address to get an address and DNS info. I have to have an
address and DNS info to register a MAC address. So how do I do this? I do
have access to a Win2k laptop if that would help. Also if I ever swap out
the device, for example later I want to go wireless, how would one do this?
Here is hoping that one of you all have been through this. Any help would be
much appreciated. Thanks.

References: <20021011072528.GB418@nellump.net> <200210111439.g9BEdT210214@tinman.seitzassoc.com> <20021012143429.A11674@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <20021015174600.GC737@nellump.net>

On Sat, Oct 12, 2002 at 02:34:29PM -0700, Sandy Herring wrote:
> 
> I've seen a similar symptom when the kernel catches an NMI during the boot.
> Try disabling them on the command line and see if the system boots.

Sounds like an interesting lead. Too bad I don't know where to begin.
:-)  Google searching for "kernel disable nmi command line" doesn't
bring up anything helpful. Any leads?


Paul (off to dig through the kernel source...)




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Oct 15 10:48:20 2002

I just called Bridgeport.  Here's the data.
                   
                50-100    100-200  guests
11/15 Friday     $650      $850
11/16 Saturday   available till 4PM, already booked for the evening
11/17 Sunday     $500      $650
11/18 Monday     $350      $500

It is possible for non-profits to get a discount, but the reservation
has to be made well in advance (3-4 months).

BTW, if you think this is expensive, you obviously haven't gotten married
recently.  :-)

From mikeraz at patch.com  Tue Oct 15 11:11:27 2002

Hello, 

The page http://www.trans.ci.portland.or.us/bicycles/default.htm only renders on
Microsoft browsers.  Partly this is due to some coding issues as demonstrated by
this feedback from the World Wide Web Consortium  HTML validator at http://validator.w3.org/

 Below are the results of attempting to parse this document with an SGML parser.

    * Line 4, column 16:

  <HTML xmlns:mso="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" xmlns:msdt=" ...
                  ^

      Error: there is no attribute "XMLNS
    * Line 4, column 35:

  ... soft-com:office:office" xmlns:msdt="uuid:C2F41010-65B3-11d1- ...
                                         ^

      Error: there is no attribute "XMLNS


I would like to view the department's web pages without being required to purchase
Microsoft products.  Other Transportation department web pages render fine on non-Microsoft
platforms, please make the bicycle page(s) compatible also.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Oct 15 11:25:32 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 11:25:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ATT Cable Internet
References: <7B2F6EA5E35E214882CB9828962BC3CF01D82519@corvallis.summit.fiserv.com>
Message-ID: <3DAC5D9C.107@sun.com>

FYI - this get discussed about once a month.  See here 
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/  for the archives.  Karl 
mentioned there was a search function, but I can't seem to find it at 
the moment.

That said, when I had ATT Broadband (we're in the middle of a move), I 
didn't have to go to said site to hook up a different machine to the 
modem.  As soon as the tech left, I unplugged the cord from the laptop, 
plugged it into the open port on my firewall, and after a couple of 
hours of tweaking scripts and such, it was up and running.

YMMV.

-R

Percival, Ray wrote:
> Hi all.
>

> it right now. My question , and I hope some of you who have already done
> this will know, is that in order to get the box I want to use as my gateway
> installed I have been told that I need to "register the MAC address" in
> order to get DHCP working. The guy who installed it, he was very good about
> sharing what knowledge he had, gave me a account number, registration code,
> and a web site https://sas.r1.attbi.com to "register the MAC address" with.
> (Note the parts in quotes are his words) So my question is I have to
> register the MAC address to get an address and DNS info. I have to have an
> address and DNS info to register a MAC address. So how do I do this? I do

>  >

>>  group that wants to eat and drink and round table? We'd need to be able
>>  to do all three. As far as numbers think 200 or so.
>
>Is this going to be yet another Survival of the Loudest, or will people who
>are not pushy and obnoxious get a chance to get a word in? Quiet people with
>manners often know one or two things worthy of sharing. I'd like to support
>the event, but not if it's another typical geekfest where the annoying ones
>dominate.


	I'd like to chime in as the (lone?) "voice of dissension", 
vis-a-vis the location. ...

	Everyone seems to naturally gravitate toward some McMenamins 
property. This is understandable, given the LARGE number of these 
places all over Portland. I have always been enamored with the raw 
creativity in each one, with respect to preservation of the original 
building architecture, etc., and these places have certainly achieved 
a cult following.
	However, the food and service at ANY McMenamins just BLOWS. 
Why people keep going to a place that is ONLY about atmosphere is 
strange to me. These places are PUBS and restaurants, and the food is 
pedestrian, at best!
  	Paradoxically, some people DO find the food and service 
adequate. However, I consider this one of the essential mysteries of 
the universe. ... Though I suppose that if someone is nostalgic for 
the feeling of being so stoned that you don't care about the quality 
of the food you eat, then any McMenamins could well be an acceptable 
choice.    ;-)

	I, obviously, vote for Bridgeport.

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Tue Oct 15 12:11:33 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 12:11:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] issues with city bicycle page
In-Reply-To: <20021015111127.A21630@patch.com>
References: <20021015111127.A21630@patch.com>
Message-ID: <p05100311b9d2175997dd@[192.168.3.1]>

At 11:11 AM -0700 10/15/02, mikeraz at patch.com wrote:
>
>The page http://www.trans.ci.portland.or.us/bicycles/default.htm 
>only renders on
>Microsoft browsers.  Partly this is due to some coding issues as 
>demonstrated by
>this feedback from the World Wide Web Consortium  HTML validator at 
>http://validator.w3.org/
>
>  Below are the results of attempting to parse this document with an 
>SGML parser.
>
>     * Line 4, column 16:
>
>   <HTML xmlns:mso="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" xmlns:msdt=" ...
>                  ^
>       Error: there is no attribute "XMLNS
>     * Line 4, column 35:
>
>   ... soft-com:office:office" xmlns:msdt="uuid:C2F41010-65B3-11d1- ...
>                                          ^
>       Error: there is no attribute "XMLNS



	These errors and code snippets would indicate that this 
"HTML" was created by "exporting" some MS document to HTML. Microsoft 
LOVES to "export" almost anything as HTML, and they tend to use XML 
code in the result.
	In addition, any MS "exported" data nearly always contains MS 
"hooks" to MS products. (e.g. MS Word document, exported to HTML, 
would likely contain FrontPage or Access "hooks".) This is what you 
are seeing.





>I would like to view the department's web pages without being 
>required to purchase
>Microsoft products.  Other Transportation department web pages 
>render fine on non-Microsoft
>platforms, please make the bicycle page(s) compatible also.



	You don't have to "purchase" MS Internet Explorer, which is 
why this browser now (statistically) accounts for roughly 90% of the 
browser market. The current "trend" is for (so called) Web developers 
to only code for MSIE. Sad, but true.

	... One of the many reasons why I can't WAIT to leave this 
(Web development) industry.    :-(





Patrick Beart

From brmiller at kudzuforest.com  Tue Oct 15 12:17:27 2002
From: brmiller at kudzuforest.com (Brendan Miller)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 12:17:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Disk image copy program
In-Reply-To: <1034632259.28785.375.camel@dereklinux>; from derek@infotects.com on Mon, Oct 14, 2002 at 02:50:59PM -0700
References: <20021014141801.A11024@kudzuforest.com> <3DAB38A8.79BCADD0@attbi.com> <1034632259.28785.375.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <20021015121727.A15896@kudzuforest.com>

Update:

I originally wrote:

> > > Windows 2000, 40GB drive, 9GB drive...
> > > I'd like to "move" my install from the 40GB to the 9GB...

Derek Loree wrote:

> The best luck I've had with this issue is Norton Ghost.  They make a PE
> version that came with the basic "SystemWorks 2000".  The PE version
> won't do the network dumps, but can move a partition of one size to a
> partition of another size on the local machine.  The drawback is that it
> boots to DOS, so SCSI transfers are painfully slow (no drivers).

This worked beautifully (by the third or so attempt when I fixed my own 
mistakes).

Here's what I did (for the archives):

1) "Pretend" to install Windows 2000 on the target disk:

   a) Boot off the Windows 2000 Professional CDROM.
   b) Tell it you want to do a fresh install.
   c) Choose the target drive.
   d) Create the partition, format NTFS.
   e) Let it copy files.

2) Use GHOST to copy from source (working Windows install to transfer) to
   target:

   a) After the initial file copy in (1e), the installer will reboot.  
      Intercept this reboot and boot from GHOST DOS boot floppy.
   b) Start GHOST.  Copy from Windows 2000 partition on source disk to 
      freshly-created, partially installed (from 1e) Windows 2000 partition 
      on target disk.
   
3) Reboot.

That's all it took.

Brendan



From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Oct 15 12:17:02 2002

Subject: [PLUG] issues with city bicycle page
Message-ID: <EX-20021015-142015-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

  I have a pdf file (one page) that allows us peasants to fill in the
blanks, but not save the filled-in form. Today, it won't print. Neither
directly to the printer nor from a postscript file written to disk. A couple
of weeks ago, it worked just fine.

  When I try printing, the printer's LEDs flash, "processing job", then it
stops processing after a few seconds and returns to comatose mode. Same
thing when I try to print the file from disk.

  Very strange and hasn't happened to me before. This is
Acroread-5.something. Has anyone seen this happen before?

  I have the postscript file if someone could discern the problem from
looking at it.

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Oct 15 12:54:18 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 12:54:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PC Reboots As Kernel Loads
In-Reply-To: <20021015174600.GC737@nellump.net>; from pem@nellump.net on Tue, Oct 15, 2002 at 10:46:00AM -0700
References: <20021011072528.GB418@nellump.net> <200210111439.g9BEdT210214@tinman.seitzassoc.com> <20021012143429.A11674@kippered.herring.org> <20021015174600.GC737@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <20021015125418.A18676@kippered.herring.org>

On Tue, 15 Oct 2002, Paul Mullen wrote: 
> On Sat, Oct 12, 2002 at 02:34:29PM -0700, Sandy Herring wrote:
> > 
> > I've seen a similar symptom when the kernel catches an NMI during the boot.
> > Try disabling them on the command line and see if the system boots.
> 
> Sounds like an interesting lead. Too bad I don't know where to begin.
> :-)  Google searching for "kernel disable nmi command line" doesn't
> bring up anything helpful. Any leads?
> 
> 
> Paul (off to dig through the kernel source...)

You didn't specify which bootloader you're using. If you use lilo, at the
boot prompt do...

    linux nmi_watchdog=0

In grub, use the command line interface to add...

    nmi_watchdog=0

...to your kernel line.

If that works, then for lilo you can add...

    append="nmi_watchdog=0"

...to the stanza in lilo.conf for your kernel du jour and then rerurn lilo.
This will take care of future boots so that you don't need to specify it on
the command line during boot. 

In grub, you'd add...

    nmi_watchdog=0

...to your kernel specification in grub.conf. e.g.,

    kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.18-5smp ro root=/dev/hde3 noapic nmi_watchdog=0
    (ymmv)

See Documentation/nmi_watchdog.txt in your kernel source tree for more info
about NMIs.

hth,
Sandy
-- 
Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/

->http://herring.org/techie.html  |/\__/     http://herring.org/pub-key.asc

<soapbox>
  I hate it when stuff is advertised or otherwise promoted as "free" 
  when it's really just included with purchase price, e.g., the 
  so-called Free Continental Breakfast at hotels.

  Stuff is only free of cost when no other purchase is necessary to 
  get and/or use it (as even that sort of free, as Jeme will no doubt 
  point out, isn't necessarily anywhere close to Free :-).
</soapbox>

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rtyler at marverde.net  Tue Oct 15 10:47:24 2002

I believe it's actually the mac address of the cable modem itself that
needs to be registered.
I did the following:
- Plugged a win xp box into the cable modem directly
- Ran the disk they give you
- tested the connection etc.
- unplugged that box & plugged in my open bsd router, hub etc
& it all worked fine

Enjoy,
Ryan
