From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Oct 15 14:38:48 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 14:38:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring a CD Burner
Message-ID: <3DAC8AE8.39201C17@attbi.com>

On my RH 7.0 machine, I have an HP 7200 series CD burner. I've never
used it for burning CDs. It works fine for reading, but when I try to
use cdrecord, I discover from the man page that I need a SCSI device. I
note that this can be a virtual device and that somehow I can load a
driver and map it. 

I've tried reading the HOWTO at:

http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/CD-Writing-HOWTO.html

It only makes partial sense to me. I tried running the scripts in the
Quickstart section, but didn't learn anything useful. Can anyone
recommend another source of information on how to configure an IDE CD
burner?

(I did figure out how to prepare the data with mkisofs.)

Thanks.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From plug at magnetinternet.com  Tue Oct 15 14:52:00 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 14:52:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring a CD Burner
In-Reply-To: <3DAC8AE8.39201C17@attbi.com>
References: <3DAC8AE8.39201C17@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1146.66.93.41.102.1034718720.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Put this in lilo.conf:

append="hdb=ide-scsi"

in the proper section for the currently booting kernel.  Substitute your
CD-R device name instead of hdb (probably hdc or hdd in a typical setup). 
Run lilo -v.  If you're not running lilo, I dunno anything about grub. 
Someone around here probably does.
You have to load the module, or if you're lucky it's in the kernel,  for
ATAPI ide-scsi emulation (called ide-scsi).  You also need SCSI support
and SCSI generic support modules or built into the kernel.  This should
get you going in the right direction.  I had it up after a few failed
attempts (and kernel recompiles).

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

[rstef at NEC /dev]$ ls -l cdrom
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root            3 Mar  3  2001 cdrom -> hdc 

Here is my lilo.conf:
[rstef at NEC /etc]$ cat lilo.conf
boot=/dev/hda
map=/boot/map
install=/boot/boot.b
prompt
timeout=50
message=/boot/message
linear
default=linux

image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.2.16-22
        label=linux
        read-only
        root=/dev/hda1

Should I put append="hdc=ide-scsi" right after the block that says
image= so that it would look like:

boot=/dev/hda
map=/boot/map
install=/boot/boot.b
prompt
timeout=50
message=/boot/message
linear
default=linux

image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.2.16-22
        label=linux
        read-only
        root=/dev/hda1

append="hdc=ide-scsi"



> Run lilo -v.  If you're not running lilo, I dunno anything about grub.
> Someone around here probably does.

Lilo is what I'm running.

> You have to load the module, or if you're lucky it's in the kernel,  for
> ATAPI ide-scsi emulation (called ide-scsi).  You also need SCSI support
> and SCSI generic support modules or built into the kernel.  This should
> get you going in the right direction.  I had it up after a few failed
> attempts (and kernel recompiles).

Does the following mean that the module is loaded, or that it's
available to be loaded?

[root at NEC /root]# modprobe -l | grep ide-scsi
/lib/modules/2.2.16-22/scsi/ide-scsi.o  

There are a lot of other scsi related lines if I grep on just scsi.

Thanks for the help.

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Tue Oct 15 17:37:37 2002

On Tuesday, Oct 15, 2002, at 16:30 US/Pacific, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Is this the way to know the device?
> [rstef at NEC /dev]$ ls -l cdrom
> lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root            3 Mar  3  2001 cdrom -> hdc

Yeah.  Try to mount it and see.  It could be just a default symlink to hdc.

> Here is my lilo.conf:
> [rstef at NEC /etc]$ cat lilo.conf
> image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.2.16-22
>         label=linux
>         read-only
>         root=/dev/hda1

Yep looks good to me.

> Does the following mean that the module is loaded, or that it's
> available to be loaded?

> [root at NEC /root]# modprobe -l | grep ide-scsi
> /lib/modules/2.2.16-22/scsi/ide-scsi.o

Yep looks like it's loaded, which probably means it loads at boot.  Try
running lilo and rebooting and see what happens.

> running lilo and rebooting and see what happens.

I ran lilo -v and then rebooted. Here's what I get, now.

[root at NEC /root]# cdrecord -scanbus
Cdrecord 1.9 (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2000 J?rg Schilling
cdrecord: No such file or directory. Cannot open SCSI driver.
cdrecord: For possible targets try 'cdrecord -scanbus'. Make sure you
are root.

[root at NEC /root]# cdrecord -dev hdc -scanbus
Cdrecord 1.9 (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2000 J?rg Schilling
scsidev: 'hdc'
devname: 'hdc'
scsibus: -2 target: -2 lun: -2
cdrecord: No such file or directory. Cannot open SCSI driver.
cdrecord: For possible targets try 'cdrecord -scanbus'. Make sure you
are root.

[root at NEC /mnt]# mount /dev/cdrom
mount: /dev/cdrom is not a valid block device  

Also, putting a music CD in no longer works. When I run a music playing
program from the Gnome menu, I get an error message that says the device
is not configured. Must be I need to do something else in addition to
the above stuff.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From plug at maneuveringspeed.com  Tue Oct 15 20:01:53 2002
From: plug at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 20:01:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advosys's spamassassin walkthrough for Postfix (and Anomy) - issue with master.cf
Message-ID: <000f01c274c0$61f3b6a0$e984d38c@Endeavor>


Upon following the walkthrough at:
http://advosys.ca/papers/printable/postfix-filtering.html

I still can't make the final jump to get this working.  Towards the end
of the document, I am instructed to change the following line that
controls the smtp daemon as follows:

smtp   inet  n   -   n   -   -   smtpd -o content_filter=filter:

...trouble is I HAVE no such line...my similar one lists bsmtp
(attached) as follows:

bsmtp     unix  -       n       n       -       -       pipe
  flags=Fq. user=foo argv=/usr/local/sbin/bsmtp -f $sender $nexthop
$recipient

I should also point out this is on two lines, and not one line as
suggested by Advosys's document.

System:
Stock Redhat 7.2 i386
1ghz Duron / 128mb / 60gb IDE
postfix (unsure of version, beleive it to be latest back in April 2002)
Anomy version 1.55 Spamassassin - fetched from CPAN today (10/15/2002)

Suggestions?

Sincerely,
Greg Long

----master.cf------------------------------------
smtp      inet  n       -       n       -       -       smtpd
#628      inet  n       -       n       -       -       qmqpd
pickup    fifo  n       -       n       60      1       pickup
cleanup   unix  n       -       n       -       0       cleanup
qmgr      fifo  n       -       n       300     1       qmgr
#qmgr     fifo  n       -       n       300     1       nqmgr
rewrite   unix  -       -       n       -       -       trivial-rewrite
bounce    unix  -       -       n       -       0       bounce
defer     unix  -       -       n       -       0       bounce
flush     unix  n       -       n       1000?   0       flush
smtp      unix  -       -       n       -       -       smtp
showq     unix  n       -       n       -       -       showq
error     unix  -       -       n       -       -       error
local     unix  -       n       n       -       -       local
virtual   unix  -       n       n       -       -       virtual
lmtp      unix  -       -       n       -       -       lmtp
#
# Interfaces to non-Postfix software. Be sure to examine the manual
# pages of the non-Postfix software to find out what options it wants.
# The Cyrus deliver program has changed incompatibly.
#
cyrus     unix  -       n       n       -       -       pipe
  flags=R user=cyrus argv=/cyrus/bin/deliver -e -m ${extension} ${user}
uucp      unix  -       n       n       -       -       pipe
  flags=Fqhu user=uucp argv=uux -r -n -z -a$sender - $nexthop!rmail
($recipient)
ifmail    unix  -       n       n       -       -       pipe
  flags=F user=ftn argv=/usr/lib/ifmail/ifmail -r $nexthop ($recipient)
bsmtp     unix  -       n       n       -       -       pipe
  flags=Fq. user=foo argv=/usr/local/sbin/bsmtp -f $sender $nexthop
$recipient
-------------- next part --------------
An embedded and charset-unspecified text was scrubbed...

Url: http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/attachments/20021015/7277496a/attachment.txt

From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Tue Oct 15 22:17:08 2002
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 22:17:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring a CD Burner
In-Reply-To: <3DACD261.54F0543F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021016051708.12595.qmail@web13807.mail.yahoo.com>

If you have scsi emulation enabled your previous IDE
device will no longer work (i.e. /dev/hdX), but only
for the devices you specify in lilo.conf. You should
access it via its new scsi device name (/dev/scd0 on
my Debian system, I've also heard of /dev/sd0).

It may be purely for asthetic reasons, but I think you
should indent the append line in your lilo.conf file
so that it's alligned with the others.

Also, did you reboot? That may be the reason that
cdrecord messes up like that.

Anyway, just some ramblings from someone who thinks
they know everthing. This advice may work, or it may
be crap. I don't know which.

Vince

From revans at e-z.net  Tue Oct 15 23:48:12 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 23:48:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring a CD Burner
In-Reply-To: <3DACD261.54F0543F@attbi.com>
References: <3DAC8AE8.39201C17@attbi.com><1146.66.93.41.102.1034718720.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com><3DACA52A.BAD44095@attbi.com>
    <49484.63.105.24.103.1034728657.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
    <3DACD261.54F0543F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021016064743.GAWR24958.sccrmhc03.attbi.com@linux>

This info is for a 2.4 kernel. I haven't played with a 2.2 kernel in a while so
I don't know if this is accurate for that series.

cat  /proc/scsi/scsi

cat /proc/sys/dev/cdrom/info

This will tell you what your drive is.

/dev/cdrom is probably still pointing at /dev/hdc. You will need to remove the
link and create another to the device name you got from
/proc/sys/dev/cdrom/info i.e. drive name:	      sr0 in my case.

If you don't get any info then you need to look for two modules, ide-scsi and
sg. Both are required for scsi emulation. If you didn't setup scsi emulation by
appending hdc=ide-scsi to lilo; if you install ide-scsi and then sg modules, it
will map your ide cdrom to a scsi /dev/whatever. You don't have to reboot. The
append in Lilo and reboot is so you have the scsi emulation at boot and don't
have to manually load modules. I like to know about loading and unloading sg
because I have had CDRWs that were a little flaky. I buy cheap. 

I like this shell script because I don't have to remember the directories in
/proc. 

http://www.garloff.de/kurt/linux/rescan-scsi-bus.sh

Thank you
Russell


On Tue, 15 Oct 2002 19:43:45 -0700, Richard Steffens said:

>  [root at NEC /root]# cdrecord -scanbus
>  Cdrecord 1.9 (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2000 J?rg Schilling
>  cdrecord: No such file or directory. Cannot open SCSI driver.
>  cdrecord: For possible targets try 'cdrecord -scanbus'. Make sure you
>  are root.

>  [root at NEC /mnt]# mount /dev/cdrom
>  mount: /dev/cdrom is not a valid block device

>  Also, putting a music CD in no longer works. When I run a music playing
>  program from the Gnome menu, I get an error message that says the device

>  the above stuff.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 16 03:46:47 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 03:46:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <3DAAFD19.7070400@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210160342540.28843-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Ah, but you ARE doing development work. You are compiling software
> from source, which is development.

That's where you've totally lost me.  Compiling software is NOT
development in any sense of the word.

Not only is it possible to develop software without compiling anything
ever, but it's possible to compile software without doing any development.

Saying that compiling software from source is development is a bit like
saying dubbing a minidisc is composing music.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 16 04:06:08 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 04:06:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <3DAB00CA.1050703@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210160346510.28843-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> It's not editing the code, but it IS part of the developement process,
> and a vast step beyond what most computer users want to do with their
> computer.

It MIGHT be part of A development process, that doesn't make it
development.  See previous post on the subject.

> *MOST* users simply want a computer that runs the programs they want,
> without any build environment at all. They just want it to work.

According to you, those people don't really WANT a general purpose
computer at all.  They want an information appliance.

> For you and I, it's not a big deal to open the source tar ball,
> configure, test and install source.

You and me.

> For Joe sixpack, he doesn't even want to know the capability is there.
> He doesn't care. He wants his computer to run, and that's it.

Again, you say he wants an appliance, not a general purpose computer.

> For the vast majority of computer users, there's no need for source,
> compilers, headers or any of this other stuff you and I like so much.
> 
> And there's nothing wrong with that. If they don't want to learn how
> to compile a program from source, they don't have to.

See, I totally disagree with this on just about every level.

I reject your assertion that "the vast majority of computer users" have no
need or desire for the ability to compile software from source.  You don't
know the hearts of any majority anywhere and neither do I.

I absolutely reject the idea that there's nothing wrong with that supposed
state of affairs.  Failure of the public to DEMAND the capabilities
inherent in a general purpose computing device will lead a world in which
such devices are not common, inexpensive, and available.  That world is
one managed by information-owning oligopolies who control not only how you
see the world but which parts of it you see at all.  Willfull ignorance by
the majority results in power (through knowledge and skills) consolidating
in the hands of the few and the temptation to use that power to exploit.  
Not caring about and learning how the systems in your world operate (be
those your computer, your bicycle, your public agencies, or your body)
makes one more and more complacent, lazy and gullible over time.

> The binary distributions do that for them, and that's what they get
> paid to do.

There are plenty of people constructing binary distributions for no pay
whatsoever.  There are other valid means of human interaction than
commerce.

> That's also what makes America great. We each have our own choices to
> make.

Being free to make choices is great.  But that doesn't mean it's great to
make any and all choices.  Choosing to be lazy and complacent or exploit
the laziness and complacency of others is not great... not by a long shot.

> In your opinion. For you, it probably is dumb. For the guy down the
> street that just wants to pick up his mail, surf, and maybe chat, a
> full-on developement system that can compile anything is dumb. He
> doesn't need it, and doesn't want it.

He needs it to maintain his personal and social freedom.  He may not want
it, but by giving up his own freedoms, he risks the freedoms of others and
that is destructive, sociopathic behavior.

> Other folks have other needs, and what fits your style might be
> totally inappropriate for others.

This isn't a question of style.  It's not dots vs. stripes or even vi vs.
emacs.  Style is ultimately superficial and determines only HOW an
endeavor is carried out.  This is a question of whether or not an endeavor
(namely, the defense of our free lives) is carried out at all.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Wed Oct 16 08:20:29 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 08:20:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bind issues with transfer
Message-ID: <1446.208.151.243.124.1034781629.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

I have a domain that was using secondary.com as a (master domain) and
secondary.com was getting updates from another machine (my local machine)
well...they are down because they just got bought.
I am transfering the domain to another dns server.

i set up the domain on another dns server as a slave server, so that i
could still update my local machine and it would notify the slave server
of changes.

everytime it tries to make a transfer, i get this.
#/var/log/syslog
dns named[1246]: client 208.151.x4x.x25#1102: zone transfer
'thevacant.com/IN' denied


# /etc/named.conf
zone "thevacant.com" {
        type master;
        file "/var/named/thevacant.com.hosts";
        allow-transfer{
               208.151.x4x.x25;
        };
};

in the zone file on the 'local' machine
i have the proper dns name of the server as a NS record.



am I missing a step?

-Robby

Check the web page, they want the MAC address of the cable modem, not your 
Computer.  It's probably printed on the outside of the cable modem.


Sean

> this will know, is that in order to get the box I want to use as my gateway
> installed I have been told that I need to "register the MAC address" in
> order to get DHCP working. The guy who installed it, he was very good about
> sharing what knowledge he had, gave me a account number, registration code,
> and a web site https://sas.r1.attbi.com to "register the MAC address" with.
> (Note the parts in quotes are his words) So my question is I have to
> register the MAC address to get an address and DNS info. I have to have an
> address and DNS info to register a MAC address. So how do I do this? I do
> have access to a Win2k laptop if that would help. Also if I ever swap out

-- 
Obviously, a man's judgement cannot be better than the information on 
which he has based it.  Give him the truth and he may still go wrong 
when he has the chance to be right, but give him no news or present 
him only with distorted and incomplete data, with ignorant, sloppy or 
biased reporting, with propaganda and deliberate falsehoods, and you 
destroy his whole reasoning processes, and make him something less 
than a man.
-- Arthur Hays Sulzberger

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Wed Oct 16 10:31:09 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 10:31:09 -0700
Subject: OT: McMenamins  & beer (was RE: [PLUG] Red Hat Road Tour ...)
In-Reply-To: 
 <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF61106049FA0@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>
References: 
 <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF61106049FA0@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>
Message-ID: <p05100314b9d34f37dd8a@[192.168.3.1]>

At 2:02 PM -0700 10/15/02, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
>  > From: Patrick Beart [mailto:patrick at WebArchitecture.com]
>>	However, the food and service at ANY McMenamins just BLOWS.
>>  Why people keep going to a place that is ONLY about atmosphere is
>>  strange to me. 
>
>I think you highly overrate the quality of food at McMenamins pubs.
>Restaurants like the Black Rabbit OTOH have great fare. 
>
>As to why people go there see
>http://mikeraz.patch.com/writing/beernotes/nwbn1999March.html which is an
>article I wrote for Northwest Beer Notes (may it rest in peace) in March
>1999 talking about why McMenamins are a great place to drink beer and hang
>with friends.


	Pardon me, but it's only a "great place to drink beer" if you 
like Ales.    :-/

	I prefer the less-bitter, more mature, and smoother Lagers to 
any Ale. McMenamins can't take the time to actually WAIT for their 
beer to mature, so all they crank out is ales. If you like bitter 
beer, then this isn't a problem. However, if you - like me - prefer 
lagers, then nearly all of the Northwest microbrews are a 
disappointment, as most are ales. Saxer, Thomas Kemper, and some 
courageous others dare to buck this decidedly British trend.

	Lagers take TIME to brew. Different (bottom-fermenting) 
yeast. Needs refrigeration to make the yeast do it's job. Just can't 
set this kind of operation up in your kitchen, for instance.

	As I said, I agree with you about the atmosphere at nearly 
any (NE Broadway is a notable exception) McMenamins. However, I 
disagree with most people regarding the quality any of the properties 
culinary, service or beverage offerings. To each their own, right?

	Nice article, btw.    ;-)





Patrick Beart

--

Web Architecture  &  "iWeb4Biz"         503-774-8280       Portland, OR
Internet Consulting, Intelligent Web site Development & Secure site Hosting.
http://www.WebArchitecture.com/

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 16 10:50:57 2002

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> 
>>Ah, but you ARE doing development work. You are compiling software
>>from source, which is development.
> 
> 
> That's where you've totally lost me.  Compiling software is NOT
> development in any sense of the word.
> 
> Not only is it possible to develop software without compiling anything
> ever, but it's possible to compile software without doing any development.
> 
> Saying that compiling software from source is development is a bit like
> saying dubbing a minidisc is composing music.

Yet again, I will not argue with you. My opinion is that compiling 
software is not an absolute must is the computer world. I'm also of the 
opinion (after talking to tens of thousands of computer users over the 
last 10 years) that users don't want to compile software.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 16 11:24:22 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 11:24:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210160346510.28843-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3DADAED6.1020407@dimstar.net>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

>>For Joe sixpack, he doesn't even want to know the capability is there.
>>He doesn't care. He wants his computer to run, and that's it.
> 
> 
> Again, you say he wants an appliance, not a general purpose computer.

In your opinion. I have a much larger view. He wants his computer to 
run, and he wants to be able to install (I said install, not compile) 
software in an easy manner, and have it work.

That more than anything else is why Windows has more "users". You can 
get the software, run the install procedure, and it usually works.

At the same time, I abhor users that "click [Next] as fast as possible" 
to get things installed. I *do* feel that users have to understand some 
of what they are doing.

I just don't think they need to know how to compile to use the computer.

>>For the vast majority of computer users, there's no need for source,
>>compilers, headers or any of this other stuff you and I like so much.
>>
>>And there's nothing wrong with that. If they don't want to learn how
>>to compile a program from source, they don't have to.
> 
> 
> See, I totally disagree with this on just about every level.

And I disagree with that. They have the RIGHT to be ignorant, if they 
choose to be. You know, honor diversity and all that. You can't just 
honor diversity as long as it matches your diversity.

> I absolutely reject the idea that there's nothing wrong with that supposed
> state of affairs.  Failure of the public to DEMAND the capabilities
> inherent in a general purpose computing device will lead a world in which
> such devices are not common, inexpensive, and available.

Then you reject the very premise that one can CHOOSE to be ignorant. 
Those who want to learn, will.

> That world is
> one managed by information-owning oligopolies who control not only how you
> see the world but which parts of it you see at all.  Willfull ignorance by
> the majority results in power (through knowledge and skills) consolidating
> in the hands of the few and the temptation to use that power to exploit.  
> Not caring about and learning how the systems in your world operate (be
> those your computer, your bicycle, your public agencies, or your body)
> makes one more and more complacent, lazy and gullible over time.

And that is their choice! It's called freedom of choice. They can do 
that if they so believe it's the right course of action.

You may not agree, and you can do what you want to try to change their 
minds, but I'll still fight for their right to be ignorant if they want 
to be.

>>The binary distributions do that for them, and that's what they get
>>paid to do.
> 
> 
> There are plenty of people constructing binary distributions for no pay
> whatsoever.  There are other valid means of human interaction than
> commerce.

Maybe. Won't put bread on my table. I deal with the world as it 
currently is, not as I'd like it to be.

>>That's also what makes America great. We each have our own choices to
>>make.
> 
> 
> Being free to make choices is great.  But that doesn't mean it's great to
> make any and all choices.  Choosing to be lazy and complacent or exploit
> the laziness and complacency of others is not great... not by a long shot.

I agree. But those that choose to be lazy (as you call them) have that 
right.

>>In your opinion. For you, it probably is dumb. For the guy down the
>>street that just wants to pick up his mail, surf, and maybe chat, a
>>full-on developement system that can compile anything is dumb. He
>>doesn't need it, and doesn't want it.
> 
> 
> He needs it to maintain his personal and social freedom.  He may not want
> it, but by giving up his own freedoms, he risks the freedoms of others and
> that is destructive, sociopathic behavior.

In your opinion. He may not see it that way, and just wants his email.

>>Other folks have other needs, and what fits your style might be
>>totally inappropriate for others.
> 
> 
> This isn't a question of style.  It's not dots vs. stripes or even vi vs.
> emacs.  Style is ultimately superficial and determines only HOW an
> endeavor is carried out.  This is a question of whether or not an endeavor
> (namely, the defense of our free lives) is carried out at all.

But don't you see, if you *FORCE* someone to do something that they 
don't normally have to, then you are becoming the very beast you decry.


--

Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

fool heads off and the ground all mucked up with plants." - Dorothy Parker




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Wed Oct 16 11:55:23 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 13:55:23 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
Message-ID: <EX-20021016-140547-0005@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

What is the basic difference between compiling software and "simply" installing it. I'm not a coder. For me compiling something consists of a small handful of commands. Most of the problems that pop up during a make install would just show up later and in other ways. Now I have installed almost everything on every system I've used for many years with apt. The exceptions being the occasional drivers and winders boxen I'm forced to use at work. With the new machine I'll be building this weekend I'll do the source thing with apt for everything except the base install. Why cause it is going to be fast and I want to watch it burn cycles. But there is *no* basic difference. Compiling can and is packaged behind various frontends. The average user does not understand an install wizard anymore than they would understand compiling and as long as the frontend consisted of making some basic choices and clicking ok it would be basically the same process. 

My point being that with the exception of coders there is almost no difference between the two processes and almost no difference in errors etc. BTW installing software does not get much easier than a Debian box once it is built. I think users don't care and just want the frontends they think they know.

Michael;

Bynari's Insight Server is reported to be a drop-in replacement for Exchange.

  http://www.bynari.net/bynari/products.html

We hosted a presentation about the server from the network administrator
from a local company. He reported the only difference was that it was a
lot more reliable and that the configuration was much easier to restore in
the event of a disaster!

From cp at onsitetech.com  Wed Oct 16 12:38:55 2002
From: cp at onsitetech.com (Curtis Poe)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 12:38:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to deal with Microsoft?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210161212330.22491-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <005601c2754b$aa7b00a0$1a01a8c0@ot.onsitetech.com>

Very interesting node that someone has posted on Perlmonks:
http://www.perlmonks.org/index.pl?node_id=205801

Essentially, the person built a site for an "unnamed" company that's very
large and infests the 9th Circle of Hell, also known as Redmond, WA.

He built the site using Linux, Apache, MySQL, and Perl.  The unnamed company
objected and stated the site could only use the unnamed company's products.
The person resorted to spoofing the header information to incorrectly report
the underlying technologies, thus leading NetCraft to "confirm" that the
technology switch was made.

--
Cheers,
Curtis Poe
Senior Programmer
ONSITE! Technology, Inc.
www.onsitetech.com
503-233-1418

Taking e-Business and Internet Technology To The Extreme!




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Wed Oct 16 12:48:31 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 12:48:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for Linux alternative to MS Exchange
In-Reply-To: <20021016122247.C71141@cogit8.org>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOGEHALIAA.mikel@quantecllc.com> <20021016122247.C71141@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <200210161248.31045.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Wednesday 16 October 2002 12:22, Rob Hudson wrote:
>>I've got about 20 people on Win2K boxen and we're running a Linux server (or
>>about to - it goes live this weekend...) and while I'd love to move everyone
>>to Linux, we have too many software packages that we rely on that are
>>Windows-only.

>>All I really need is the contact list and calendar management and sharing
>>features of Exchange, as we'll be using PostFix.

> Suse has something in the works...
> http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,634107,00.asp

SuSE already has a nice product, SuSE Linux eMail Server 3.1. Based on 
Postfix, Cyrus, OpenLDAP, and Squirrelmail. See 
http://networking.earthweb.com/netos/article/0,,12083_1466561,00.html for a 
brief review by the fabulous me.

Bynari and Caldera's Volition are similar, and work well, what I don't like is 
they both charge client licenses for server products. SuSE's email server is 
one price no matter how many users connect.

A better solution for you might be Time & Chaos, it's a Windows shared 
calendar/contacts app. It works great on either a peer network, or 
server/client. http://www.isbister.com/chaos32.html.  It won't be all 
mega-integrated like Exchange/Outlook, but it's inexpensive, stable, and a 
hell of a lot easier to admin than Exchange.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Red Hat 8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Michael;

Bynari's Insight Server is reported to be a drop-in replacement for
Exchange.

  http://www.bynari.net/bynari/products.html

We hosted a presentation about the server from the network administrator
from a local company. He reported the only difference was that it was a
lot more reliable and that the configuration was much easier to restore in
the event of a disaster!

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Oct 16 15:51:08 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 15:51:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: Configuring a CD Burner
References: <3DAC8AE8.39201C17@attbi.com><1146.66.93.41.102.1034718720.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com><3DACA52A.BAD44095@attbi.com>
	    <49484.63.105.24.103.1034728657.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
	    <3DACD261.54F0543F@attbi.com> <20021016064743.GAWR24958.sccrmhc03.attbi.com@linux>
Message-ID: <3DADED5C.3D73757A@attbi.com>

Many thanks to all who offered advice, particularly to Matt King for
walking me through several steps of this process, and to Russell Evans
for his suggestions for figuring out to which channel my CD Burner is
connected.

For the archives, here's how I got my CD Burner working on a RH 7.0
machine. (Note that if your burner is connected to a different cable,
you would need to use something other than hdc in the first step.)

Add  append="hdc=ide-scsi"  to my lilo.conf file. Then run
  lilo -v
and reboot the machine. On my machine, it was necessary to run
  mknod /dev/sr0 b 11 0
  modprobe ide-scsi
and
  modprobe sg

Now, when I run
  cdrecord -scanbus
it reports:

Cdrecord 1.9 (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2000 J?rg Schilling
Linux sg driver version: 2.1.38
Using libscg version 'schily-0.1'
scsibus0:  0,0,0     0) 'HP      ' 'CD-Writer+ 7200 ' '3.01' Removable
CD-ROM

I successfully burned a CD with an image made from mkisofs with:
  cdrecord dev=0,0 /home/public/cd.iso

Along the way, I got useful information from running:
  lsmod   
to learn what modules are currently loaded, and
  dmesg
  cat  /proc/scsi/scsi
  cat /proc/sys/dev/cdrom/info
which told me that my CD-Burner is on hdc - thanks, Russell.

There appear to be only two concerns. 

1) Playing a music CD doesn't work right. When I pop a music CD into the
drive, one of the player applications starts up, and acts like it's
playing, but there's no sound. cdparanoia still works, and gramophile
will play a .wav file ripped with cdparanoia.

2) Ripping with cdparanoia seems to take much longer than it did before.

Other than that, I'm quite satisfied with the results. Thanks again to
all those who helped.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Oct 16 07:39:02 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 07:39:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] MS sucks reason 4971
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021016-172315-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210160736410.11166-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 16 Oct 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:

> Granted I've not installed a winders box since 98 was new. But does not even a normal winders install overwrite the MBR without asking? 

He is hot taking about overwriting the MBR.  You can do that without 
screwing over the partition table.  (Lilo and grub will overwrite the MBR 
as well.)

That version of XP is overwriting the *partition table*.  This causes any 
of your other data to \go away, not just be inaccesable.  (Especially 
since this step is followed by a format.)


> 
> Also it would seem to me that since you paid for the license you would be morally if not legally justified in getting a copy of XP from how shall we say less than official sources.
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Neal 
> Sent: Wednesday, October 16, 2002 3:16 PM

 is=20
one price no matter how many users connect.

A better solution for you might be Time & Chaos, it's a Windows shared=20
calendar/contacts app. It works great on either a peer network, or=20
server/client. http://www.isbister.com/chaos32.html.  It won't be all=20
mega-integrated like Exchange/Outlook, but it's inexpensive, stable, and =
a=20
hell of a lot easier to admin than Exchange.

--=20

Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 16 16:26:42 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 16:26:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <3DADA701.60109@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210161623090.12829-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 16 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > 
> >>Ah, but you ARE doing development work. You are compiling software
> >>from source, which is development.
> > 
> > 
> > That's where you've totally lost me.  Compiling software is NOT
> > development in any sense of the word.
> > 
> > Not only is it possible to develop software without compiling anything
> > ever, but it's possible to compile software without doing any development.
> > 
> > Saying that compiling software from source is development is a bit like
> > saying dubbing a minidisc is composing music.
> 
> Yet again, I will not argue with you.

Again?  Coupled with when?

You wrote that when you compile software "you ARE doing development
work".  I countered that and you say you will not argue.  So you changed
your mind and you agree with me?

So it IS dumb to call them -devel packages when they have are required for
tasks that are NOT development.  That was my whole point.

> My opinion is that compiling software is not an absolute must is the
> computer world.

Unless you want every programmer in the world to write in machine code,
compiling software IS an absolute must in the computer world.

> I'm also of the opinion (after talking to tens of thousands of
> computer users over the last 10 years) that users don't want to
> compile software.

So?  What does this have to do with the fact that -devel packages are
badly named?

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 16 16:54:37 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 16:54:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ./configure error
In-Reply-To: <3DADAED6.1020407@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210161626540.12829-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

Understand that this is a very different argument than whether or not
"devel" packages are properly named.  I'd like to keep them separate.

On Wed, 16 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Mon, 14 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> >>For Joe sixpack, he doesn't even want to know the capability is there.
> >>He doesn't care. He wants his computer to run, and that's it.
> > Again, you say he wants an appliance, not a general purpose computer.
> 
> In your opinion. I have a much larger view.

How is your view "much larger" when it considers only immediate, selfish
desires and fails to consider long-term social implications?

> He wants his computer to run, and he wants to be able to install (I
> said install, not compile)  software in an easy manner, and have it
> work.

To this type of user that you describe, it doesn't matter whether the
software compiles locally or not.  If it's easy and it works, this
apathetic slob doesn't care, right?

> That more than anything else is why Windows has more "users".

I think you should probably take a look at your industry history again.  
There are lots of reasons Windows has more users than anything for which
source code is available and none of them have to do with being easier and
more opaque.

> You can get the software, run the install procedure, and it usually
> works.

That's no different than what I do.  I get the software and run the
install procedure.  And it usually works.

> I just don't think they need to know how to compile to use the
> computer.

They don't and I don't believe anyone implied that they did.  I wrote that
they SHOULD and that failing to understand the inner workings of their
systems is ultimately destructive to themselves and their society.  But I
didn't write that can't use those systems in some capacity without knowing
how to use them to their full capacity.  That's absurd.  Hell, my father
can work a VCR for some purposes.

> >>For the vast majority of computer users, there's no need for source,
> >>compilers, headers or any of this other stuff you and I like so much.
> >>And there's nothing wrong with that. If they don't want to learn how
> >>to compile a program from source, they don't have to.
> > See, I totally disagree with this on just about every level.
> 
> And I disagree with that.

You disagree that I disagree?  Please, show me how I agree.

> They have the RIGHT to be ignorant, if they choose to be. You know,
> honor diversity and all that. You can't just honor diversity as long
> as it matches your diversity.

Wow.

That kind of reasoning would lead one to statements like, "They have the
RIGHT to have sex with their children." or "They have the RIGHT to shit in
the park."  "Honor diversity, brother!"

Nobody has the right to be destructive and ignorance is socially
destructive.

> > I absolutely reject the idea that there's nothing wrong with that supposed
> > state of affairs.  Failure of the public to DEMAND the capabilities
> > inherent in a general purpose computing device will lead a world in which
> > such devices are not common, inexpensive, and available.
> 
> Then you reject the very premise that one can CHOOSE to be ignorant.  

I don't reject the premise that one can choose to be ignorant.  I reject
the premise that one SHOULD choose to be ignorant.

> Those who want to learn, will.

...and those who don't, should be shown why they should.

> And that is their choice! It's called freedom of choice. They can do
> that if they so believe it's the right course of action.

And I can help show them why it is NOT the right course of action.

> You may not agree, and you can do what you want to try to change their
> minds, but I'll still fight for their right to be ignorant if they
> want to be.

What does that even MEAN?  How do you fight for the right to be ignorant?  
Will you work against education initiatives claiming that they violate
people's freedom of choice of ignorance?

> > There are plenty of people constructing binary distributions for no pay
> > whatsoever.  There are other valid means of human interaction than
> > commerce.
> 
> Maybe. Won't put bread on my table.

That's not true.  I know lots of people that would put bread on your table
without one bit of consideration for commerce.

Hell, I have friends and neighbors give me bread all the time.  And I
usually put it on my table.

> I deal with the world as it currently is, not as I'd like it to be.

Perhaps you should get up and try to improve your situation, then.

> But those that choose to be lazy (as you call them) have that right.

But they DON'T have that right because it impinges upon the rights of
others by creating a powerful exploitative class.

The price of freedom is eternal vigilance.  People who become ignorant and
complacent are not practicing their eternal vigilance and are, therefore,
sacrificing their freedom.  They are also threatening the freedom of every
other person by allowing a few people to use that ignorance and
complacence to gain power and that power can then be asserted over those
who DO practice their eternal vigilance.  And what do we do about threats
to our freedom?

> > He needs it to maintain his personal and social freedom.  He may not want
> > it, but by giving up his own freedoms, he risks the freedoms of others and
> > that is destructive, sociopathic behavior.
> 
> In your opinion. He may not see it that way, and just wants his email.

"He" doesn't see it that way, sure.  But that's because of his precious
ignorance.  It is our responsibility as the informed to fight ignorance
and teach.

> > This isn't a question of style.  It's not dots vs. stripes or even vi vs.
> > emacs.  Style is ultimately superficial and determines only HOW an
> > endeavor is carried out.  This is a question of whether or not an endeavor
> > (namely, the defense of our free lives) is carried out at all.
> 
> But don't you see, if you *FORCE* someone to do something that they
> don't normally have to, then you are becoming the very beast you
> decry.

People DO normally have to defend their freedoms!  I don't think that I'd
be encouraging a person to do something they don't normally have to do by
encouraging them to practice eternal vigilance and work to be more
informed about the systems around them.

The only people that encourage ignorance are those who would like to
exploit it.  And those who exploit are looking to gain power and the
consolidation of power is a threat to freedom as a whole.

Fighting ignorance is defending freedom.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

high-speed connection to the Internet.  I can get SDSL through Worldcom 
(who currently filed bankruptcy) and ISDN through QWest.  Since we 
currently have phone service through QWest, I was thinking this would be 
a good idea.  Also, I was hoping to switch to a Linux router with the 
addition of a high-speed connection (we have ICS over a modem currently, 
don't ask).  

So, should I go for ISDN with Linux, or use DSL?  Does Linux care 
whether I'm using ISDN or DSL?

Thanks

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Wed Oct 16 17:35:33 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 17:35:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ISDN with Linux
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021016173521.00a8f220@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

Unless you're doing hosting, SDSL is probably a waste of your money.

Earthlink DSL works great with Linux and offers a very competitive 
price.  Many local ISPs like Coho and Internet Arena also offer DSL, 
usually through Verizon.  Some also offer ISDN if you're sure that's what 
you want.

I wouldn't recommend working with Qwest unless it's strictly 
necessary.  I'd like to tell you about all the great experiences I've had 
setting up services with Qwest, but I don't think I've had one yet.

Dylan

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Wed Oct 16 18:48:26 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 18:48:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ISDN with Linux
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021016173521.00a8f220@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021016173521.00a8f220@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <p0510031bb9d3c68de755@[192.168.3.1]>

At 5:35 PM -0700 10/16/02, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:
>Unless you're doing hosting, SDSL is probably a waste of your money.
>
>Earthlink DSL works great with Linux and offers a very competitive 
>price.  Many local ISPs like Coho and Internet Arena also offer DSL, 
>usually through Verizon.  Some also offer ISDN if you're sure that's 
>what you want.
>
>I wouldn't recommend working with Qwest unless it's strictly 
>necessary.  I'd like to tell you about all the great experiences 
>I've had setting up services with Qwest, but I don't think I've had 
>one yet.


	Well, I have to disagree with this.

	I had ISDN with Qwest, starting in 1995, then again last 
year. QWest will come to your house/business if your ISDN goes wacky. 
One bill, good service (really!).
	EarthLink works with local telco providers, so if you're in 
Qwest territory for your phone system, you're going to end up working 
with Qwest whether you want to or not. Deal with it.

	FYI, I wrote the original article on ISDN for ComputerBits 
magazine, several years ago. Search under my name, if you care.



Patrick Beart

-------------------------
>At 05:10 PM 10/16/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>>Hey,
>>
>>I currently work at a dentist's office and we are looking for a 
>>high-speed connection to the Internet.  I can get SDSL through 
>>Worldcom (who currently filed bankruptcy) and ISDN through QWest. 
>>Since we currently have phone service through QWest, I was thinking 
>>this would be a good idea.  Also, I was hoping to switch to a Linux 
>>router with the addition of a high-speed connection (we have ICS 
>>over a modem currently, don't ask).
>>
>>So, should I go for ISDN with Linux, or use DSL?  Does Linux care 
>>whether I'm using ISDN or DSL?

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Wed Oct 16 19:21:48 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 19:21:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: OO install
Message-ID: <3DAE1EBC.80005@attbi.com>

 > What does this mean;
 > # rpm -Uvh OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
 > Preparing...                ###########################################
 > [100%]
 > installing package OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3 needs 11Mb on the / filesystem
 >
 > and what is the mount point /dev/shm on RedHat 7.3? I've got 440M and
 > it's empty.It says it is a tmpfs. A temp filesystem of 440M?!



It means you don't have 11Mb free on your root partition.
Type,
	$ df -h
to see what you have where.

Re: /dev/shm on RH 7.3, the relevant part of `mount` says
   none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)

probably similar to yours.  (Was surprised when the installer asked a 
bigger
swapfile, I already had allocated a generous swap partition).  But I don't
think this is your problem.  Open Office wants a permanent place to install
itself.

Type,
	$ rpm -qilp OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
you'll see where it wants to plant itself.  If it's /opt, then create a 
symlink
	$ln -s /home/on/the/range /opt

--

I have an hda4 which is extended and on that file I have an hda6, an 
ext3 which has 72,779M. How do I access that part of the drive?
Dirk




From verso at mac.com  Wed Oct 16 13:50:27 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 13:50:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] File Rename via Samba?
Message-ID: <B9D31F23.5282%verso@mac.com>

Hey all,

After much technological upheaval at my house, I'm up against this problem
once again. Two new hard drives and three reformats later, I finally got my
Samba Server on and the Wintendo is able to connect and do basic things:
read, copy to, and delete from the share he's connected to. However he
cannot rename files. Is rename a completely separate permission? It doesn't
matter if he logs in as himself (w/admin rights) or me (w/admin/su rights),
that machine is unable to rename on my machine. When he tries, it says "The
source or destination file may be in use". Any idea what could cause this?
My machine is running OSX, his is running Win2k Pro. I've tried all manner
of permission juju, googling for the error, thus far, no dice.  Help!

-Kelly

My advice? Let the Wookiee win.




From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Wed Oct 16 19:50:36 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 19:50:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Eschelon Telecom?
References: <86hefne85m.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <009301c27587$f8851060$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

It's a trap!

Echelon is perhaps the most powerful intelligence gathering organization in
the world. Several credible reports suggest that this global electronic
communications surveillance system presents an extreme threat to the privacy
of people all over the world. According to these reports, ECHELON attempts
to capture staggering volumes of satellite, microwave, cellular and
fiber-optic traffic, including communications to and from North America.
This vast quantity of voice and data communications are then processed
through sophisticated filtering technologies.

This massive surveillance system apparently operates with little oversight.
Moreover, the agencies that purportedly run ECHELON have provided few
details as to the legal guidelines for the project. Because of this, there
is no way of knowing if ECHELON is being used illegally to spy on private
citizens.

:-)

And while I'm at it, why can't those satellites from the movie "Enemy of the
State" find the DC sniper?

From sean at fork.com  Wed Oct 16 20:11:32 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 20:11:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ISDN with Linux
In-Reply-To: <3DADFFEF.4090808@logiccloud.com>
References: <3DADFFEF.4090808@logiccloud.com>
Message-ID: <20021017031132.27AEF2EE06@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I wouldn't bother with a linux isdn solution.  For about $100 you can get a 
used cisco 700 router in ebay.  If you get the right model 700 you can also 
get spare teleco ports on it and hook the fax machine up to one of the lines. 
 If a fax goes out it drops one of the 64k connections for the fax and 
continues routing data over the other 64k line.  Set that up and then set up 
a linux firewall. Let cisco do what it does best and linux do what it does 
best.


Sean

On Wednesday 16 October 2002 17:10, you wrote:
> Hey,
>
> I currently work at a dentist's office and we are looking for a
> high-speed connection to the Internet.  I can get SDSL through Worldcom
> (who currently filed bankruptcy) and ISDN through QWest.  Since we
> currently have phone service through QWest, I was thinking this would be
> a good idea.  Also, I was hoping to switch to a Linux router with the
> addition of a high-speed connection (we have ICS over a modem currently,
> don't ask).
>
> So, should I go for ISDN with Linux, or use DSL?  Does Linux care
> whether I'm using ISDN or DSL?
>

From jimwebb at charter.net  Wed Oct 16 20:26:08 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (James H. Webb)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 23:26:08 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Home network connectivity problem
Message-ID: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>

I have a home network problem that has me puzzled.  I hope that somebody out
there has more smarts and/or experience to help me.

When my house was built I had cat5 jacks placed in 4 rooms.  The cable led
to a closet where I had my cable brought into the house.  In that closet I
have the cable connected to the Motorola modem which connects to my hardware
firewall.  This in turn is connected to an 8 port 10/100 Netgear hub.  I
have cat5 cable connected from the hub into wall jacks that lead back to the
4 rooms.

I noticed today that when I attempted to attach a 4 port Netgear 10/100 hub
in one of the rooms to the wall jack that I was unable to connect to the
network.  This is the same network that I can successfully connect out to
the internet when I have one pc, without the hub, connected to that same
wall jack.  I switched cat5 cables.  That didn't help.  I moved the hub into
another room and the same problem occurred.  I can connect to the internet
with one pc, but not after I connect one or more pc's through the hub.

A friend thought that it may be due to some IEEE standard about how the wall
jack might be set up, but he couldn't remember the details.

Has anybody seen anything like this?  Can anybody help????


TIA,

Jim Webb

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Wed Oct 16 20:38:25 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 20:38:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Home network connectivity problem
In-Reply-To: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>
References: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>
Message-ID: <49176.63.105.24.103.1034825905.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Does the hub have an uplink port?  Hook it up to that port.  If not use a
crossover cable between the hub and the wall jack, then hook the other
systems up normally...


-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

You have attempted to connect a hub/switch to a hub/switch.  This calls for a

From bprew at logiccloud.com  Wed Oct 16 20:45:14 2002
From: bprew at logiccloud.com (Benjamin Prew)
Date: 16 Oct 2002 20:45:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Home network connectivity problem
In-Reply-To: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>
References: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>
Message-ID: <1034826315.886.838.camel@laptop>

This may seem mundane, but are you connecting to the uplink port in the
4-port hub?  You will need to do this in order to chain a hub to another
hub/switch. 

I'm assuming you have lights on the hub and all that, right?  

If so, can you ping/see other computers in different rooms with a
computer connected through your 4-port hub?  

Can you ping/see computers connected to the same 4-port hub?

I've installed wall jacks before and have been able to chain hubs
together through them. I've run into other problems, but it sounds like
the 4-port hub either isn't working or isn't attached to the 8-port hub
properly.

From satimis at writeme.com  Wed Oct 16 20:55:41 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 11:55:41 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Power-Off problem
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017115336.02b80900@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi All Folks,

CPU  AMD Athlon 1.4G
Motherboard	  2thMax 8KHA
ATX system
OS	Rh8.0

I suffered this problem since running RH7.3.  My RH8.0 was upgraded from a 
RH7.3 box

During "shutdown PC" on graphic mode RH8.0 closed but the PC is not 
power-off.  Following text displayed on screen

- snip -
Halting system
md: stopping all md devices
flushing ide device : hda hdc hdd
Power down

The screen hangs here and power is still on.

When "shutdown PC" on Console window with command

# shutdown -y -g0

same result.

Previously I have been playing around with BIOS and PC setup but no 
solution reached

Any advice.

Thanks in advance.

Stephen Liu

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 16 21:01:43 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 21:01:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Home network connectivity problem
In-Reply-To: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGOEBKCAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210162100280.15287-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 16 Oct 2002, James H. Webb wrote:
> I noticed today that when I attempted to attach a 4 port Netgear
> 10/100 hub in one of the rooms to the wall jack that I was unable to
> connect to the network.  This is the same network that I can
> successfully connect out to the internet when I have one pc, without
> the hub, connected to that same wall jack.  I switched cat5 cables.  
> That didn't help.  I moved the hub into another room and the same
> problem occurred.  I can connect to the internet with one pc, but not
> after I connect one or more pc's through the hub.

It seems to me that your problem is related to crossing transmit and
receives all over the place.  Nothing to do with wall jacks per se.

If you're going to connect a hub/switch to another hub/switch, you have to
go from a regular port on one to the "uplink" port on another or use a
crossover cable.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

> is running Win2k Pro. I've tried all manner of permission juju, googling

I find it's helpful to see two things when looking at samba probs.:

1. The file permissions on the file in question.
2. The relevant sections of the smb.conf; i.e. the share definition.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Oct 16 21:32:06 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 21:32:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: OO install
References: <3DAE1EBC.80005@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DAE3D46.3010002@pacifier.com>

Dirk Ouellette wrote:
>  > What does this mean;
>  > # rpm -Uvh OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
>  > Preparing...                ###########################################
>  > [100%]
>  > installing package OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3 needs 11Mb on the / filesystem
>  >
>  > and what is the mount point /dev/shm on RedHat 7.3? I've got 440M and
>  > it's empty.It says it is a tmpfs. A temp filesystem of 440M?!
> 
> 
> 
> It means you don't have 11Mb free on your root partition.
> Type,
>     $ df -h
> to see what you have where.
> 
> Re: /dev/shm on RH 7.3, the relevant part of `mount` says
>   none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
> 
> probably similar to yours.  (Was surprised when the installer asked a 
> bigger
> swapfile, I already had allocated a generous swap partition).  But I don't
> think this is your problem.  Open Office wants a permanent place to install
> itself.
> 
> Type,
>     $ rpm -qilp OpenOffice-suite-1.0-3.i386.rpm
> you'll see where it wants to plant itself.  If it's /opt, then create a 
> symlink
>     $ln -s /home/on/the/range /opt
>
> I have an hda4 which is extended and on that file I have an hda6, an 
> ext3 which has 72,779M. How do I access that part of the drive?


Did you find out where OpenOffice wants to install itself?

Is /dev/hda6 mounted? type `mount`
If it is not mounted (not in the list) and there is no line for it in 
/etc/fstab, then you probably won't step on anything by doing the following,

# mkdir /mnt/hda6
# mount /dev/hda6 /mnt/hda6
# cd /mnt/hda6

poke around.

If /dev/hda6 does show up in the previous `mount` command, it will tell you 
the mountpoint, something like
  /dev/hda6 on /usr type ext3 (rw)

Then you know that /usr is on that partition.

Make sense?

--
Kyle Accardi

From jimwebb at charter.net  Thu Oct 17 04:23:18 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (James H. Webb)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 07:23:18 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] RE: CRIME Home network connectivity problem
In-Reply-To: <20021017064258.GB6027@wirex.com>
Message-ID: <NAEMLOHDCGGNKGMHCPFGKECACAAA.jimwebb@charter.net>

Thanks to everyone for your assistance.  I hadn't thought about the concept
that I was attaching one hub to another hub even though they were in
different rooms.  I used the uplink switch and now I'm able to connect two
pc's from one room using the 4 port hub.

Thanks,

Jim Webb

-----Original Message-----
From: Seth Arnold [mailto:sarnold at wirex.com]
Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2002 2:43 AM
To: CRIME
Cc: James H. Webb
Subject: Re: CRIME Home network connectivity problem


On Wed, Oct 16, 2002 at 11:26:08PM -0400, James H. Webb wrote:
> I noticed today that when I attempted to attach a 4 port Netgear 10/100
hub
> in one of the rooms to the wall jack that I was unable to connect to the
> network.  This is the same network that I can successfully connect out to
> the internet when I have one pc, without the hub, connected to that same
> wall jack.  I switched cat5 cables.  That didn't help.  I moved the hub
into
> another room and the same problem occurred.  I can connect to the internet
> with one pc, but not after I connect one or more pc's through the hub.

Were you able to ever get any computers to talk to the internet through
the 4 port hub? Were you able to get any two computers to talk to each
other through only the 4 port hub? Were you able to get any two
computers to talk to each other through both the 4 port hub and the 8
port hub?

Were you using the uplink port on only _one_ of the hubs? (You've got to
use exactly one -- no more, no less[1].)

Do the answers to any of the previous questions change if you plug the 4
port hub directly into the 8 port hub, rather than using the in-built
wiring?

My guess is that you need to use the uplink ports on one of the hubs;
the 4 port might be 'easier', in the sense that it is more mobile than
the 8 port hub. But don't use the uplink ports on both. If this isn't
it, try the other questions as starting points for troubleshooting.


[1] with the exception of crossover cables, but this discussion is
complicated enough without bringing them into the middle of it. :)

--
http://sardonix.org/





From hapibeli at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 05:58:08 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)

Subject: [PLUG] Re: O O install
Message-ID: <3DAEB3E0.7090009@attbi.com>


Did you find out where OpenOffice wants to install itself?

Is /dev/hda6 mounted? type `mount`
If it is not mounted (not in the list) and there is no line for it in
/etc/fstab, then you probably won't step on anything by doing the following,

# mkdir /mnt/hda6
# mount /dev/hda6 /mnt/hda6
# cd /mnt/hda6

Kyle Accardi


Thanks Kyle. It is actually  hda5 and I set up the mount for it.
I also added the last line for it in /etc/fstab. From # man /etc/fstab 
I'm assuming "1 2" is the proper nomenclature
Dirk


LABEL=/                 /                       ext3    defaults        1 1
LABEL=/boot             /boot                   ext3    defaults        1 2
none                    /dev/pts                devpts  gid=5,mode=620  0 0
none                    /proc                   proc    defaults        0 0
none                    /dev/shm                tmpfs   defaults        0 0
/dev/hda2               swap                    swap    defaults        0 0
/dev/cdrom              /mnt/cdrom              iso9660 
noauto,owner,kudzu,ro 0 0
/dev/cdrom1             /mnt/cdrom1             iso9660 
noauto,owner,kudzu,ro 0 0
/dev/fd0                /mnt/floppy             auto 
noauto,owner,kudzu 0 0
/dev/hda5               /mnt/hda5               ext3    defaults        1 2




From hapibeli at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 06:18:14 2002

Group       : X11/Desktop                   Source RPM:

Size        : 193139880                        License: GPL
Packager    : Eric Harrison <eharrison at mesd.k12.or.us>
URL         : http://www.openoffice.org
Summary     : OpenOffice suite

This from another source;
  If you want to use it as /home, put it in your /etc/fstab file. 
Re-create your user as that account will not be in your filesystem when 
you mount the empty partition on /home.

How do I use , or add hda5 to /home and mv ,if necessary, the files to hda5?
Dirk




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 06:35:44 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 06:35:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210161637450.23228-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170630210.14207-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 16 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I have an opportunity to buy a 19" equipment rack (4' tall) for a
> very good price. I'd like to build a couple of workstations and a
> firewall system to fit in there and replace the under-desk units we
> have. But, I don't have a clue how many "U" are in a 4' case, what
> size case I should look to buy, and so on.

FWIW: Here's my take on the various xU sizes:

* 1U  : looks cool, but loud since tiny fans spin so quickly
* 2U  : the sweet spot!
* 3U  : a bit big, but not bad
* 4U+ : too big unless you need lots of local disks

If you can, you might think about getting a rack-mountable UPS to 
stick at the bottom of your rack...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Oct 17 07:07:50 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 07:07:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170630210.14207-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210170656540.32235-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

Since I lust for the ultimate rack mount I'll add some totally irreverent 
comments.

> * 1U  : looks cool, but loud since tiny fans spin so quickly

	Holds one switch or an Integrated Cabinet Console (Keyboard, 
        fold-down LCD display - StarTech.Com :-).

> * 2U  : the sweet spot!

	At a little over 3 inches will it hold a 'normal' main board 
	and expansion cards?
	Many nice pre-built systems come this way.

> * 3U  : a bit big, but not bad
	Holds 18-20 Blades!!!

> * 4U+ : too big unless you need lots of local disks
	Holds a 2 TB iSCSI unit - RaidZone.

> If you can, you might think about getting a rack-mountable UPS to 
> stick at the bottom of your rack...

	Oh yeah.


Rod

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Thu Oct 17 07:51:09 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)

This is what I got out of ATT. Thought some of you might like to use this info.

Ray

-----Original Message-----
From: AT&T Broadband Internet Customer Care 
Sent: Wednesday, October 16, 2002 7:44 PM
To: Percival, Ray
Subject: Re: Modem Connectivity <<#370936-715234#>>


Ray,

Thank you for writing to AT&T Broadband.

I apologize for the confusion. Once you have your computer set to DHCP, you should then be able to gain an IP and then access the site you were given. The Servers are set to provide a basic 1 hr IP lease to perform this process.

You do not need to run the Virtual Technician software to gain the necessary connection.

If you do not know how to configure to DHCP for your system, or need more information on how to configure your computer, please visit:
http://help.broadband.att.com/faq.jsp?content_id=1729&category_id=93

This page will give you the instructions you need. Please remember, AT&T Broadband does not provide static IP addresses.

Your feedback is important to us. If you have any service-related concerns or questions, please contact our Online Customer Support Center at http://help.broadband.att.com. Our Online Customer Care Specialists are available 24-hours a day, seven days a week.

Thank you again for contacting AT&T Broadband.

T-Dean S
AT&T Broadband Online Customer Support Center

Problem: Modem Connectivity
Description: I just ordered the service and had it installed yesterday. I have not played with it yet but plan on getting everything set up this evening. I just have one question. I do not want to run the virtual tech software. The person who installed the system said I could register my MAC address by going to https://sas.r1.attbi.com and putting in my account info and registration code. I have not tried this yet but my basic question is if I have to register the MAC address to make DHCP work and I need to have DHCP working to get an IP and get to the page to register the MAC address, How do I register my MAC address? I hope I have been clear if not please mail me with any questions you might have. And please note running the Virtual Tech software is *not* an acceptable answer. Thanks.

Ray Percival

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Now I'm confused.This is my output on RH 7.3;

The differing timestamps suggest that /home and /mnt/hda5 aren't the
same filesystem. The lack of a lost+found directory in /home suggests
that it's part of the root (/) filesystem, while /mnt/hda5 is a
separate partition.

What's the output of 'mount' without any arguments?


> root]# ls -lah /home
> total 24k
> drwxr-xr-x    6 root     root         4.0k Oct  7 22:20 .
> drwxr-xr-x   19 root     root         4.0k Oct 17 06:06 ..
> drwx------   26 booda    booda        4.0k Oct 17 08:27 booda

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 17 08:44:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 08:44:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DIG 8.3
In-Reply-To: <3DAED58F.5010102@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170842020.26102-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Terrel Woolbright wrote:

> Thanks for the suggestion. I did try the man page first! It had lots of 
> great info on the options to use with it. I was just really looking for 
> a good explanation of ALL the fields within the output of DiG. I am 
> really new at networking and am trying to learn all this.
 
Terrel,

  I thought that I had read all that on the man page. "IN" means Internet.
"MX" is Mail Server, "SOA" is the Start of Authority (the highest level
authoritative name server that knows how to reach that IP address) and "NS"
is the name of the Domain Name Server for that IP address.

HTH,

Rich





From m at netpro.to  Thu Oct 17 09:07:57 2002

auto-login"




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Oct 17 09:08:56 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 09:08:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Confusion
In-Reply-To: <3DAED7C9.1000408@attbi.com>
References: <3DAED7C9.1000408@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <41900.192.168.1.2.1034870936.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

Dirk;

The 2.4.x kernels allow you to mount a partition containing a filesystem
to more than one location. My guess is that you mounted /dev/hda5 to
/mnt/hda5 sometime in the past and forgot about it.

I have used the multi-mount feature more than once. It is a very handy
thing to have.

If you do not wish to see /mnt/hda5 listed like this, simply unmount it:

   cd /
   umount /mnt/hda5

If it will not unmount, see the man page for `fuser.' If normal `nice'
things to not unmount this filesystem, perform the following:

   fuser -km /mnt/hda5
   umount /mnt/hda5


-Cooper

> Now I'm confused.This is my output on RH 7.3;
>
> root]# ls -lah /home
> total 24k
> drwxr-xr-x    6 root     root         4.0k Oct  7 22:20 .

> drwxr-xr-x    3 booda    root         4.0k Oct 16 20:11 PHOTOS

>Terrel,
>
>  I thought that I had read all that on the man page. "IN" means Internet.
>"MX" is Mail Server, "SOA" is the Start of Authority (the highest level
>authoritative name server that knows how to reach that IP address) and "NS"
>is the name of the Domain Name Server for that IP address.
>

Okay, I installed Bynari. Wanted to try it out. Will have to wait.

Bynari seems to take over the whole machine. If you surf to your server,
i.e., 10.0.0.3, you get the (very nicely done) admin and config screens for
the Bynari server.

You also have to disable anything using FTP, HTTP, POP just to install it.
I'm starting to rething the whole thing.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 09:42:57 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 09:42:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <20021017092848.C8736@patch.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170936590.14207-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002 mikeraz at patch.com wrote:

> > * 1U  : looks cool, but loud since tiny fans spin so quickly
> 
> And as soon as you have more than three of them stacked up the cable
> management gets to be a huge PITA.  Especially if you have KVM
> cables running to each.

<heinleins-maxim>
  A server is only ready for deployment when it can be fully managed
  with only two cables -- power and serial console -- and fully 
  deployed with only three -- the first two plus ethernet.

  Any extra cables for things like redundant power, UPS warnings, or 
  multiple NICs are just gravy.

  <corrolary>
    GUI-bound servers are never ready for deployment.
  </corrolary>
</heinleins-maxim>

:-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

(under the floor).

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Oct 17 10:04:40 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 17 Oct 2002 10:04:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170659090.25631-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170659090.25631-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <867kgh809j.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>> If you can, you might think about getting a rack-mountable UPS to
>> stick at the bottom of your rack...

Rich>   I may bid on a 4U case with motherboard; it's atx form factor
Rich> for the mounts so it should be upgradable in the future. Could
Rich> put a couple of SCSI drives there and use it as the server for
Rich> our little LAN. Over time I can add 2U units as workstations and
Rich> firewall. I thought about the UPS problem, too. It would be nice
Rich> to remove three mini-/mid-/full tower cases and three UPSes from
Rich> the floor under the desks and simplify the wiring. I suppose
Rich> that I could velcro the DSL modem to the side of the rack,
Rich> too. :-)

A couple things I have "learned", rack-mount cases are *expensive*.
At least historically, they've been hard to find for less than
$150-250.  In comparison, a nice adequate mid-tower costs about $40.
Secondly, anything less than 3U means that you need to mount PCI cards
sideways with a little perpendicular adapter.  This naturally reduces
the utility of PCI slots.  I quote "learned" because I've never
actually brought myself to buy one, so my knowledge here is mostly
theoretical.

                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!''

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 10:07:29 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 10:07:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: Confusion
Message-ID: <3DAEEE51.5020102@attbi.com>

Thanks Paul.


The differing timestamps suggest that /home and /mnt/hda5 aren't the
same filesystem. The lack of a lost+found directory in /home suggests
that it's part of the root (/) filesystem, while /mnt/hda5 is a
separate partition.

What's the output of 'mount' without any arguments?


root]# mount
/dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
none on /proc type proc (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
/dev/hda1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda5 on /mnt/hda5 type ext3 (rw)
none on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)
none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
none on /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc type binfmt_mis




From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Oct 17 10:28:49 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 10:28:49 -0700

Message-ID: <20021017170711.DBAF235B47@ados.com>

-GLL



From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Oct 17 10:40:28 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 10:40:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RE: Confusion
In-Reply-To: <3DAEEE51.5020102@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210171026150.14207-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> What's the output of 'mount' without any arguments?
> 
> root]# mount
> /dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
> none on /proc type proc (rw)
> usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
> /dev/hda1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda5 on /mnt/hda5 type ext3 (rw)
> none on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)
> none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
> none on /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc type binfmt_mis

OK, here's more or less what I'd do if you want /dev/hda5 to become 
/home. Make sure everyone's logged out, then from the first virtual 
console

#
# this code is untested and provided without warranty :-)
#
# go to single-user mode
#
/sbin/telinit s
#
# test a sync; note that trailing slashes or lack thereof
# are crucial!
#
rsync -nav /home/ /mnt/hda5
#
# if everything looks kosher, then do a live sync
#
rsync -av /home/ /mnt/hda5
#
# get rid of competing /home candidates
#
umount /mnt/hda5
/bin/rm -rf /home/*
#
# edit the following fstab entry as needed
#
cat <<__eof__ >>/etc/fstab
/dev/hda5          /home           ext3   defaults     1 2
__eof__
#
# bring /dev/hda5 online for real
#
mount /home
#
# bring back to old runlevel
#
/sbin/telinit $(grep ':initdefault:' /etc/inittab | cut -d: -f2)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

	You are confusing the company (Echelon telco) with the code

have trademark issues with choosing a name that is already taken.

there's no conflict - at least with respect to trademark.
