From derek at infotects.com  Thu Oct 17 11:25:34 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 17 Oct 2002 11:25:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and WinME connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g>
References: <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g>
Message-ID: <1034879135.28786.462.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Stephen,

On Thu, 2002-10-17 at 02:48, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi all folks
> 
> I encountered another Samba and WinME connection problem both boxes are
> connected with a crossover cable.  Ping both boxes showed
> connected/connecting 
> 
> Name of WinME = IWILL
> share folder = Shared
> IP address = 192.168.0.1
> 2 NICs
> eth0   IP add = 192.168.0.1  connected to Samba server
> eth1   dynamic IP for broadband connection
> 
> Name of Samba server = M40G
> OS = RH8.0
> IP address = 192.168.0.2
> share folder = /test
> 2 NICs
> -connected to WinME
> -connected to broadband    dynamic IP
> 
> Workgroup = SEC
> 
> /etc/Samba/smb.conf  (BASIC)
> [global]
> workgroup = SEC 
> guest account = IWILL

This account needs to be a valid linux user (like nobody, which should
already be on your system), not the remote machine name.

> encrypt passwords = Yes
> hosts allow = yes
> security = share

 
Setting security to "user" will make trouble shooting a little easier,
then you will know what user is logged into the samba server.

What is the resolving order?  Did you set up (or designate) a wins
server?  What is the OS level?  Is there some sort of browse master (at
least local)?

> 
> [test] 
> comment = test share 
> path = /test
> browseable = yes 
> read only = no
> guest only = no 
> guest ok = yes 
> 

What about the /home entry?  If you change security to "user", the
/home/valid-linux-user directories become easy to access, as long as you
are logged into the Winbox as that linux user (and either use no
password, or the passwords should match on both machines).

It might help if you got rid of the second NIC in the Winbox, MS OS's
have a hard time keeping their routing tables straight.

Another piece of advise, reboot the Winbox frequently while you are
testing, often it is the only way to make it re-read the changes made on
the server.

Fear not, it will work.

Derek Loree




From derek at infotects.com  Thu Oct 17 11:35:05 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 17 Oct 2002 11:35:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Power-Off problem
In-Reply-To: <200210162209.37528.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017115336.02b80900@pop.net-yan.com>
	<3DAE3980.5090506@pacifier.com>  <200210162209.37528.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1034879706.28785.472.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-10-16 at 22:09, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> Does power management need to be enabled in the CMOS setup to get this 
> functionality to work? I can't recall and I don't want to reboot my box 
> to find out.
> 
> Tony

No, this is a function in the kernel, most of the time APM is enable in
the kernel, but is set to NOT turn on with boot, you can turn it on with
an "append apm=on" (or something like that) in lilo.conf, there must be
something similiar to that for GRUB.

There is another kernel option called "Real Mode power down" (or
something like that) that needs to be set for the system to actually
power itself down.  This may start to function when apm is turned on, it
may not.  If it doesn't, you will need to compile your own kernel to
turn it on.

HTH

Derek Loree

On Wed, 9 Oct 2002, MJ Coe wrote:

> Looking for folks interested in a community education course on:
>
>
> LTSP SYSTEM ADMINISTRATION
>
>
> WHY:  LTSP (Linux Terminal Server Project) might possibly be the
> education/workplace computing wave of the future.  In an effort to provide
> the Linux community with opportunities to learn more about LTSP
> installation, configuration, and system administration, this course is
> designed to provide hands-on practical LTSP lab/Linux server and networking
> experience.
>
> (Basically, this course is being coordinated by an individual disappointed
> with the lack of currently available LTSP and advanced Linux hands-on
> educational opportunities)
>
> WHO: Created in response to the needs of college students, K-12 public
> school educators/IT coordinators, and business sysadmins wishing to learn
> more about the capabilities and administration of LTSP labs.
>
> WHAT: Providing hands-on experience by building a working LTSP lab from
> scratch.  The intent is to provide each participant with their own LTSP
> computer/server and clients to set up and configure.  For a general course
> outline (still considered a working document) and list of preferred course
> prerequisites, see the following link:
>
> http://www.mjsunderground.net/LTSPCourseOutline.htm
>
>
> WHEN: Thursdays, Oct. 24 - Dec. 19, 6-9 p.m.  (8 classes, one class per
> week -- no class on Thanksgiving).  If class doesn't start until Oct. 31,
> there will only be 7 classes.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct 17 16:14:22 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 16:14:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210161637450.23228-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170630210.14207-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <20021017092848.C8736@patch.com>
Message-ID: <3DAF444E.4010104@dimstar.net>

mikeraz at patch.com wrote:

>On Thu, Oct 17, 2002 at 06:35:44AM -0700, Paul Heinlein typed:
>  
>
>>FWIW: Here's my take on the various xU sizes:
>>
>>* 1U  : looks cool, but loud since tiny fans spin so quickly
>>    
>>
>
>And as soon as you have more than three of them stacked up the
>cable management gets to be a huge PITA.  Especially if you have
>KVM cables running to each.
>
>  
>
I prefer 2U cases, since it at least allows a couple of add-on cards, 
which reduces costs. I found some really good 2U chassis at 
www.servercase.com. Seemed to be good folks to work with, even when I 
ordered 40 of one model at once.  2U is also good if you have to 
retrofit a slot 1/A processor motherboard. These won't fit in a 1U chassis.

If you don't want to deal with riser cards, then you either have to have 
all your peripherals on the motherboard, or go at least 3U to allow use 
of the slots in your motherboard.




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct 17 16:27:53 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 16:27:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210170659090.25631-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <867kgh809j.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <3DAF4779.2020100@dimstar.net>

Russell Senior wrote:

>A couple things I have "learned", rack-mount cases are *expensive*.
>At least historically, they've been hard to find for less than
>$150-250.  In comparison, a nice adequate mid-tower costs about $40.
>
The trade off being space saved. In a standard 44U (7 foot) rack, you 
can fit a max of 8 of those mid tower chassis. When doing this, I used 
2U for the UPS.

If I put 4U chassis in there, I can fit 10 machines in the same space.

If I put 2U chassis in there, I can fit 20 machines in there. (Need 3U 
for the UPS now)

Chassis have dropped markedly in the last couple of years. When I did my 
first 4U chassis, I opted for some that were $169 each, with 300Watt 
power supplies from Enlight. That was about 2 years ago.

Earlier this year, I outfitted 40 machines, and put them in 2U chassis 
that only cost $175, with 350 watt power supplies. These came with 3 
slot riser cards that actually plugged into three pci slots instead of 
simply extending one slot. As a comparison, when I bought the 4U chassis 
above, the least expensive 2U chassis I could find was $399. 

>Secondly, anything less than 3U means that you need to mount PCI cards
>sideways with a little perpendicular adapter.  This naturally reduces
>the utility of PCI slots.
>
Most 2U chassis come with a way to mount at least 2 PCI cards. BUT, you 
can't use the AGP  slot, so one of those PCI slots will be your video, 
unless it's built in, or you use serial.

Russ





From mike at computer-arts.net  Thu Oct 17 17:12:55 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 17:12:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Driver question: 0x8000 in "file" struct
Message-ID: <3DAF5207.C919EE02@computer-arts.net>

Kernel 2.4.9-34

In the driver code:

int open(struct inode *inode, struct file *fp)
{
    printk("mydrv: fp->f_mode=0x%x, fp->f_flags=0x%x\n",
           fp->f_mode, fp->f_flags);
}

In f_flags, I'm seeing the values I expect, such as O_RDONLY,
O_WRONLY, O_APPEND, and so on. But I'm also seeing the bit 0x8000
set. Can anyone point me to the definition of this bit?  I can't
find it.

The 0x8000 is not there when I open the device with my own code,
but when I use either the "cat" or "echo" commands on the device
the 0x8000 shows up (in addition to the bits I expected.)

-Mike

From robbert at vafam.com  Thu Oct 17 18:41:53 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: 17 Oct 2002 18:41:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partition Size
In-Reply-To: <200210171824.39763.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0210171432540.7446-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com> 
	<200210171824.39763.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
Message-ID: <1034905314.2075.7.camel@linux>

Is there a way to change the size of a partition.  More specifically, I
am trying to upgrade to the new kernal via Up2Date.  I am getting a
message stating that my /boot partition needs to be at least 3MB (it's
under 3 by a little bit).  Is there a way to increase the size of this
partition.  Obviously, the space will come from another partition (I
have 85% free on my /home partition).






From fixin at peak.org  Thu Oct 17 20:17:50 2002
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 20:17:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210172008070.22658-100000@tpol.peak.org>

I'm building a web interface for a series of tools, written in perl,
that build data files for a PalmOS game (like Scrabble(tm)) my kids
and I designed and wrote for fun.  Users will upload text files, and a
bunch of CGI scripts will compress the files into Palm databases and
return them to the user.  I'll need to generate web pages, keep track
of state as a session progresses, and manage large files on disk.  No
database access, though.  And no interaction with other sites for
credit cards or what have you.

I've never done anything like this before, but I know perl, and there
seem to be a lot of useful modules (CGI.pm among them) for this sort
of thing.  But a friend who does web apps semi-commercially recommends
PHP -- though he doesn't know perl and so can't exactly compare the
two.

Anybody out there care to make a recommendation or suggest somewhere
to explore the question.

Perhaps I should mention that this is strictly for fun.  I want to
provide a service to people quickly and effeciently and then get back
to writing apps in C/C++.  I'm not expecting to do this
professionally.

Thanks,

--Eric House

******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *
******************************************************************************




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Thu Oct 17 21:01:38 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 21:01:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Partition Size
In-Reply-To: <1034905314.2075.7.camel@linux>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210171432540.7446-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
        <200210171824.39763.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
        <1034905314.2075.7.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <65102.12.231.181.15.1034913698.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Robbert van Andel said:
> Is there a way to change the size of a partition.

parted

http://www.gnu.org/software/parted/parted.html

I'm sure everyone here will agree that resizing partitions can be dicey,
so good backups are highly recommended, if you like your data.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu Oct 17 21:07:54 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 21:07:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210172008070.22658-100000@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017205418.00a7db90@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

You'll find partisans for every possible approach.  Each will be right, to 
some extent.

Which leads me to recommend my language of choice: Python.  Web-based apps 
are what I do and Python is just about all I use.  It is about as intuitive 
a programming language as one could ask for, and far more versitile than 
PHP.  And if you're programming for the Palm, there's even a port of Python 
available for that platform: http://pippy.sourceforge.net/ .  It's a 
particularly good language for beginners and kids.

That said, there are many here who will vouch for Perl.  Perl and Python 
are very different languages, but each has broad applicibility and 
usefulness beyond CGI.  Either would make a great choice.

Zope might be particularly worth looking into if you're putting together 
any more than a few pages.  It makes sessions and state maintenance about 
as easy as possible and does heaps more besides.  It can be extended with 
either Python or Perl, though its support for Python is far better.

IMO, YMMV, etc.

Dylan

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> You'll find partisans for every possible approach.  Each will be right, to
> some extent.
>
> Which leads me to recommend my language of choice: Python.  Web-based apps
> are what I do and Python is just about all I use.  It is about as intuitive

Why Python, if I may ask? The reason I ask is because I've been curious
about Python, but I was never sure whether to spend the time to learn
it or not.

I'm a Java programmer professionally. I have used (do use) a variety of
languages in my career including Perl, ASP, JavaScript, SQL, C, C++ and
now I'm doing PHP in my spare time for personal websites. So I've had no
need yet to learn Python, but I've been curious.

Reason I ask is because if the reason to use it is that it's easier then
that's not *super* compelling to me since I already know other languages.
But if it's something else, then, well... I'd be interested.

Preston




From bsr at spek.org  Thu Oct 17 21:48:36 2002
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: 17 Oct 2002 21:48:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210172008070.22658-100000@tpol.peak.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210172008070.22658-100000@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <1034916516.6750.7416.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Thu, 2002-10-17 at 20:17, Eric House wrote:
> I've never done anything like this before, but I know perl, and there
> seem to be a lot of useful modules (CGI.pm among them) for this sort
> of thing.  But a friend who does web apps semi-commercially recommends
> PHP -- though he doesn't know perl and so can't exactly compare the
> two.
> 
> Anybody out there care to make a recommendation or suggest somewhere
> to explore the question.
> 
> Perhaps I should mention that this is strictly for fun.  I want to
> provide a service to people quickly and effeciently and then get back
> to writing apps in C/C++.  I'm not expecting to do this
> professionally.

I'm sure you'll get replies saying to use <insert language here>, and
just about any language can do the job.  However, since you already know
perl, the tools you want to provide a web interface to are already
written in perl, and you want to get back to programming C/C++ apps,
don't waste your time learning the idiosyncrasies of a new language and
just use perl.

--Brent



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Oct 17 21:57:41 2002

Along these lines, any pointers to the 30,000' view of all the web 
languages?  I subscribe to both Linux Magazine and Linux Journal and they 
regularly feature what is supposedly the best thing since last weeks sliced 
bread.  I usually skip those parts since I'm not a web developer (whatever 
that means anymore), but if were to learn a new language, how does one

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Thu Oct 17 22:11:04 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 22:11:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
In-Reply-To: <3DAF94C5.6090902@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210172205340.13968-100000@serpentor.cobrala>

On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Depends, I know and I can't define what my intentions are either.  But I
> can't even say what PHP is.  Is it an API for CGI?  Alternative? Etc...would
> love to see a breakdown of the big picture.  Python, Lamp, PHP, PCP, LSD,
> they all sound great, where to start?

For my money PHP is VERY handy. It's sort of syntactically similar to C,
C++ and the like so learning it won't hurt you down the road to know it.
You can use it for web programming AND for scripting on the console.
Recently I wanted to write a script in a pinch to use various console
tools in the service of donwloading a radio show in real audio. PHP fit
the bill perfectly. Quick and easy.

Preston




From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu Oct 17 22:35:48 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 22:35:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210172113580.13864-100000@serpentor.cobrala
 >
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017205418.00a7db90@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017222348.00a714f8@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

At 09:17 PM 10/17/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Why Python, if I may ask? The reason I ask is because I've been curious
>about Python, but I was never sure whether to spend the time to learn
>it or not.

It won't take much of your time if you're an experienced programmer.  If 
you're pretty well-versed in the use of basic structures like linked lists 
and hash tables, Python's built-in objects will be second nature.  The 
toughest thing about it is it's *very* OO.  Everything is an object... 
functions, files, properties, methods, etc.


>Reason I ask is because if the reason to use it is that it's easier then
>that's not *super* compelling to me since I already know other languages.
>But if it's something else, then, well... I'd be interested.

It's easier in a uncluttered-syntax, easy-to-read sense, not in a "for 
dummies" sense.  My #2 reason for using Python is that I can write a lot of 
functioning code quickly.  My #1 reason is that I can look at that code 6 
months later and still see how it works.

If you'd like a more thorough (and partisan) argument in favor of Python, 
you might enjoy Eric Raymond's classic rant: 
http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=3882

There's also a lot of interesting Python work going on in Portland.  For 
more info on that, check out PorPIG (the Portland Python Interest Group): 
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/porpig

HTH,

Dylan




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Oct 17 23:22:49 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 23:22:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app? (Ruby?)
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021017222348.00a714f8@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210172244440.11761-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> At 09:17 PM 10/17/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> >Why Python, if I may ask? The reason I ask is because I've been curious
> >about Python, but I was never sure whether to spend the time to learn
> >it or not.
>
> It won't take much of your time if you're an experienced programmer.  If
> you're pretty well-versed in the use of basic structures like linked lists
> and hash tables, Python's built-in objects will be second nature.  The
> toughest thing about it is it's *very* OO.  Everything is an object...
> functions, files, properties, methods, etc.

At the risk of starting _Language Wars_, I can recommend Ruby
(http://www.ruby-lang.org  http://www.rubycentral.com ) for very much the
same reasons with some advantages for Perl programmers:
*Everything is an object - even regexes and numbers:
/^SomeString/.type #=> RegExp
3.times { |i| print i } #=> prints 123 (example of sending a message to a
                        # FixNum object
*Built-in classes are always open meaning that you can add methods to
built-in types.  Example:

class String
  def encrypt
    #apply some sort of encryption routine to the string
  end
end

After that all string objects will reply to the encrypt message:
myString = "This String"
myString.encrypt
(you can also add methods to single instances of a class.)
[Ooops... the String class already has a crypt method, so no need to add
an encrypt method.]

*Iterators - a very cool feature.  Python has recently added iterators,
but since they've been in Ruby from the start they tend to be well
integrated into Ruby's class libraries.

*borrows the idea of sigils from Perl, but uses them much more sparingly
and (I think) to good effect(to indicate scoping).  For example, instance
variables of a class start with '@'.  This makes it easy to spot your
instance variables in your class.  Also globals start with '$' which also
makes it easy to spot them (and get rid of them ;-)

Ruby offers the following advantages for Perl programmers:
*Easy to move from Perl -> Ruby.  I did Perl for several years.  After I
had done OO Perl for a while I decided that it was just too ugly.  I
picked up Ruby and was productive in a matter of a day or two.
*No indentation as syntax issues.  I did try Python prior to trying Ruby,
but I really couldn't get comfortable with the indentation thing.


>
> >Reason I ask is because if the reason to use it is that it's easier then
> >that's not *super* compelling to me since I already know other languages.
> >But if it's something else, then, well... I'd be interested.
>
> It's easier in a uncluttered-syntax, easy-to-read sense, not in a "for
> dummies" sense.  My #2 reason for using Python is that I can write a lot of
> functioning code quickly.  My #1 reason is that I can look at that code 6
> months later and still see how it works.
>

Yeah, that can be a problem in Perl.

Anyway, I tend to find that Ruby is like a much cleaner Perl (it's been
called Perl's younger, prettier sister) and the whole system (by that I
mean the language and it's associated libraries) is just well designed and
just tends to feel like it as you work with it.  I also find that my
productivity in Ruby is greater than it was in Perl (don't get me wrong, I
really _used_ to like Perl a lot).

I really don't have any web experience, though, so I can't give you a lot
of advice in that department.  There are CGI modules and web application
frameworks available as well as a very nice XML parser (REXML).

Phil




From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Thu Oct 17 23:44:48 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 23:44:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Bind Denying transfers
Message-ID: <1742.192.168.1.253.1034923488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

My primary nameserver is not allowing a slave to get transfers from it.
I just recently moved from mandrake 8.2 to 9.0 and have shorewall running.
I assume that since its getting to the /var/log/syslog that its getting
through the firewall, so I can eliminate that possibility.

this is what the slave service is giving me as a result of the transfer
failure:
Reason for Last Failure:  Error 5 returned for AXFR query

My /var/log/syslog shows:
Oct 17 23:31:52 dns named[1246]: client 204.74.104.97#36486: zone transfer
'domainName.com/IN' denied

some sniplets from /etc/named.conf:

acl secondary.com { 204.74.104.97; };

zone "domainName.com" {
        type master;
        file "/var/named/domainName.com.hosts";
        allow-transfer{ secondary.com; };
        allow-query{ any; };
};

is there anything else that I am missing to get this to work?
When I was using Mandrake 8.2 (not sure what bind version), I had no
problems like this.

My current bind version is: bind 9.2.1-4mdk

any advice would be greatly appreciated.

-Robby

From jamesf at efn.org  Fri Oct 18 00:32:34 2002
From: jamesf at efn.org (James)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 00:32:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Security violation: Relay access denied
Message-ID: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0210180029330.19313-100000@garcia.efn.org>

I am using an old version of Mandrake (7.0) as a web server, and I am
using postfix.  I was just able to check my logs for today, and starting
at around 7:00 this evening I started getting huge "relay access
denied" security violations.  It looks like someone is trying to use my
server as a relay spam mailer since every 15 minutes there are about 100
relay attempts which are denied by my postfix.  

I've seen this a couple of times before, but once the relay access was
denied, the flooding usually stopped within a minute.  This time, though,
it's been going on for the last 3 hours non-stop.  Here is an example of
the security violations list:

Security Violations
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Oct 17 22:30:02 postfix/smtpd[28173]: reject: RCPT from
unknown[202.97.133.78]: 554 <boeckes at aol.com>: Recipient address
rejected: Relay access denied; from=<young98231580 at ecx.net>
to=<boeckes at aol.com>
Oct 17 22:30:03 postfix/smtpd[28008]: reject: RCPT from
200-4.cable.guam.net[202.128.24.200]: 554 <jalfajr at aol.com>: Recipient
address rejected: Relay access denied; from=<young95293792 at ecx.net>
to=<jalfajr at aol.com>

Oct 17 22:35:42
postfix/smtp[28256]: 95C3179825: to=<shirleyvera at aol.com>,
relay=mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.136.121], delay=7209, status=deferred
(host mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.136.121] said: 421 SERVICE NOT AVAILABLE,
TEMPORARY DNS FAILURE)
Oct 17 22:35:42
postfix/smtp[28253]: E5AC17981E: to=<buildabike at aol.com>,
relay=mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.138.89], delay=7226, status=deferred
(host mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.138.89] said: 421 SERVICE NOT AVAILABLE,
TEMPORARY DNS FAILURE)
===================================================================

That's just a very tiny bit of the thousands of these I've already had in
the last few hours.  What I want to know is, why does this continue even
when the relay access is denied, and also, "TEMPORARY DNS FAILURE".. is
this a denial of service attack on my server?

I'm building a different server that I will have the latest Mandrake
running, but for now, I don't want to upgrade my current older version
because if something goes wrong, I've lost the server and I can't have it
go down for more than a day.  So for now I just want to figure out how to
stop this current relay attempt on my system.

james

From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Fri Oct 18 07:52:18 2002

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Oct 18 07:59:19 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 18 Oct 2002 07:59:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PHP or perl for web app?
References: <mailman.1034911093.8472.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <864rbj94jc.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Eric" == Eric House <fixin at peak.org> writes:

Eric> I've never done anything like this before, but I know perl, and there
Eric> seem to be a lot of useful modules (CGI.pm among them) for this sort
Eric> of thing.  But a friend who does web apps semi-commercially recommends
Eric> PHP -- though he doesn't know perl and so can't exactly compare the
Eric> two.

I'm going to stay out of this, except to say that when you compare
"Perl" to PHP, be sure you are comparing a Perl web application
system, like Apache::Template and Template Toolkit running under
mod_perl, not just Perl-as-CGI.

Too many people compare Perl-CGI to $web_language_X, and discover
that indeed $web_language_X is better, for some definition of better.

stonehenge.com runs Apache::Template
Slashcode (slashdot and friends) is Template Toolkit based.

It's quite a good system.  See perl.apache.org for "why mod_perl"
and tt2.org for details about Template.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

  I just re-installed acroread-5.0.6 but I cannot print a form from within
it. The form prints just fine from xpdf, but I cannot fill in text in that
application.

  This had worked before, and other pdf docs print just fine from this
version, but not this one-pager. Filled in or not, it sends the job to the

back to comatose mode.

it?

Rich




From plug at magnetinternet.com  Fri Oct 18 09:03:52 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 09:03:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Bind Denying transfers
In-Reply-To: <1960.208.151.243.122.1034952738.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <1742.192.168.1.253.1034923488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210180548250.30434-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
        <1542.192.168.1.253.1034946846.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <1960.208.151.243.122.1034952738.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <49240.63.105.24.103.1034957032.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

zone "mydomain.com" {
  type master;
  file "/var/named/mydomain.com.hosts";
  also-notify {
    x.x.x.x;
    };
  };

Is what I have for all my domains on my primary server (names and IPs
changed to protect the innocent)...and they all work.  Bind 9 (slackware
package).  I think it's more of a push thing than a pull...

P.S.  I dunno if you use it or not but webmin has a nice BIND admin
interface...that's what I use.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Fri Oct 18 09:21:34 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 09:21:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Bind Denying transfers
In-Reply-To: <1960.208.151.243.122.1034952738.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <1742.192.168.1.253.1034923488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210180548250.30434-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
        <1542.192.168.1.253.1034946846.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <1960.208.151.243.122.1034952738.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <49254.63.105.24.103.1034958094.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

zone "mydomain.com" {
  type slave;
  file "/var/named/domain.com.hosts";
  masters {
    y.y.y.y;
    };
  allow-transfer {
    y.y.y.y;
    };
  };

Should have included this in the other e-mail.  Here's what's on the
backup server as the slave entry for the same domain....the y.y.y.y is the
IP of the primary server...

Matt King

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Oct 18 09:22:46 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 09:22:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tagged Message Delivery Agent (TMDA)
Message-ID: <20021018092246.A18308@kippered.herring.org>

Anyone tried and/or have any opinions about this...

http://tmda.net/

It certainly looks interesting...

* MTA independent (supports qmail, Postfix, Exim, Courier, and Sendmail). 
* Integrated "blacklist" and "whitelist" functionality. 
* Optional automatic whitelisting of confirmed senders. 
* Smart auto-responding -- won't reply to a mailing list or bounce message.
  Includes auto-response rate limiting to prevent mail loops. 
* Client-side support for both Unix and non-Unix (e.g, Outlook, Eudora,
  Mozilla) mail clients.
* Package installation available for Linux, and Free/Net/OpenBSD.
* Supports vpopmail and vmailmgr.
* Flexible filtering language allowing fine-grained control over how
  incoming and outgoing mail is disposed of.
* Local mail delivery, including qmail-style Maildirs, mboxrd-format mboxes,
  program (pipe) delivery, and forward to an e-mail address.
* Supports DBM and CDB databases, including on-demand auto-regeneration of
  DB files. 
* Optional logging of incoming and outgoing messages.
* Easy customization of confirmation messages through templates.
* Use of HMAC (Hashed Message Authentication Codes) for "cookie" generation
  and verification


Sandy
--

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Oct 18 09:59:22 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 09:59:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Security violation: Relay access denied
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0210180029330.19313-100000@garcia.efn.org>
References: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0210180029330.19313-100000@garcia.efn.org>
Message-ID: <200210180959.22355.aschlemm@attbi.com>

While I don't run an open mail server, I have had cases of being 
severely port probed by the same system over and over again. In these 
cases I have generally tweaked my firewall rules to quietly deny any 
and all incoming packets from the IP address of the system in question. 
This kept my syslog from filling up with unnecessary messages.

>From the looks of it is would seem that some luser is attempting to 
relay email to users at AOL through your server. It may be that 
whatever means the luser is using doesn't doing much in the way of 
error detection so the sending process appears to be completely 
oblivious to the fact that no mail is being relayed at all.

Tony

On Friday 18 October 2002 00:32 am, James wrote:
> I am using an old version of Mandrake (7.0) as a web server, and I am
> using postfix.  I was just able to check my logs for today, and
> starting at around 7:00 this evening I started getting huge "relay
> access denied" security violations.  It looks like someone is trying
> to use my server as a relay spam mailer since every 15 minutes there
> are about 100 relay attempts which are denied by my postfix.
>
> I've seen this a couple of times before, but once the relay access
> was denied, the flooding usually stopped within a minute.  This time,
> though, it's been going on for the last 3 hours non-stop.  Here is an
> example of the security violations list:
>
> Security Violations
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> Oct 17 22:30:02 postfix/smtpd[28173]: reject: RCPT from
> unknown[202.97.133.78]: 554 <boeckes at aol.com>: Recipient address
> rejected: Relay access denied; from=<young98231580 at ecx.net>
> to=<boeckes at aol.com>
> Oct 17 22:30:03 postfix/smtpd[28008]: reject: RCPT from
> 200-4.cable.guam.net[202.128.24.200]: 554 <jalfajr at aol.com>:
> Recipient address rejected: Relay access denied;
> from=<young95293792 at ecx.net> to=<jalfajr at aol.com>
>
> Oct 17 22:35:42
> postfix/smtp[28256]: 95C3179825: to=<shirleyvera at aol.com>,
> relay=mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.136.121], delay=7209,
> status=deferred (host mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.136.121] said: 421
> SERVICE NOT AVAILABLE, TEMPORARY DNS FAILURE)
> Oct 17 22:35:42
> postfix/smtp[28253]: E5AC17981E: to=<buildabike at aol.com>,
> relay=mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.138.89], delay=7226, status=deferred
> (host mailin-02.mx.aol.com[64.12.138.89] said: 421 SERVICE NOT
> AVAILABLE, TEMPORARY DNS FAILURE)
> ===================================================================
>
> That's just a very tiny bit of the thousands of these I've already
> had in the last few hours.  What I want to know is, why does this
> continue even when the relay access is denied, and also, "TEMPORARY
> DNS FAILURE".. is this a denial of service attack on my server?
>
> I'm building a different server that I will have the latest Mandrake
> running, but for now, I don't want to upgrade my current older
> version because if something goes wrong, I've lost the server and I
> can't have it go down for more than a day.  So for now I just want to
> figure out how to stop this current relay attempt on my system.
>
> james

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Oct 18 10:06:57 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 18 Oct 2002 10:06:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and WinME connection problem
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021018141948.00a9d010@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g> <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g> 
	<5.1.1.6.0.20021018141948.00a9d010@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1034960818.25544.36.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Stephen,

On Fri, 2002-10-18 at 00:18, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi Derek,
> 
> Thanks for your response.
> 
> At 11:25 AM 2002/10/17 -0700, Derek Loree wrote
> 
> >- snip -
> 
> The revised  smb.conf  is as follow:
> 
> [global]
> 
> workgroup = Mshome
> guest account = satimis
> encrypt passwords = yes
> hosts allow = yes
> security = user
> 
> [test]
> comment = share
> path = /test
> browseable = yes
> read only = no
> guest only = no
> guest ok = yes
> 
> [home]
> path = /home/satimis
> 
Did you restart samba after making these changes (something like
"/etc/init.d/samba restart")?
> 
> 
> I reset WinME box by performing following steps
> 
> 1) Removed all old passwords
> 
> 2) Removed the  "network folder" with
> 
> Start -> Run - Regedit -> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE -> Network
> 
I seriously doubt that this had the intended effect, removing the folder
from the desktop doesn't reset any of the network services or protocols,
it just makes it tougher to find them.

> 3) Rebooted WinME to enter new user and new password
> 
> User = AministratorME
> 
My advise was to login to the ME box as a known linux user (like
"satimis").

> 4) Start "Home Network Wizard"
> 
> (Remark: I was not allowed to enter "SEC" as workgroup.  I must select 
> "MSHOME" as workgroup.  If I entered "SEC" as workgroup, after roboot WinME 
> did not appear in the network)

Sounds like M$ lost track of reality again.
> 
> 
> Hardware
> 1) Removed the NIC for broadband connection
> 2) From
> 
> Neighbour networking -> properties
> removed all corresponding   NIC adapter, NetBEUI and TCP/IP

Dump NetBEUI altogether, if you have any other network protocols, the
Winbox may (or may not, it is not very predictable) try to use that for
SMB communication.  Stick to just TCP/IP, double check your address.
> 
> Identification changed to
> workgroup = MSHOME
> 
> Rebooted WinME, new workgroup "MSHOME" found together with the old 
> workgroup "SEC" in the network.  But RH8.0 (Samba serve) could not 
> connected to the network nor appear there.  Neither WinME could be mounted 
> from RH8.0

This is because the Winbox is acting as the "Browse Master" and has
cached information about SEC.  It'll go away in a day or two.
> 
> After playing several times including rebooting WinME the workgroup 
> "MSHOME" disappeared from neighbour networking.  Reset "home networking 
> wizard" could not solve the problem,  But "search computer" still could 
> find WinME either with its computer name or its IP address.
> 
> I could not move any further and I am at a loss what is its cause
> 
> 
> >What is the resolving order?  Did you set up (or designate) a wins
> >server?  What is the OS level?  Is there some sort of browse master (at
> >least local)?
> 
> Sorry I don't catch your question.  I just connect a WinME box to a RH8.0 
> box using Samba for files sharing.

Those are settings in samba.conf, they have an affect on the "election"
that SMB enabled computers hold every 15 min.  You need to have an OS
level of 2 or greater to have the linux box win the election (OS level
greater than 128 if your battling Win2000 server or any version of XP). 
I highly recommend setting this up, linux makes a much better "Browse
Master" than any M$ product (unless your battling a domain controller,
in which case give up, it will win in the end -- though it may take a
few months).
> 
> The funny thing is, last time I succeeded using this WinME box (almost same 
> settings) to connect to another Linux box (RH7.3) also using Samba for 
> testing files sharing.  It worked without much setup and difficulties also 
> with 2 NICs.

Yep, that is the way it is supposed to work.
> 
> >  - snip -
> >Another piece of advise, reboot the Winbox frequently while you are
> >testing, often it is the only way to make it re-read the changes made on
> >the server.
> 
> This is the question.  If I reboot WinME with a crossover cable connected 
> to RH8.0, occasionally it is hard to boot.  If with the cable removed then 
> it defeats the purpose of reboot.

If you have static address assignments, then whether or not the cable is
connected really shouldn't change the boot up behavior (unless you have
a flaky NIC).  I think you've changed the ME configuration too many
times, and the OS is getting more unstable, you might want to
re-install.
> 
> I am going to connect RH80, the Samba Server, to a Win98 box with the 
> target to find out whether its settings having problem, also with a 
> crossover cable for connection.

This might behave a little better.  IMHO Win98 is more stable than ME,
in fact an avalanche is more stable than ME, but that is just MHO.

> 
> I am going to reply your comment in another box, hoping that the thread can 
> still be traced
> 
Good Luck

Derek Loree

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Oct 18 10:36:59 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 10:36:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] An acroread problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181011400.30293-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181011400.30293-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200210181036.59323.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 18 October 2002 10:14, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Bill Barry wrote:
> > Fill in the form with acroread
> > print it to a file
> > open it with ghostview
> > print it.
> > ask adobe for the source to acroread so you can fix it :)
>
> Bill,
>
>   I tried printing it to a file and printing it directly. Same results as
> trying to print from within acroread. Didn't try gv.
>
>   But, it is, I believe, a problem with the form. I just re-installed
> acroread-4.0.5, repointed /usr/bin/acroread to that version's wrapper
> script, and the filled-in form printed just fine. So, I conclude that
> there's something in a form generated under acrobat-4 that no longer works
> under Acrobat-5. Isn't this the Redmond model?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Rich

The Linux installation of Acroread is a mess. They don't seem overly concerned 
with details.  I just triumphed over a new installation of 5.06 that did not 
even want to start: "Warning: charset "UTF-8" not supported, using 
"ISO8859-1".

Now I don't know if RH 8 is doing something goofy, or Adobe, and I'm getting 
to the point where having to track down and fix these kinds of issues is a 
seriously irritating waste of time. I found the fix, the acroread script must 
be edited thusly, add:

LANG=en_US
 export LANG

to the beginning of the script.

I also had a similar printing problem- Acroread was trying to call up a 
printing subsystem that was not installed. Take a good look at the printer 
dialogue when it comes up, maybe it will be that simple.

Maybe.
-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Red Hat 8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From jgraham at pdx.edu  Fri Oct 18 10:36:32 2002
From: jgraham at pdx.edu (jGraham)
Date: 18 Oct 2002 10:36:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple Daily PLUG list?
Message-ID: <1034962592.2024.14.camel@Dark>

Hey, i'm new here (thanks for the great LUG) and was wondering why the
daily archives arrive multiple times a day.  That is it's not a daily
list, but 4 or so each with 15 (or so) messages.
thanks
JGraham






From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Oct 18 10:46:14 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 10:46:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple Daily PLUG list?
In-Reply-To: <1034962592.2024.14.camel@Dark>; from jgraham@pdx.edu on Fri, Oct 18, 2002 at 10:36:32AM -0700
References: <1034962592.2024.14.camel@Dark>
Message-ID: <20021018104614.A20403@patch.com>

The digest form of lists can be configured to send out a digest whenever
X number of messages or Y number of bytes of message are queued up. 

When the size of the digest-to-be passes the threshold a digest is sent out.

This lightens the burst load on the server and the reader.

On Fri, Oct 18, 2002 at 10:36:32AM -0700, jGraham typed:
> Hey, i'm new here (thanks for the great LUG) and was wondering why the

> list, but 4 or so each with 15 (or so) messages.
> thanks
> JGraham

Ralph,

  In CUPS I have redefined the laser jet from laser5 to both laser5_ps and
laser5_non_ps. The former prints duplex and the latter prints simplex. I
specified laser5_ps in both acroread-4 and acroread-5. It worked only with
the former.

Rich

From revans at e-z.net  Fri Oct 18 12:29:15 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)

    Win98replacing WimME)
In-Reply-To: <1034945512.1867.68.camel@localhost.m40g>
References: <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g> <1034848094.2187.8.camel@m40g>
    <5.1.1.6.0.20021018141948.00a9d010@pop.net-yan.com>
    <1034945512.1867.68.camel@localhost.m40g>
Message-ID: <20021018192837.DTDD22897.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@linux>

A person on another list was having difficulties getting Samba to work on RH
8.0. It turned out the issue was that he had iptables blocking the ports needed
by Samba. I don't know if this was a default or if he configured the rules this
way.

Thank you
Russell

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Fri Oct 18 13:19:25 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 14:19:25 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?
Message-ID: <3DB06CCD.9E85DDDD@gisnet.com>

After fighting all day trying to install Red Hat 7.1 on a brand
new Athlon XP1800 and having IDE bus problems (drivers don't seem
to work), we were wondering if it would be worth just snagging
the $150 RedHat Professional 8.0 CD set from CompUSA (y'know
support the good guys and have it NOW rather than slooowly
teasing off the FTP archives.)

We do want server capability, but are the improvements worth the
price? Is it going to install on this hardware anyway? Any
caveats about doing this that anyone here is aware of?

TIA,

- Bill Thoen



From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Oct 18 13:29:22 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 13:29:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?
References: <3DB06CCD.9E85DDDD@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <3DB06F22.5010603@sun.com>

If you want my opinion, do NOT install anything from RH on a .0 release. 
  History has shown that they're usually horribly broken, unstable and 
generally unusable unless you *like* living on the bleeding edge.

If you're stuck on Redhat, I'd suggest going with 7.3, since it's on the 
third (fourth?) iteration, it should be more mature and stable.

However, if you're installing a server system, why go with Redhat at 
all?  IMHO, Redhat and Mandrake are the 'eye candy' distributions.  They 
specifically tweak the system to make it look as pretty as possible on 
the desktop.  Who cares if you have a pretty desktop on a server?  All 
three of my server-type systems run headless, so no need for X or any 
other desktop-related items.  That said, I would suggest Debian, simply 
because it is much easier to keep on top of updates - which, on a 
headless server system, is key.

Also - you might try linux googling for 'Athlon IDE problem', perhaps 
adding your chipset version in there for good measure.  Chances are, 
someone, somewhere, has run into the same problem and has posted a fix 
for it on the web.  I was having a horrible time putting a 2940U2W into 
my AMD/VIA KT133 system until I found out that ONE bios setting caused 
the whole thing.  After I flipped the bit on that setting, it worked 
flawlessly.

I personally wouldn't patronize either RH or CompUSA.  Find a local 
retailer that sells Linux CD's for cheap, and then donate directly to 
your favorite distribution.

But that's just me.

-R

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Oct 18 13:41:33 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 13:41:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?
In-Reply-To: <3DB06CCD.9E85DDDD@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181336220.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> After fighting all day trying to install Red Hat 7.1 on a brand new
> Athlon XP1800 and having IDE bus problems (drivers don't seem to
> work), we were wondering if it would be worth just snagging the $150
> RedHat Professional 8.0 CD set from CompUSA (y'know support the good
> guys and have it NOW rather than slooowly teasing off the FTP
> archives.)
> 
> We do want server capability, but are the improvements worth the
> price? Is it going to install on this hardware anyway? Any caveats
> about doing this that anyone here is aware of?

It depends on how you'll be deploying the box. If you're mostly 
interested in providing network services (http, dns, etc), I'd stick 
with Red Hat 7.3 (and its subsequent updates).

If this will be someone's desktop machine, and you're interested in 
the latest GNOME and KDE releases, then 8.0 offers a better solution.

A couple things worth knowing about 8.0:

* it ships with gcc 3.2, which produces binaries that are incompatible 
  with prior gcc dynamic libaries

* it ships with Apache 2.x, which may or may not be what you want

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> out.  So if you don't pay, and the servers are busy, you are SOL.

> They may have changed that policy since I heard that.  I don't know.

  Nope. Same ol' policy.

  I'm running apt-rpm. Eventually most of the updates make it to the
tuxfamily.org repositories. Those that don't, I get from rpmfind.net.

Rich




From fmann at aracnet.com  Fri Oct 18 15:21:48 2002
From: fmann at aracnet.com (Floyd Mann)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 15:21:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021018-155620-0003@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181515060.19041-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

> How many command does it require?

One.

Regarding the pricing, a Red Hat Network subscription is 60 bucks a
machine, I believe.  There is some kind of premium service that costs
more if you want all the bells and whistles.

The company I just started working for has been using up2date to keep
a handful of Linux boxes running happily w/ no linux guru on staff and
 just the cheapo subscription.  I was suprised to see how well it works.

-F

> On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Richard Langis wrote:

> > top of updates - which, on a headless server system, is key.

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Fri Oct 18 15:32:02 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 16:32:02 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] up2date - is it worth it? (was: Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth
 $150?)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210181351560.8597-100000@lukem.com> <3DB07788.8030309@sun.com>
Message-ID: <3DB08BE2.66EF51A0@gisnet.com>

Richard Langis wrote:
> 
> Matt Alexander wrote:
> >
> > Hmm...  RedHat's up2date utility is pretty easy...
> 
> Never used it.
> 
> Although I had heard that you have to pay a monthly fee to become a
> 'preferred' customer, so that you are guaranteed updates *when* they
> come out.  So if you don't pay, and the servers are busy, you are SOL.
> 
> They may have changed that policy since I heard that.  I don't know.
> 

Well, "up2date -u" to update everything in one go sounds pretty
easy, but it failed for me because some configuration file was
changed outside of rpm's control. Must have been the custom
install I did of PHP a while ago. Anyway, I put the job off until
later when I had more time to deal with that. Then RedHat 8.0 was
released the next day. Freeloaders like me were then barred from
using up2date due to "high volume" on the Red Hat site. You need
to pay them $60 per system to get preferred treatment. I still
can't get in today. So from my experience, don't depend on
up2date to keep your system safe from hackers. By the time you
finally get your update, the robo hackers will have screwed,
blued, and tattooed your machine to their infinite delight.

OTH, if you MUST stay on top of these things for commercial
reasons, then expect to pay for the convenience. I don't like it,
but I don't expect RedHat to do everything for free. But at least
if you haven't paid for the service, you can get an instant
refund!

- Bill Thoen



From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Fri Oct 18 15:34:42 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 15:34:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bind firewall ports?
In-Reply-To: <1743.208.151.243.124.1034978705.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <1743.208.151.243.124.1034978705.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <1969.208.151.243.124.1034980482.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

i think i finally tracked down the problem to the firewall.
/etc/named.conf was squeaky clean.

# iptables -A INPUT -p udp --sport 53

seemed to allow my zone transfers to work.
is this secure to open up?

-Robby


<?echo Robby Russell managed to take the time to type out the following:
> what would a typical ipchains rule look like to allow highports from the
> source port 53.
>
> is this something i need to have setup to allow zone transfers?
>
> -robby

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Oct 18 15:41:20 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 15:41:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?c
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181508420.31006-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181534460.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I'm running apt-rpm. Eventually most of the updates make it to the
> tuxfamily.org repositories. Those that don't, I get from
> rpmfind.net.

I'm running rpm-update on a couple dozen machines at work and a 
couple more at home:

  http://www.kleemann.org/rpm-update/

You can point it at a variety of mirror sites (I like
mirrors.kernel.org, but opnsrc.support.compaq.com is a good backup). 
I've got a daily cron job that runs it in "tell me what's available 
for download, but don't actually download anything" mode:

  35   5   *   *   *    USER=$LOGNAME /usr/bin/rpm-update -d -n

Then I

  # download the updates
  rpm-update -d
  # find out what needs to be installed on any given local host
  rpm-update -r
  # hand-install touchy packages like kernel-* or rpm-*
  # and then let rpm-update handle the mass installations
  rpm-update -i
  # and, occasionally, clear out obsolete packages
  rpm-update -c

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From bthoen at gisnet.com  Fri Oct 18 15:57:17 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 16:57:17 -0600

Thanks for all the quick advice. We should have researched it
more. The guy whose machines needed the install on (Athlon xp
1800 and HP Pentium 4) couldn't wait and went out and got the RH
8.0. It also failed to install on either machine as well. Wahoo.
There's something about these new machines that doesn't like
Linux. He suspects something to do with the IDE drivers, but we
still don't know. Probably they have a Microsoft XP-friendly
chipset (muhaha.)

So the lesson learned is to be wary of the latest equipment; it
might not work.

- Bill Thoen

a couple of stumpers for the experts), but I live far away and
over the mountains. But thanks again for all the help so far!

Here's a little script to make the up2date work for you automatically.
This script keeps issuing the up2date command until it does not give
an error.  It could fill up your system with processes or files.  But,
most of the time it just gets the rpms.



########################Cut here################################
#!/usr/bin/perl
#
# script for polling Redhat
#

my ( $OUTPUT );
print $OUTPUT = `up2date-nox -u`;
if ( $OUTPUT =~ /Error*/ ) 
{
   print ".";
   `./uptodate.pl`;
}
#######################Cut here#################################

Ken, cad2cam.com, cadtocam.com

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Sat Oct 19 10:54:13 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 10:54:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210181710070.20706-100000@serpentor.cobrala>

On Friday 18 October 2002 17:10, Preston Crawford wrote:
> On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:
> > We do want server capability, but are the improvements worth the
> > price? Is it going to install on this hardware anyway? Any
> > caveats about doing this that anyone here is aware of?
>
> Boy, I don't know. Depends on if Red Hat is your bag. I tried it and
> stuck with SuSE, which costs half as much.

Hmm same here.  I won a copy of SuSE 5.0 or something roughly that old in a 
raffle at a Linux user group meeting.  Stuck with it ever since then.  The 
online update stuff has worked quite well (and I don't have to pay a fee 
for access).  SuSE's got several mirrors that are automatically downloaded 
into the update app.

I've never had any problems with getting things with the online update.  
Sometimes the speeds are slow (I managed to do an update the day that SuSE 
8.1 was released), but I got everything.  I didn't even know that RH cost 
money for guaranteed access.  That would have made me run in the other 
direction if I hadn't already been a SuSE fan.  I hope that SuSE doesn't 
start doing that.

Best,
Kyle

Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 12:45:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Virus - Hello!
Message-ID: <4.3.2.7.2.20021019123239.00ab42d0@mail.dsl-only.net>

Hi All,

Well... My mother sent me a virus. OK, I tries to explain to her not to open files with more than 1 dot, but it was from a friend that said they could not open the file, so....

I'm trying to identify which virus it is so I can try to clean up her computer. Subject line was "Hello!"
A file was simply attached - Budget.xsl.scr. The budget spreadsheet is an actual file of hers so the virus picked it up and attached itself then went through her address book and sent it out.

Her components are: Opera 6.1 for all browsing, and Eudora Pro 4.3 for her mail. Most e-mail virus warnings I've seen posted are due to the wonderful Microsoft Outlook products, so I'm not sure which virus this is.

Any help or direction to look would be appreciated.

Thanks,
Steve Coffman

From russj at dimstar.net  Sat Oct 19 15:45:28 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 15:45:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Rack-mount cases for linux boxes
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210170656540.32235-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <3DB1E088.5070102@dimstar.net>

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> On Thu, 17 Oct 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
> Since I lust for the ultimate rack mount I'll add some totally irreverent 
> comments.
> 
> 
>>* 1U  : looks cool, but loud since tiny fans spin so quickly
> 
> 
> 	Holds one switch or an Integrated Cabinet Console (Keyboard, 
>         fold-down LCD display - StarTech.Com :-).

You can find plenty of "system" chassis at this size too. Usually won't 
do any cards though. All the peripherals need to be on the mb.

>>* 2U  : the sweet spot!
> 
> 
> 	At a little over 3 inches will it hold a 'normal' main board 
> 	and expansion cards?

It'll hold the main board, and then do 1 to 3 expansion cards (depending 
on the chassis and riser card). 2U isn't high enough to plug the cards 
directly into the mb.

>>* 3U  : a bit big, but not bad
> 
> 	Holds 18-20 Blades!!!

Minimum size for using the expansion card slots vertically.

--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #14 (Collect all 17)
"There is a point beyond which even justice becomes unjust." - Sophocles




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Oct 19 17:25:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 17:25:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210191718100.1977-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I've decided to put off lobbying for an Oregon anti-spam law until after
the elections. No sense lobbying someone who may not be in a position to
help. Depending on who wins, I think that we can get 3-4 sponsors of an
anti-spamming law; house and senate.

  What encourages me is the article in today's Oregonian reporting that
Washington has successfully procecuted its first spammer under its law. This
is a 28-year-old from Salem who sent about 300,000 spam mails soliciting
sales of his $40 book on how to make money on the Internet. Under Washington
law, each incident can result in a fine of $20,000 plus the cost of
procecution. The judge dropped the conviction to a single incident and
lopped a third off the restitution of costs. The defendent now owes the
state of Washington $96,000.

  With precedent set across the river, it will be easier to garner support
among the legislators. I look forward to getting gowing on this next month.

Rich

On Friday 18 October 2002 17:10, Preston Crawford wrote:
> On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:
> > We do want server capability, but are the improvements worth the 
> > price? Is it going to install on this hardware anyway? Any caveats 
> > about doing this that anyone here is aware of?
>
> Boy, I don't know. Depends on if Red Hat is your bag. I tried it and 
> stuck with SuSE, which costs half as much.

Hmm same here.  I won a copy of SuSE 5.0 or something roughly that old
in a 
raffle at a Linux user group meeting.  Stuck with it ever since then.
The 
online update stuff has worked quite well (and I don't have to pay a fee

for access).  SuSE's got several mirrors that are automatically
downloaded 
into the update app.

I've never had any problems with getting things with the online update.

Sometimes the speeds are slow (I managed to do an update the day that
SuSE 
8.1 was released), but I got everything.  I didn't even know that RH
cost 
money for guaranteed access.  That would have made me run in the other 
direction if I hadn't already been a SuSE fan.  I hope that SuSE doesn't

start doing that.

Best,
Kyle

From sandy at herring.org  Sat Oct 19 19:09:16 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 19:09:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] procmail filter for 'no such person'
In-Reply-To: <20021018162930.B5526@defiant.ncplus.net>; from brucek@kingkon.com on Fri, Oct 18, 2002 at 04:29:30PM -0700
References: <20021018162930.B5526@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <20021019190916.A30106@kippered.herring.org>

Bruce,

You mean "addressee unknown"? Like this?


## capture the address that caused delivery
:0
* ^X-Envelope-To: \/.*
{
	ENVELOPE_TO="$MATCH"
}

# bounce email not to me
:0
* ! ENVELOPE_TO ?? ^brucek at kingkon.com$
{
    # EX_NOUSER = 67 from sysexits.h
    EXITCODE = 67
    :0
    /dev/null
}


This assumes, of course, that your MTA/MDA is configured to add the
X-Envelope-To: header so that you can reconcile Bcc's, etc.

hth,
Sandy

p.s.    You may want to replace the /dev/null action with a delivery to a
        spam folder until you're content it's working.

On Fri, 18 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> such user' syndrome?
>

> something that will send back to the sender an automated message,
> without manual intervention.
> 
> Thanx,
> -bk

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Sat Oct 19 20:16:44 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 20:16:44 -0700
Subject: WAS (RE: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?)  Now: SuSE Update?
In-Reply-To: <000001c277db$63297640$67a8a8c0@tina>
References: <000001c277db$63297640$67a8a8c0@tina>
Message-ID: <200210192016.44190.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Saturday 19 October 2002 18:52, Intel Richard wrote:
> Which brings up a totally "newbie" question:  I have SuSE 6.1.  If I
> load it, and get all the updates via the web, is it equivalent to SuSE
> 8.0?  Never really thought of it that way...

Hmm, I suppose it would be theoretically possible. I've tended to alternate 
between upgrading and reinstalling.  I generally buy each version of SuSE 
Pro.  However, all the RPMs are available for download.  They just aren't 
organized with ISO images etc.

I've thought about mirroring all the RPMs locally, but with 8.0, I was able 
to just copy the CDs all to my drive and then twiddle a couple of things 
to point YaST there and haven't needed to load the CDs since.  Very handy.  
Hopefully 8.1's redone RPM handling supports this better. 

I think that SuSE doesn't officially support anything before about 7.0 now.  
So, you'd have to figure out how to manually upgrade to 7.0 and then 
probably do it one version at a time after that.  Unless you time is free, 
I'd suggest just buying the CDs :-)

Best,
Kyle




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Oct 19 20:30:36 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 20:30:36 -0700
Subject: WAS (RE: [PLUG] Reviews of RedHat 8.0 - is it worth $150?)  Now: SuSE Update?
In-Reply-To: <200210192016.44190.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
References: <000001c277db$63297640$67a8a8c0@tina> <200210192016.44190.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <200210192030.36776.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think it was just this past summer when SuSE stopped supporting 6.4 
although they did release an OpenSSH patch for it a few months back 
because it was a rather severe problem. I finally retired my old SuSE 
6.4 gateway/firewall when they discontinued support for it. 

The system was a minimal install on a small hard drive and I was pushing 
the limits of how many upgrades I could go through without the root 
filesystem running out of space. The system was pretty close to full 
after the upgrade from 6.3 to 6.4 so I just left the system alone and 
only installed the patches SuSE made available from time to time for 
it.

Tony

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Oct 19 21:19:54 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 19 Oct 2002 21:19:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CDW Commercials
Message-ID: <1035087594.29769.7.camel@bittersweet>

Every notice that CDW commercial on TV, where the people say stuff about
crashing the internet, frying a motherboard and the fatherboard, etc?

There's a scene showing people assembling computers, and a guy in the
center of the screen plugs a peripheral board into a mainboard, then
reaches over and pushes a key on the keyboard to his left.  So, is he
using a checklist on a second computer, or is he plugging a board into a
live system???

From colin at dabritz.org  Sun Oct 20 00:17:02 2002
From: colin at dabritz.org (Colin Dabritz)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 00:17:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210191718100.1977-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce>

    May I chime in with something I have considered for a while?  Oregon
already has a 'no spam' law for telephones, called the oregon 'no-call' law
www.ornocall.com, where you can be put on a list they are required to check
before making a call to anyone in oregon.  It makes solictications illegal,
with a few cevats (covering the obvious, like prior buisness relationships,
and non-profit organizations).
    We could campaign for a no email-spam law and win.  And then campaign
for a no snail-mail spam law and win.  And we could campaign for laws
against sticking flyers on your door, and in your car windshield wiper.  And
then we could campaign again when television ads go digital and are targeted
directly at individual viwers.  And 50 years in the future when the next
communications medium goes big (telepathic advertising? *shudders*).  And we
could keep fighting every single step of the way.  But perhaps there is a
better solution.
    What I want is a 'no direct contact for buisness purposes without prior
consent' law.  It would make ANY directly targeted advertising illegal
unless that buisness has prior consent, either in writen form, or the prior
buisness thing from ornocall.com.  The details are fuzzy, but think of the
advantage.  If a law such as this had been passes when comsumers got fed up
with cataloges and junk mail at thier door, and soliticors on the phone,
then it would have automatically applied to the unforseen format of 'email'.
We could be the first state with a 'no harassment of consumers' law.  How
cool would that be?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Oct 20 07:52:43 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 07:52:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210200727150.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 20 Oct 2002, Colin Dabritz wrote:

> We could campaign for a no email-spam law and win.  And then
> campaign for a no snail-mail spam law and win.

As the old saw goes, be careful what you wish for.

In the first and second quarters of 2002, the US Postal Service had
revenues of approx. $31 billion. Of that, $7.3 billion (23%) was from
"Standard Mail," which is primarily advertising.

I know a number of people who've spent time in Europe who will tell
you that our postal service is so much cheaper and more dependable 
than what you find in other countries.

If we vote to ban roughly 25% of the USPS's income, then postage
becomes a *lot* more expensive for consumers.

I'm a big fan of the Internet and digital information transfers, but 
I'm nowhere near comfortable enough with electronic security to forego 
completely a signature sent via snail mail.

For me, I'd rather ignore the junk mail that subsidizes the USPS than 
face much higher rates.

YMMV, of course.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From stever at woo-hoo.com  Sun Oct 20 08:48:12 2002
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 08:48:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] USB hard drive with Linux?
Message-ID: <32795.209.210.31.3.1035128892.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Compusa is selling a 40GB USB2.0/1.1 external hard drive for
about $50 after rebates.  This price is a lot lower than say
a ZIP drive and tremendously higher capacity.  I bought one
and am trying to get it to work with RH7.2.  Could use some
help understanding Linux & USB.
I _think_ that it is being recognized and drivers being
loaded from the following output:
[root at sparky root]# cat /proc/bus/usb/devices
<snip>
T:  Bus=01 Lev=01 Prnt=01 Port=01 Cnt=02 Dev#=  3 Spd=12  MxCh= 0
D:  Ver= 2.00 Cls=00(>ifc ) Sub=00 Prot=00 MxPS=64 #Cfgs=  1
P:  Vendor=0c0b ProdID=b001 Rev=11.10
S:  Manufacturer=DMI
S:  Product=USB 2.0 Storage Adaptor
S:  SerialNumber=0B02014204448CD3
C:* #Ifs= 1 Cfg#= 2 Atr=c0 MxPwr= 98mA
I:  If#= 0 Alt= 0 #EPs= 3 Cls=08(stor.) Sub=06 Prot=50 Driver=usb-storage
E:  Ad=01(O) Atr=02(Bulk) MxPS=  64 Ivl=0ms
E:  Ad=82(I) Atr=02(Bulk) MxPS=  64 Ivl=0ms
E:  Ad=83(I) Atr=03(Int.) MxPS=   2 Ivl=32ms
[root at sparky root]#

According to this link, the driver "usb-storage" will create
the drive as /dev/sda (assuming no other SCSI devices are
installed):
http://www.linux-usb.org/USB-guide/x498.html


I presume the first task on order is to fdisk it and make a
partition.  This seemed to go well and the partition I created
on /dev/sda1 persists across reboots.

Wouldn't the next task be to create a filesystem on /dev/sda1?
I tried /sbin/mke2fs /dev/sda1 and it runs for awhile, gets to
the part about making inodes and hangs at about 577/1024.  Thought
I wasn't patient enough so I let it run overnight and it didn't
get any further.

Any help or suggestions would be appreciated.  I have read about
some usbide drivers but don't understand when or whether these
are needed, given the output of cat /proc/bus/usb/devices above
(doesn't that mean I already have drivers loaded?)
http://bravin.home.cern.ch/bravin/usbide/usbide.html

Does it stand to reason that if fdisk is working fine, that I
can create a partition which fdisk can read later, that all the
drivers are working correctly and it is now just a matter of
correctly creating a file system & mounting?

Thanks!






From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Sun Oct 20 11:05:35 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 11:05:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210200727150.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021020105521.00aa6c80@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

>If we vote to ban roughly 25% of the USPS's income, then postage
>becomes a *lot* more expensive for consumers.

Seems to me USPS has managed to achieve higher rates all on their own.  And 
that junk mail is subsidized *by* us, it's not a subsidy *to* us.

On the other hand, if we did away with the legal monopoly USPS enjoys, we 
might actually see rates decline once FedEx and UPS entered the market.

Of course, if we de-monopolized the mail system, how long would it be 
before MS took over and had us all buying Passport-enabled postage 
chips?  It could be the next great virus vector. :-)

Dylan

From revans at e-z.net  Sun Oct 20 11:58:50 2002

Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 11:58:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Power-Off problem
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021020183340.00b036e0@pop.net-yan.com>

Try passing 
apm=real-mode-poweroff
at the boot prompt.

If that works then append it to your boot loader.

Thank you
Russell

From colin at dabritz.org  Sun Oct 20 12:58:46 2002
From: colin at dabritz.org (Colin Dabritz)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 12:58:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210200727150.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <002a01c27873$19e18f20$7301a8c0@CDnforce>

> As the old saw goes, be careful what you wish for.
Yeah, making it work would take a lot of changes I'm sure, and I *know* it
would have a great impact on the economy.  Imagine buinsnesses that had to
sell actuall products.
> In the first and second quarters of 2002, the US Postal Service had
> revenues of approx. $31 billion. Of that, $7.3 billion (23%) was from
> "Standard Mail," which is primarily advertising.

> If we vote to ban roughly 25% of the USPS's income, then postage
> becomes a *lot* more expensive for consumers.

There would be some casualties of course.  On the email ban you might argue
the big telcos would lose out on all the asian spam overseas traffic.  I'm
willing to pay more for postage in return for less junk mail.  Alternatively
you could agree to recieve junkmail in return for lower rate postage.  Would
you do it?  I'm sure I wouldn't, but then I don't send much snail mail.

> I'm a big fan of the Internet and digital information transfers, but
> I'm nowhere near comfortable enough with electronic security to forego
> completely a signature sent via snail mail.
This will probably get better over time, right?

> For me, I'd rather ignore the junk mail that subsidizes the USPS than
> face much higher rates.

Like I said above, what about an agreement where they send you junk, and you
get cut rates?  That makes it your choice.  Remeber the www.ornocall.com
list is completely optional.  Actually the majority of oregonions aren't on
it.  A similar, but more general list, would still be opt in probably.

I'm not sure about it flying politically, but can't we go over thier heads
in this case?  Get enough signatures and it goes on the ballot, no questions
asked?  Its certainly something I would campaign for.  Of course it requires
not a small amount of refactoring, and research, as well as some pretty
detailed exceptions.  Who says we can't? :)  I mostly wanted to get the idea
out there for feedback.  Thanks a lot for the ideas!

> YMMV, of course.
YAAINFW.  (Yet Another Acronym Im Not Familiar With).

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=YMMV
Your Milage May Vary
Is there anything google can't do?

I've always wondered about that. In that "other" OS, I can have a little
icon with all the possible resolutions for my screen, and can switch
between them fairly easily. It comes in handy when designing web pages.
Sure, I like to work in 1024 x 768, but how does that page look in 640 x
480, or 800 x 600? My laptop supports 800 x 600, but not 1024 x 768, my
wife doesn't want 1024 x 768, and my mother-in-law wants 640 x 480
because it's easier to see. Family web pages have to look good for all
the family.

I'm looking forward to trying that out when it becomes available.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sun Oct 20 18:00:42 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 18:00:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian X configuration on Thinkpad
Message-ID: <3DB351BA.9653951D@attbi.com>

At yesterday's clinic I was trying to find out why my X console came on
dim when I switched back to it after switching to a text console. (The X
console came on at normal brightness when X first started up.) There
weren't any Debian gurus there while I was, and I had to leave early, so
we were unable to resolve the problem. But Dan (I think it was Dan) gave
me some ideas of where to look. We tried running xf86cfg, but couldn't
get the buttons to respond. I decided to have a look at XF86Config-4 to
see what I could learn. Well, the first think I learned was that Debian
has an X Configuration tool. So, I ran dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86,
as instructed and walked through the various configuration options.

The important thing that I had to change was what I told the
configuration program I had for a video device. When I first installed
the OS, I had chosen vega, since I didn't know any better. Today, I did
some google searching and found a page with some more details:

http://www.linuxcare.com/labs/certs/pad390x-suse64-sys.epl

>From that, I learned that I should be using NeoMagic instead of vega.
Now, when I switch from the X console to a text console and back again,
the X console is at normal brightness.

So thanks, Dan, for pointing me in a direction that led me to the
solution.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From revans at e-z.net  Sun Oct 20 19:22:18 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 19:22:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] USB hard drive with Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1035150236.1656.3.camel@linux>
References: <32795.209.210.31.3.1035128892.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
    <20021020184456.TPJU22897.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@linux>
    <1035150236.1656.3.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <20021021022138.CFGY26432.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

Works well expect hotplug, I'm not using an official suse 8.1 and
http://www.suse.de/en/private/products/suse_linux/i386/new_features.html 
claims Hardware: Hotplug support for USB2 and Firewire so I came up with a
script to load the modules and mount the drive, so I'm happy with the firewire.
I've copied my running 8.0 system to it, repartitioned the boot drive,
installed a 8.1 beta wiping everything out, and then copied everything back. I
think the total I moved was 15G both ways.

Having an external USB ide CDRW is alot easier as the CDRW is reckonized as
SCSI without having to set up ide-scsi and sg.	Hotplug will set it up for you.
I was only able to burn an iso image at 12X max with USB, both 2.0 and 1.1,
with a 24x and 48x burner. ( I can burn a 670M iso in 144 sec with the 48x via
the IDE interface ). I can't remember what I got with the CDRW in the firewire
box. I got tired of booting from floppy and moved the CDRW back into the case.
Although the MB I have supports booting from an USB CD, I was never able to do
so. I updated the MB BIOS to the latest when I was playing with this, but got
no joy.

The price for an external USB at ENU have come down by about 1/4 since I bought
my external case and the deals on cheap CDRW, got the 48x for $29.95, make a do
it yourself external fall under my $100 per part budget, 59.95 + $29.95 =
$89.90. The firewire enclosures are still the about the same at $79.95.  

Thank you
Russell
