From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Oct 20 19:57:08 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 19:57:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce> <5.1.1.6.0.20021020105521.00aa6c80@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <3DB36D04.2020702@dimstar.net>

Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

>
>> If we vote to ban roughly 25% of the USPS's income, then postage
>> becomes a *lot* more expensive for consumers.
>
>
> Seems to me USPS has managed to achieve higher rates all on their own.


Due, mostly, to the decline in volume. Less volume makes the system less 
efficient, and, in turn, cost more.

It's the inverse of why memory is so cheap these days.

Regardless, we still have the least expensive postal service in the 
world. I remember a time when we had the best telephone system in the 
world. We "de-monopolized" it, and it went to shit.

>   And that junk mail is subsidized *by* us, it's not a subsidy *to* us.

How do you figure? The USPS doesn't get one penny of taxes. It's 
supported entirely by postage fees.

> On the other hand, if we did away with the legal monopoly USPS enjoys, 
> we might actually see rates decline once FedEx and UPS entered the market.

The only monopoly the USPS "enjoys" is sending first class mail. UPS, 
FedEx, Airborne, all of them, are able to move anything else. Even then, 
you can send correspondence through FedEx, they even call it a letter.

You want FedEx et al to pick up at your doorstep daily? And just how 
inefficient do we have to make it?

 From what I understand, the big package movers don't want the letter 
business.

Russ




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Sun Oct 20 20:12:35 2002
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 20:12:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mail handling agents for users
Message-ID: <2437.216.99.218.67.1035169955.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>

I have a domain that I manage for another and would like to give them
ability to decide how their mail to handled.  I'm allowing two mail boxes
on the server and all mail is being sent to one account on the server.

Thus:

user1
user2

postfix alias file:
@domain.com   user1

I had a promail file setup such they can do the follow:

:0:
  * ^TO_joeuser at domain\.com
  ! user2 at localhost


then the user1 could forward all the email to the other user on the same
machine.  The problem seems that the mail is not all going to that user. 
User2 has signed up for some maillist and the mailer is sending them BBC
or some other hidden way.

Is there a way that I can use procmail or some other tool that the user
could alter in his home directory to decide which mail goes where?

I know that I can put an entry in the postfix user alias file and now have
to temporary resolve the issue but would like the user of the domain to be
able to handle his email.

Thanks for any suggestions.

Josh





From satimis at writeme.com  Sun Oct 20 21:24:35 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 12:24:35 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Power-Off problem
In-Reply-To: <20021020185810.QDHI26524.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021020183340.00b036e0@pop.net-yan.com>
 <3DAE3980.5090506@pacifier.com>
 <5.1.1.6.0.20021017115336.02b80900@pop.net-yan.com>

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Oct 21 06:09:23 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 07:09:23 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210200727150.26114-100000@pecos.madboa.com> <002a01c27873$19e18f20$7301a8c0@CDnforce>
Message-ID: <3DB3FC83.645EAA77@gisnet.com>

Colin Dabritz wrote:
> > If we vote to ban roughly 25% of the USPS's income, then postage
> > becomes a *lot* more expensive for consumers.
> 
> There would be some casualties of course.  On the email ban you might argue
> the big telcos would lose out on all the asian spam overseas traffic.  I'm
> willing to pay more for postage in return for less junk mail.  Alternatively
> you could agree to recieve junkmail in return for lower rate postage.  

I think that if the ISPs --all the way up the line to the one that
is the North American connection to the Mother of All Spam Pipes
(the Korean Konnection)-- could be tasked with either charging for
spam or blocking it or paying us for it themselves, then most spam
would disappear.

The reason we have so much spam is that there is practically no cost
for the spammers. If we inspire or compel ISPs to charge a fee from
their upstream providers or spammers directly for spam sent into the
'net, I imagine we see an end to the junk. The fee doesn't have to
be large; even a 20 cent fee per 100 recipients would add up and
provide ISPs with some extra income that could possibly translate
into 25% less cost to us in user fees.

- Bill Thoen



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 21 06:50:57 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 06:50:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A regex conundrum
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210650430.20067-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Yesterday morning someone from Japan attempted to crack our network via
ssh. The attempt was rejected and I want to report this to the originating
domain. However, I'm having a problem getting the outgoing message past my
postfix spam filters.

  The domain is "nic.ad.jp", and the problem is with the ".ad." portion.
Postfix sees this as "any character, followed by the letters 'ad', followed
by any character". This matches " addresses", " advertisement", and so on.
It's an interesting conundrom.

  I've seen ".ac.<country_code>" for academic domains, but I've not before
encountered an "ad". I suppose this is for the Network Administrative Center
in Japan, where I thought I should report this. I'll try the specific
domain, digirh.com, and that should go through.

  But, what does one do with an address that is so generic that it matches
spam filters as a regex when it's part of the domain name?

Thanks,

Rich









From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Mon Oct 21 07:16:29 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 07:16:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject)
Message-ID: <3738.208.151.243.124.1035209789.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

Last friday i added this to my iptables...and it opened up my dns to allow
zone transfers. Only problem is that it seemed to screw up the machines
behind the firewall. They were unable to use the dns properly to resolve
domain names. Is there a better command to allow outgoing and incoming
requests like this?

# iptables -A INPUT -p udp --sport 53








From raanders at acm.org  Mon Oct 21 07:26:22 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 07:26:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A regex conundrum
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210650430.20067-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210210715360.362-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   But, what does one do with an address that is so generic that it matches
> spam filters as a regex when it's part of the domain name?

I'm guessing you have out-going SPAM tests.  The major pain method would
be to connect directly to their mail server server (SMTP port) and deliver
the message directly using telnet.  Some of the mail clients for browsers 
did/do this.
   A special program to send mail by-passing the local SMTP server would
be a neat thing.  Kind of like the spammers do (??? :-) but for us white
hats.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Oct 21 08:24:10 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 08:24:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210191718100.1977-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210191718100.1977-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021021152410.GA21466@rauhaus.org>

* Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> [021019 17:30]:
>   What encourages me is the article in today's Oregonian reporting that
> Washington has successfully procecuted its first spammer under its law. This
> is a 28-year-old from Salem who sent about 300,000 spam mails soliciting
> sales of his $40 book on how to make money on the Internet. Under Washington
> law, each incident can result in a fine of $20,000 plus the cost of
> procecution. The judge dropped the conviction to a single incident and
> lopped a third off the restitution of costs. The defendent now owes the
> state of Washington $96,000.

I seem to recall that the Washington spam law makes it relatively easy
for private individuals to be awarded damages from spammers. I would
really like to see a proposed Oregon law do the same so that we do have
to wait for the Oregon state attorney general to decide that a spammer
is egregious enough to persue.

--Stafford

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 21 08:48:15 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 08:48:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <200210211429.g9LET7E28920@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210846520.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> How would ISP's track spammers to charge them a money if 
> most of the mail headers are spoofed anyway?

Alex,

  I may be slightly off on the details, but while the domain name, from and
to may be spoofed, the originating IP address can be found. Sometimes some
of those are spoofed, too, but there's enough info to track it back down
using whois, dig, nslookup (deprecated), host and other standard tools.

Rich

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Oct 21 08:23:52 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 08:23:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210846520.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200210211523.g9LFNq429016@gate.daniloff.com>

Well, it means that ISP's or government should spend some 
forensic resources to investigate each spam message if anti-spam 
law is adopted.
Who will pay for these procedures? Legiment users?
What if spam servers located overseas? 
Who will they charge then - domain owners or foreign governments?
The problem as I envision it is in anchient mail protocol standards
itself. There is no non-spoofable hard links or pointers to the real
host from which message was sent. What if mail servers just refuse to
accept/deliver mail messages without proper headers with clear
authentication. Then spam will vanish on its own. 
I'm just dreaming about it while deleting >200 spam messages 
I'm getting every day.

Alex

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Well, it means that ISP's or government should spend some forensic
> resources to investigate each spam message if anti-spam law is adopted.

Alex,

  I suspect that ISPs will spend no more than they now do on their abuse
teams and the additional hardware and bandwidth needed to move spam around
the 'Net.

> Who will pay for these procedures? Legiment users?

  The spam generators.

> What if spam servers located overseas? 

  Cut their keyboard cord. Er, mouse cord.

> Who will they charge then - domain owners or foreign governments?

  What do you do now if you have a violation of US/state statute by a
foreign entity?

> I'm just dreaming about it while deleting >200 spam messages I'm getting
> every day.

  Write better filters. I keep working on it which is why I sometimes
totally trash the mail system here and reject every incoming and outgoing
mail. Fixing the problem is not what I want to be doing at 6 am. :-) But,
other than last evening's major no-no, I'm getting much better at it. I even
understand what I'm doing -- some of the time.

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 21 10:19:19 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 10:19:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Anti-virus that works with fetchmail?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210211007360.7327-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210211016150.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Preston Crawford wrote:

> Anyone know of an anti-virus package for Linux (frequently updated,
> commercial okay) that works with fetchmail/pine?
 
Preston,

  There are a few advertised in Linux Journal. AFAIK, they all work in front
of the MTA, not back with the MUA or with fetchmail.

  If you're using fetchmail then your ISP should be filtering the virul
messages. Send them a message and ask what they're doing about the problem.
You can probably craft procmail recipes or use spamassassin (or one of the
other context analyzers) on your end.

Rich






From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Oct 21 10:49:24 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 10:49:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Anti-virus that works with fetchmail?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210211007360.7327-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <27899-61638@sneakemail.com>

F-Prot for Linux is free, though not open source.  The updates are
frequent and readily available.  However, as you would expect from a free
product, you're on your own to figure out how to update the files
automatically should you so desire.  (You just need to FTP them and
extract...)

You would need to set up procmail to run the messages through the scanner.  
I generally don't bother since Klez (the virus I see the most often)
doesn't infect *NIX variants running Pine.  ;-)

  -- Steve

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Preston Crawford wrote:

> 
> Anyone know of an anti-virus package for Linux (frequently updated,
> commercial okay) that works with fetchmail/pine?
> 
> Preston




From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Mon Oct 21 10:55:26 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 10:55:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] iptables help...? dns incoming/outgoing?
In-Reply-To: <3738.208.151.243.124.1035209789.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <3738.208.151.243.124.1035209789.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <1694.208.151.243.124.1035222926.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

is there a way to allow incoming and outgoing with this?
how would i enter that into IPTABLES?

> incoming requests like this?

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Oct 21 10:02:01 2002

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210937290.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Mon Oct 21 11:05:30 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 11:05:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <3DB36D04.2020702@dimstar.net>
References: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce>
 <5.1.1.6.0.20021020105521.00aa6c80@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021021100526.00ab7b88@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

>Less volume makes the system less efficient, and, in turn, cost more.

Perhaps.  Or the inefficiency might come from the other business ventures 
they're plodding in to.  USPS, a *federal agency*, is one of the largest 
advertisers in the US.  Why is it necessary to advertise a service that you 
hold a legally granted monopoly for?  Because they are actively branching 
out into other domains, and that is simply not what they are good at, nor 
what they have been created to do.


>>   And that junk mail is subsidized *by* us, it's not a subsidy *to* us.
>
>How do you figure? The USPS doesn't get one penny of taxes. It's supported 
>entirely by postage fees.

Yes, the USPS is funded through our postage.  Bulk rates are significantly 
cheaper than other kinds of delivery.  There may be *some* efficiency to 
bulk mail, in that it sorts faster or is pre-sorted.  But the real expense, 
delivery, presents few economies of scale.  Every time we pay postage, 
we're paying not only for the delivery of *our* mail but for the delivery 
of *junk* mail.


>The only monopoly the USPS "enjoys" is sending first class mail. UPS, 
>FedEx, Airborne, all of them, are able to move anything else. Even then, 
>you can send correspondence through FedEx, they even call it a letter.

That little, insignificant monopoly is a $60+ billion business.

>You want FedEx et al to pick up at your doorstep daily?

Why not?  Seems like they're here daily anyway.   :-)

More to the point, who says that a competitor would try to do exactly the 
same thing?  The value of competitors is that they will try *different* 
things.   Seems to me that one of the big cost factors in the USPS model is 
that they are burdened with the expectation of daily home visits to every 
address in the country.  Talk about inefficiency!  Eliminate the bulk mail 
and the daily at-home pick-up and you've got a far cheaper model to work 
with.

Would it really be such a bad thing if first class delivery happened only 
three times a week or if you had to put your mail in the box at the corner 
if you needed same-day pickup?  There's *lots* of room for innovation, but 
the USPS won't be able to make it fly... only a private competitor will.


> From what I understand, the big package movers don't want the letter 
> business.

They don't want the "replicate the USPS business model" business.  If they 
were allowed to deliver first class mail, they'd find a better way of doing 
it.  There are tens of billions at stake, of course they want a piece of 
that business.  They just don't want to play be the same rules as the post 
office and I don't blame them... the USPS doesn't want to play by those 
rules either.  Problem is, they're stuck with them.

The problem here is not that all government agencies or monopolies are evil 
or inefficient.  It's that when you ask customers to declare their 
requirements up front, they usually over-specify... when you offer a range 
of services at varying prices, *then* they show what they'll really pay for.

The USPS is in much the same problem as the Apple Newton (trying 
desperately to make this a little on topic).  When Apple did their 
research, what they heard was that handwriting recognition would have to be 
a *key* component of any PDA device.  And they did it, and nobody bought 
it.  What Palm proved was that focus groups are often misleading... making 
a product that worked more reliably and cheaply by *not* giving customers 
handwriting recognition proved to be a much more successful proposition.

We constantly tell the USPS that daily home visits are at the very heart of 
our most basic expectations.  We endow that expectation with the force of a 
legal mandate. But I suspect that if daily visits were put side-by-side 
with a service offered a different model, we would see what people are 
actually willing to pay for pretty quickly.

Dylan

(if you'd like to continue this, I'd be happy to move over to plug-talk)

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Oct 21 12:56:27 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 13:56:27 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <200210211429.g9LET7E28920@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3DB45BEB.C9E61CDB@gisnet.com>

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> 
> How would ISP's track spammers to charge them a money if
> most of the mail headers are spoofed anyway?

I don't know. But rather than give up and say it can't be done,
it would be more useful to consider how it *can* be done. It
would probably require a change in the e-mail protocol that would
treat an unknown message's status from "trusted until proven to
be spam" to "not trusted until proven legitimate." Spammers do it
for the money, so all we have to do is make it more expensive for
them to operate. Spammers are using our resources without paying
us, either directly or through lower access costs for us. By all
definitions they are stealing from us. 

I say put the squeeze on ISPs to figure something out because the
higher up the pipe you go the more concentrated the spam load is
with a better economy of scale in which to develop and implement
anti-spam techniques.

But I do know that if each us tries to independently filter spam
on the extreme downstream end, we will not ever be able to bring
enough concentration of pressure to bear on these spamming
parasites to wipe them off the face of the earth. They will
continue to improve their delivery throughput (because without
checks, that's the way the economic equation goes) and we will
all end up spending all our time trying to design better spam
filters and seeing our systems performance degrade under what
will eventually amount to a spam-fueled DDoS attack. I don't want
to have to spend all my time and money garrisoning and defending
a fortress; I want to have some fun with the internet too!

- Bill Thoen



From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Oct 21 13:00:37 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 13:00:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] GNOME window title bar text
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210211256390.7706-100000@joan.burling.com>

Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> on 21 Oct 2002 12:00:10 -0700 wrote:

> Is there an easy way to put your own text in a GNOME
> window title bar?

I'm not clear on what you're asking for, Ed. If you want to manipulate
the text line for an xterm or rxvt window, the Bash-Prompt-HOWTO
has a lot of good ideas for getting past the ``xterm -T 'Title of Window'"
stage.

If there is nothing in Gnome -- or its window managers -- that support
the equivalent of the -T flag, then I have one more reason to
dislike Gnome.

Geoff

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 21 12:58:18 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 12:58:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam law update
In-Reply-To: <3DB45BEB.C9E61CDB@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210211255220.21108-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> I don't know. But rather than give up and say it can't be done, it would
> be more useful to consider how it *can* be done. It would probably require
> a change in the e-mail protocol that would treat an unknown message's
> status from "trusted until proven to be spam" to "not trusted until proven
> legitimate." Spammers do it for the money, so all we have to do is make it
> more expensive for them to operate. Spammers are using our resources
> without paying us, either directly or through lower access costs for us.
> By all definitions they are stealing from us.

  An article in yesterday's "Oregonian" noted that a company is tryign to do
this. They have "legitimate" mass mailers post a bond ($100,000 was the
figure mentioned) against spamming. If they violate the trust, they lose
part of their money, directly proportional to the number of complaints
received.

  I didn't pay too much attention to the details because this is a
for-profit operation and the implication is that if we peons want to make
use of the trust certification we'll have to pay for it.

  I'd rather push for a state-wide law and get folks enforcing it. Cheaper
on my end.

Rich

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 21 13:05:40 2002

On Mon, 2002-10-21 at 11:26, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> I'm trying to use Mozilla as an e-mail client on my laptop. The window 
> for adding a new card to the address book has no scroll bar, and is 
> taller than 600 pixels. Unfortunately, the control buttons for 
> performing the addition are at the bottom of the window. I have looked 
> for a setting in preferences, but don't find anything that will let me 
> change the size of the window, or in some other way allow me to see 
> everything displayed in it.

Problems like this is what prompted me to start using blackbox as a
window manager.  If you grab any border, except at the lower corners,
you can move the window anywhere.  Very handy for recovering from the
full screen mode of mozilla, too.

Different window managers behave differently, some have this
functionality, others don't.

HTH

Derek Loree




From lennon at day-reynolds.com  Mon Oct 21 13:05:32 2002
From: lennon at day-reynolds.com (Lennon Day-Reynolds)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 13:05:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using Mozilla for e-mail
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210211200480.20930-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3DB45E0C.3040403@day-reynolds.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
>
>  
>
>>I'm trying to use Mozilla as an e-mail client on my laptop. The window 
>>for adding a new card to the address book has no scroll bar, and is 
>>taller than 600 pixels. Unfortunately, the control buttons for 
>>performing the addition are at the bottom of the window. I have looked 
>>for a setting in preferences, but don't find anything that will let me 
>>change the size of the window, or in some other way allow me to see 
>>everything displayed in it.
>>    
>>
>
>  I ran into this problem with some X application on my notebook. Never did
>figure out what to do about it.
>
One solution I've found is to use a "small screen" window manager like 
'ion' or 'matchbox', as they at least force the window to fit within the 
current screen dimensions. Unfortunately, if the application hard-codes 
the window dimensions and widget placement, rather than using some sort 
of dynamic layout manager, you'll still be out of luck.

Another option (if you have another machine with X and a larger display 
available on the network) would be to run the offending app there, then 
resize the window manually to be within the constraints of your smaller 
screen. Mozilla, at least, does a fairly good job of "remembering" 
window sizes and placement between sessions, so as long as the same 
profile folder is being used, you should be able to switch back to the 
smaller display and still have the re-sized windows.

>
>  
>
>>I'll be trying other e-mail tools, but since I already know how Netscape 
>>works, I thought it would be easier to stick with the familiar for the 
>>time being.
>>    
>>
>
>  pine fits very well in all window sizes and resolutions; it works very
>well with ispell.
>
There are even other GUI mail clients that work well on smaller screens 
-- Balsa is certainly one of my favorites, but Sylpheed or KMail can be 
fine, as well. In general, I've found any of the Mozilla applications 
fairly frustrating to use on low-resolution displays; it seems that 
compactness of the basic widgets just wasn't a priority in the 
development of the standard themes. (Of course, you can always just 
download one of the "compact" themes -- I'm somewhat partial to 'Lo-Fi', 
myself.)

>
>Rich
>
>

>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 21 13:08:10 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 13:08:10 -0700
Subject: OT: [PLUG] Spam law update
References: <005f01c27808$b04ad180$7301a8c0@CDnforce> <5.1.1.6.0.20021020105521.00aa6c80@www.dylanreinhardt.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021021100526.00ab7b88@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <3DB45EAA.9050305@dimstar.net>

In the interest of topicness, any future responses to this thread will 
be on plug-talk. This message is sent to both lists.

Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

>
>> Less volume makes the system less efficient, and, in turn, cost more.
>
>
> Perhaps.  Or the inefficiency might come from the other business 
> ventures they're plodding in to.  USPS, a *federal agency*, is one of 
> the largest advertisers in the US.  Why is it necessary to advertise a 
> service that you hold a legally granted monopoly for?  Because they 
> are actively branching out into other domains, and that is simply not 
> what they are good at, nor what they have been created to do.

It's necessary in this day and age because they have to build up their 
image in the general publics eye.

Right, wrong or indifferent, if the USPS doesn't toot it's own horn, 
then it will suffer from the negative campaigns put on by the profit 
motivated competitors. And don't get me wrong, they ARE competitors.

> Yes, the USPS is funded through our postage.  Bulk rates are 
> significantly cheaper than other kinds of delivery.  There may be 
> *some* efficiency to bulk mail, in that it sorts faster or is 
> pre-sorted.  But the real expense, delivery, presents few economies of 
> scale.  Every time we pay postage, we're paying not only for the 
> delivery of *our* mail but for the delivery of *junk* mail. 

No we're not. We're paying for delivery of our first class letter to 
it's destination. At about 40 cents, it's a hell of a lot cheaper than 
any other country in the world, and we have better service.

The reason bulk is cheaper is exactly that. It's bulk, it's presorted. 
That deserves a break in price. Yes, the junk mail senders abuse the 
system, just like spammers abuse the email system. Personally, I don't 
think junk mail should qualify as bulk mail, but that adds another layer 
to the system.

>> The only monopoly the USPS "enjoys" is sending first class mail. UPS, 
>> FedEx, Airborne, all of them, are able to move anything else. Even 
>> then, you can send correspondence through FedEx, they even call it a 
>> letter.
>
>
> That little, insignificant monopoly is a $60+ billion business.

And it would cost another entity much more to do a comparable job.

>> You want FedEx et al to pick up at your doorstep daily?
>
>
> Why not?  Seems like they're here daily anyway.   :-)

They visit the business I work at daily. I doubt they visit my 
neighborhood daily. Not to mention the fact that small towns would be 
lucky to get service once a month. Part of the economy of scale is that 
every town has a post office. If it's privatized, then where to towns 
like Banks end up?

> More to the point, who says that a competitor would try to do exactly 
> the same thing?  The value of competitors is that they will try 
> *different* things.   Seems to me that one of the big cost factors in 
> the USPS model is that they are burdened with the expectation of daily 
> home visits to every address in the country.  Talk about 
> inefficiency!  Eliminate the bulk mail and the daily at-home pick-up 
> and you've got a far cheaper model to work with.

First, if you don't have any inbound mail, they aren't required to pick 
up outgoing. So that's a half arguement. If you absolutely have to have 
it go out, you have to put it in an outbound box. (Definition of 
outbound box includes mailboxes with flags to indicate outbound mail.) 
Even back in the 70's and 80's, I remember plenty of days where the 
mailman would just drive by 3 or 4 houses because he didn't have any 
mail to deliver. Many times, we DID have outbound mail on those days.

> Would it really be such a bad thing if first class delivery happened 
> only three times a week or if you had to put your mail in the box at 
> the corner if you needed same-day pickup?  There's *lots* of room for 
> innovation, but the USPS won't be able to make it fly... only a 
> private competitor will.

And we can watch yet another great American institution go to hell. We 
did it to the telephone system, so why not the postal system too.

> The problem here is not that all government agencies or monopolies are 
> evil or inefficient.  It's that when you ask customers to declare 
> their requirements up front, they usually over-specify... when you 
> offer a range of services at varying prices, *then* they show what 
> they'll really pay for.

The problem I have with this theory is that the USPS is, by and large, a 
very efficient organization. The move billions of peices of mail and 
lose a very small percentage of it. For about 40 cents, you can sent a 
letter from anywhere in the country to anywhere else in the country, and 
have it arrive in about 3 days.

I do not believe the money making entities could do that.

> We constantly tell the USPS that daily home visits are at the very 
> heart of our most basic expectations.  We endow that expectation with 
> the force of a legal mandate. But I suspect that if daily visits were 
> put side-by-side with a service offered a different model, we would 
> see what people are actually willing to pay for pretty quickly.

Only delivery is certain. Many families and businesses depend on daily 
delivery.

Russ

>>>>> "Ray" == Percival, Ray <Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com> writes:

Ray> For the love of all that is good in the universe please
Ray> don't. [...] Emacs makes a horrible mail client and is not so hot
Ray> as a browser and IMO does not even do the test editing thing so
Ray> well.

Having used Emacs for email and USENET for, oh, close to 10 years now,
I'll say that Emacs/Gnus is wonderful for both.  I can click on
embedded links in messages and have the URL sent to my local display
host's browser to load (e.g. if I am reading email with Emacs on my
office machine over a ssh link from home, the browser on my home
machine gets the URL to load).

Some people don't like Emacs.  While I cry for them, I also recognize
it is their right to wander in the desert.  ;-)

> I'm trying to use Mozilla as an e-mail client on my laptop. The window

At least in sawfish (gnome) you can alt-click anywhere on the window and 
drag it until you can grab a corner to make the window the size you want.

Then click the upper left corner box and go to History | Remember dimensions 
(usually works).

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Oct 21 16:05:54 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 16:05:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] System Hangs on Shutdown
Message-ID: <3DB48852.518633B3@attbi.com>

When I choose to halt or reboot my Debian desktop machine, the process
hangs at:

usb.c: deregistering driver usbdevfs

At that point, the only thing that has any effect on the system is the
reset button. If, instead of choosing reboot or halt from the X login
screen, I instead switch to a text console, log in as root, run telinit
1, give root's password when asked if I want to perform maintenance, and
then run halt, the system will shut down correctly.

It seems to me that the problem must be related to the USB smartcard
reader (I'm pretty sure that's what the usbdevfs is pointing to). Could
there be something wrong with the order in which shut down occurs? Where
can I find what controls telinit 1 versus normal shutdown? Maybe by
looking at the order of shutdown for telinit 1, I can see what the order
should be for a normal shutdown, and see if it indeed is.

Thanks in advance.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 21 17:37:03 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 21 Oct 2002 17:37:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] System Hangs on Shutdown
In-Reply-To: <3DB48852.518633B3@attbi.com>
References: <3DB48852.518633B3@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1035247024.25572.136.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2002-10-21 at 16:05, Richard Steffens wrote:
> When I choose to halt or reboot my Debian desktop machine, the process
> hangs at:
> 
> usb.c: deregistering driver usbdevfs
> 
> At that point, the only thing that has any effect on the system is the
> reset button. If, instead of choosing reboot or halt from the X login
> screen, I instead switch to a text console, log in as root, run telinit
> 1, give root's password when asked if I want to perform maintenance, and
> then run halt, the system will shut down correctly.
> 
> It seems to me that the problem must be related to the USB smartcard
> reader (I'm pretty sure that's what the usbdevfs is pointing to). Could
> there be something wrong with the order in which shut down occurs? Where
> can I find what controls telinit 1 versus normal shutdown? Maybe by
> looking at the order of shutdown for telinit 1, I can see what the order
> should be for a normal shutdown, and see if it indeed is.
>
You want to look in the /etc/rc*.d directories (for debian systems), the
scripts in /etc/init.d are called from these "run level" directories. 
The ones that start with K are stopped, the ones that start with S are
started, but some of the scripts are "started" to facilitate a shutdown
(like umountnfs.sh).

HTH

Derek Loree

the screen- I've tried all kinds of commands and it won't work. Any 
suggestions for having it do both?

make >& make.out

Random thought #14 (Collect all 17)

From brucek at kingkon.com  Mon Oct 21 21:30:46 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Mon, 21 Oct 2002 21:30:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A regex conundrum
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210738570.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Mon, Oct 21, 2002 at 07:39:39AM -0700
References: <20021021072911.B8383@defiant.ncplus.net> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210210738570.20390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021021213046.E8383@defiant.ncplus.net>

Rich Shepard's Log: StarDate 1021.0739:
> On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> 
> > escape the dot:  "\.ad\."
> 
> Bruce,
> 
>   Does this work in an address?

AFAIK, regex is consistant. If you're not sure where the dot is in the
string, then it gets more complicated (unless you're good with sed,
I'm not).

Your message indicated you were filtering on .ad., and getting
strings where any char might be in the dot; that tells me that your
filter is using regex, so you should be able to escape the dot in your
filter recipe.

I'd just give it a try, and see what happens. route the 'found'
strings somewhere to see if you're trapping the right stuff.

-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Oct 22 06:28:02 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 06:28:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A regex conundrum
In-Reply-To: <20021021213046.E8383@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210220624290.23284-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 21 Oct 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> Your message indicated you were filtering on .ad., and getting
> strings where any char might be in the dot; that tells me that your
> filter is using regex, so you should be able to escape the dot in your
> filter recipe.

Bruce,

  I see that I was not clear in my writing. My postfix regex filters include
those for "advertisement" in its various guises, such as "adv" or "ADV". I
tweaked the syntax so it no longer filters out the "adv"anced linux group
notices, but I suspect it was this string that caught the address.

  The address to which I wished to send the message was ... at nic.ad.jp. I'm
speculating that the header check for the advertising spam picked up the
"ad" part of the domain name. I may very well be mistaken.

Rich




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Oct 22 08:46:15 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 10:46:15 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] ATT Cable Modem
Message-ID: <EX-20021022-105103-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Well as some of you will recall last week I sent out a message asking a question about getting ATT Cable modems running. Now I might have missed something but the only thing I could get to work was installing a Winders box and running the stupid virtual tech disk. Once that worked everything worked but I could not get the webpage to work and could not get it to work on a work laptop. So in short my advice if you are going to get cable plan on having a win box to finish the install with after that you should be fine. 




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Tue Oct 22 08:54:52 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 08:54:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Job Openning: Network/System Admin @ Tigard-Tualatin School District
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210220851490.23416-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

Tigard-Tualatin School District has a position open for a Network Systems
Administrator. My peers over at TTSD are friendly and clueful, I've always
enjoyed working with them.

As you can see from what they are looking for, they also have some *very*
*serious* bandwidth and are Linux friendly. What more could you ask for? ;-)

Here's the official job posting:

http://www.ttsd.k12.or.us/hrwebsite/mod.php?mod=userpage&menu=10349&page_id=69

-Eric


Network Administrator

Oversees maintenance and administration of Tigard-Tualatin School
District's network. Supports, monitors, tests and troubleshoots hardware
and software problems pertaining to the LAN/WAN. Schedules and performs
network maintenance, installation, configuration, and repairs. Provides
support for all routers, switches, firewall, VLANs, ATM, and Ethernet
technologies. Designs standard network security measures that address
medium and strong levels of security for above environments, including
firewalls, VPNs, Proxy Servers, DNS Servers, intrusion
detection/prevention systems and other access-control methodologies to
mitigate security threats. Interfaces with other senior level personnel
and delivers technical information in a concise, understandable and
accurate fashion.

Education and/or Experience Required:

* Bachelor's degree desired
* 3-5 years of experience with Cisco routing protocols; experience with
  VLANs a must
* Knowledge and experience with CISCO network infrastructure equipment
* Knowledge and experience with CISCO PIX firewall and VPNs
* Thorough understating of TCP/IP, Ethernet, Gigabit Ethernet, and ATM
  networks
* Hands-on experience with Cisco and 3com networking switch gear
* Hands-on experience with network monitoring tools such as packet
  sniffers, traffic shapers, and/or Intermapper.
* Knowledge and experience with DNS and Proxy Servers
* Thorough understanding of network security
* Knowledge and experience with Red Hat Linux
* Desire to work in a K-12 educational environment
* Have the physical capacity to lift computers, monitors and electronic
  equipment weighing 40-70 lbs.
* Current valid Oregon drivers license, personal transportation to use
  in course of work
* Salary: TTSD Classified Position: AB Salary Schedule: (approx. =
  $49,428-64,563 depending on experience)

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Oct 22 09:01:17 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 09:01:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ATT Cable Modem
References: <EX-20021022-105103-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <3DB5764D.7080102@sun.com>

Heh.

I had cable internet installed on Sunday.  The Virtual Technician disk 
would NOT work for me - for some reason it couldn't find my nic card.

So I came to work for a while, found the thread about this subject, 
printed it out, and did a google search for more information.

Found this:

http://www.dslreports.com/faq/attbi?text=1

And the last entry worked *perfectly*, using whichever browser you so 
desire.  I believe I finished the install with a win98 box I scrounged 
up - it was connected to the modem due to the Virtual Technician disc 
needing that configuration, and I'm lazy.

However, 30 minutes after I arrived home, it was working.  YMMV.

-R

Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
Message-ID: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g>

Hi All Guys,

The problem is as follows:

ipchains and iptables stopped
# service smb start

On Win98
- 2 members found in the workgroup "Scw98"(Win98) and "M40G".
Samba server 
- Clicking "M40G" popup a warning "permission not allowed"
- Searching computer with the name of Samba server "M40G" found it there
but searching with its IP address could not find it
- Ping M40G and IP address of Samba server showed connected

On Samba server
"as root"
- "mount" could not mount Samba server
- Ping SCW98 and IP address of Win98 showed connecting


INFORMATION
===========

Both Win98 and Samba server need password to login

Samba server
OS - RH8.0
2 NICs - one for broadband connection another for connecting Win98 via a
crossover cable
IP address - 192.168.0.2
Computer name - M40G

/etc/samba/smb.conf (basic configure)

[global]

workgroup = SEC 
guest account = satimis
encrypt passwords = no
hosts allow = yes
security = share 

[test] 
comment = share 
path = /home
browseable = yes
read only = no
guest only = no 
guest ok = yes

/etc/hosts
127.0.0.1       localhost.localdomain   localhost
192.168.0.1     SCW98
192.168.0.2     M40G
        

Win98
IP address - 192.168.0.1
Computer name - SCW98

Components
....
- IPX/SPX
- Net BEUI
- NetBIOS support for IPX/SPX
- TCP/IP
....


Kindly advise.  Thanks in advance.

Stephen Liu

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Oct 22 10:00:22 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 10:00:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Exchange HOWTO Update
In-Reply-To: <1035303959.27377.149.camel@dereklinux>

Message-ID: <51204.192.168.1.2.1035306022.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

> Too bad it isn't a real replacement, no server side calender.

Yep. Gosh, only web-based LDAP compatable web based solutions that offer
Outlook synchronization is available:

  http://www.webevent.com/products/team/

Imagine getting your calendering information through a browser from
anywhere on the Internet without having an Outlook client on your
computer. At the same time, imaging the user nestling in with their
familiar Outlook calender when they return to their desks...

This is just one of at least a dozen other products available.

The goal here is to make sure our customers are free of vendor lock while
at the same time giving them as many (secure) acess options as possible.


-Cooper

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Tue Oct 22 10:12:26 2002

What a lot of people don't understand is that in the corporate world they
want something that works like outlook, because they don't want to change
the way they do things.  If there was a very comparable outlook-like app
for linux (or even windows) it would be a no-brainer.  Throwing all the
web-based stuff at them isn't really going to fly well with most suits.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Oct 22 10:36:36 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 10:36:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g>
References: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g>
Message-ID: <20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-22 09:18]:
> Both Win98 and Samba server need password to login
> 
> Samba server
> OS - RH8.0
> 2 NICs - one for broadband connection another for connecting Win98 via a
> crossover cable
> IP address - 192.168.0.2
> Computer name - M40G
> 
> /etc/samba/smb.conf (basic configure)
> 
> [global]
> 
> workgroup = SEC 
> guest account = satimis

Does the "satimis" user exist in /etc/passwd? All samba users must also
exist as unix users. 

> encrypt passwords = no

I believe for Windows 98, you will need encryption on, as Windows 98
encrypts by default. That is, unless you've run the registry hack to
turn it off. It's easier to just use "encrypt passwords = yes"

> hosts allow = yes

This should be an IP, not a yes or no. Valid entries are 192.168.0.0/24,
127.0.0.1/8, 10.1.1.1, etc.

> security = share 

security = user is the recommended setting, as this validates against
existing user settings. 

> [test] 
> comment = share 
> path = /home
> browseable = yes
> read only = no
> guest only = no 
> guest ok = yes

For home directories, use the following section:

[homes]
	comment = Home Directories
	read only = No
	guest ok = Yes

Nothing more is needed in that section. Remember, the Windows login name
and the unix login name must be the same, or the smbusers file must map
unixname to windowsname. 

Quite frankly Stephen, it looks like you tried to build this by hand
without reading the massive quantities of help files on the samba.org
website. 

As a suggestion, I recommend using swat to configure samba. Install
swat, if it's not already there, and point your web browser to
http://hostname:901. In addition to being able to configure the server
completely, there is a ton of documentation there at the click of a
button. Each entry has a help button with the complete documentation
that opens in another window. 

I also recommend that you get the original smb.conf file that comes with
your distribution and start with that. Then run swat to configure from
there. 

Make one change at a time, and see if it works better. Most of the time,
I can take the default file, change the workgroup, the password
configuration, add users, and go. It then works for the home directories. 
At that point, you can add other shares.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #16 (Collect all 17)
"It is often easier to fight for principles than to live up to them." - Adlai Stevenson



From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Oct 22 10:59:58 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 10:59:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Exchange HOWTO Update
In-Reply-To: <2776.66.93.41.102.1035306746.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>; from plug@magnetinternet.com on Tue, Oct 22, 2002 at 10:12:26AM -0700
References: <50862.192.168.1.2.1035302649.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name> <1035303959.27377.149.camel@dereklinux> <51204.192.168.1.2.1035306022.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name> <2776.66.93.41.102.1035306746.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <20021022105957.A27887@cooper.kattare.com>

Matt;

> What a lot of people don't understand is that in the corporate world they
> want something that works like outlook, because they don't want to change
> the way they do things.  If there was a very comparable outlook-like app
> for linux (or even windows) it would be a no-brainer.  Throwing all the
> web-based stuff at them isn't really going to fly well with most suits.

I could'nt agree more. We can't just walk in and say, ``okay, we need you to ditch 5 years of (insert application here). We're going with product X now!''

Specifically for this case, we need a drop-in calendering replacement for use with Outlook. It must also be transparent to the user. If it has web-based functionality, all the better.

For connecting to a standard IMAP server with calendering through an Outlook client, Bynari's Insight Connector does exactly this. You don't have to buy the whole Bynari package, just the connector plug-in. The back-end may then remain standard. This increases the robustness and flexability of the system:

  http://www.bynari.net/bynari/insightcon.html


Best,


Cooper

  Forwarded from the PostgresQL users list.

Rich

---------- Forwarded message ----------
The position is in Walnut Creek California. We are looking for a highly
experienced postgres consultant that has significant experience in tuning
postgres data bases.  The person we are looking for would have recent
experience in doing tuning.  Recent defined as within the last year.  The
individual would have data base design and modeling experience.  Would have
programming experience with SQL.  Would have 10 or more years experience
doing sophisticated data base design data modeling and performance tuning of
large, complex data bases.  Need to know postgres internals.  Need to have
deep expertise in development and performance tuning of stored procedures. 
Need to have somebody in the Bay Area; we are located in Walnut Creek
California.  A definite plus would someone who has worked on the Berkeley
postgres project or contributed to the open source postgres system.  The
person would be a consultant, not an employee of a company.
 
We estimate that this person would be required for a maximum of four
weeks.

To get more information, reply to ibrody at pacbell.net







From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Oct 22 15:28:03 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Procmail recipe
Message-ID: <20021022222803.GA26369@sthelens.dimstar.net>

I'm just now getting to some of the more convoluted procmail stuff.

I have the following in my .procmailrc:

#SPAM
:0:
* ^Subject:\*\*\*\*\*SPAM\*\*\*\*\*
| ${FORMAIL} -A"X-Folder: SPAM" >>~/Mail/SPAM

Basically, I want any mail with "*****SPAM*****" in the subject line to
go to the spam holding area, ~/Mail/SPAM. 

What I have above isn't working. 

I've tried * ^Subject:*****SPAM***** too, and that didn't work either.

What have I overlooked?

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Oct 22 15:36:15 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 15:36:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sound quit working
Message-ID: <3DB5D2DF.6E2BD527@attbi.com>

I'm not sure what I did, but sound used to work on my RH 7.0 machine,
and now it doesn't. The most recent change was getting the CD-burner to
work last week. After the CD-Burner was working, I couldn't play a CD on
the machine, but I could rip a CD with cdparanoia, I could play a .wav
file with gramophone, and I could play a .mp3 file with mpg123.

I don't know what happened between then and now, (the machine has been
up the whole time), but now, I can't play a .wav file from gramophone,
and gramophone no longer records. Also, gramohpone program does not know
that it isn't working; I get no error messages, but I also get no sound.
The same is true with mpg123; no error messages and no sound.

I've been looking at the sound HOWTO and have one clue. It recommends
running:

tail /var/log/messages

The second to last entry is:

Oct 22 14:06:48 NEC modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
sound-service-0-6

I assume that I used to have a module called sound-service-0-6, and that
now I don't, but I don't know what I did to create said module, or to
destroy it.

Here is some additional information.

lsmod shows:

emu10k1		42952	2
soundcore	 2596	4	[emu10k1]

dmesg shows:

Creative EMU10K1 PCI Audio Driver, version 0.6, 16:20:54 Aug 22 2000
emu10k1: EMU10K1 rev 8 model 0x8064 found, IO at 0xff80-0xff9f, IRQ 10

Any ideas? Could it have anything to do with starting up sg and the
other things I did to get the CD-Burner working?

Thanks in advance for any assistance you can provide.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Oct 22 16:17:03 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 16:17:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail recipe
In-Reply-To: <20021022222803.GA26369@sthelens.dimstar.net>; from russj@dimstar.net on Tue, Oct 22, 2002 at 03:28:03PM -0700
References: <20021022222803.GA26369@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20021022161703.A5271@kippered.herring.org>

Russ,

I take it you want to both (1) add an "X-Folder: SPAM" header, and (2)
deliver it to your SPAM mail folder. This will do it...

#SPAM
:0:
* ^Subject:.*\*\*\*\*\*SPAM\*\*\*\*\*
| ${FORMAIL} -A"X-Folder: SPAM"
SPAM

...assuming, of course, the `${FORMAIL}' expands to the location of the
`formail' executable on your system (e.g. /usr/bin/formail). That's not an
environment variable which is automatically set by `procmail'.

BTW, note the inclusion of the ".*" regexp after the "Subject:" header.

Lastly, if it's spamassassin that's tagging the Subject: for you (I'd bet a
brewskie on that :-), you could simply test against the header it inserts...

## Flagged as SPAM by spamassassin?
:0:
* ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
SPAM

...and not even bother adding your own X-header.

hth,
Sandy


On Tue, 22 Oct 2002, Russ Johnson wrote: 
> I'm just now getting to some of the more convoluted procmail stuff.
> 
> I have the following in my .procmailrc:
> 
> #SPAM
> :0:
> * ^Subject:\*\*\*\*\*SPAM\*\*\*\*\*
> | ${FORMAIL} -A"X-Folder: SPAM" >>~/Mail/SPAM
> 
> Basically, I want any mail with "*****SPAM*****" in the subject line to
> go to the spam holding area, ~/Mail/SPAM. 
> 
> What I have above isn't working. 
> 
> I've tried * ^Subject:*****SPAM***** too, and that didn't work either.
> 
> What have I overlooked?
> 
> -- 
> --
> Russ Johnson
> Dimension 7/Stargate Online
> http://www.dimstar.net

-- 
Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/

sndconfig. It worked, but when I switched back to the X console and
tried to log in, X hung after I entered my password. I've managed to
confuse my Debian system with my RH system and tried running telinit 1,

again. I was told that new hardware was found, my CD-Burner. I'm sure

From revans at e-z.net  Tue Oct 22 17:03:30 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)

Look at your /etc/modules.conf. sound-service-0-6 is an alias to the module,
not the module's name.

Thank you
Russell

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Oct 22 18:39:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 18:39:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] [ANNOUNCE] OpenMFG:  PostgreSQL-backed ERP for small manufacturers
 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210221838030.25148-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  For anyone interested.

Rich
---------- Forwarded message ----------
Greetings,

Just a quick note to let everyone here know of a new product that ought to
further the acceptance of PostgreSQL as a serious mission-critical business
database.  We announced the launch today of a new product called OpenMFG - a
sophisticated ERP system for small manufacturers that runs on PostgreSQL.

It's built with the Qt framework for C++ (400,000 lines) and also makes
extensive use of PL/PGSQL for the ERP business logic.  Qt gives us the
ability to run the client on Windows, Linux, any other Unix, even OS X.  We
can run multiplatform on the server side as well, although we're currently
happiest on Linux; when the native PostgreSQL for Windows port is done in
7.4, we'll support that fully as well.

Part of the Qt client work we've done is a fully cross-platform report
writer and rendering engine, which stores the report definitions in
PostgreSQL in XML format.

If there are any manufacturing/ERP types on this list, and you'd like to
talk, please give me a shout; we're doing some pretty interesting stuff -
including making source code available to our partners and customers.

More info on the software and the company is at www.openmfg.com.  There's a
press release at http://lwn.net/Articles/13366/.

Regards,
Ned

--
Ned Lilly
President/CEO
OpenMFG, LLC
420 North Center Drive
Building 11, Suite 115
Norfolk, VA 23502
tel. 757.461.3022
email: ned at openmfg.com
www.openmfg.com

over fiber optic cable)". Then this information has to be presented to

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Oct 22 20:52:39 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 20:52:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Light based signal encoding techniques
In-Reply-To: <3DB60DF5.5060309@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0210222036110.26174-100000@ox.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Some interesting research has been done on collecting light signals from
blinker leds and turning it back into data. For example, the led blinks on
some types of modem and router can be collected from a few hundred yards
away and reconstituted into the data passing through the modem, assuming a
fairly low (1 Mbps) bitrate. Basically it's like fiber optics w/no fiber.

Here's a clip I submitted last spring or so:

http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=02/03/06/1221224&mode=thread&tid=172

and the paper itself:

"Information Leakage from Optical Emanations", Joe Loughry and David
Umphress.

http://applied-math.org/optical_tempest.pdf

HTH,

Tyler



On Tue, 22 Oct 2002, Terrel Woolbright wrote:

> I have a class at PCC and with it a term project. I need to find out
> what I can about "Light based signal encoding techniques (sending data
> over fiber optic cable)". Then this information has to be presented to
> the class. Is there anyone out here that would have information about

> Terrel

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Oct 22 20:57:58 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 20:57:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Light based signal encoding techniques
References: <3DB60DF5.5060309@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DB61E46.5976C90D@attbi.com>

Terrel Woolbright wrote:

> I have a class at PCC and with it a term project. I need to find out
> what I can about "Light based signal encoding techniques (sending data
> over fiber optic cable)". Then this information has to be presented to
> the class. Is there anyone out here that would have information about
> this or know where to direct me? Web sites, files, company information,
> standards, etc would be fine and much appreciated.

Third entry on a google search of "fiber optic cable" turns up this:

http://www.howstuffworks.com/fiber-optic.htm

A "search within results" for "tia/eia" on the first search gets you
closer to the standards setting organizations, the Telecommunications
Industry Association," and the "Electronic Industries Alliance." These
are the guys who publish the standard for Category 5 cable (and the
other "CAT's" too). They also handle fiber standards, like the "Fibre
Distributed Data Interface (FDDI)." (Add "fddi" to the above search and
look at http://www.berktek.com/berktek/technical/gloss114.asp )

Another source of information might be an electrical contractor like
Electrical Construction or Christiansen. If there's anybody still at
home in their Voice & Data departments, during the current economic
downturn, they might have some brochures you could get, or some other
ideas of where to look.

Hope that helps.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Oct 22 21:42:29 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 21:42:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Light based signal encoding techniques
References: <3DB60DF5.5060309@attbi.com>

Terrel Woolbright wrote:
> I have a class at PCC and with it a term project. I need to find out 
> what I can about "Light based signal encoding techniques (sending data 
> over fiber optic cable)". Then this information has to be presented to 
> the class. Is there anyone out here that would have information about 
> this or know where to direct me? Web sites, files, company information, 
> standards, etc would be fine and much appreciated.

And if you're looking for more ideas...Quantum encrytion (believed 
unbreakable) [1] was discussed in "The Code Book", by Simon Singh.  It has 
been "workable" for a few years [2] and everyone wants it now.  Just the 
thing for all the dark fiber around the country.

Still fuzzy why a quantum computer can't break a quantum encryption scheme. 
     But I'm sure there's a good reason, and a bad reason, and a few others.


[1] Defined: <http://www.disenchanted.com/dis/lookup?node=1176>
[2] Thumbnail: <http://www.mitre.org/pubs/edge/january_02/gilbert2.html>

Also: 
<http://www.trnmag.com/Stories/2002/080702/Quantum_secrets_ride_phone_lines_080702.html>


Cheers,
Accardi Kyle




From satimis at writeme.com  Tue Oct 22 21:55:41 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 12:55:41 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g> 
	<20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1035348941.1485.84.camel@m40g>

Hi Russ,

Lot of thanks for your advice.  It works now with following adjustment
made to 

1)
/etc/samba/smb.conf
[global]

workgroup = SEC 
guest account = satimis
encrypt passwords = yes
security = user 

[homes]
comment = Home Directories
read only = No
guest ok = Yes

2) Delete  IPX/SPX  on Win98

3) New  /etc/hosts
127.0.0.1	localhost.localdomain	localhost
192.168.0.1	SCW98
192.168.0.2	M40G


I still have following problems and expected to be advised.

1) # umount /mnt/Win98  could not dismount the directory.  I have to
stop Samba server with "service smb stop" first.

2) If I don't add "192.168.0.2	M40G" in /etc/hosts, the computer-name of
Samba server appears as "localhost" under the workgroup on Win98.  If I
add ""192.168.0.2  M40G" in /etc/hosts",at starting RH8.0 it takes quite
long time to detect

a) Starting sendmail  [OK]
b) Starting sm-client [OK]

> swat, if it's not already there, and point your web browser to

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Oct 22 22:24:38 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 22:24:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1035348941.1485.84.camel@m40g>
References: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g> <20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035348941.1485.84.camel@m40g>
Message-ID: <20021023052438.GA2309@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-22 21:56]:
> 
> I still have following problems and expected to be advised.
> 
> 1) # umount /mnt/Win98  could not dismount the directory.  I have to
> stop Samba server with "service smb stop" first.

Hmm, the samba service has nothing to do with the mounting of the drive
from the Windows box. You shouldn't have to have samba running to mount
the drive from the windows box. 

What is the error you get when you try to umount it? 

> 2) If I don't add "192.168.0.2	M40G" in /etc/hosts, the computer-name of
> Samba server appears as "localhost" under the workgroup on Win98.  If I
> add ""192.168.0.2  M40G" in /etc/hosts",at starting RH8.0 it takes quite
> long time to detect
> 
> a) Starting sendmail  [OK]
> b) Starting sm-client [OK]

Unless you are RECEIVING email on this system, turn off sendmail. You
don't need sendmail running as a daemon unless you are receiving email
from another system. You can turn off sendmail by running
/etc/init.d/sendmail stop. Make sure it doesn't turn on again at the
next reboot by running ntsysv (on Redhat) and unselecting sendmail.

> > - snip -
> > Does the "satimis" user exist in /etc/passwd? All samba users must also
> > exist as unix users.
> 
> - snip -
> satimis:x:500:500:Stephen Liu:/home/satimis:/bin/bash
> - snip -

OK, it's weird to have a regular user as the "guest" user. You probably
want 'nobody' or something like that. 

'satimis' would be a regular user, not a guest. 

If you specify satimis as guest, everyone inherits his files when they
log in as guest via samba.

>  
> > - snip -
> > Nothing more is needed in that section. Remember, the Windows login name
> > and the unix login name must be the same, or the smbusers file must map
> > unixname to windowsname.
> 
> Sorry I am not quite clear about your comment.  The Win98 login name and
> password are same as Samba server user, only one user for this test, but
> root is different.  I login in as root for all tests because if I login
> as user "satimis" I am not allowed to start Samba server even with "su"
> on command line.  What do you mean "smbusers file must map unixname to
> windowsname"

check out the smbusers file and that section of the docs. You may not
have to worry about it, unless you have windows login names and unix
login names that don't match. Remember, case matters in unix. The
windows user "Chris" won't match the unix user "chris".

--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

problems.  So being that fdisk reports it as a 38GB drive, any partition

ext3.  Someone suggested using instead ReiserFS which I haven't tried, as
it may better results in freeing up the remainer of the drive.  So for $50
I am fairly happy with this big (but slow) removable backup drive.

when the file is modified?
I expect mtime and atime to change, but ctime? Seems

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 23 09:32:49 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 09:32:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1035372537.1531.84.camel@m40g>
References: <1035303449.1688.13.camel@m40g> <20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035348941.1485.84.camel@m40g> <20021023052438.GA2309@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035372537.1531.84.camel@m40g>
Message-ID: <20021023163249.GA19930@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-23 04:29]:
> Now "umount" works.  Last time when I issued this command as root it
> complained with something like "it is busy" but I already closed all
> files, directories and applications except Console window on KDE.

Most likely, "something" was open, or wedged. 

> There are still have 2 problems unsolved
> 
> 1) '# mount' could not mount  /mnt/Win98  As root I have to issue
> following command
> 
> # mount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98/
> Password:
> 
> I just hit [Enter] then it can mount.  'Password' seems having no
> function

Specify the password on the command line. 

mount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o password=""

I haven't tested this, so it may not work. 

> 2) On Win98 following directories shown in workgroup under Samba server
> 
> homes
> myshare
> satimis
> Profiles
> Public
> tmp
> 
> Can I issue "chmod 755" to get rid some of them.  In such a case whether
> other users on Samba server still can visit them.

Are you saying the all those shares appear as shared on the linux box
when you browse to it from the Win98 box?

If that's the case, and you don't want that, remove their entries from
the smb.conf file, restart samba and they should go away. Since Windows
98 caches this information, it may take a reboot on the Windows 98 side
to make it go away, once the samba server isn't sharing them anymore.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 23 10:02:17 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 10:02:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
In-Reply-To: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red>
References: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red>
Message-ID: <20021023170217.GA20858@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> [2002-10-23 09:31]:
> Can someone with a richer Unix background than I give
> me a historical perspective on why a file's ctime changes
> when the file is modified?
> I expect mtime and atime to change, but ctime? Seems
> like lunacy to me, which means there's a good reason
> I'm not privy to.

ctime is "time of last modification of file status information"

If the file information (size, inode, mtime, atime, anything at all?)
changes, then the ctime changes.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson

Hi All,

I came across a listing at the Symantec site of a trojan that is
targeted to only linux systems.  The strange part is, a password must be
supplied to run it!  Somebody must be planning some serious social
engineering. (Make the trojan so secure that only serious security
hackers can run it?)

http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/backdoor.wiween.html

Anyway, I thought it was worth a heads-up.

Derek Loree




From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Oct 23 10:29:25 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 10:29:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
In-Reply-To: <20021023170217.GA20858@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red> 
	<20021023170217.GA20858@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1035394165.25623.347.camel@red>

On Wed, 2002-10-23 at 10:02, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> [2002-10-23 09:31]:
> > Can someone with a richer Unix background than I give
> > me a historical perspective on why a file's ctime changes
> > when the file is modified?
> > I expect mtime and atime to change, but ctime? Seems
> > like lunacy to me, which means there's a good reason
> > I'm not privy to.
> 
> ctime is "time of last modification of file status information"
> 
> If the file information (size, inode, mtime, atime, anything at all?)
> changes, then the ctime changes.

Thanks. Other file systems/operating systems I've dealt with
consider ctime to be the file's creation time. You always know
when the file was created because that historic information is
always there. We don't have this with Linux/ext2/3. On the
positive side, we know the date and time of the last change
to a file's properties. Unfortunately, ctime is changed not
only when you change a property, but also when you modify
the file's contents - making it far less valuable to a user
or administrator.

Ed




From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 23 10:52:25 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 10:52:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
In-Reply-To: <1035394165.25623.347.camel@red>
References: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red> <20021023170217.GA20858@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035394165.25623.347.camel@red>
Message-ID: <20021023175225.GA21487@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> [2002-10-23 10:25]:
> Unfortunately, ctime is changed not
> only when you change a property, but also when you modify
> the file's contents - making it far less valuable to a user
> or administrator.

Except when you modify the contents of the file, you are modifying file
properties. The size, mtime and inode will all possibly change upon
a modification of the content of the file. 

As far as other file systems, which ones? I've looked on solaris, linux
and hp-ux, and all say that ctime is what I said previously. Everything
I've found so far says that this is a POSIX standard, and that all
systems that are POSIX compliant have to follow this. That would include
the three I've listed above, plus AIX, Tru64, the BSDs and many others. 

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Wed Oct 23 11:05:32 2002
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 18:05:32 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] perl advice (forking, lists problems)
Message-ID: <20021023180539.DORO8248.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>

Good morning! 

I'm working on this perl script. I'm not very good (yet) at Perl, but 
I'm getting there. Most of my learning has been at the hands of 
the Perl Cookbook (Bighorn Ram) and Programming Perl 
(Camel).  I've got this perl script that is replacing another script.

What I need to do is process a file of 30000 lines; and normally 
to do it takes a very long time (The process takes a long time, 
not the perl part). I can break it down into 6 5000 line files and it 
goes much faster.  Currently I'm running 6 copies of the script 
concurrently each with its own input file:
$ script.1 &
$ script.2 &
$ script.3 & (etc.)

That's clumsy and it won't work well for my next step without a 
rewrite (which will require processing on the main data file) 
And since I'm rewriting it anyway ... 

Here's what I have now:
----------
#!/usr/bin/perl

# sub: handleme
# input: index for the $lists array.
# output: whatever the function does.
# use: processes the @lists[$reference] array
# with these items.
sub handleme
{
  my ($reference) = @_;
  print "$reference has " . @lists[$reference]. " elements\n";
  sleep 2;
}


# set up our array of array references.
# these first two arrays are sub-arrays for 
# the main "lists" array.
@list1=();
@list2=();
@lists=(\@list1,\@list2);

# splittest.data contains 1\n2\n etc through 20
# live functionality has 30000 lines.

open BIGDOG, "< splittest.data";
while (<BIGDOG>)
{
  chomp;
  push(@bigarray, $_);
}
close BIGDOG;

while (scalar (@bigarray) > 0)
{ 
  push @list1, shift(@bigarray);
  push @list2, shift(@bigarray);
}
 print "data acquired\n";

# now list1 and list2 contain alternating lines of the 
# original file. The alternating doesn't matter.


# this is the main processing area.
# i is the index of @lists that we're working with
# and it's also the number of children. 
$i=0;
FORK:
{
  if ($pid= fork) 
  { 
    # parent here
    # this is currently testing against 1; 
    # in development, we want 6 iterations not 2
    # it's the last index of the array
    # and it's the maximum children.
    while ($i<1)
    {
    print " $i - father stuff\n";
    $i++;
    redo FORK;
    }
  }
  elsif (defined $pid)
  {
    print "\tchild process begin\n";
    handleme $i;
    print "\tchild process end\n";
  }
  elsif ($! =~ /No more process/)
  {
  sleep 5;
  redo FORK;
  }
  else
  {
   die "ack! $! \n";
  }
}

-----------

However, in the function, I can't access the arrays; with a 
"foreach $item (@array) {print "$item\n"}, I get "ARRAY(code)".
If I ask "what am I doing wrong?" I'm sure you'll say "oh geez, 
where do we begin" so perhaps ... "How do I reference the 
arrays in @lists, so I can see the items of the lists in lists ?"

Your help is appreciated :)

-Russ



From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Oct 23 02:57:13 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 02:57:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] strange trojan
In-Reply-To: <1035393753.27377.172.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210230255010.4412-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

This is similar to the "ABFrag exploit".

ABFrag supposedly will hack a remote linux or bsd using a tcp/ip 
fragmentation attack. It is actually a trojan that steals /etc/shadow and 
a few other things and sends it off to the author of the program.

I guess Outlook users have become too easy of a target.

On 23 Oct 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Oct 23 11:53:31 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 11:53:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Bizarre audio CD player problem
In-Reply-To: <1030059785.14021.7225.camel@dereklinux>
References: 
	<4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com> 
	<20020822220306.GA13212@znet.com>  <1030059785.14021.7225.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1035399211.25544.205.camel@dereklinux>

Just to follow up, for the archive.  I have not tracked down the cause
of this problem, but I did find a player that will work for a normal
user, and play all of the way to the end of the audio tracks, with no
problems.  The name of the program is cdcd, it is command line only, but
is very functional, and has CDDB lookup capabilities.

I stumbled across it because my son wanted to use his computer as an
alarm, so I created a cron job that will start his CD player, and
increase the volume over a 10 minute time interval.  The cdcd program
does this, or it will start a shell if you don't give the command line
any options.

Derek Loree

gilmanhunt at attbi.com wrote:

>Good morning! 
>
>I'm working on this perl script. I'm not very good (yet) at Perl, but 
>I'm getting there. Most of my learning has been at the hands of 
>the Perl Cookbook (Bighorn Ram) and Programming Perl

>
>What I need to do is process a file of 30000 lines; and normally 
>to do it takes a very long time (The process takes a long time, 
>not the perl part). I can break it down into 6 5000 line files and it 
>goes much faster.  Currently I'm running 6 copies of the script 
>concurrently each with its own input file:
>$ script.1 &
>$ script.2 &
>$ script.3 & (etc.)
>
>That's clumsy and it won't work well for my next step without a 
>rewrite (which will require processing on the main data file) 
>And since I'm rewriting it anyway ...

>----------
>#!/usr/bin/perl
>
#turn on warning

#!/usr/bin/perl -w

# I always use strict...

># input: index for the $lists array.
># output: whatever the function does.
># use: processes the @lists[$reference] array
># with these items.
>sub handleme
>{
>
# I'm not quite sure what this function is doing... and, you won't be 
able to access @lists inside this sub...
# you can shift here... then you're not required to make a list for a 
single value
my $reference = shift;
# or
my $reference = $_[0];

>  my ($reference) = @_;
>
# but, if you could, @lists is a list of lists... so
my $list_ref = @lists[$reference];
print "$reference has " . @$list_ref  . " elements \n";

>  sleep 2;
>}
>
>

># these first two arrays are sub-arrays for 
># the main "lists" array.
>

my @list1;
my @list2;
my @lists = (\@list1, \@list2);

>@list1=();
>@list2=();
>@lists=(\@list1,\@list2);
