># live functionality has 30000 lines.
>
>open BIGDOG, "< splittest.data";
>while (<BIGDOG>)
>{
>  chomp;
>  push(@bigarray, $_);
>}
>close BIGDOG;
>
my $file = "splittest.data";
open (BIGDOG, $file) or
    die("Err opening $file: $!\n");

#slurps the file into the array
@bigarray = <BIGDOG>;

close (BIGDOG);
#chomps all elements in @bigarray
chomp @bigarray;

#If you're only splitting into 2 lists, I would recommend something like 
this

for(my $i; $i < ($#bigarray / 2); $i++) {
    push @list1, shift(@bigarray);
}
#then
@list2 = @bigarray;

#and I'm sure there's an even better way to do that, but I can't think 
of the way off-hand.

>while (scalar (@bigarray) > 0)
>{ 
>  push @list1, shift(@bigarray);
>  push @list2, shift(@bigarray);
>}
> print "data acquired\n";
>
># now list1 and list2 contain alternating lines of the 
># original file. The alternating doesn't matter.
>
>
># this is the main processing area.
># i is the index of @lists that we're working with
># and it's also the number of children. 
>
#this will have to by my'ed as well.. also, perl defaults the value to 
0, so you don't need to specify it.
my $i ;

>$i=0;
>FORK:
>{
>  if ($pid= fork)
>
# should be (note the 2 equals signs)
if( $pid == fork)

> 
>  { 
>    # parent here
>    # this is currently testing against 1; 
>    # in development, we want 6 iterations not 2
>    # it's the last index of the array
>    # and it's the maximum children.
>    while ($i<1)
>    {
>    print " $i - father stuff\n";
>    $i++;
>    redo FORK;
>    }
>  }
>  elsif (defined $pid)
>  {
>    print "\tchild process begin\n";
>    handleme $i;
>    print "\tchild process end\n";
>  }
>  elsif ($! =~ /No more process/)
>  {
>  sleep 5;
>  redo FORK;
>  }
>  else
>  {
>   die "ack! $! \n";
>  }
>}

From yrn4dsl at attbi.com  Wed Oct 23 13:40:29 2002

You need to dereference the values stored in @lists. Here's an explanation by someone smarter than me.
http://www.perldoc.com/perl5.6.1/pod/perlreftut.html

From lennon at day-reynolds.com  Wed Oct 23 13:57:24 2002
From: lennon at day-reynolds.com (Lennon Day-Reynolds)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 13:57:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] perl advice (forking, lists problems)
In-Reply-To: <20021023180539.DORO8248.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>
References: <20021023180539.DORO8248.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>
Message-ID: <1035406647.1075.11.camel@dell.urusai.org>

Is there any chance you could use Perl 5.8? If so, I would highly
recommend a multi-threaded, rather than forking, approach. If you fork
the "slave" processes, you have to do a full copy of their working data
(unless you're using shared memory, of course, which is far more complex
to use correctly than threads). Also, multiple threads can much more
easily share rich data structures (like intermediate results of work)
than multiple processes.

Of course, if this really is just a one-off script with a fixed data
set, you could also just let it run in a single 'niced' process for as
long as it needs to, rather than spending hours and hours trying to
optimize the processing time. Remember the old adage: programmer time is
exponentially more expensive than processor time.

Lennon Day-Reynolds
lennon at day-reynolds.com





From bprew at logiccloud.com  Wed Oct 23 14:53:15 2002
From: bprew at logiccloud.com (Ben Prew)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 14:53:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] perl advice (forking, lists problems)
References: <20021023180539.DORO8248.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58> <1035406647.1075.11.camel@dell.urusai.org>
Message-ID: <3DB71A4B.8060009@logiccloud.com>

Here's more or less what I would do... as long as it solves your 
problems... but maybe it will give you some ideas...

#!/usr/bin/perl -w

use strict;

#split a file into 6 different pieces and send each piece out to a different
#process.

my $file = "foo";
my $splits = 6; #You can change this to fit the number of splits

open(INFILE, $file) or
    die("Error: Could not open file: $file $!\n");

my @list = <INFILE>;
chomp @list;

close INFILE;

my $marker = int(@list / $splits);
my @proc_list;
my $sys_call = "dir";
for(my $i=0; $#list > 0; $i++) {
    if( $i >= $marker ) {
        $i = 0;
        # this is where you would "do something"... I'm just making
        # system calls, but you have 1/6 of the list...
        system( $sys_call, @proc_list ) or
            die("Err: system call failed $!\n");
        @proc_list = ();
        next;
    }
    push( @proc_list, shift(@list) );
}

# I'm not sure how much information you need to store, but... this will
# give you the list broken up... if you need to store them longer, you
# could put them in a hash, etc...
   
--
Ben

Derek Loree wrote:

> On Mon, 2002-10-21 at 16:05, Richard Steffens wrote:
> > When I choose to halt or reboot my Debian desktop machine, the process
> > hangs at:
> >
> > usb.c: deregistering driver usbdevfs
>
> You want to look in the /etc/rc*.d directories (for debian systems), the
> scripts in /etc/init.d are called from these "run level" directories.
> The ones that start with K are stopped, the ones that start with S are
> started, but some of the scripts are "started" to facilitate a shutdown
> (like umountnfs.sh).

Getting back to this system, today. I rebooted, but the system hung
before it finished. I'm not all that familiar with anything other than
the term "stack dump," but that may be at what I am looking. The first
thing still on the screen is:

Starting hotplug subsystem: usbUnable to handle kernel paging request at
virtual address c403ee8f
current->tss.cr3 = 038ce000, %cr3 = 038ce000
*pde = 03854063
*pte = 00000000

...

Stack: (followed by three lines of hex numbers)
...
Call Trace: (followed by 11 sets of [<hex number>])
...
Code: ac ae 75 08 84 c0 75 f8 31 c0 eb 04 19 c0 0c 01 85 c0 0f 84
/etc/hotplug/usb.rc: line 39:   339 Segmentation fault     modeprobe -q
usb-uhci >/dev/null 2>&1


At that point, I disconnected the smart media reader from its cable, and
the system responded with:

The system echoes the keyboard, but I'm not sure what to type to do
anything useful at this point.

on the machine and might notice.)  Thus gives you something to do later.

From flee at aracnet.com  Wed Oct 23 16:26:15 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 16:26:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
In-Reply-To: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red> on 23 Oct 2002 09:34:39 PDT.
Message-ID: <200210232326.g9NNQHF21226@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

ctime means 'change time' not 'creation time'.  I'm not sure
why unix doesn't record creation time; perhaps it was
considered unimportant.
--



From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Oct 23 16:30:42 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 16:30:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] strange trojan
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210230734200.6094-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210230734200.6094-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <200210231630.42043.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I remember when I was in college and a number of students would try to 
crack passwords on C/S department's Unix servers. This was in the days 
when user passwords resided in /etc/passwd so they were viewable by 
everyone. A simple program that would use the contents of a simple 
dictionary for passwords generally got a number of hits on the servers.

At one job I worked the admins ran a password cracking program on the 
network and there were only two people in the entire company that had 
strong passwords. It was a strange coincidence but it turned out that 
myself and the gal that sat next to me had the only strong passwords in 
the company. 

I never thought my passwords were special but I do use a mix of letters 
and numbers which is more secure that what a lot of people use I guess.

Tony

On Wednesday 23 October 2002 07:35 am, alan wrote:

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Oct 23 17:56:43 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 17:56:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
References: <1035390880.25623.333.camel@red> <20021023170217.GA20858@sthelens.dimstar.net> <mailman.1035393919.10256.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <8665vs4ptg.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Ed" == Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> writes:

Ed> Thanks. Other file systems/operating systems I've dealt with
Ed> consider ctime to be the file's creation time. You always know
Ed> when the file was created because that historic information is
Ed> always there. We don't have this with Linux/ext2/3. On the
Ed> positive side, we know the date and time of the last change
Ed> to a file's properties. Unfortunately, ctime is changed not
Ed> only when you change a property, but also when you modify
Ed> the file's contents - making it far less valuable to a user
Ed> or administrator.

You mean far *more* valuable.

The timestamps are simple.  People wanna make them too hard.

mtime - when the contents change.  Make needs to know this.

ctime - when the contents *or* meta info changes.  Incremental backups
need to know this.

atime - when you've last looked at a file.  Mostly just for you, to
know how much disk space you're wasting.

So, ctime *must* work that way.  How else would you do an incremental
backup?

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Oct 23 17:58:40 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Oct 2002 17:58:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ctime and lunatics
References: <mailman.1035415766.21165.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <861y6g4pq7.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <flee at aracnet.com> writes:

Felix> ctime means 'change time' not 'creation time'.  I'm not sure
Felix> why unix doesn't record creation time; perhaps it was
Felix> considered unimportant.

No, it's just undefinable or useless.  A lot of the updating
algorithms on Unix use "rename over previous name".  Would you call
that a new file or an old file?  Do you think your neighbor would
answer the same way?

That's the problem.  "Creation time" means very different things to
different people, and thus at what point is actually useful?

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Oct 23 19:15:42 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 19:15:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RAM size
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEIBCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>; from bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph on Thu, Oct 24, 2002 at 08:02:09AM +0800
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEIBCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20021023191542.A18939@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 24 Oct 2002, BMDimaculangan wrote: 
> hi,
> 
> is there a way or a command in linux to see the RAM size without rebooting
> it....

Dan, Don, Rich and Ryan's suggestions are fine as long as you haven't
crossed a memory threshold...

CONFIG_NOHIGHMEM is not set
CONFIG_HIGHMEM4G=y
CONFIG_HIGHMEM64G is not set

...by adding or removing memory - and not recompiling the kernel. i.e., if
you had 2G of memory and added another 3G without recompiling the kernel,
/proc isn't going to report more than 4G. There is a BIOS interrupt which
will accurately tell you how much physical memory you have installed,
regardless of how the kernel was config'd. If you want to make yourself ill,
take a look at setup.S (on RH7.3, it's in /usr/src/.../arch/i386/boot). If
you're really clever, take a look at how Anaconda discovers your true
physical memory :-)

Sandy

> > 
> > homes

> > satimis
> > Profiles
> > Public
> > tmp
> > 
> > Can I issue "chmod 755" to get rid some of them.  In such a case whether
> > other users on Samba server still can visit them.

> Are you saying the all those shares appear as shared on the linux box
> when you browse to it from the Win98 box?

Yes.  They can be browsed on Win98 and also on WinME box.  I only need
"satimis" sub-directory to be open to public

> If that's the case, and you don't want that, remove their entries from
> the smb.conf file, restart samba and they should go away. Since Windows
> 98 caches this information, it may take a reboot on the Windows 98 side
> to make it go away, once the samba server isn't sharing them anymore. 

Following is /etc/smb.conf  HOME section

[homes]
comment = Home Directories
read only = No
guest ok = Yes

Whether you meant changing to "comment = home" OR removing "comment =
Home Directories" and replacing it with "path = /satimis".  But
"satimis" is a subdirectory under "home"

Thanks

From m at netpro.to  Wed Oct 23 20:44:05 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 23 Oct 2002 20:44:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1035430207.1528.15.camel@m40g>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210232035030.8417-100000@lukem.com>

On Thu, 2002-10-24 at 00:32, Russ Johnson wrote:
> - snip -
>
> Specify the password on the command line.
>
> mount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o password=""
>
> I haven't tested this, so it may not work

I haven't been following this thread, so I'm not sure what the original
question was, but the command should be:

smbmount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o username=someuser password=somepass

You can leave off the password in the command and you'll just be prompted
for it.  You can also leave off the username, assuming the username you're
logged into the *nix box with is the same as the one on the Windows
server.  If you want regular users to be able to mount and unmount SMB
shares, you'll need to
chmod 4755 `which smbmnt` && chmod 4755 `which smbumount`

You'll probably want to add the Windows server name to your /etc/hosts as
well.
~M

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210232035030.8417-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210232035030.8417-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <1035434895.1528.52.camel@m40g>

Hi Matt,

Thanks for your advice

On Thu, 2002-10-24 at 11:44, Matt Alexander wrote:

> - snip -
> I haven't been following this thread, so I'm not sure what the original
> question was, but the command should be:
> 
> smbmount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o username=someuser password=somepass

What I need to add is 'a password' only so that mounting is not open to
public.  Even with the user's name mounting is not allowed.  Now it can
mount with the user's name with any password or without a password when
requesting for.  Just hit [Return] key

Thanks

Stephen Liu

 
> You can leave off the password in the command and you'll just be prompted
> for it.  You can also leave off the username, assuming the username you're
> logged into the *nix box with is the same as the one on the Windows
> server.  If you want regular users to be able to mount and unmount SMB
> shares, you'll need to
> chmod 4755 `which smbmnt` && chmod 4755 `which smbumount`
> 
> You'll probably want to add the Windows server name to your /etc/hosts as
> well.
> ~M

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Oct 24 08:17:22 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 08:17:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Drive Puzzlers
Message-ID: <20021024145454.1E3E43639A@ados.com>

At the last clinic, a kind soul helped me get Caldera 2.2 running on my 
233Mhz ATX box. We (mostly he) also installed a new HD. I got to learn a bit 
about fdisk, fsck, looking in dmesg, editing fstab, and linking.

But not enough - when the 'new' disk drive DIED 4 hours later, I bought a 
replacement (and this time NOT from Fry's...) 

Now I've been trying to install the new one myself with 4 Linux books for 
company:
Siever, "Linux in a Nutshell"
Ball, "Teach Yourself Linux in 24 Hours"
Wells, "Linux! I Didn't Know You Could Do That..."
Welsh & Kaufmann, "Linux A-Z"

To derail any RTFM comments in the bud, I can state that NONE of these books 
has an index entry for 'mount point.' This is a term I learned at the clinic, 
and since it's missing from these books, we know that NONE of them have the 
proper detail or organization to teach people how to install a new hard 
drive. There's also no explanation for what the zeros mean in

/dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1 ext2 defaults 0 0 

or when you might want to use other digits. Anyways, I've had to run on 
memory.

PUZZLER #1: The CHS numbers in the disk drive are different from what the 
BIOS guesses if set to 'AUTO' (so I manually entered the CHS from the manual 
into BIOS and left LBA as AUTO,) and then dmesg comes up with a third set of 
numbers. Which ones are correct? 

So we know that the new HD is being found, at least. Using the CHS numbers 
from dmesg, I created two partitions and formatted them (I think - mke2fs?)

Now we're at that 'mount point' point. PUZZLER #2:

mkdir /mnt/hdb1? 
ln /dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1?
ln -s?
mkfs?  (So far this one says it's "not a block special device.")

Lastly, PUZZLER #3:

I have a CDROM, a floppy and two hard disks, but ls mnt/ shows:

cdrom fd0 fd1 floppy floppy2  /hdb1* /hdb2*
 
(Of course, /hdb1 and -2 aren't working yet)

But what are fd0, fd1 and floppy 2?

-GLL

From don at truedisk.com  Thu Oct 24 09:29:12 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 09:29:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Drive Puzzlers
References: <20021024145454.1E3E43639A@ados.com>
Message-ID: <3DB81FD8.8020209@truedisk.com>

Good job working with the resources.
  ... now try "man fstab" (author ducks, runs for cover! :-) )

Actually, the fact that you know /etc/fstab is where this
stuff is located is a *major* step in managing Unix disk
space.  (OK, so some call it /etc/vfstab, others might use
/etc/filesystems, but you know the table exists.)

A "mount point" is any directory you care to specify as
the starting point for the new file system you're going
to add to the system file/data space.

    > /dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1 ext2 defaults 0 0

So, in the above line:

    /dev/hdb1  --> device [partition] holding your new file system
    /mnt/hdb1  --> the directory where you want to go to access the
                   data on this new file system  (maybe you want to
                   call it "/data", "/home/guy/music", "/tools" ...)
    ext2       --> the file system type is "ext2" (relevant for
                   fsck(8) command to know what kind of filesys to check)
    defaults   --> options used by mount(8) when mounting filesystem
                   "defaults" is a Linux-specific term meaning "do the
                   right thing".  See the mount(8) man page (damned near
                   a chapter) for more about what can happen in this
                   column.
    0          --> A [obsolete] used by the dump(8) backup command for
                   deciding if a given filesystem needs backup.  Just
                   leave it "0".
    0          --> An index suggesting what order the filesystems should
                   be checked when "fsck -A" is done at system boot time.
                   Unless you have many different drives in your system
                   (e.g. LAN fileserver) you probably don't need to worry
                   too much about this one.

- Don

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct 24 09:34:43 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 09:34:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210232035030.8417-100000@lukem.com>
References: <1035430207.1528.15.camel@m40g> <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210232035030.8417-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20021024163443.GB22605@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> [2002-10-23 20:42]:
> On Thu, 2002-10-24 at 00:32, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > - snip -
> >
> > Specify the password on the command line.
> >
> > mount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o password=""
> >
> > I haven't tested this, so it may not work
> 
> I haven't been following this thread, so I'm not sure what the original
> question was, but the command should be:
> 
> smbmount //scw98/shared /mnt/Win98 -o username=someuser password=somepass
> 
> You can leave off the password in the command and you'll just be prompted
> for it.  You can also leave off the username, assuming the username you're
> logged into the *nix box with is the same as the one on the Windows
> server.  If you want regular users to be able to mount and unmount SMB
> shares, you'll need to
> chmod 4755 `which smbmnt` && chmod 4755 `which smbumount`
> 

The problem is that Stephen is being prompted for a password when he
attempts to mount the directory from Windows. All he does is press
[ENTER] and it mounts. 

As far as the smbmount you list above, according to the samba team, you
shouldn't use it directly. You should use the mount command, and specify
the type (-t) on the command line. 

--

Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

On Fri, 2002-10-25 at 00:30, Russ Johnson wrote:

I clear all old stuffs from smb.conf.  Hereinafter is the complete
content of /etc/samba/smb.conf

[global]

workgroup = SEC 
guest account = nobody
encrypt passwords = yes
security = user 

[homes]
comment = Home Directories
read only = No
guest ok = Yes


Now only following 2 directories appear on Win98 neighbour network as
shared folder

homes
satimis

I expect to create a share folder which is open to Win98 users,
registered, and close the above 2 folders for sharing

Thanks

Stephen Liu




From sarnold at wirex.com  Sat Oct 19 14:18:40 2002
From: sarnold at wirex.com (Seth Arnold)
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 14:18:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CRIME Virus - Hello!
In-Reply-To: <4.3.2.7.2.20021019123239.00ab42d0@mail.dsl-only.net>
References: <4.3.2.7.2.20021019123239.00ab42d0@mail.dsl-only.net>
Message-ID: <20021019211840.GB14596@wirex.com>

On Sat, Oct 19, 2002 at 12:45:56PM -0700, Steve Coffman wrote:
> I'm trying to identify which virus it is so I can try to clean up
> her computer.

I'm a little curious why you posted this query to so many not-windows
lists. What answer would you expect from redhat-list readers, aside from
"go install redhat"?

The easiest solution is to put the hard drive in another computers with
a virus scanner. Since a virus can install itself into the boot process
of the computer, installing a virus scanner now has only a marginal
chance of success. So do the virus scanning on another machine.

The next easiest solution is to simply reformat and reinstall. Depending
on how many documents your mother has created and how many applications
she runs, this may be easier than cleaning up after the virus. (This has
the especial advantage that you can use this opportunity to install an
operating system with access controls -- so your mother's email client
can't modify system files. Take your pick: NT 4, Win 2k, WinXP, any of
the Linux distributions, any of the BSD distributions -- only you and
your mother can decide what operating system is right for her. But pick
one where her email client can't trash the system.)

The next solution is to take this current tack and try to find out the
virus itself using the various information databases the antivirus
vendors supply, and do the work manually.

Whatever you do, you may wish to consider making a {christmas, hanakah,
ramadan, kwanza, all pagans' day} gift out of an antivirus software, if
whatever operating system you reinstall with has some available. :)

Oh yeah, and ask windows questions in windows mail lists. :) I've left
them in the CC: as a way of saying that I've already asked you to be
careful in the future, so no one else feels obligated to do the same. :)

-- 
"There's an old saying in Tennessee, i know it's in Texas, probably in
Tennessee, that says, 'Fool me once... shame on ... shame on .. you; but
fool--you can't get fooled again.'" -- Commander in Chief of the US Military

Hi Guy,


On Thu, 2002-10-24 at 08:17, guy1656 wrote:
> At the last clinic, a kind soul helped me get Caldera 2.2 running on my 
> 233Mhz ATX box. We (mostly he) also installed a new HD. I got to learn a bit 
> about fdisk, fsck, looking in dmesg, editing fstab, and linking.
> 
> But not enough - when the 'new' disk drive DIED 4 hours later, I bought a 
> replacement (and this time NOT from Fry's...) 
> 
> Now I've been trying to install the new one myself with 4 Linux books for 
> company:
> Siever, "Linux in a Nutshell"
> Ball, "Teach Yourself Linux in 24 Hours"
> Wells, "Linux! I Didn't Know You Could Do That..."
> Welsh & Kaufmann, "Linux A-Z"
> 
> To derail any RTFM comments in the bud, I can state that NONE of these books 
> has an index entry for 'mount point.' This is a term I learned at the clinic, 
> and since it's missing from these books, we know that NONE of them have the 
> proper detail or organization to teach people how to install a new hard 
> drive. There's also no explanation for what the zeros mean in
> 
> /dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1 ext2 defaults 0 0 
> 
> or when you might want to use other digits. Anyways, I've had to run on 
> memory.
> 
> PUZZLER #1: The CHS numbers in the disk drive are different from what the 
> BIOS guesses if set to 'AUTO' (so I manually entered the CHS from the manual 
> into BIOS and left LBA as AUTO,) and then dmesg comes up with a third set of 
> numbers. Which ones are correct? 

It doesn't matter, the only thing that linux needs from the BIOS is to
start the boot process, once the kernel loads, it doesn't pay any
attention to what the BIOS says.  My suggestion is to leave it on AUTO
AUTO.
> 
> So we know that the new HD is being found, at least. Using the CHS numbers 
> from dmesg, I created two partitions and formatted them (I think - mke2fs?)
> 
> Now we're at that 'mount point' point. PUZZLER #2:
> 
> mkdir /mnt/hdb1?

This created your mount point.
 
> ln /dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1?

Linking won't work, block devices need to be "mount"ed to mount points:

mount /dev/hdb1 /mnt/hdb1

If this command fails, then you haven't formatted the drive, for that
use:

mke2fs /dev/hdb1

> ln -s?

The best kind of link, called a symlink, it is used to create files or
directories with more than one name, but only one real copy of the
data.  (For example, /usr/doc usually has a whole slew of symlinks to
/usr/share/doc)

> mkfs?  (So far this one says it's "not a block special device.")

See above
> 
> Lastly, PUZZLER #3:
> 
> I have a CDROM, a floppy and two hard disks, but ls mnt/ shows:
> 
> cdrom fd0 fd1 floppy floppy2  /hdb1* /hdb2*
>  
> (Of course, /hdb1 and -2 aren't working yet)
> 
> But what are fd0, fd1 and floppy 2?

At this point, they are just empty directories waiting for someone to
mount something to them.  So, for example, if you insert a CD, it will
most likely get mounted on /mnt/cdrom, which is where you will find the
contents of the CD.  For a list of mounted block devices, run the
command:

mount

without any arguments.

HTH

Derek Loree




From pem at nellump.net  Thu Oct 24 11:08:51 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 11:08:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Drive Puzzlers
In-Reply-To: <20021024145454.1E3E43639A@ados.com>

On Thu, Oct 24, 2002 at 08:17:22AM -0700, guy1656 wrote:
> 
> To derail any RTFM comments in the bud, I can state that NONE of these books 
> has an index entry for 'mount point.' This is a term I learned at the clinic, 

Sadly enough, many tech books simply suck. I don't if it's because
they're rushed to market or written/edited by mueless clorons or what,
but that's the way things are. My first place to look for help is always
the Linux Documentation Project (LDP). While I haven't read through the
entire thing, the Hard Disk Upgrade HOWTO looks appropriate to your
task:

<http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/mini/Hard-Disk-Upgrade/index.html>

The RUTE project also goes into fairly gory detail about the most common
Linux topics:

<http://rute.sourceforge.net/>


Paul

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Thu Oct 24 11:54:59 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 12:54:59 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Colo recommendations?
In-Reply-To: <8066.66.93.41.98.1035477269.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
 from Matt King at "Oct 24, 2002 09:34:29 am"
Message-ID: <200210241854.MAA03871@eris.coyotesong.com>

Matt King wrote:
> Sure if everyone has about $10,000 to pitch in.  Co-Lo is very expensive
> to setup and maintain, with all the power required, clean, redundant
> power...and the people to staff it, and the redundant internet
> connection...

????

The whole point of the co-op is that people are willing to accept 
compromises to keep the costs down... even willing to volunteer some
of their time for the grunt work.  If you really need clean power,
redundant connections, etc., then pay the $1000+/month for a single
2U box that many commercial sites want.

But that doesn't mean that there's no value in, oh, somebody with an
unused corner of their basement volunteering to set aside some space and
run a couple T-1 lines into his house.  Toss in a good UPS (or just tell
everyone to bring their own UPS :-) and you're set. 

I've also heard of co-ops being hosted at commercial ISP sites as an
employee perk, but that usually has strict non-commercial-use restrictions
on the boxes.  I think the age of a co-op being hosted in a university's
server room is pretty much over.

Bear



From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct 24 11:58:41 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 11:58:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CRIME Virus - Hello!
In-Reply-To: <20021019211840.GB14596@wirex.com>

* Seth Arnold <sarnold at wirex.com> [2002-10-24 10:41]:
> The easiest solution is to put the hard drive in another computers with
> a virus scanner. Since a virus can install itself into the boot process
> of the computer, installing a virus scanner now has only a marginal
> chance of success. So do the virus scanning on another machine.

Wouldn't it be even easier to use one of the many virus scanners that
work from a boot disk? Boot with a read only floppy, made from a known
clean machine, and scan from a read only floppy. 

> The next easiest solution is to simply reformat and reinstall. Depending
> on how many documents your mother has created and how many applications
> she runs, this may be easier than cleaning up after the virus. (This has
> the especial advantage that you can use this opportunity to install an
> operating system with access controls -- so your mother's email client
> can't modify system files. Take your pick: NT 4, Win 2k, WinXP, any of
> the Linux distributions, any of the BSD distributions -- only you and
> your mother can decide what operating system is right for her. But pick
> one where her email client can't trash the system.)

Many of the viruses today can be cleaned quite easily. Maybe not too
quickly, but it's usually fairly easy for a clueful user. 

> The next solution is to take this current tack and try to find out the
> virus itself using the various information databases the antivirus
> vendors supply, and do the work manually.

Yup, manually.... 

> Whatever you do, you may wish to consider making a {christmas, hanakah,
> ramadan, kwanza, all pagans' day} gift out of an antivirus software, if
> whatever operating system you reinstall with has some available. :)

to support it's less powerful engine in Norton Utilities. I haven't like
Symantecs antics in the last couple of years though. Seems the CEO that
took over doesn't care about the people. Only about the corporate
entitiies he can sell to.

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-24 10:31]:
> I clear all old stuffs from smb.conf.  Hereinafter is the complete
> content of /etc/samba/smb.conf
> 
> [global]
> 
> workgroup = SEC 
> guest account = nobody
> encrypt passwords = yes
> security = user 
> 
> [homes]
> comment = Home Directories
> read only = No
> guest ok = Yes
> 
> 
> Now only following 2 directories appear on Win98 neighbour network as
> shared folder
> 
> homes
> satimis
> 
> I expect to create a share folder which is open to Win98 users,
> registered, and close the above 2 folders for sharing

Make "guest ok = no" and then only the directory for the currently
logged in user will appear. That's normal, and expected behavior.

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Thu Oct 24 12:30:34 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 13:30:34 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Colo recommendations?
In-Reply-To: <1035485354.11622.3166.camel@obelisk.spek.org> from Brent Rieck
 at "Oct 24, 2002 11:49:14 am"
Message-ID: <200210241930.NAA04185@eris.coyotesong.com>

> Brent wrote:
> I believe it was more for pooling resources for rack space rental rather
> than actually starting a colocation facility.  Erik Walthinsen was
> trying to ge something going, more information at
> http://www.omegacs.net/colo/

With a colo, you can also share some responsibilities.  E.g., there's
probably no need for EVERYONE to run their own public mail server, or
news server, or SNORT + NIDS + firewall, etc.  You could even have
community databases, web servers, and the like.

So what you can do with a co-op is identify a core group who will provide
basic services in exchange for free or reduced hosting in for their boxes.
If you've ever had to set up these servers, you will NOT mind paying a
 couple extra bucks per month for somebody else to handle it for you.

Taken to its extreme, the core group would offer hosting just like
any other site.  In this case the hosting fees would go to cover the
cost of the colo rental, power and bandwidth, but not salaries or
profits.  I think some LUGs now offer such hosting to anyone who's a
member of the LUG.  Yahoo equivalence (mail, 10MB of web space) is
free, and you have modest fees for domain parking, more web space,
etc.

Bear

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 24 15:11:53 2002

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210241509000.564-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I cannot get xcdroast to run properly, so I use mkisofs followed by
cdrecord. For the occasional cd-r I make, this is just fine with me. But,
what I don't know how to do is compare the newly burned cd-r image with the
iso image on the hard drive to ensure that it was done correctly. Also,
comparing the hard drive image with the source image on the cdrom.

  Are there ways of doing these two validity checks?

TIA,

Rich




From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Thu Oct 24 15:36:05 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 16:36:05 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Verifying a cd-r image
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210241509000.564-100000@appl-ecosys.com> from Rich
 Shepard at "Oct 24, 2002 03:11:53 pm"
Message-ID: <200210242236.QAA05496@eris.coyotesong.com>

> But,
> what I don't know how to do is compare the newly burned cd-r image with the
> iso image on the hard drive to ensure that it was done correctly. Also,
> comparing the hard drive image with the source image on the cdrom.

# md5sum image.iso /dev/cdrom

Bear



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 24 15:49:58 2002

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Thu Oct 24 16:10:31 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 17:10:31 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Verifying a cd-r image
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210241548300.799-100000@appl-ecosys.com> from Rich
 Shepard at "Oct 24, 2002 03:49:58 pm"
Message-ID: <200210242310.RAA05750@eris.coyotesong.com>

> > # md5sum image.iso /dev/cdrom
> 
>   Verifying the new cd-r is of more interest to me. Perhaps just reading the
> mounted directory in the cdrom drive is sufficient.

Hmm, maybe I misunderstood the question.

If you want to verify that you wrote the data to the CD-R correctly,
check the MD5 on the ISO image.

If you want to verify that the ISO image was properly generated, run

# find . -type f -size +0 -print0 | xargs -0 md5sum > MD5SUMS

(or something like that) on your original data, then when you mount
the ISO image (ideally via the loopback device on the hard disk image
since it's *much* faster than reading the CD, esp. if the disk layout
isn't optimized to minimize seeks) run

# md5sums -c /cdrom/MD5SUMS

Bear



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 24 16:17:10 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

From m at netpro.to  Thu Oct 24 18:04:23 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 18:04:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] winbindd, PAM, and logging into X
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210241745001.9610-100000@lukem.com>

I've read:

http://us6.samba.org/samba/ftp/docs/htmldocs/winbind.html

...and I've been playing with winbindd.  So far I've managed to telnet and
ftp into my Linux box by authenticating to an account on the Win2K domain
controller.  So far, so good.
Does anyone know what I need to change so I can login to X using a Win2K
account?  I'm using KDM.

I'm quite a newbie when it comes to PAM, and I'm guessing there's a PAM
file I need to modify in just the right way, like I did for FTP, so I can
login to my box using a Win2K account.  I can login to a console fine, and
here's the contents of /etc/pam.d/login:

#%PAM-1.0
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_securetty.so
auth       sufficient   /lib/security/pam_winbind.so
auth       sufficient   /lib/security/pam_unix.so use_first_pass
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_nologin.so
account    sufficient   /lib/security/pam_winbind.so
account    required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
password   required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
session    required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
session    optional     /lib/security/pam_console.so


So then I modified /etc/pam.d/kde and /etc/pam.d/xserver:

#%PAM-1.0
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
auth       sufficient   /lib/security/pam_winbind.so
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_nologin.so
account    required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
account    sufficient   /lib/security/pam_winbind.so
password   required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
session    required     /lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
session    optional     /lib/security/pam_console.so

But...  I still can't login to X with a Win2K account.
Any suggestions?
Thanks,
~M

Hi Russ,

Sorry, problem still remains after change made as advised.  Samba
restarted each time after changed made to smb.conf   Followings are
discovered during repeated tests.  It is quite interesting

A sub-directory named "satimis-shared" created in "satimis" (also
subdirectory under "home")


1)
/etc/samba/smb.conf
[global]

netbios name = M40G
workgroup = SEC 
guest account = nobody
encrypt passwords = yes
security = user 

[homes]
comment = Home Directories
read only = No
guest ok = No


Following directories appeared in 'workgroup' (SEC)
-homes
-satimis

Many hidden files found in each directory. Subdirectory "satimis-shared"
also found in each directory.

But there is no directory name "homes"(plural) under root (super root) 


2) Changed "homes" to "home" (singular) and "Home Directories" to "Home
Directory" (also singular)

/etc/samba/smb.conf
[global]

netbios name = M40G
workgroup = SEC 
guest account = nobody
encrypt passwords = yes
security = user 

[home]
comment = Home Directory
read only = No
guest ok = No


Only "home" (singular) was found in the workgroup.  Also there area many
hidden files there but subdirectoris "satimis" and "satimis-shared"
disappeared.

Browsing /home/ with Konqueror, no hidden file was found there only a
subdirectory "satimis" there.  In "satimis" there are many hidden files
and "satimis-shared" was also there.

Have you got any idea?

Thanks

Stephen Liu



On Fri, 2002-10-25 at 03:04, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-24 10:31]:
> > I clear all old stuffs from smb.conf.  Hereinafter is the complete
> > content of /etc/samba/smb.conf
> > 
> > [global]
> > 
> > workgroup = SEC 
> > guest account = nobody
> > encrypt passwords = yes
> > security = user 
> > 
> > [homes]
> > comment = Home Directories
> > read only = No
> > guest ok = Yes
> > 
> > 
> > Now only following 2 directories appear on Win98 neighbour network as
> > shared folder
> > 
> > homes
> > satimis
> > 
> > I expect to create a share folder which is open to Win98 users,
> > registered, and close the above 2 folders for sharing
> 
> Make "guest ok = no" and then only the directory for the currently
> logged in user will appear. That's normal, and expected behavior.

<?echo Bear Giles managed to take the time to type out the following:
>> Brent wrote:
>> I believe it was more for pooling resources for rack space rental
>> rather than actually starting a colocation facility.  Erik Walthinsen
>> was trying to ge something going, more information at
>> http://www.omegacs.net/colo/
>
> With a colo, you can also share some responsibilities.  E.g., there's
> probably no need for EVERYONE to run their own public mail server, or
> news server, or SNORT + NIDS + firewall, etc.  You could even have
> community databases, web servers, and the like.
>
> So what you can do with a co-op is identify a core group who will
> provide basic services in exchange for free or reduced hosting in for
> their boxes. If you've ever had to set up these servers, you will NOT
> mind paying a
>  couple extra bucks per month for somebody else to handle it for you.
>
> Taken to its extreme, the core group would offer hosting just like any
> other site.  In this case the hosting fees would go to cover the cost of
> the colo rental, power and bandwidth, but not salaries or
> profits.  I think some LUGs now offer such hosting to anyone who's a
> member of the LUG.  Yahoo equivalence (mail, 10MB of web space) is free,
> and you have modest fees for domain parking, more web space, etc.
>
> Bear
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Haven't tried wine in years and it's time again.

The path of least resistance is to see if it's already installed, and seems 
to be on this RH 7.3 machine.

Mal-incantation is
$ wine something.exe
wine: error while loading shared libraries: libntdll.dll.so: cannot open 
shared object file: No such file or directory

libntdll.dll.so is located in /usr/lib/wine
(I even added the path to ld.so.conf, but don't think that's why it's not 
being found.)

man says I need a ~/.wine/config and there is a sample in the source 
tarball.  So I get that and see that /etc/wine.reg is the same basic file 
and I copy that into ~/.wine/config.

Still no love.

Is there an envar that needs to be set?

Kyle Accardi

	/usr/lib/wine

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Oct 25 06:31:04 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 06:31:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Yes a basic wine question
In-Reply-To: <3DB8E7DA.40808@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210250623320.2879-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 24 Oct 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Did the install really fail because it wasn't happy with my midi device?

  Yes. And no.

  For reasons that have never been explained to me (I suppose because there
is no explanation), you must have a multi-medium section in the config file.
Here's what I have in ~/.wine/config:

[WinMM]
"Drivers" = "wineoss.drv"
"WaveMapper" = "msacm.drv"
"MidiMapper" = "midimap.drv"

  The sticking point for me -- and apparently many others -- is getting
Install Shield to run to completion and do its thing. I'd _really_ like to
know how to do this.

Rich

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Oct 25 09:25:43 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 09:25:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash prompt
In-Reply-To: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0210250856400.21726-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Is it possible to set up a bash prompt that has a line feed?  Mine shows
> the path, which I want, but when long commands wrap it gets ugly.
> Just wondering.

Does this mean you have the path and $ on the same line, causing the
commands to wrap around on long paths? If so, have you tried splitting the
$ and path into two lines? If you have a problem with the path getting too
long and wrapping around on the first line, here's some code to
dynamically resize it:

"11.10. Controlling the Size and Appearance of $PWD"
"Bash Prompt HOWTO"
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Bash-Prompt-HOWTO/x768.html

Even cooler, here is some code to dynamically resize the path according to
the size of your terminal:

"12.7 A Prompt the Width of Your Term"
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Bash-Prompt-HOWTO/x848.html

HTH,

Tyler



On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Michael Montagne wrote:

> Is it possible to set up a bash prompt that has a line feed?  Mine shows
> the path, which I want, but when long commands wrap it gets ugly.
> Just wondering.
>
> --
>   Michael Montagne  [montagne at boora.com]   503.226.1575

> the whole point of wine.

not just for games, music and movies. Strange breed we are, I admit, but
there it is.

  I'm trying to get MapInfo running over wine so folks that need that
application for their business can defenestrate and still have access to a
critical application. It's not a game even though it's built for the
Microsoft environment.

Rich




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Fri Oct 25 09:33:11 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 11:33:11 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Yes a basic wine question
Message-ID: <EX-20021025-113932-0004@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Oh well the only reason I can think of to use wine is for games just because if you can run *nix at work why would you want winders. But then again you might find that you have a hard time getting something like MapInfo running without a winders partition. In which case you have just defeated the whole purpose in a business setting. 

And just because some of us play games don't assume that we don't work. Its just that for real work winders offers no tools I or anyone I know needs or wants. Therefore in my mind the only reason to run a winders emulator would be the occasional game.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Oct 25 09:44:53 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 09:44:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server and Win98 connection problem
In-Reply-To: <1035518149.1339.268.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20021022173636.GA20388@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035348941.1485.84.camel@m40g> <20021023052438.GA2309@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035372537.1531.84.camel@m40g> <20021023163249.GA19930@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035430207.1528.15.camel@m40g> <20021024163015.GA22605@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035480676.3295.39.camel@localhost.localdomain> <20021024190417.GD22605@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1035518149.1339.268.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20021025164453.GA17605@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-10-24 20:56]:
> A sub-directory named "satimis-shared" created in "satimis" (also
> subdirectory under "home")

And it would be expected that any directories under satimis would be
visible from within the satimis directory, if the satimis directory is
shared. 

> /etc/samba/smb.conf
> [global]
> 
> netbios name = M40G
> workgroup = SEC 
> guest account = nobody
> encrypt passwords = yes
> security = user 
> 
> [homes]
> comment = Home Directories
> read only = No
> guest ok = No
> 
> 
> Following directories appeared in 'workgroup' (SEC)
> -homes
> -satimis
> 
> Many hidden files found in each directory. Subdirectory "satimis-shared"
> also found in each directory.

>From my testing, it appears that both /homes and /satimis should go to
the same directory, and yes, any files that are in that directory will
show up too. This is normal. It's the files in that users home
directory. This is normal and expected behavior. You want the user to
have access to his files.  

> Browsing /home/ with Konqueror, no hidden file was found there only a
> subdirectory "satimis" there.  In "satimis" there are many hidden files
> and "satimis-shared" was also there.

The [homes] share in samba is a special share that shares the users home
directory. More information can be found in the samba documentation. 

--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Oct 25 10:01:15 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 10:01:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash prompt
In-Reply-To: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
References: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20021025170115.GB17605@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Michael Montagne <montagne at boora.com> [2002-10-25 06:36]:
> Is it possible to set up a bash prompt that has a line feed?  Mine shows
> the path, which I want, but when long commands wrap it gets ugly.
> Just wondering.

Yes. My prompt is set like this:

(in .bashrc)

COLOR1="\[\033[1;35m\]"
COLOR2="\[\033[1;36m\]"
COLOR3="\[\033[1;32m\]"
COLOR4="\[\033[0m\]"
PS1="[\@][$COLOR2\u$COLOR4@$COLOR1\h $COLOR3\w$COLOR4]\n\$ "

Which gives me a nice colorful prompt, and puts the $ on a new line
below the time, loginname at machine, and path. 

Example:

[09:59 AM][russj at sthelens ~]
$  

Of course, the color isn't coming through, but you get the idea. 

--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #16 (Collect all 17)
"It is often easier to fight for principles than to live up to them." - Adlai Stevenson



From pem at nellump.net  Fri Oct 25 10:24:02 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 10:24:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash prompt
In-Reply-To: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
References: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20021025172402.GA613@nellump.net>

On Fri, Oct 25, 2002 at 06:36:11AM -0700, Michael Montagne wrote:
> Is it possible to set up a bash prompt that has a line feed?  Mine shows
> the path, which I want, but when long commands wrap it gets ugly.

Yes, and it makes the prompt much more readable if you're the type that
prefers to have the entire path displayed, not just the name of the
current working directory.

In tcsh, I include the following in my .cshrc file:

    set     prompt="\n[%n@%m: %/]\n% "

If you're using bash, try the following in your .bashrc[1]:

    export PS1="\n[%n@%m: %/]\n% "

The linebreaks are indicated by the "\n" pair. I included one right
before the prompt so that consecutive commands and outputs don't blend
together. As someone else pointed out, the Bash-Prompt HOWTO is pretty
informative, though I found many of their prompts to be overkill.

[1] Or is it .login? I always confuse the two.


Paul

From patrick at WebArchitecture.com  Fri Oct 25 13:07:24 2002
From: patrick at WebArchitecture.com (Patrick Beart)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 13:07:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: NEW WORM - Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer
Message-ID: <p05100315b9df531010ef@[192.168.3.1]>

Folks:

	There is a NEW Windows virus out. This one DOES NOT have any 
"fixes" from the usual anti-virus companies (e.g. Symantec, McAfeee, 
etc.), for reasons that are alluded to, below.

	This "Worm" is different that previous viruses, in that it 
relies on user ignorance (stupidity!) to install itself. Basically, 
it uses YOU to do it's nastiness by assuming that you won't read the 
EULA (End-User License Agreement) that comes along with it.

	Here's Symantec's information on it, followed by a post from 
one of the original discoverers of this - who happens to be a friend 
of mine. My friend's company spent most of yesterday looking into 
this new worm, so the remainder of the post is HIGHLY technical in 
nature.

	http://www.sarc.com/avcenter/venc/data/friendgreetings.html





Patrick Beart

---------------

>Delivered-To: mail.webarchitecture.com-patrick at tesla.iweb4biz.com
>From: Russell Washington <russ.washington at vaultsentry.com>
>To: "'list at dshield.org'" <list at dshield.org>
>Subject: [Dshield] Friendgreetings.com mass emailer
>Date: Thu, 24 Oct 2002 15:02:53 -0700
>
>We've been researching an item that "landed" in an end-user's inbox this
>morning.  Given the lack of information on this mass emailer I thought I
>should get some more seasoned eyes on it.  Here's the dump of information I
>have to date.  Symantec is aware of this item but (at least when we talked
>to them) has it classified as "non-malicious malware" and is still debating
>whether to include detection for it in the Norton Anti-Virus product.
>
>It is probably worthwhile to figure out what the background process this
>thing leaves running is actually up to.  When we locked down the NTFS (yes,
>Windows, sorry) permissions on the directory containing the executable and
>its DLLs, other processes (no pattern determined) became unhappy.  Might be
>coincidence, might be causal.
>
>Anyway, have at this one guys.  Our research is far from comprehensive.
>
>The trojan runs a program called OTMS.EXE in the background and sets the
>system up to restart it at each logon. What purpose this program serves is
>unknown and we have been unable to test it. At this point I believe the
>safest assumption to make is that it represents a security compromise, and
>the process should be terminated on any machine running it.
>
>The program comes from an outfit called "Permission Media" and installs
>something for "Friend Greetings". It looks like Friend Greetings is the user
>and Permission Media is the creator. Important to note is the following
>License Agreement verbage ("Friendgreetings License Agreement") that I dug
>out of what appeared to be the install point:
>
>	1. Consent to E-Mail Your Contacts. As part of the installation
>process, Permissioned Media will access your MicroSoft Outlook(r) Contacts
>list and send an e-mail to persons on your Contacts list inviting them to
>download FriendGreetings or related products. By downloading, installing,
>accessing or using the FriendGreetings, you authorize Permissioned Media to
>access your MicroSoft(r) Outlook(r) Contacts list and to send a personalized
>e-mail message to persons on your Contact list. IF YOU DO NOT WANT US TO
>ACCESS YOUR CONTACT LIST AND SEND AN E-MAIL MESSAGE TO PERSONS ON THAT LIST,
>DO NOT DOWNLOAD, INSTALL, ACCESS OR USE FRIENDGREETINGS.
>
>End User Zero claimed they never saw this agreement.  However, Symantec
>claimed that this verbage is in fact presented and we have confirmed this.
>Either way it explains exactly what we saw, which was that the first
>infected machine started shoveling customized-to-the-contact copies of the
>original email to everyone in the victim's address book.
>
>We only found one reference in Google that I was able to find under a
>variety of searches, and the message thread only underscores the unknown
>nature of this program. You can find the thread at
>http://forums.techguy.org/t100166/s49b6012a49a2b50020b83e4d76bce31f.html. It
>should be noted that one of the filenames installed, "winsrvc.exe", is
>referenced in knowledge bases as being associated with the 2000-era Navidad
>virus. This does not appear to be the same program or even a variant.
>
>Technical details known to date:
>
>The installer uses an MSI package and invokes the Windows Installer service.
>
>
>The installer placed materiel in the directories c:\program files\common
>files\media, c:\temp\_IS5, and
>c:\temp\{499AFE40-6C35-483D-B6F3-F6AB95C2E6EC}. The last two directories may
>be temporary install points that are deleted when installation is
>successfully completed. The "license agreements" are in the last directory.
>
>The installer inserts the item "PMedia" under
>HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with the value C:\Program
>Files\Common Files\Media\OTMS.exe.
>
>The installer invokes OTMS.EXE with the obvious intent of having it run this
>process in the background.
>
>The installer places an application called "WinSrv Reg" in Add/Remove
>Programs (HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall)
>
>---- Begin original message----
>From: (infected sender)
>Sent: Thursday, October 24, 2002 9:59 AM
>To: (Recipient email "friendly name" in sender's Outlook Contacts folder)
>Subject: (recipient first name) you have an E-Card from .
>Greetings!
>has sent you an E-Card -- a virtual postcard from FriendGreetings.com. You
>can pickup your E-Card at the FriendGreetings.com by clicking on the link
>below.
>http://www.friendgreetings.com/pickup/pickup.aspx?code=Humayun&id=2410021
>Message:
>------------------------------------------------------------
>(recipient first name),
>I sent you a greeting card. Please pick it up.
>------------------------------------------------------------
>----End original message----


-- 
------------------------------------------------
Web Architecture  &  "iWeb4Biz"         503-774-8280       Portland, OR
Internet Consulting, Intelligent Web site Development & Secure site Hosting.
http://www.WebArchitecture.com/

controversial."

From ziggy at anodizing.com  Fri Oct 25 13:16:58 2002
From: ziggy at anodizing.com (Abraham Zwygart)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 13:16:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake install
References: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com> <20021025172402.GA613@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <3DB9A6BA.FA0A1E80@anodizing.com>

Hi
Just downloaded Mandrake 9.0 and installed it.  I was pleased that it
recognized the nt partition and made a mount point for me.  That is really
nice.  Also thought that it was cool that it saw several printers on the
network and allowed me to attach/configure them.  I skipped that part.  Just
wanted the local printer.  Have two questions.

I have a cd-r and a cd-w  on my system.  As far as I can tell the system
always mounts both cd's as read only.  I also noticed that in the fstab
both have a ',ro,' on there mount line.  I think I need to make the cd-w
read/write. Not sure how to do this.

Email/kmail.  When I start it it tells me to go the the network and
configure it there.  At the network configuration I found email and have
entered in all the information except application.  I cannot find kmail
that is on the desk top?  Not sure  what to do?

On another note, on install when I pick a mouse that has a wheel
the screen started to fickler and the mouse when to the top right of
the screen.  After re-installing (pick generic mouse, work) I tried
to setup the wheel mouse again.  Again the screen flickers and the
mouse runs to the top right of the screen.  Un able to move easily
I did the <ctrl> <alt> <delete> and log off.  At this point the computer
rebooted.  After logging in, going to a web site, I noticed that the
wheel was working.  That was really strange.


Thanks for any help you can give me.
Abraham Z.





From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Fri Oct 25 13:18:14 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 15:18:14 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: NEW WORM - Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer
Message-ID: <EX-20021025-152202-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Just so you know what IP to block in your firewall

www.friendsgreetings.com

66.172.0.91

Won't keep you from getting the emails but it will prevent your lusers from infecting themselves. Also , and you really should be doing this anyway, if you strip out activex they won't be able to infect themselves.

Ray

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Oct 25 13:41:36 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct 25 13:50:30 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 13:50:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] unsolicited election email
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021025-101012-0004@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210251345310.12252-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:
> By default you have made it a discussion on merits. I can't vote for
> or against her but I would encourage you all who can to vote against
> her and make it clear this is why.

You'd really elect someone about whom you know nothing merely based on a
single misdeed by the opponent?

Now, I'm all for a none-of-the-above option and even more for discouraging
the uninformed from voting at all (at best, it just adds noise; at worst,
it improves the count for the side with the biggest marketting budget),
but I would never EVER consider voting for one person as a vote against
another.  That's just foolishness.

> To answer your question she got it the same way any spammer gets it.
> Bots, buying it off lists. Any of the many ways those scumbags use to
> get a email address. Google or search /. on the subject and you will
> see that it is quite common and that they work with the same people
> who send out all the other spam.

That's a really silly notion, too.  How can a bot tell whether an address
is within a particular city council district?

There is something more careful at work here than mere bots.  Think about
the problem and imagine a solution.  Automated email harvesting from the
mailing list archives and USENET probably isn't a part of it.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Fri Oct 25 14:01:12 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 15:01:12 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM - Friendgreetings.com mass
 E-mailer)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251340400.4116-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3DB9B118.9919A906@gisnet.com>

If I wanted to block all messages coming from 66.172.0.0 to
66.172.63.255 in my /etc/mail/access file without blocking
66.172.64.0 to 66.172.255.255, how would I do it? Adding just
66.172 blocks too much, but I don't want add lots of individual
IPs either. Is there an allow/deny scheme for filter e-mail with
the access file?

- Bill Thoen

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Fri Oct 25 13:54:41 2002

You are most likely right on the bots.

OTOH as far as voting against her goes you must keep in mind that this would very much be a vote against her and not for the other person and that this is , for me, a litmus test issue. In other words I will vote against spam *every* time because to me with this development that just became the single biggest issue in the race. You may disagree with me but I most likely think many things that you use as a political litmus test are "foolish".

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Fri Oct 25 14:11:43 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 16:11:43 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM -
 Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer)
Message-ID: <EX-20021025-161414-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

I don't know the technical answer to your question. But if you are trying to keep from getting these mails that won't work. The way it works is someone gets the beast downloads and installs an activex control. Said activex control has you click through on a EULA. In the EULA you give it permission to mail a greeting card to everyone in your address book it then does so. So the mails are coming from everywhere. The IP that I sent was to keep lusers from going to the site and getting the activex controller. To filter the mail you would most likely want to just filter on some word or phrase  

Here is the text of the mail.

 you have an E-Card from .

Greetings!

 has sent you an E-Card -- a virtual postcard from FriendGreetings.com. You can pickup your E-Card at the FriendGreetings.com by clicking on the link below.

http://www.friendgreetings.com/pickup/pickup.aspx?code=&id=2410024

Message:
------------------------------------------------------------
,
I sent you a greeting card. Please pick it up.

------------------------------------------------------------

-----Original Message-----
From: Bill Thoen 
Sent: Friday, October 25, 2002 2:00 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM -
Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer)

66.172.63.255 in my /etc/mail/access file without blocking
66.172.64.0 to 66.172.255.255, how would I do it? Adding just
66.172 blocks too much, but I don't want add lots of individual
IPs either. Is there an allow/deny scheme for filter e-mail with
the access file?

- Bill Thoen

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Oct 25 14:25:39 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 25 Oct 2002 14:25:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM -
	Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer)
In-Reply-To: <3DB9B118.9919A906@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251340400.4116-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
	<3DB9B118.9919A906@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1035581139.25572.297.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-10-25 at 14:01, Bill Thoen wrote:
> If I wanted to block all messages coming from 66.172.0.0 to
> 66.172.63.255 in my /etc/mail/access file without blocking
> 66.172.64.0 to 66.172.255.255, how would I do it? Adding just
> 66.172 blocks too much, but I don't want add lots of individual
> IPs either. Is there an allow/deny scheme for filter e-mail with
> the access file?

Seems like you should be able to block the network specified with a
netmask.  I believe (someone might check my math) that the netmask for
this is /18, so the address range that you want to block is
66.172.0.0/18 or written another way 66.172.0.0 255.255.192.0

HTH

Derek Loree

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct 25 14:35:43 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 14:35:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] unsolicited election email
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021025-160357-0004@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210251430340.12786-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:
> OTOH as far as voting against her goes you must keep in mind that this
> would very much be a vote against her and not for the other person and
> that this is , for me, a litmus test issue.

I don't know what kind of voting system they use in the state in which you
live, but here, in Oregon, you can't vote against a person running for
elected office.  You can vote for someone ELSE or you can abstain.  There
is no such thing as a vote against someone.

> In other words I will vote against spam *every* time because to me
> with this development that just became the single biggest issue in the
> race. You may disagree with me but I most likely think many things
> that you use as a political litmus test are "foolish".

Actually, I think the whole concept of a "litmus test" (being a single
issue or event that "makes or breaks" a candidate) is pretty foolish.  

Personally, I vote for candidates I support and when a race has no GOOD
candidate, I abstain.  I really can't think of a single thing a candidate
could do or say that would ensure my vote on its own.

But we can take those up on plug-talk if you like.

J.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Oct 25 14:42:54 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 14:42:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM - Friendgreetings.com
 mass E-mailer)
In-Reply-To: <3DB9B118.9919A906@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251440560.4116-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> If I wanted to block all messages coming from 66.172.0.0 to
> 66.172.63.255 in my /etc/mail/access file without blocking
> 66.172.64.0 to 66.172.255.255, how would I do it? Adding just
> 66.172 blocks too much, but I don't want add lots of individual
> IPs either. Is there an allow/deny scheme for filter e-mail with
> the access file?

  Thar ain't no shortcut, unfortunately. The MTAs don't read CIDR addresses
so you need to list each one; e.g.:

66.172.0	550 Whatever
66.172.1	550 Whatever
66.172.2 ...
...
66.172.63	550 Whatever

Rich

It's amateurish, but just what I needed- 
I'm sharing it with y'all because ... well because I thought you 
might find it interesting, or not.

I didn't change web servers or email addresses because it's not 
exactly secret information. It's just a perl script that checks my 
server(s) to make sure they're alive; we've been experiencing 
some hardware problems lately.    There's also a script that 
runs that checks the md5 hash (I used  $var = `lynx -dump | 
md5sum` and reports if there's a change;  it's fairly similar in 
conception to this one.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Oct 25 15:55:16 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 15:55:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP
In-Reply-To: <3DB9C62F.630E3441@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251552120.4392-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> So I can't use:
> 
> 66.172.0.0 255.255.192.0     550 Repent sinner!
> or 
> 66.172.0.0/18                550 Spam B Damned
> 
> ??? Are those "CIDR" addresses? Seems like a pretty useful
> notation.

  Yes, the latter is a CIDR address and the former fails because there's
more than one address per line. Postfix, and I assume sendmail, checks the
topmost "Received from: " line for at IP address and checks it against your
list. It's gotta' be one-by-one.
 
> In that case, can the access file get *too* big? I want to block
> the junk, but I don't want to wedge my server trying to do it.

  My /etc/postfix/badip file has 1139 lines (crafted by hand, one line at a
time <g>). But -- and I know sendmail works this way, too -- it's hashed so
the lookup is very fast. It's the data entry that's so darned slow!

Rich




From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct 25 16:23:21 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 16:23:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Resize your X display on the fly...
In-Reply-To: <3DB34A2B.4A405D52@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210251621310.13538-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 20 Oct 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> In that "other" OS, I can have a little icon with all the possible
> resolutions for my screen, and can switch between them fairly easily.
> It comes in handy when designing web pages. Sure, I like to work in
> 1024 x 768, but how does that page look in 640 x 480, or 800 x 600? My
> laptop supports 800 x 600, but not 1024 x 768, my wife doesn't want
> 1024 x 768, and my mother-in-law wants 640 x 480 because it's easier
> to see. Family web pages have to look good for all the family.

OK, that's something I've never understood.  Why would you have to change
screen resolutions to see how a browser would render a page when resized?

It's easy enough to just pop open your browser at the desired size and see
without actually changing your display mode.

Hell, you can have three or four browser windows open at a time, each
sized differently and refreshing with changes.

Anyway, just kind of griping...
J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From flee at aracnet.com  Fri Oct 25 16:42:58 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 16:42:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resize your X display on the fly...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210251621310.13538-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> on Fri, 25 Oct 2002 16:23:21 PDT.
Message-ID: <200210252343.g9PNh0I24237@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>:
> OK, that's something I've never understood.  Why would you have to change
> screen resolutions to see how a browser would render a page when resized?

because it's not just about the way a page is rendered, it's
about the viewer experience, and the closer you get to
duplicating the viewer experience, the easier it is to spot
problems.  watching a movie on a 15" tv is not the same as
watching it in an imax theater.  different details become
important.
--



From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Oct 25 17:18:06 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 17:18:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Korn Shell Profile with Aterm
Message-ID: <34990.192.168.1.2.1035591486.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

All;

I just solved a nagging problem with Aterm (basically a transparent xterm)
executed with WindowMaker from an icon.

You see, Aterm seems to ignore some of my ~.kshrc, ~.profile, ~.inputrc
directives. It's failure to set the terminal to vi mode command line
operation using the `set -o vi' directive chief among them. The prompt's
lack of tab filename completion comes in second.

My prompt is fine using a regular (Ctrl-Alt-F*) terminal.

The solution in my case was to insert the following in the ``Application
path and arguments'' field in Aterm's ``Applications path and arguments''
field in the ``Docked application Settings'' dialog box:

  /usr/local/bin/ksh -c "/usr/local/bin/aterm -tr -trsb -tint DarkBlue
-tintingType true -fg cyan -e /usr/local/bin/ksh -o vi -o vi-tabcomplete
&"

The -c switch tells the Korne Shell to ``run the following command.'' The
-tr, trsb, tint, tintingType,and -fg flags are just window dressing
(pardon the pun).

Pay special attention to the `-e ksh -o vi -o vi-complete' directive. See
ksh's man page for details.

Note: The Korne Shell is very feature rich. I daresay the fullest shell
available. Your opinion may vary.

The -e flag is Aterm's flag to ``run the following, '' in this case ksh
with the vi options.

I half expected to have to type `exit' or execute a Ctrl-D twice to
terminate this shell. That was fortunately not the case. That is because
Window maker spawns the command as a child process independent of the
parent.I watched `top' while double-clicking the icon to observe this.

So, the bottom line is that if you are having trouble with terminal
emulators ignoring your shell's initialization profile, this trick may
work for you.


Best,


Cooper

From revans at e-z.net  Fri Oct 25 18:56:30 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 18:56:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash prompt
In-Reply-To: <20021025170115.GB17605@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20021025133611.GA2004@boora.com>
    <20021025170115.GB17605@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20021026015614.XJAV3104.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

I like Russ's prompt but was playing around and came up with this. Works on a
black term. Matches my brown, yellow, and black "theme"

DARK_GREY="\[\033[1;30m\]"
RED="\[\033[1;31m\]"
GREEN="\[\033[1;32m\]"
YELLOW="\[\033[1;33m\]"
LIGHT_BLUE="\[\033[1;34m\]"
PURPLE="\[\033[1;35m\]"
CYAN="\[\033[1;36m\]"

OFF="\[\033[0m\]"

PAYDAY="1 15"

DAY=`date +%e`

for PLEASE in $PAYDAY ; do
	if [ $DAY = $PLEASE ] ; then
		 export PS1="$OFF$GREEN\@ - \d \w\n\u@\h \$ $YELLOW"
	else
		export PS1="$OFF$RED\@ - \d \w\n\u@\h \$ $YELLOW"
	fi
done


Thank you
Russell


On Fri, 25 Oct 2002 10:01:15 -0700, Russ Johnson said:


>  Yes. My prompt is set like this:
>  
>  (in .bashrc)
>  
>  COLOR1="\[\033[1;35m\]"
>  COLOR2="\[\033[1;36m\]"
>  COLOR3="\[\033[1;32m\]"
>  COLOR4="\[\033[0m\]"
>  PS1="[\@][$COLOR2\u$COLOR4@$COLOR1\h $COLOR3\w$COLOR4]\n\$ "

From lennon at day-reynolds.com  Sat Oct 26 16:04:55 2002
From: lennon at day-reynolds.com (Lennon Day-Reynolds)
Date: 26 Oct 2002 16:04:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Colo recommendations?
In-Reply-To: <200210241854.MAA03871@eris.coyotesong.com>
References: <200210241854.MAA03871@eris.coyotesong.com>
Message-ID: <1035673501.1263.21.camel@dell.urusai.org>

There's also the option of using a setup somewhat like John Companies
(http://www.johncompanies.com), where one multi-processor box hosts
multiple "virtual servers" -- not in the sense of normal virtual
hosting, where each client gets a regular user account and
Apache/MySQL/mail services, but in the sense of using User-Mode Linux
and an equivalent FreeBSD extension to allow multiple full instances of
the OS to run on one machine. 

That means that every "user" of the system gets full root-level access
to a full instance of their preferred *NIX on a *very* beefy box (2GB+
RAM, 10,000+ RPM SCSI RAID, etc.), without the risk of other users on
the same machine causing issues. With a low number (3-4) of instances on
each server, you end up much better off than with your own standard 2U
colo server in terms of available disk space, processor time, and
memory, and the machines can be much more robust than compact standalone
boxes.

The co-op could provide the bandwidth, add servers as needed to support
the number of clients, and perhaps offer some of the basic services
people have mentioned (firewall, mail server, database cluster, etc.).
Since John Companies manages to sell all of this for $65-75 a month
while staying in business, a non-profit should be able to shave a good
portion off of that price and still stay viable.

Personally, I would absolutely jump at the opportunity to get something
like this going, and while I don't have a large chunk of startup capital
sitting around, I would be more than happy to invest as much sweat
equity as necessary to get the thing off the ground. 


Lennon Day-Reynolds
lennon at day-reynolds.com

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Sat Oct 26 17:03:49 2002

Good advice, but sometimes you really do need a separate system.  The 
reason my friend and I bought some surplus rack-mount systems instead of 
going for conventional hosting was because I was working towards an open 
source CA.  For low-value certs (e.g., $10 personal certs) you don't 
need deep security, but you do need a dedicated box that you can lock 
and seal.

them when I'm in Portland next week.  But with the chaos in the move I'm 
now thinking that I won't be able to do anything until early next year.

From m at netpro.to  Sat Oct 26 19:20:16 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 19:20:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Streaming .ogg files easily
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210261912470.21164-100000@lukem.com>

This is WAY too easy...

http://edna.sourceforge.net/

edna will stream your MP3 or Ogg files.  It takes about a minute to setup.
You edit a config file for your setup (port, ACLs, music directory), and
they run a python script.  Boom!  You're streaming music off your box.

No one here uses MP3 anymore, right?  Right?  Right.  To enable Ogg
support, just edit edna.py and add:

'.ogg' : 'audio/ogg',

...to the section with MIME types (just do a search for WinAMP).
~M

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Oct 26 22:22:33 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 22:22:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Program control of windows under Gnome
References: <3DBA4D52.B576270A@computer-arts.net> <mailman.1035652004.408.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <3DBB40C8.7D9F4AD3@computer-arts.net>
