Mike Witt wrote:
> Kyle Accardi wrote:

>>How about `expect`?


> That might be a way to go. I don't really know much about sawfish.
> Is there any way to communicate with it from a running program or
> script?  There appears to be this sawfish thing called synthesize-event
> which could (I think) do what I want - if I could somehow access
> it from the context of a regular program.

I'm no sawfish expert either--can't even figure out how to create a 
shortcut/launcher on the desktop (it used to be easy, but seems to have been 
obfiscated--can't spell good either).

Have only used `expect` in the most basic way, as in a login script.  But it 
is gui-aware using `expectk`.  I think the idea is that you have to perform 
the mouse/keyboard action while it is recording/learning, then it can replay 
the sequence anytime you want.  ORA's "Exploring Expect" is pretty thorough 
and the author of the language (and the book), Don Liebes, is email friendly.

Your idea seems more flexible.  Be sure to share when you realize it.  From 
your initial post, it sounds like creating environments beforehand and 
copying then into place won't suffice, you want to alter the desktop 
on-the-fly, programaticaly, yes?

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From mike at computer-arts.net  Sun Oct 27 00:32:54 2002

> on-the-fly, programaticaly, yes?

Yes, that's really what I want to do. Other than controlling which
desktop windows end up on, everything was easy (once I had all the
right ssh keys installed in the right places on all the machines :-)

Actually, I don't know that expect would be any less flexible (I'm
not sure) but I really don't know how I feel about having one more
layer of stuff in the process just to achieve this one effect. I
understand the need to use expect on a Windows 95 box or whatever,
but on my system it just *seems* like I ought to be able to write 
a piece of code that requests what I want directly from the 
window manager.

-Mike


From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Oct 27 14:44:11 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 27 Oct 2002 14:44:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail by IP (was Fwd: NEW WORM -
	Friendgreetings.com mass E-mailer)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251440560.4116-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210251440560.4116-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1035758652.1428.20.camel@red>

On Fri, 2002-10-25 at 14:42, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 25 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:
> 
> > If I wanted to block all messages coming from 66.172.0.0 to
> > 66.172.63.255 in my /etc/mail/access file without blocking
> > 66.172.64.0 to 66.172.255.255, how would I do it? Adding just
> > 66.172 blocks too much, but I don't want add lots of individual
> > IPs either. Is there an allow/deny scheme for filter e-mail with
> > the access file?
> 
>   Thar ain't no shortcut, unfortunately. The MTAs don't read CIDR addresses
> so you need to list each one; e.g.:
> 
> 66.172.0	550 Whatever
> 66.172.1	550 Whatever
> 66.172.2 ...
> ...
> 66.172.63	550 Whatever
> 
> Rich

The Postfix Per User patch allows CIDR notation but it is
not well documented. Another solution is to put CIDR addresses
in Bernstein's RBL server and point Postfix to the server. The
latter approach is what I use with escrubber.biz.

Ed 




From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Oct 27 14:58:22 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 27 Oct 2002 14:58:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-headed system
Message-ID: <1035759502.1429.33.camel@red>

I've not yet had the pleasure of building a dual-headed system
so this is a newbie question.

Suppose I put a MDA (monochrome display adapter) and VGA card
in the same computer (a PC) and connect a monochrome monitor to
the MDA card and a color monitor to the VGA card. I then run a
single X server that uses the VGA card and color monitor. I want
the monochrome monitor to display my virtual consoles - using
no X server, of course.

Is this possible?

How do I control the keyboard focus? (How do I direct keystrokes
to the virtual console and not the X server?)

Ed

 






From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Sun Oct 27 19:07:00 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Sun, 27 Oct 2002 20:07:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Colo recommendations?
References: <200210241854.MAA03871@eris.coyotesong.com>	<1035673501.1263.21.camel@dell.urusai.org> 	<3DBB2D65.7020907@coyotesong.com> <1035694478.1286.27.camel@dell.urusai.org>
Message-ID: <3DBCA9D4.1040601@coyotesong.com>

Lennon Day-Reynolds wrote:
> On Sat, 2002-10-26 at 17:03, Bear Giles wrote:
> 
>>Good advice, but sometimes you really do need a separate system.  The 
>>reason my friend and I bought some surplus rack-mount systems instead of 
>>going for conventional hosting was because I was working towards an open 
>>source CA.  For low-value certs (e.g., $10 personal certs) you don't 
>>need deep security, but you do need a dedicated box that you can lock 
>>and seal.
> 
> That sounds like exactly the kind of service that the co-op could
> provide/support as a special incentive for members. Most people are only
> want a basic server, without the special physical security measures
> necessary for a "trusted" service like a CA.

Once you have the infrastructure, there's definitely a lot of 
interesting things you can do with it.  In fact, that's why drove our 
design - we started out with the wish to scratch a few itches, but 
quickly realized that we really needed to run our own CA.  And that, in 
turn, lead us to conclusion that we would want a mix of "black" and 
"grey" systems.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun Oct 27 21:49:33 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 27 Oct 2002 21:49:33 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Visualizing debian releases (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0210272142540.25787-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

FYI, here's a graph posted to debian-users showing how the debian releases
are organized.


 sid-------------------------------------------
          \                 \
           \                 \
            \                 === etch ========
             \
              \
               == sarge ======?????| 3.1 ******
                                   |
                                   |
 woody ========???| 3.0 ***********|###########
                  |                |
                  |                |
 2.2 potato ******|################| [moved of to archive.debian.org]
                  |                |
                  |                |
                  %                $

where "-" == unstable    "|" == release of a new stable
      "=" == testing     "%" == release of woody as 3.0
      "*" == stable      "$" == release of sarge as 3.1
      "#" == oldstable   "\" == branching of of a new testing release; older
                                testing (???) slowly frozen to stability

This should hopefully illustrate how sid will remain unstable, while all
other distributions start as new testings branched from unstable and later
move on to become stable and finally oldstable.

HTH,
Ray

"J.H.M. Dassen (Ray)" <dm at zensunni.demon.nl>
To: debian-user at lists.debian.org

> To present how the different debian releases are related, I'd like to
> visualize with a graph. The graph represents package versions (and
> overall functionality):
---------- Forwarded message ----------

>>>>> "Tyler" == Tyler F Creelan <creelan at engr.orst.edu> writes:

Tyler> FYI, here's a graph posted to debian-users showing how the
Tyler> debian releases are organized.

As a happy Debian user, I've got to say that this "release naming" is
one of the most inexplicably designed things I've ever seen.  Don't
they know the difference between a "nominal" and "ordinal" scale?  If
there is an order to releases, as there clearly is, they ought not to
be named nominally.  Maybe it just because I never saw "Toy Story",
but it constantly annoys me.

<?echo Lennon Day-Reynolds managed to take the time to type out the
following:
> There's also the option of using a setup somewhat like John Companies
> (http://www.johncompanies.com), where one multi-processor box hosts
> multiple "virtual servers" -- not in the sense of normal virtual
> hosting, where each client gets a regular user account and
> Apache/MySQL/mail services, but in the sense of using User-Mode Linux
> and an equivalent FreeBSD extension to allow multiple full instances of
> the OS to run on one machine.
>
> That means that every "user" of the system gets full root-level access
> to a full instance of their preferred *NIX on a *very* beefy box (2GB+
> RAM, 10,000+ RPM SCSI RAID, etc.), without the risk of other users on
> the same machine causing issues. With a low number (3-4) of instances on
> each server, you end up much better off than with your own standard 2U
> colo server in terms of available disk space, processor time, and
> memory, and the machines can be much more robust than compact standalone
> boxes.
>
> The co-op could provide the bandwidth, add servers as needed to support
> the number of clients, and perhaps offer some of the basic services
> people have mentioned (firewall, mail server, database cluster, etc.).
> Since John Companies manages to sell all of this for $65-75 a month
> while staying in business, a non-profit should be able to shave a good
> portion off of that price and still stay viable.
>
> Personally, I would absolutely jump at the opportunity to get something
> like this going, and while I don't have a large chunk of startup capital
> sitting around, I would be more than happy to invest as much sweat
> equity as necessary to get the thing off the ground.
>
>
> Lennon Day-Reynolds
> lennon at day-reynolds.com
>
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 28 13:44:02 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 28 Oct 2002 13:44:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-headed system
In-Reply-To: <1035759502.1429.33.camel@red>
References: <1035759502.1429.33.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1035841442.25572.344.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Ed,

On Sun, 2002-10-27 at 14:58, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I've not yet had the pleasure of building a dual-headed system
> so this is a newbie question.
> 
> Suppose I put a MDA (monochrome display adapter) and VGA card
> in the same computer (a PC) and connect a monochrome monitor to
> the MDA card and a color monitor to the VGA card. I then run a
> single X server that uses the VGA card and color monitor. I want
> the monochrome monitor to display my virtual consoles - using
> no X server, of course.
> 
> Is this possible?

Probably not, it looks like the dual-heads need to be on the PCI bus
(AGP is on the PCI bus).  Both video cards will also need to support
running multiple cards.  It would take a very special monochrome card to
fit this bill.

Anyway, the dual-head only works under X, so there is no way you will
get a console to display on one card, and X on the other card.
 
HTH

Derek Loree




From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Oct 28 14:03:24 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 14:03:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Visualizing debian releases (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021028-131755-0003@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210281358310.14404-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 28 Oct 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:
> Well for example back when Potato was stable and no one was sure if
> Woody was going to be 2.x or 3.0 it gave a non-cumbersome way to refer
> to it.

So what's wrong with "testing" and "unstable"?

> On most projects they are used before and official name/version number
> has been decided on. At least this is true for the projects I've been
> involved in.

Since Debian has moved to this "fork and stabilize" structure, I'd be
happy to just see the ever-mutating development branch be simply
"unstable" and each cut be given a date of cut and kernel revision number
with either a testing or stable designation (i.e., S20020401-2.2 or
T20021022-2.4).

J.

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Oct 28 14:26:02 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 15:26:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Non-unix behavior in RedHat 8.0
Message-ID: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com>

Noticed something strange in RedHat's ver 8.0. In a terminal
window launched from Gnome, if you type:

$ echo 'abc\n'

you get 

$ abc\n
$

(no newline; the slash-n is treated like a literal.)  In any
other UNIX I've seen, you'd get:

$ abc

$
(a newline after the 'abc') How do I get the traditional behavior
(i.e. echo the newline)?

- Bill Thoen



From m at netpro.to  Mon Oct 28 14:28:36 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 14:28:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Non-unix behavior in RedHat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210281428090.2370-100000@lukem.com>

It's not RedHat, it's GNU.  Try this:

echo -e 'abc\n'

man echo


On Mon, 28 Oct 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> Noticed something strange in RedHat's ver 8.0. In a terminal
> window launched from Gnome, if you type:
>
> $ echo 'abc\n'
>
> you get
>
> $ abc\n
> $
>
> (no newline; the slash-n is treated like a literal.)  In any
> other UNIX I've seen, you'd get:
>
> $ abc
>
> $
> (a newline after the 'abc') How do I get the traditional behavior
> (i.e. echo the newline)?
>
> - Bill Thoen
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>




From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 28 14:38:05 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 14:38:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Non-unix behavior in RedHat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com>
References: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <20021028223805.GA21144@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Bill Thoen <bthoen at gisnet.com> [2002-10-28 14:22]:
> Noticed something strange in RedHat's ver 8.0. In a terminal
> window launched from Gnome, if you type:
> 
> $ echo 'abc\n'
> 
> you get 
> 
> $ abc\n
> $
> 
> (no newline; the slash-n is treated like a literal.)  In any
> other UNIX I've seen, you'd get:
> 
> $ abc
> 
> $
> (a newline after the 'abc') How do I get the traditional behavior
> (i.e. echo the newline)?

Appears to be a "bashism":

[02:27pm][rjohnson at eagle ~]
$ echo 'abc\n'
abc\n
[02:27pm][rjohnson at eagle ~]
$ /bin/sh
$ echo 'abc\n'
abc

$

Bash is my default shell, and the example above is on Solaris 8. I also
tested on mandrake 9. I got the same results as the bash stuff above...
/bin/sh is a symlink to /bin/bash.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #4 (Collect all 17)
"Life does not have to be perfect to be wonderful." - Annette Funicello

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Oct 28 14:48:05 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 14:48:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-headed system 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "28 Oct 2002 13:44:02 PST."
             <1035841442.25572.344.camel@dereklinux> 
Message-ID: <200210282248.g9SMm5210414@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > I've not yet had the pleasure of building a dual-headed system
> > so this is a newbie question.
> > 
> > Suppose I put a MDA (monochrome display adapter) and VGA card
> > in the same computer (a PC) and connect a monochrome monitor to
> > the MDA card and a color monitor to the VGA card. I then run a
> > single X server that uses the VGA card and color monitor. I want
> > the monochrome monitor to display my virtual consoles - using
> > no X server, of course.
> > 
> > Is this possible?
> 
> Probably not, it looks like the dual-heads need to be on the PCI bus
> (AGP is on the PCI bus).  Both video cards will also need to support
> running multiple cards.  It would take a very special monochrome card to
> fit this bill.
> 
> Anyway, the dual-head only works under X, so there is no way you will
> get a console to display on one card, and X on the other card.
>  

Based on this message from the lkml, it sounds like what Ed wants to do
is possible.

http://www.uwsg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0202.1/0493.html

galen

-----Original Message-----

On Mon, 28 Oct 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:
> Well for example back when Potato was stable and no one was sure if
> Woody was going to be 2.x or 3.0 it gave a non-cumbersome way to refer
> to it.

So what's wrong with "testing" and "unstable"?

> On most projects they are used before and official name/version number
> has been decided on. At least this is true for the projects I've been
> involved in.

Since Debian has moved to this "fork and stabilize" structure, I'd be
happy to just see the ever-mutating development branch be simply
"unstable" and each cut be given a date of cut and kernel revision number
with either a testing or stable designation (i.e., S20020401-2.2 or
T20021022-2.4).

J.

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Oct 28 15:10:12 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Dual-headed system

On Mon, 2002-10-28 at 14:48, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > > I've not yet had the pleasure of building a dual-headed system
> > > so this is a newbie question.
> > > 
> > > Suppose I put a MDA (monochrome display adapter) and VGA card
> > > in the same computer (a PC) and connect a monochrome monitor to
> > > the MDA card and a color monitor to the VGA card. I then run a
> > > single X server that uses the VGA card and color monitor. I want
> > > the monochrome monitor to display my virtual consoles - using
> > > no X server, of course.
> > > 
> > > Is this possible?
> > 
> > Probably not, it looks like the dual-heads need to be on the PCI bus
> > (AGP is on the PCI bus).  Both video cards will also need to support
> > running multiple cards.  It would take a very special monochrome card to
> > fit this bill.
> > 
> > Anyway, the dual-head only works under X, so there is no way you will
> > get a console to display on one card, and X on the other card.
> >  
> 
> Based on this message from the lkml, it sounds like what Ed wants to do
> is possible.

Your right!  A little more digging, and I found this:

http://old.lwn.net/1999/0513/a/multihead.html

Which is a little on the old side, but the basic idea is there. 
Apparently most MDA cards do support multiple heads, not sure who told
me that they didn't.

Sorry for the confusion.

Derek Loree






From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Oct 28 15:16:00 2002
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 16:16:00 -0700

Message-ID: <3DBDC530.B5C56354@gisnet.com>

Seems I can only get it to work by using both yours and Matt's
suggestion together.

This works:
$ /bin/sh
$ echo -e 'abc\n'
abc

$

This doesn't work:
$ /bin/sh
$ echo 'abc\n'

Nor does this:
$ echo -e 'abc\n'

Guess I better check what /bin/sh points to on this RH8.0 box...

- Bill Thoen

handed over his Multi-Head Mini-HOWTO for inclusion in this HOWTO."

And that is one of the reason I like it. It tends to keep newbies away. Tends to reduce demand for stupid things like GUI installers and auto installing hardware. Debian IMNSHO *should* be hard and scary for people who don't want to take the time and make the effort to learn it. But then again from previous conversations I'm guessing my goals and thoughts on what I want are *very* different from yours. To each their own.

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Oct 28 16:11:44 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 16:11:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Non-unix behavior in RedHat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3DBDC530.B5C56354@gisnet.com>
References: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com> <20021028223805.GA21144@sthelens.dimstar.net> <3DBDC530.B5C56354@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <20021029001144.GB21144@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Bill Thoen <bthoen at gisnet.com> [2002-10-28 15:12]:
> Guess I better check what /bin/sh points to on this RH8.0 box...

Most likely, /bin/sh is a symlink to /bin/bash. I believe this is true
on all Linux distributions. Which means that you have to use the other
solution on linux, but on other unixes, you can run a bourne shell and
it'll work.

Russ Johnson

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Mon Oct 28 17:41:58 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 17:41:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] /mnt/hda5  & Sound
Message-ID: <3DBDE766.3080805@attbi.com>

Thanks josh, I'll check the cable.

Paul, I've tried this 4 times, from a terminal as root 3 times and once 
without logging in as anyone [Ithought maybe I'd misinterpreted the 
everyone logged out line], and the only result is a blinking cursor and 
nothing. I've used ctl-alt-del to reboot.;

OK, here's more or less what I'd do if you want /dev/hda5 to become
/home. Make sure everyone's logged out, then from the first virtual
console

#
# this code is untested and provided without warranty :-)
#
# go to single-user mode
#
/sbin/telinit s
#
# test a sync; note that trailing slashes or lack thereof
# are crucial!
#
rsync -nav /home/ /mnt/hda5
#
# if everything looks kosher, then do a live sync
#
rsync -av /home/ /mnt/hda5
#
# get rid of competing /home candidates
#
umount /mnt/hda5
/bin/rm -rf /home/*
#
# edit the following fstab entry as needed
#
cat <<__eof__ >>/etc/fstab
/dev/hda5          /home           ext3   defaults     1 2
__eof__
#
# bring /dev/hda5 online for real
#
mount /home
#
# bring back to old runlevel
#
/sbin/telinit $(grep ':initdefault:' /etc/inittab | cut -d: -f2)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From revans at e-z.net  Mon Oct 28 16:41:31 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)

Interesting, a hostname change would invalidate your magic cookie. I think kdm
would still use the old magic cookie but starting x from a console you just
logged into, would create a new cookie. Well if you or dhcp didn't change your
hostname, then maybe there is another way to invalidate a magic cookie?

Restart kdm if you haven't.

Thank you
Russell

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Mon Oct 28 00:28:54 2002
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (BMDimaculangan)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 16:28:54 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail  trhough IP add
In-Reply-To: <3DB9C62F.630E3441@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEJPCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

how do i block email messages coming from certatin ip add (local and
private), where would i put it in header or body checks.




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Oct 28 17:55:14 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 17:55:14 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking e-mail  trhough IP add
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEJPCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210281752230.26987-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 28 Oct 2002, BMDimaculangan wrote:

> how do i block email messages coming from certatin ip add (local and
> private), where would i put it in header or body checks.

  What MTA?

  In postfix, you can add a smtpd_recipient_restrictions rule something like
these:

header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks
body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks

  Put your IP address or domain name in there with a REJECT command.

Rich




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Oct 28 17:59:00 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 17:59:00 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Cookie bear for Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021029005140.GKNI3093.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0210281744070.7186-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

This reminds me - Is there a unix clone of the multics "cookie bear"
program ?  That is, the program you could run on someone's terminal and it
would keep printing "Can I have a cookie?" until the user typed "cookie",
then go into the background to run again later?

I've found the source for the old MIT Multics version, written in PL/1,
but it seems someone would have ported it to Unix in 25+ years...


More info:
------------------
Origin of the Cookie Monster

The idea for the program was born during a Senior House bull session in
1970. Seth Stein, an MIT freshman from Providence, volunteered a story
about an IBM computer operator at Brown who liked to tease his users by
locking out their terminals and manually sending them messages asking for
a cookie until they typed "cookie." "Say," I immediately thought, "this
concept cries out for automation!"

The programming itself was relatively simple, and was done during a
vacation week on a 2741 that SIPB had recently installed into the dorm for
student use.

Because of Multics' fine security, the perpetrator usually had to wait
until his victim left a terminal unattended to cause the program to run in
the victim's process. Occasionally, a user left one or more of his files
unguarded, allowing a tormentor to insert a command to invoke the cookie
program in that user's start_up command file, his abbreviatioe ever
involved.)

The hack was made truly difficult to find and purge by an unusual feature
of Multics: the ability for a program to set an alarm timer and then
terminate. At the specified time, the alarm timer would invoke a program,
exactly as if the user had typed a command. That program could set another
alarm timer, and so on. (The closest analogy I can think of is UNIX cron,
except that no processes other than the user's own were ever involved.)

...http://www.multicians.org/cookie.html



Tyler

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon Oct 28 18:13:00 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 18:13:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Non-unix behavior in RedHat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3DBDB97A.ED89442F@gisnet.com> on Mon, 28 Oct 2002 15:26:02 MST.
Message-ID: <200210290213.g9T2D2p26630@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Bill Thoen <bthoen at gisnet.com>:
> (a newline after the 'abc') How do I get the traditional behavior
> (i.e. echo the newline)?

there is no traditional behavior.  'echo' is a traditional
Unix incompatibility, one of the original BSD vs System V
problems.  And Tenth Edition Unix (Bell Labs) only
interprets backslash escapes if you give echo the -e option,
whereas modern Unix standards like
   http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/007908799/xcu/echo.html
say that echo doesn't interpret any options (not even -n).

use 'printf' instead of 'echo' for anything non-trivial.
--

From keith at ahapala.net  Mon Oct 28 22:08:00 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Snort / Wireless Packets
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210282133500.3503-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

So I installed snort to see what that is all about and ran snort -vd to 
just see what is flying around on my wireless LAN. Quite a few of the 
following packets are going by and I need some help understanding this.

10/28-21:28:22.816613 192.168.0.100:1901 -> 239.255.255.250:1900
UDP TTL:150 TOS:0x0 ID:9 IpLen:20 DgmLen:343

32 35 35 2E 32 35 30 3A 31 39 30 30 0D 0A 43 61  255.250:1900..Ca
63 68 65 2D 43 6F 6E 74 72 6F 6C 3A 6D 61 78 2D  che-Control:max-
61 67 65 3D 31 32 30 0D 0A 4C 6F 63 61 74 69 6F  age=120..Locatio
6E 3A 68 74 74 70 3A 2F 2F 31 39 32 2E 31 36 38  n:http://192.168
2E 30 2E 31 30 30 3A 35 36 37 38 2F 72 6F 6F 74  .0.100:5678/root
44 65 73 63 2E 78 6D 6C 0D 0A 4E 54 3A 75 72 6E  Desc.xml..NT:urn
3A 73 63 68 65 6D 61 73 2D 75 70 6E 70 2D 6F 72  :schemas-upnp-or
67 3A 73 65 72 76 69 63 65 3A 57 41 4E 49 50 43  g:service:WANIPC
6F 6E 6E 65 63 74 69 6F 6E 3A 31 0D 0A 4E 54 53  onnection:1..NTS
3A 73 73 64 70 3A 61 6C 69 76 65 0D 0A 53 65 72  :ssdp:alive..Ser
76 65 72 3A 4E 54 2F 35 2E 30 20 55 50 6E 50 2F  ver:NT/5.0 UPnP/
31 2E 30 0D 0A 55 53 4E 3A 75 75 69 64 3A 75 70  1.0..USN:uuid:up
6E 70 2D 57 41 4E 43 6F 6E 6E 65 63 74 69 6F 6E  np-WANConnection
44 65 76 69 63 65 2D 31 5F 30 2D 30 30 39 30 61  Device-1_0-0090a
32 37 37 37 37 37 37 3A 3A 75 72 6E 3A 73 63 68  2777777::urn:sch
65 6D 61 73 2D 75 70 6E 70 2D 6F 72 67 3A 73 65  emas-upnp-org:se
72 76 69 63 65 3A 57 41 4E 49 50 43 6F 6E 6E 65  rvice:WANIPConne
63 74 69 6F 6E 3A 31 0D 0A 0D 0A                 ction:1....

192.168.0.100 is my Linksys wireless router. Why is it sending this UDP 
packet to 239.255.255.250:1900? I ran a google search and it came back 
with http://www.futurenet-consulting.com/mrwvuln.pdf which details a UPNP 
exploit in Windows. whois shows this for the destination IP:

Comment:    This block is reserved for special purposes.
            Please see RFC 3171 for additional information.

RFC 3171 describes the ip as...

9. Administratively Scoped Address Block (239/8)

   Addresses in the Administratively Scoped Address block are for local
   use within a domain and are described in [RFC2365].

So, I looked at my Linksys configuration and turned off UPNP and that 
seemed to have stopped the flow. Is that destination non-routable and the 
packets would be dropped up stream of me? Anyone have any more info on 
this?

Thanks,
Keith




From cschluti at pdx.edu  Mon Oct 28 23:25:09 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (charlieS)
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 23:25:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] filtering files with double extension name
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEKOCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <001601c27f1c$509d8eb0$4500000a@SERVANYA>

Try these:

/name=".*\....\.scr"/i REJECT
/name=".*\....\.pif"/i REJECT
/name=".*\....\.exe"/i REJECT
/name=".*\....\.vbs"/i REJECT

or maybe: 

/name=".*\....\.vbs|exe|pif|scr"/i REJECT


-CharlieS

> How can you tell the size of a directory?

Dirk,

  du -c

  You can also add an 'h' for human readable.

Rich

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Oct 29 08:53:37 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 08:53:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File server package recommendation
References: <1035879695.1334.22.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3DBEBD11.3040706@sun.com>

FTP?

Or I suppose you could use something like giFT (gift.sourceforge.net) if 
you don't mind sharing with others.

Something like Samba won't work over the 'net unless you setup a VPN 
between the systems you want to share with...and even then it probably 
won't fall under bullet #3.

I'd say ftp would probably be the best bet, with a web-based search 
engine.

-R

Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi All Folks
> 
> Kindly recommend a File Server package for
> 
> 1) files sharing via Internet and Intranet
> 2) having searching function
> 3) easy to setup
> 
> Thanks in advance.
> 
> Stephen Liu

On Tue, 2002-10-29 at 08:53, Richard Langis wrote:
> FTP?

or sftp?  

WinSCP is a pretty good windows client that uses an ssh tunnel for file
transfers (it also displays the real file structure in Winblows, not the
virtual crap that Windows Explorer displays; example: IE cache files). 
Free for the download too.

when trying to cancel print jobs, even as root, I get a
"client-error-forbidden" message.  anyone figure out a way to eliminate

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Tue Oct 29 10:22:47 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael J. Luevane)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 10:22:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba + Windows question: can act as admin locally, but not when logged into the domain
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOOEBOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Hello, PLUGgers...

First, a caveat - I'm a relative newbie at Linux et al, so if I make a
"newbie" mistake, it's to be expected.

I'm trying to get backup software (Veritas Backup Exec) to work on my NT
box.

First, the background:

I have a mixed networks - Linux server + NT/98/2k clients. Linux server is
running Samba and is acting as PDC for the domain.

I have a Windows NT 4 Server (SP6) that I is the BDC for the domain. This is
the machine I want to run the backup software on.

So, the software and hardware are installed. As the *local* administrator, I
can run the backup software, but I can't get it to connect to the server.

I log in as the administrator (or root) on the domain and I can get to the
network drive just fine. But now I can't run the software because I don't
have administrator or backup operator rights.

So, what I have is this:

Local: can run software, can't get to server
Domain: can't run software, can get to server

It looks like (from other things that I've tried to do) the Administrator
account rights are "overruled" by the rights that the account has on the
Linux server, but the administrative rights don't come over. Or something
like that.

Am I making sense?

Help! :)

Mike




From plug at magnetinternet.com  Tue Oct 29 10:30:36 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 10:30:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba + Windows question: can act as admin locally, but not when logged into the domain
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOOEBOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOOEBOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <9568.66.93.41.98.1035916236.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

I've setup the veritas UNIX agent on a linux box before, works like a
charm.  The password mechanisms for it are separate from the domain stuff
so it should work for you. Under Veritas on windows the box will show up
as a UNIX agent (once you have it running as a daemon on the Linux
server), you specify the password and voila you're in to back up your
Linux box.

You can get the client off of the Veritas Install CD or on their web site.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From lemming at attbi.com  Tue Oct 29 12:21:30 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (Mark)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 12:21:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS "client-error-forbidden"
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210291123500.30294-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3DBEEDCA.70508@attbi.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 29 Oct 2002, Eric Jahn wrote:
> 
> 
>>hmmm...I've got the same permissions.  I'm suspicious it's a CUPS new
>>version thing...
> 
> 
>   May well be. With a couple of applications, openoffice's Writer in
> particular, I can no longer put paper in the manual feed tray and have it
> selected over the main tray without changing the printer definition each
> time. That's a new CUPS "feature" that I don't particularly like.

I just went through a major hassle with setting up CUPS supporting a
HP Deskjet 5550.  I went through the instructions at hp.com for setting 
it up.  It mostly involved packages from sourceforge.net.

Once I followed everything, it worked.  Before dealing with that, I had 
several problems with client errors as well.  I also had to hand edit 
/etc/cups/printers.conf and /etc/cups/cupsd.conf for optimal results.

Check your Allow,Deny settings.

On the paper feed, no idea I'm afraid.

The hassle with the printer was worth it.  Awesome photo printing.

-Mark

From david at davudsplace.net  Tue Oct 29 15:12:38 2002
From: david at davudsplace.net (david may)
Date: 29 Oct 2002 15:12:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] disk space by user
In-Reply-To: <mailman.1035928161.3668.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
References: <mailman.1035928161.3668.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <874rb496vt.fsf@davudsplace.net>

i'd prolly use something like this but i'll bet you get some  perl 
to do the same thing as well.

find . -mount -printf "%u %k\n" | awk '{total[$1]+=$2;};END {for (i in total ) {print total[i], i;};}'

From kaile at centerspan.com  Tue Oct 29 15:31:40 2002
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 15:31:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris and Decent Authentication
Message-ID: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC439BECC@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>

Hello,

I have been searching fervently to try and find some sort of solution
that allows Solaris (7 and 8, though 8 is more important) to
authenticate with MD5 (like linux, freebsd, etc...) instead of DES like
it currently uses. I am failing. I was hoping someone on this list could
help me.

Having 8 significant chars in passwords is irritating. Beyond that, I am
going to be implementing NIS (and later LDAP) soon for authentication,
and I would MUCH prefer to use MD5 across the board rather than DES. Is
there a patch, pam update, pam module, etc... that can do what I'm
looking for, or am I SOL?

I know that you can use whatever auth scheme you want for LDAP, but I
was looking for a near term solution for the NIS deployment.

Anyone have any info on this subject? I'd appreciate any information.


Thanks,

Kaile

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Oct 29 16:23:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 16:23:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris and Decent Authentication
In-Reply-To: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC439BECC@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210291611560.26184-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 29 Oct 2002, Kaile Riser wrote:

> Having 8 significant chars in passwords is irritating. Beyond that,
> I am going to be implementing NIS (and later LDAP) soon for
> authentication, and I would MUCH prefer to use MD5 across the board
> rather than DES. Is there a patch, pam update, pam module, etc...
> that can do what I'm looking for, or am I SOL?

As far as I know, NIS is locked into DES, so any NIS solution is 
DES-bound regardless of OS.

I'm unsure whether Solaris can work with MD5 hashes with LDAP 
authentication, but I'm pretty sure it can't use them in any 
files-based scheme like passwd/shadow.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From derek at infotects.com  Tue Oct 29 16:27:02 2002

From m at netpro.to  Tue Oct 29 16:45:27 2002

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Tue Oct 29 17:11:01 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 18:11:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] disk space by user
References: <mailman.1035928161.3668.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <874rb496vt.fsf@davudsplace.net>
Message-ID: <3DBF31A5.7050606@coyotesong.com>

I tried to send a followup from a different account (where I could 
attach some code inline) but forgot that the message would be blocked at 
the moderator.  hint hint... :-)

Anyway, this is a much harder problem than you might first think.  The
sample script counts any symlinks against the user, probably not 
something you want to do.  It's easy to add -type f to the find, but 
what about hard links?  Sparse files?

You probably also want to collect other statistics.  Do users have an 
unusual number of directories?  Symlinks?  Do they have any special 
files, sockets, devices?  What about SUID or SGID files?

Bear




From jon at manymoons.net  Tue Oct 29 17:07:02 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 30 Oct 2002 01:07:02 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Yahoo! goes with PHP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210291644580.10481-100000@lukem.com>

Message-ID: <1035940023.1649.1288.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Yes, this was very interesting to me since when I was working for them
(via WebRing) we did Perl but one of the very few who did.  Mostly they
did C or C++.  What I wondered is why they went with PHP and not Perl. 
Amazon recently decided to move towards Perl over PHP but apparently the
reasoning at Yahoo is different.

Either way, this makes sense.  PHP (and Perl) are so much easier to use
and development will go much faster.

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Tue Oct 29 17:28:01 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 18:28:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris and Decent Authentication
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210291611560.26184-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <3DBF35A1.3010800@coyotesong.com>

Solaris supports smart cards, if you want 'more than decent' 
authentication.  You still need a passphrase for the private key on the 
smart card, but the card can be set up so that it never reveals the 
private key.

Bear




From hapibeli at attbi.com  Tue Oct 29 21:19:24 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Unused hda5
Message-ID: <3DBF6BDC.2090406@attbi.com>

what does 'mount' show?  Is hda5 actually mounted to /mnt/hda5 or is
that just a directory off of the root filesystem?

-R

]# mount
/dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
none on /proc type proc (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
/dev/hda1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda5 on /mnt/hda5 type ext3 (rw)
none on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)
none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
none on /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc type binfmt_misc (rw)

Dirk

mailman, pop-before-smtp, a few other goodies. eth0 is the only NIC.

as copying over the directories....leaving the /boot partition alone?

packages with 8.0 CD's plus up2date once that is in.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct 30 08:48:39 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 08:48:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300839010.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  This week's issue of The Economist has a special report on computer
security. It's pretty good (I've not read the whole thing yet), identifying
Microsoft IIS specifically and often, but not identifying e-mail virii to
the same origin. Anyway, the report makes passing reference to exploits
based on SQL insertions to a web server that causes the backend database to
return what would normally be hidden data.

  This brings me to my question: is this exploit possible on _all_ web
servers or is it brand (or database) specific? That is, are apache servers
with mySQL or postgres backends susceptible to this attack?

Just curious,

Rich




From plug at magnetinternet.com  Wed Oct 30 08:56:55 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 08:56:55 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300839010.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300839010.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <7350.66.93.41.98.1035997015.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

 Rich Shepard busted out the keyboard and typed:
>   This brings me to my question: is this exploit possible on _all_ web
> servers or is it brand (or database) specific? That is, are apache
> servers with mySQL or postgres backends susceptible to this attack?

I know with MySQL, it only allows connections by default from localhost
only.  You can add users and where they can connect as needed.

I would think MySQL at least is affected, but only if it's wide open for
anyone to connect to it, and they know a username and password (or the
default password is blank).  Same probably goes for any other database
server.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com





From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Oct 30 09:07:31 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 09:07:31 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300839010.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300905300.29666-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 30 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> This brings me to my question: is this exploit possible on _all_ web
> servers or is it brand (or database) specific? That is, are apache
> servers with mySQL or postgres backends susceptible to this attack?

It all depends on the code used to interface between Apache and the 
RDBMS. If the code does the proper bounds checking, character 
escaping, etc., then everything is fine. If the code accepts remote 
input without strict checks, then all sorts of mischief is possible.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct 30 09:07:41 2002

> I would think MySQL at least is affected, but only if it's wide open for
> anyone to connect to it, and they know a username and password (or the
> default password is blank).  Same probably goes for any other database
> server.

  Thanks, Matt. Perhaps I should rephrase my question to ask if anyone knows
of such a breech of a linux-hosted site. I don't run a web server here but
I'm curious.

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct 30 09:24:04 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 09:24:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300905300.29666-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300921370.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 30 Oct 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> It all depends on the code used to interface between Apache and the 
> RDBMS. If the code does the proper bounds checking, character 
> escaping, etc., then everything is fine. If the code accepts remote 
> input without strict checks, then all sorts of mischief is possible.

  Well, this does answer my question. So, it's a human issue (programming
care and skills) rather than a platform issue.

  Are these rare, or fairly common but not publicized? I'm just wondering
about my information stored -- I'm sure -- on Web sites I've used for
purchases.

Many thanks, Paul,

Rich




From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 30 10:01:36 2002

Dimension 7/Stargate Online

Random thought #4 (Collect all 17)

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Wed Oct 30 10:18:58 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 11:18:58 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300921370.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com> from Rich
 Shepard at "Oct 30, 2002 09:24:04 am"
Message-ID: <200210301818.LAA19624@eris.coyotesong.com>

> On Wed, 30 Oct 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
>   Are these rare, or fairly common but not publicized? I'm just wondering
> about my information stored -- I'm sure -- on Web sites I've used for
> purchases.

I'm sure that they're very common.

The way that they work is they attack web site scripts generate queries
from user data.  So where you expect the query to look like 

  select * from table where user = 'bob';

(where you've gotten "bob" from the user form, they'll have filled out
the form with

  username: "bob' and more sql here ending with 'this"

so the query you actually run is

  select * from table where user = 'bob' and more sql here ending with 'this';

This is easy to fix in most cases, e.g., if you collect information on
a web page that will be echoed to a web page, replace ' with &apos; and
" with &quot;... and also replace <, > and & to prevent abusive HTML.
But many sites don't bother.

Bear



From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Wed Oct 30 10:21:28 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 10:21:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210300906270.1212-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <7350.66.93.41.98.1035997015.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021030095340.00ae0650@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

SQL insertion isn't a platform issue so much as a SQL/middleware 
issue.   Sanitizing all user input before passing it to a database engine 
is a crucial (but often overlooked) practice.

SQL is a pretty powerful language and if you're able to pass arbitrary 
strings to the DB engine, virtually anything is possible, particularly if 
you have some knowledge of the implementation details.

An excellent study in some of the relevant issues can be found here:

http://www.sensepost.com/misc/SQLinsertion.htm




From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Oct 30 10:28:43 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 30 Oct 2002 10:28:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
References: <mailman.1035997894.3387.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <861y676ask.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   Thanks, Matt. Perhaps I should rephrase my question to ask if
Rich> anyone knows of such a breech of a linux-hosted site. I don't
Rich> run a web server here but I'm curious.

The "linux" part of the hosting is irrelevant.  It's just that
there's an "impedence mismatch" between Web Form Fields and
SQL, so you have to bridge the gap with a decent language (like Perl),
and when you don't do it right, people might be able to include
SQL-metacharacters into their data and "the fun begins".

Hint: this is wrong:

my $search_for = param('search_for');
my $query = "SELECT name, address FROM atable WHERE name = '$search_for'";

For Perl, the key thing is *** use DBI placeholders ***.  It's amazing
how many people don't do that, and instead try to substitute into the
text.  Bleh.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Oct 30 10:34:45 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 30 Oct 2002 10:34:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] disk space by user
References: <mailman.1035928161.3668.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <mailman.1035933262.5943.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86smyn4vy2.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "david" == david may <david at davudsplace.net> writes:

david> i'd prolly use something like this but i'll bet you get some  perl 
david> to do the same thing as well.

david> find . -mount -printf "%u %k\n" | awk '{total[$1]+=$2;};END {for (i in total ) {print total[i], i;};}'

    use File::Find;
    my %total_blocks;
    find sub {
      my @stat = lstat or return;
      $total_blocks{$stat[4]} += $stat[12];
    }, "/";

    for (sort keys %total_blocks) {
      printf "%3d %10s %d\n",
        $_, scalar getpwuid($_), $total_blocks{$_};
    }

If you want it sorted by biggest disk wasters, er, users, replace
that last loop start with:

    for (sort { $total_blocks{$b} <=> $total_blocks{$a} } keys %total_blocks) {

--

<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Oct 30 10:30:55 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 30 Oct 2002 10:30:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Yahoo! goes with PHP
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210291644580.10481-100000@lukem.com> <mailman.1035940522.12033.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86wunz4w4g.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Jon" == Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net> writes:

Jon> Yes, this was very interesting to me since when I was working for them
Jon> (via WebRing) we did Perl but one of the very few who did.  Mostly they
Jon> did C or C++.  What I wondered is why they went with PHP and not Perl. 
Jon> Amazon recently decided to move towards Perl over PHP but apparently the
Jon> reasoning at Yahoo is different.

The mod-perl list has been abuzz with this discussion.  The bottom
line is that they *ignored* their own performance data (mod_perl
was shown to be faster than PHP in the data from that report)
and are making the mistake of "some of it in Perl, some of it in PHP".

I predict that in two years, they'll either admit it should have been
mod_perl and Template Toolkit (or maybe Mason) but are now too
invested, or they'll cut over.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 30 10:41:00 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 10:41:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact
In-Reply-To: <000501c28030$c9111280$6401a8c0@Endeavor>

* Greg Long <plug at maneuveringspeed.com> [2002-10-30 08:26]:
> I want the 60gb drive for the workstation :)

In that case, you can use cpio to copy the files from one hard drive to
another. Either over the wire (nfs mount) or locally (install the hard
drive as a slave in the source computer. 

I think I'd use this command:

$find . | cpio -pm /dest

I seem to remember using this command when moving home directories
around.

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Wed Oct 30 10:53:52 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 11:53:52 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <861y676ask.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> from "Randal L. Schwartz" at
 "Oct 30, 2002 10:28:43 am"
Message-ID: <200210301853.LAA19672@eris.coyotesong.com>

> For Perl, the key thing is *** use DBI placeholders ***.  It's amazing
> how many people don't do that, and instead try to substitute into the
> text.  Bleh.

I'm sure Perl doesn't have this problem :-), but you have to be careful
because some implementations just blindly substitute the text in the
query sent to the RDBMS and using placeholders gains you nothing.

To be absolutely safe, you need to explicitly encode the data sent to
the database to mask any metacharacters.

Bear

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Wed Oct 30 12:09:29 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 14:09:29 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] CISCO Router Frontend
Message-ID: <EX-20021030-141200-0009@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

You might want to take a look at the configmaker. You have to have a CCO account to get it. But it is *very* limited. In general there are no good or evern very usable frontends. Basically you need to learn IOS to do anything and just like a CLI on Linux once you learn it it is a lot easier and faster than any GUI could be. It would be best to take this offline but what kind of problems are you having? Maybe I can help you with a better way to do it.

Ray

From marie at mmt.org  Wed Oct 30 12:45:26 2002
From: marie at mmt.org (Marie Deatherage)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 12:45:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Need advice, suggestions, etc.
Message-ID: <3DC044E7.29C0108E@mmt.org>

Hello,

I am a former subscriber who recently returned to the fold, as it were.
For the past few years at my workplace, I have been the staff person
assigned to get Internet access for our office, primarily based on the
fact that I set up a LAN and got DSL service for my family at home the
first month it was available in Portland.  Therefore, I was further
along on the learning curve than anyone else in the office, hence the
duties fell to me.  After researching the options, I recommended we use
Linux on a proxy server.  My boss went for the notion, and it has served
us very well from a stability standpoint, but since I have way too many
other job duties, I never had time to learn Linux and just sort of
patched my way through learning just enough to do a few simple things.

We hired an outside source to provide Linux support, but it apparently
went out of business shortly thereafter (hopefully there was no
connection).  We have continued to limp along, but I have been very very
worried about our lack of technical support.

Recently we had a change in our leadership, and our new director is
prepared to get serious about technology.  We've been getting assessed
by outside consultants, and perhaps it will come as no surprise to
anyone on this list that the standard recommendation is to purchase a
windows server and become a windows/access/explorer/etc. world and all
that it entails.  We are told that Linux hardware and software cost just
as much and are much harder to figure out, maintain, etc.  This flies in
the face of what I think I know and believe, but I do not have the
expertise to do much more than raise questions (but what about licensing
fees? etc.) and say things like "That's not what I have heard."

At the individual user level in our office, we are mostly a Macintosh
environment.  We have not yet made the transition to OS X.  We have a
very large database in Filemaker pro.  We have quite a few users who, if
not technophobes, are not particularly sophisticated or confident, so
keeping things simple at the desktop level is a must.  Unfortunately, it
seems that there is a tendency among consultants  to completely overlook
what we already have and recommend that we migrate to windows for
everything.  I am concerned that this snowball could just keep rolling
all the way to the bottom of the hill unless I figure out how to stop
it.

So here is my question:  is there anyone(s) on this list with a combined
expertise in Linux and Mac (esp. OS X) who might be able to assess what
we have and provide an alternative view?  In addition to deciding what
hardware/software changes we might need, we will be looking to hire
someone on a long term part time basis to train staff, sys admin, etc.
etc.

Please contact me privately if you have this expertise and can suggest
something and/or might be interested in following up.

Thank you,
--
Marie Deatherage
marie at mmt.org





From verso at mac.com  Wed Oct 30 12:57:22 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 12:57:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Need advice, suggestions, etc.
In-Reply-To: <3DC044E7.29C0108E@mmt.org>
Message-ID: <B9E587B2.5561%verso@mac.com>

Hi Marie,

I know a lot about osx, I run it at home and used to at work. I do a lot
with it, both in the gui and the cli portions. I'm not so much the linux
geek, but I know how to get things done or find out how. What sort of help
do you need?

-Kelly

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Wed Oct 30 12:52:44 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 14:52:44 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Need advice, suggestions, etc.
Message-ID: <EX-20021030-145607-0008@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

I don't really have the time to do this. But the reason consultants want you to go to Windows is because that is what they know. You can see this from them saying that it is "harder to figure it out" So yes you are doing the right thing. Good luck in finding someone.



-----Original Message-----
From: Marie Deatherage 
Sent: Wednesday, October 30, 2002 12:47 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] Need advice, suggestions, etc.


Hello,

I am a former subscriber who recently returned to the fold, as it were.
For the past few years at my workplace, I have been the staff person
assigned to get Internet access for our office, primarily based on the
fact that I set up a LAN and got DSL service for my family at home the
first month it was available in Portland.  Therefore, I was further
along on the learning curve than anyone else in the office, hence the
duties fell to me.  After researching the options, I recommended we use
Linux on a proxy server.  My boss went for the notion, and it has served
us very well from a stability standpoint, but since I have way too many
other job duties, I never had time to learn Linux and just sort of
patched my way through learning just enough to do a few simple things.

We hired an outside source to provide Linux support, but it apparently
went out of business shortly thereafter (hopefully there was no
connection).  We have continued to limp along, but I have been very very
worried about our lack of technical support.

Recently we had a change in our leadership, and our new director is
prepared to get serious about technology.  We've been getting assessed
by outside consultants, and perhaps it will come as no surprise to
anyone on this list that the standard recommendation is to purchase a
windows server and become a windows/access/explorer/etc. world and all
that it entails.  We are told that Linux hardware and software cost just
as much and are much harder to figure out, maintain, etc.  This flies in
the face of what I think I know and believe, but I do not have the
expertise to do much more than raise questions (but what about licensing
fees? etc.) and say things like "That's not what I have heard."

At the individual user level in our office, we are mostly a Macintosh
environment.  We have not yet made the transition to OS X.  We have a
very large database in Filemaker pro.  We have quite a few users who, if
not technophobes, are not particularly sophisticated or confident, so
keeping things simple at the desktop level is a must.  Unfortunately, it
seems that there is a tendency among consultants  to completely overlook
what we already have and recommend that we migrate to windows for
everything.  I am concerned that this snowball could just keep rolling
all the way to the bottom of the hill unless I figure out how to stop
it.

So here is my question:  is there anyone(s) on this list with a combined
expertise in Linux and Mac (esp. OS X) who might be able to assess what
we have and provide an alternative view?  In addition to deciding what
hardware/software changes we might need, we will be looking to hire
someone on a long term part time basis to train staff, sys admin, etc.
etc.

Please contact me privately if you have this expertise and can suggest
something and/or might be interested in following up.

Thank you,
--
Marie Deatherage
marie at mmt.org



_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug





From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 30 13:34:54 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 13:34:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact
In-Reply-To: <001601c28050$c62b7130$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
References: <20021030184100.GB31534@sthelens.dimstar.net> <001601c28050$c62b7130$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <20021030213454.GC31534@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Greg Long <plug at maneuveringspeed.com> [2002-10-30 12:15]:
> Thanks. I actually have the files over on the "new" box in .tgz backups.
> These are dated, but serve for a good test. I guess my greatest concern
> was that even though only root will be logged in, in Runlevel 3, it
> wouldn't like me untar'ing the archives on top of the existing
> directories: Dumping home.tgz into /home replacing existing, dumping
> etc.tgz into /etc replacing existing, etc. -- (or should I say "and so
> on" in lieu of "etc."?)
> 
> I may as well try it....it's an "expendable" system at this point.

It should work just fine. One of the beauties of Linux (and most Unixes)
is the ability to replace files, while the system is up. 

In most cases, the file gets replaced, and the new version is used the
next time it's loaded. Any copies in memory continue to run as normal. 

When replacing a lot of files, it's probably a good idea to reboot after
your done, to make sure the new files are in use. 

Depending on the options used to make the tarballs, you may or may not
have success doing this. If the permissions or other attributes aren't
in the tarball, then they may come out without the "right stuff" to run. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Random thought #4 (Collect all 17)
"Life does not have to be perfect to be wonderful." - Annette Funicello



From plug at maneuveringspeed.com  Wed Oct 30 13:37:11 2002
From: plug at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 13:37:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact
In-Reply-To: <20021030213454.GC31534@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <001901c2805c$819f1bf0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>

Good point on permissions. I used for example to archive the /usr dir:

tar -czf usr.tgz /usr

Shouldn't that do the deal?  If not, it's no big, as these backups are
two weeks old. I will do this early morn on a weekend most likely.

both use /dev/hda1 and /dev/hda2, and a <swap> partition mounted at the
end. /dev/hda3 (?)

---Greg

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Oct 30 14:13:00 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 14:13:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact
In-Reply-To: <001901c2805c$819f1bf0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
References: <20021030213454.GC31534@sthelens.dimstar.net> <001901c2805c$819f1bf0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <20021030221259.GE31534@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Greg Long <plug at maneuveringspeed.com> [2002-10-30 13:39]:
> Good point on permissions. I used for example to archive the /usr dir:
> 
> tar -czf usr.tgz /usr
> 
> Shouldn't that do the deal?  If not, it's no big, as these backups are
> two weeks old. I will do this early morn on a weekend most likely.

I would add a 'p' to that list of options:

$tar -zcpvf tarball.tar.gz /source

'p' is 'p'ermissions.

The 'v' would be optional, but causes 'v'erbos output.

From m at netpro.to  Wed Oct 30 14:22:21 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 14:22:21 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Samba + Windows question: can act as admin locally,

In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOEEGKLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210301420390.14576-100000@lukem.com>

You don't have to actually reboot.  The install should create a startup
script for you called /etc/rc3.d/S96somethingsomething

I had to refresh the view in Backup Exec to get the Unix Clients to show
up.  But they should be listed on the left side with the other systems.

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Wed Oct 30 15:32:38 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael J. Luevane)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 15:32:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba and Windows - 'nother issue - slow browsing
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Hello, pluggers.

In yet another display of n00bness, I'm having an issue with my Samba server
and Windows boxen. When anyone goes to open a file that's on the file server
(the Linux box with Samba) it takes forEVER (okay, maybe more like a coupla
minute or so - but  still longer than the seconds we're used to) to download
the file. Or see everything in the drop-down file listing of an Open File
dialog box. Or see the entire network when browsing the My Network Places.
(yep, they're Win2k boxen).

I won't post my smb.conf file (to save bandwidth) unless someone
specifically asks for it.

Pointers? Tips? Places to look? Need more info?

<yodavoice>
Thank you I would like.
</yodavoice>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct 30 15:29:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

To my utter amazement, a post to the mod_perl mail list pointed out 
that eWeek has written a glowing review of Bricolage, the Perl-based, 
PostgreSQL-back-ended content management system. Read all about it!

   http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,652977,00.asp

From bjh at avalongroup.net  Wed Oct 30 15:35:22 2002
From: bjh at avalongroup.net (Brian Hoag)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 15:35:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba and Windows - 'nother issue - slow browsing
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <000701c2806d$03c68e50$6b0aa8c0@diesallotxp>

I have seen this as a problem with name resolution and not actually
Samba.  We fixed this once by putting the IP addresses and computer
names in the host file on the server so it doesn't try to resolve names
other than using the host file.  This worked for us.  Not sure you have
the exact same situation, but it is similar.  Try one box and see if it
works. 

--Brian Hoag
--Group Avalon Technology Services, Inc.

From revans at e-z.net  Wed Oct 30 15:57:03 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 15:57:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba and Windows - 'nother issue - slow browsing
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGOLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <20021031002420.ZFFC24071.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux>

Take a look at what is happening on the server, ie uptime , top, netstat -i
/dev/ethX, hdparm -v /dev/hdX (if you have ide drives ), .... to see if the
problem is box related. Samba related issues, nmblookup -S server, compare
nmblookup times to nslookup, smbclient -L server, use netview on a windows
box,...
Take a look at what is happening on the network with iptraf, or ntop. use
ethereal to get packet data. 

Using Samba p320

Our Recommendations

[global]
log level =1
socket options = TCP_NODELAY IPTOS_LOWDELAY
read raw = yes
write raw = yes
oplocks - yes
max xmit = 65535
dead time = 15
getwd cache = yes
lpq = 30
[okplace]
veto oplock files = /this/tah/theotherfile
[badplace]
oplocks = no

Thank you
Russell




On Wed, 30 Oct 2002 15:32:38 -0800, Michael J. Luevane said:

>
>  Pointers? Tips? Places to look? Need more info?
>

From eric at ejahn.net  Wed Oct 30 17:06:25 2002
From: eric at ejahn.net (Eric Jahn)
Date: 30 Oct 2002 17:06:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another Postgres GUI Client
Message-ID: <1036026386.22092.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

check out http://www.kazak.ws/xpg/index.php
Seems to have a better GUI than PGaccess, but you need the JRE
installed.

I got it connected to Postgres 7.2, but had to use the postmaster -i
switch to get the Postgres server to accept TCP/IP connections.  RH 8.0
doesn't setup the postmaster invocation this way, so I'll have to
reconfigure my init stuff, I guess.






From plug at maneuveringspeed.com  Wed Oct 30 18:08:42 2002
From: plug at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 18:08:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact - hee hee that was fun
In-Reply-To: <20021030221259.GE31534@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <002501c28082$6fafa100$6401a8c0@Endeavor>

well, seems you can't move the /bin directory without losing several
commands.  Same holds true with moving the /lib directory, though
there's not an easy way to recover without booting into a rescue mode
(easier to start anew with the "restoration)

So... rather than extract the .tgz's and then attempting to move the
directories from the /bak folder I created to the / folder... I imagine
I need to just extract them and overwrite at the same time... I can't
see which options to do this with "tar --help".

It occurred to me that I should be able to just COPY the extracted
directories on top of the existing ones with

	cp -Rpdf /bak/lib /

The problem is there seems to still be countless overwrite prompts,
unlike what would be expected with a -f option.

Suggestions?


-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Russ Johnson
Sent: Wednesday, October 30, 2002 2:13 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact


* Greg Long <plug at maneuveringspeed.com> [2002-10-30 13:39]:
> Good point on permissions. I used for example to archive the /usr dir:
> 
> tar -czf usr.tgz /usr
> 
> Shouldn't that do the deal?  If not, it's no big, as these backups are

> two weeks old. I will do this early morn on a weekend most likely.

I would add a 'p' to that list of options:

$tar -zcpvf tarball.tar.gz /source

'p' is 'p'ermissions.

The 'v' would be optional, but causes 'v'erbos output. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct 30 18:14:48 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 18:14:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
In-Reply-To: <861y676ask.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0210301811180.20457-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 30 Oct 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> Hint: this is wrong:
> 
> my $search_for = param('search_for');
> my $query = "SELECT name, address FROM atable WHERE name = '$search_for'";
> 
> For Perl, the key thing is *** use DBI placeholders ***.  It's amazing
> how many people don't do that, and instead try to substitute into the
> text.  Bleh.

More importantly, use TAINT CHECKING!

#!/usr/bin/perl -T

This won't let you use user input (like the $search_for in the example
above) without first running it through some kind of filter of your own
devising (preferably a regex that escapes metacharacters and the like).


I don't think I've written a piece of perl (other than one liners) in
years that didn't begin:

#!/usr/bin/perl -Tw
use strict;

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

At 3:24 PM -0800 10/30/02, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   My corporate attorney just sent me a copy of the FriendlyGreeting.com
>virus that was discussed here last week. Anyone want a copy -- with full
>headers, of course?


	Technically, this is NOT a virus, it's "malware". Some sites 
are calling it a "worm", however,  most likely due to user stupidity 
or ignorance in blindly clicking "yes" on the EULA.
	One of my friends was one of the first to "discover" it, and 
there has been an extensive thread on the DSheild list about it. 
Basically, it's not a virus because you AGREE to let them E-mail this 
to all of your contacts by agreeing to the terms of the EULA.

	Symantec, in particular, has not posted a position on the 
issue for those who are interested.

	http://www.sarc.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.friendgreet.worm.html

running that keep my modem alive, so I'd like to kill just it.

From bl.nordlund at verizon.net  Wed Oct 30 19:09:33 2002
From: bl.nordlund at verizon.net (Brian & Lori Nordlund)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 19:09:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Quick Printing Question
Message-ID: <000a01c2808a$f0a543c0$021ea8c0@nisse>

I have never been able to get printing to work.  However, I have only been doing SMB / file server and ipchains up until now so it hasn't been an issue.  Now I am trying to get a printer to work (Laserjet IIp Plus) so I have been digging into it and have come up short.  I am running mandrake 7.2.

I used printtool to try to get things set up.  When it didn't work, I tried to use linuxconf but still have not seen it work.  Whip me now, I know I shouldn't have tried the easy way out, but here I am.

My spool directory is lpd/lp0.  The printer is connected to dev/lp0.  However, if I try to print something with "lpr file.txt", it responds with "lpr: lp: unknown printer".  Shouldn't it be trying to print to the default printer specified in printcap?  As far as I know, my printer is named "Laserjet IIp"
 
Here is my etc/printcap:
# /etc/printcap
#
# This file was generated by Linuxconf's Printer module
# You may edit this file directly, but only standard printcap entries
# will be preserved.

##PRINTTOOL3## LOCAL ljet2p 300x300 letter {} LaserJet2p Default {}
Laserjet IIp:\
        :if=/var/spool/lpd/lp0/filter:\
        :lp=/dev/lp:\
        :mx#0:\
        :sd=/var/spool/lpd/lp0:\
        :sh:                      



dev/lp0 is a valid device:

[root at dovreguben /etc]# tunelp /dev/lp0
/dev/lp0 using IRQ -1


When I try lpc status, here is what I see:

lpc> status
Laserjet IIp:
        queuing is enabled
        printing is enabled
        no entries
        no daemon present   


Does anyone have any ideas of where to look?  It seems like I am close but just missing something.
Thanks,
Brian.

From bprew at logiccloud.com  Wed Oct 30 19:57:46 2002
From: bprew at logiccloud.com (Benjamin Prew)

Subject: [PLUG] [GENERAL] Bricolage Reviewed by eWeek! (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210301528160.3466-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

(http://www.everydevel.com), its another cms/perl/mysql-thingies.  I was
looking at it, and since it runs perlmonks.org how bad can it be?

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Oct 30 20:04:10 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)

Subject: [PLUG] Anyone want a copy of the new Microsoft virus?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210301919230.4071-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <p05100300b9e656f88de0@[192.168.3.1]>

I've been getting what I assume to be legitimate notices from automated 
software that my message could not be delivered because it contained an 
infected attachment.

Needless to say, I'm not sending infected attachments and the notices are 
coming from domains that I've never sent mail to.  I'd suspect the notice 
itself is a virus/hoax except there is no "click here" for more info.

Guessing that folks that have my addy in their address books are infected 
and I'm afraid I will start showing up on RBLs.

I guess it's time to change my addy and never correspond with MS users...

Kyle Accardi

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Wed Oct 30 21:02:06 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 21:02:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG]  Cisco Router Frontend
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210301509580.17362-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <00c001c2809a$a9c3de20$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

You can set up http server on the router.  It's no more complicated than

# conf t
router(config)# http server

Or something like that..  You can then load up a browser and
http://<loopback0> (or really any address on the router) and voila!  There's
tremendous security flaws involved in leaving it on so don't

I would make a snide comment about a Linux user not wanting to type, but
I've reached my asinine quotient today.  Come back tomorrow.

Todd Sarratt
CCNA CSCO10362093 (with experience, too, dammit!) and looking for work...

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Wed Oct 30 21:11:45 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 21:11:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding new ethernet card to Sun20 running debian
Message-ID: <00e701c2809c$0287c160$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

I inherited a Sun Sparc20 with two ethernet cards, one on board and an SBUS SCSI/10Meg Ethernet card.  Box takes DHCP over ETH0 and I haven't tried plugging anything into ETH1 but it looks alright (P.S. running debian) :

gibraltar:/etc# ifconfig
eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 08:00:20:72:F3:7A
          inet addr:192.168.0.23  Bcast:192.168.0.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          RX packets:2499 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:3273 errors:3 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:3
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:100
          RX bytes:266726 (260.4 KiB)  TX bytes:293539 (286.6 KiB)
          Interrupt:38

eth1      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 08:00:20:72:F3:7A
          inet addr:10.38.69.1  Bcast:10.255.255.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:100
          RX bytes:0 (0.0 b)  TX bytes:0 (0.0 b)
          Interrupt:55

lo        Link encap:Local Loopback
          inet addr:127.0.0.1  Mask:255.0.0.0
          UP LOOPBACK RUNNING  MTU:16436  Metric:1
          RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:0
          RX bytes:0 (0.0 b)  TX bytes:0 (0.0 b)

A friend slid an SBUS FastEthernet card my way and I'd like to set it up as eth2.  Here's what my interfaces file looks like :

gibraltar:/etc/network# more interfaces
# /etc/network/interfaces -- configuration file for ifup(8), ifdown(8)

# The loopback interface
# automatically added when upgrading
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The first network card - this entry was created during the Debian installation
# automatically added when upgrading

# This faces AT&T and that crazy internet
auto eth0
iface eth0 inet dhcp

#  This is the local zone.  Various rules will control it, probably
#  only allow HTTP connections out, etc.  It's 10.38.69.1/24
auto eth1
iface eth1 inet static
address 10.38.69.1
netmask 255.255.255.0

#   This is the DMZ.  Anything goes out.  Deciding still what
#   comes in.  This is 172.22.38.1/24
auto eth2
iface eth2 inet static
address 172.22.38.1
netmask 255.255.255.0

However, trying to restart the interfaces gives me :
gibraltar:/etc/network# ../init.d/networking restart
Reconfiguring network interfaces: eth2: ERROR while getting interface flags: No
such device
SIOCSIFADDR: No such device
eth2: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
SIOCSIFNETMASK: No such device
eth2: ERROR while getting interface flags: No such device
done.

I'm sure I'm missing something very obvious.  What is it?

Thanks,
Todd
