From rzeller at efn.org  Wed Oct 30 23:13:20 2002
From: rzeller at efn.org (Ralph Zeller)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 23:13:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Quick Printing Question
In-Reply-To: <000a01c2808a$f0a543c0$021ea8c0@nisse>
References: <000a01c2808a$f0a543c0$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <20021031071320.GA15600@zellercpa.com>

Brian,

There are many ways to fix printing problems, this isn't necessarily the
best, it's just what I would do.  I'm a newbee too and I don't use Mandrake.

First, you should use a name for the printer that doesn't have any spaces or
special puctuation, something like "lj2p" will work.  Next, add a command
like this one to your /home/brian/.bashrc file:
export PRINTER=lj2p

Ralph

On 10/30/02 07pm, Brian & Lori Nordlund wrote:
> I have never been able to get printing to work.  However, I have only been
> doing SMB / file server and ipchains up until now so it hasn't been an issue. 
> Now I am trying to get a printer to work (Laserjet IIp Plus) so I have been
> digging into it and have come up short.  I am running mandrake 7.2.
>  
> I used printtool to try to get things set up.  When it didn't work, I tried to
> use linuxconf but still have not seen it work.  Whip me now, I know I shouldn't
> have tried the easy way out, but here I am.
>  
> My spool directory is lpd/lp0.  The printer is connected to dev/lp0.  However,
> if I try to print something with "lpr file.txt", it responds with "lpr: lp:
> unknown printer".  Shouldn't it be trying to print to the default printer
> specified in printcap?  As far as I know, my printer is named "Laserjet IIp"
>  
> Here is my etc/printcap:
> # /etc/printcap
> #
> # This file was generated by Linuxconf's Printer module
> # You may edit this file directly, but only standard printcap entries
> # will be preserved.
>  
> ##PRINTTOOL3## LOCAL ljet2p 300x300 letter {} LaserJet2p Default {}
> Laserjet IIp:\
>         :if=/var/spool/lpd/lp0/filter:\
>         :lp=/dev/lp:\
>         :mx#0:\
>         :sd=/var/spool/lpd/lp0:\
>         :sh:

>

> dev/lp0 is a valid device:
>  
> [root at dovreguben /etc]# tunelp /dev/lp0
> /dev/lp0 using IRQ -1
>  
>  
> When I try lpc status, here is what I see:
>  
> lpc> status
> Laserjet IIp:
>         queuing is enabled
>         printing is enabled
>         no entries
>         no daemon present

From plug at maneuveringspeed.com  Wed Oct 30 23:36:54 2002
From: plug at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 23:36:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact - Celeron a i686?
In-Reply-To: <20021031023040.GA23742@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <002f01c280b0$48eac4e0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>

I think I may have found a glitch.  The Redhat 7.2 login msg states it
is "Kernel 2.4.7-10 on an i686"  I don't suspect the Kernel version to
be an issue but rather "i686".  The 300mhz Celeron is not an i686 I
don't beleive.

At any rate, after following a guide on hard disk upgrades I have copied
everything over but after using a boot disk, the system spontaneously
reboots and I'm in a loop as soon as it gets finished with the boot
disk.

All the files have been copied over OK mounting the new disk:

	cp -a /boot /etc /home /n

(with the new disk mounted on /n)

The walkthrough for disk upgrades is at:

http://help-site.com/LDP/HOWTO/mini/Hard-Disk-Upgrade/index.html

I did plug the drive as single master back into the 1ghz Duron box.  It
booted, but dropped out unable to mount the / partition correctly, only
the /boot partition it seems...I can troubleshoot that later, but it was
at LEAST able to load the kernel.

Thanks for all the help.  I think my next step may be to leave the hard
drive as is with the directories copied over, and rerun the anaconda
setup without formatting.  I imagine it should redetect hardware and
take care of housekeeping chores.  At least this works in Win, which as
we all know you MUST rerun setup if you have a new motherboard/CPU.

----Greg

From ken at new.cgi101.com  Wed Oct 30 23:59:56 2002
From: ken at new.cgi101.com (Ken Brush)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 01:59:56 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris and Decent Authentication
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210291611560.26184-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC439BECC@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210291611560.26184-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <20021031075956.GA13723@cgi101.com>

On Tue, Oct 29, 2002 at 04:23:36PM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Tue, 29 Oct 2002, Kaile Riser wrote:
> 
> > Having 8 significant chars in passwords is irritating. Beyond that,
> > I am going to be implementing NIS (and later LDAP) soon for
> > authentication, and I would MUCH prefer to use MD5 across the board
> > rather than DES. Is there a patch, pam update, pam module, etc...
> > that can do what I'm looking for, or am I SOL?
> 
> As far as I know, NIS is locked into DES, so any NIS solution is 
> DES-bound regardless of OS.
> 
> I'm unsure whether Solaris can work with MD5 hashes with LDAP 
> authentication, but I'm pretty sure it can't use them in any 
> files-based scheme like passwd/shadow.
> 

LDAP standard passwords are SHA1 encrypted. Solaris can support LDAP as
an authentication method starting at version 8.

In fact, Solaris 9 comes with an ldap server. 

-Ken



From fixin at peak.org  Thu Oct 31 00:05:29 2002
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 00:05:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] mixing executable and non-executable files in cgi-bin?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210302355190.1856-100000@tpol.peak.org>

I'm building a small website generated entirely by cgi scripts written
in perl, but with the generated html pages linking in an external css
style sheet.  For convenience, I want the .css file to live in the
same directory as the .cgi file.

I'm testing the site on two machines, one at home and the other at my
ISP (peak.org).  Both run apache on Linux (Debian at home, RedHat at
peak.)  When served from the ISP's apache all is well: the styles are
applied to the html.  But when I run from home apache tries to execute
the .css file and complains that it can't.

I've found lots of discussion of the problem online.  If apache is
configured to think every file in the cgi-bin directory is a script
then it'll try to execute them all.  But I can't find any concrete
suggestions on how to configure apache not to do this.  And comparing
my own httpd.conf and my ISP's doesn't help.  They seem to be pretty
much the same where cgi and execution are concerned.

Can anybody help me figure out how to get apache to just serve that
.css file rather than try to run it?

Thanks,

--Eric House

*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Oct 31 05:00:37 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 31 Oct 2002 05:00:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
References: <mailman.1035997894.3387.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <861y676ask.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <86n0ou226i.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Randal" == Randal L Schwartz <merlyn at stonehenge.com> writes:

Randal> Hint: this is wrong:

Randal> my $search_for = param('search_for');
Randal> my $query = "SELECT name, address FROM atable WHERE name = '$search_for'";

Randal> For Perl, the key thing is *** use DBI placeholders ***.  It's amazing
Randal> how many people don't do that, and instead try to substitute into the
Randal> text.  Bleh.

Heh.  I was wondering why this was sounding so familiar.... I wrote a
column on this very subject a few months ago.

See the text at <http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/LinuxMag/col40.html>.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Oct 31 05:01:41 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 31 Oct 2002 05:01:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SQL insertion attacks
References: <mailman.1036030524.8303.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86iszi224q.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> More importantly, use TAINT CHECKING!

Jeme> #!/usr/bin/perl -T

Jeme> This won't let you use user input (like the $search_for in the example
Jeme> above) without first running it through some kind of filter of your own
Jeme> devising (preferably a regex that escapes metacharacters and the like).


Jeme> I don't think I've written a piece of perl (other than one liners) in
Jeme> years that didn't begin:

Jeme> #!/usr/bin/perl -Tw
Jeme> use strict;

That's not enough to catch this.  A DBI call is not considered
"outside world" enough for tainted data to be annoying.

Good intention, insufficient result.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Oct 31 05:05:56 2002

millions of hits served (it's what slashdot and a hundred other sites
runs; everything2 is used by under a dozen sites that I'm aware of).
And Template Toolkit is an integral part of Slashcode.  Nice.

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Oct 31 05:31:19 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 05:31:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Quick Printing Question
In-Reply-To: <000a01c2808a$f0a543c0$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210310528510.27261-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 30 Oct 2002, Brian & Lori Nordlund wrote:

Along with what Ralph Zeller said another quick/cheap trick is to modify 
the following line and restart lpd.

> Laserjet IIp:\

  lp|Laserjet IIp:\

>         :if=/var/spool/lpd/lp0/filter:\
>         :lp=/dev/lp:\
>         :mx#0:\
>         :sd=/var/spool/lpd/lp0:\
>         :sh:                      


Rod

  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Oct 31 07:13:25 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 07:13:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding new ethernet card to Sun20 running debian 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 30 Oct 2002 21:11:45 PST."
             <00e701c2809c$0287c160$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> 
Message-ID: <200210311513.g9VFDP203317@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Were all three of your ethernet interfaces detected at boot time?
dmesg or /var/log/messages ought to show all three interfacess.
I would expect you to see the sparc equivalent of this three times.

tulip.c:v0.91g-ppc 7/16/99 becker at cesdis.gsfc.nasa.gov
eth0: Digital DS21140 Tulip rev 34 at 0xa400, 00:40:05:A1:C2:09, IRQ 14.
eth0:  EEPROM default media type Autosense.
eth0:  Index #0 - Media MII (#11) described by a 21140 MII PHY (1) block.
eth0:  MII transceiver #0 config 0000 status 780d advertising 01e1.
eth0: Setting full-duplex based on MII#0 link partner capability of 41e1.

Also, are you certain that your kernel/modules support the new card?

Perhaps Paul H. can provide some additional insight.

galen





From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Thu Oct 31 07:32:17 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 07:32:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact - Celeron a i686?

Greg wrote:
>I think I may have found a glitch.  The Redhat 7.2 login msg states it
>is "Kernel 2.4.7-10 on an i686"  I don't suspect the Kernel version to
>be an issue but rather "i686".  The 300mhz Celeron is not an i686 I
>don't beleive.

<snip>

Well, I can't respond to your problems loading the kernel, however, it is not reporting the CPU wrong.  All the processors from the Pentium Pro through the Pentium 4 are considered i686 chips.

From terrelw1 at attbi.com  Thu Oct 31 07:31:07 2002
From: terrelw1 at attbi.com (Terrel Woolbright)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 07:31:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] network setup problems
Message-ID: <3DC14CBB.5080109@attbi.com>

    Hello everyone. I am attempting to do a  network setup here at home. 
I have AT&T cable, a Mandrake 9 Linux box between it and an Intel 10/100 
hub and connected to the hub a Win98 box and Mandrake 9 Linux box. I can 
ping from any box to another box and to the outside (@ AT&T) so I figure 
I am "getting out". But I cannot start up lynx or Mozilla or anything 
else and get connected to the internet on any machine but the one just 
behind the cable modem.
    The box behind the modem is set for dhcp on eth0 for AT&T and eth1 
one is set static. The other two boxes are set with static IP addresses 
and the gateway to the IP of eth1 for the first box. It seemed like such 
a great thing to be able to ping to the outside. I just seem to be 
missing something or just not sure which step is next to take.

Thanks,
Terrel Woolbright
terrelw1 at attbi.com




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Thu Oct 31 08:00:43 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 08:00:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing hardware but keeping system intact - Celeron
 a i686?
References: <002f01c280b0$48eac4e0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <3DC153AB.7030204@parkrose.k12.or.us>

Greg Long wrote:
> I think I may have found a glitch.  The Redhat 7.2 login msg states it
> is "Kernel 2.4.7-10 on an i686"  I don't suspect the Kernel version to
> be an issue but rather "i686".  The 300mhz Celeron is not an i686 I
> don't beleive.

Celerons are just PII/PIIIs that have been neutered of some/all of their 
L2 cache and underclocked on the frontside bus. Still i686 though...

From mikedela at ipns.com  Thu Oct 31 08:27:59 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 08:27:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] network setup problems
In-Reply-To: <200210310809.20153.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <QK2VSRBIESO3POIH1Y75SO1TIFZW85.3dc15a0f@miked>

I agree with Carla, you can check to see if your DNS is set correctly by browsing 
via IP address. See the oregonlimo.com at http://209.210.228.34. No name, no need 
for DNS. You might check to see if your gateway is set. With my DSL and a 
firewall, I set my gateway to the internal address of my firewall.

HTH,
Mike

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 31 08:31:27 2002

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Oct 31 08:37:26 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 08:37:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG]  Cisco Router Frontend
In-Reply-To: <00c001c2809a$a9c3de20$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210301509580.17362-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <00c001c2809a$a9c3de20$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
Message-ID: <20021031163726.GA25392@rauhaus.org>

* todd.sarratt <todd.sarratt at attbi.com> [021030 21:01]:
> You can set up http server on the router.  It's no more complicated than
> 
> # conf t
> router(config)# http server

This is definitely not recommended for any Cisco router that is exposed
to Internet traffic - there have been a number of DOS-type problems with
the embedded http server.

--Stafford



From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Oct 31 08:42:48 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 08:42:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Cisco Router Frontend
In-Reply-To: <20021031003845.VAZH24555.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@linux>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0210301509580.17362-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <20021031003845.VAZH24555.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@linux>
Message-ID: <20021031164248.GB25392@rauhaus.org>

* Russell Evans <revans at e-z.net> [021030 16:40]:
> An expect script can save on typing if you are doing the same thing again and
> again, with only variable changes.
> 
> http://expect.nist.gov/

Also check our RANCID (Really Awesome New Cisco confIg Differ) at
http://www.shrubbery.net/rancid/.

While RANCID is designed to keep archives of all your router & switch
configs in a CVS repository, I've used the "clogin" script that comes
with it to do quick mass changes:

for i in `cat my_router_list`; do
	clogin -c "conf t; (config changes here); exit; write" $i
done

--Stafford



From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Oct 31 08:51:58 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 08:51:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Potpourri of questions this morning
Message-ID: <20021031165158.GA4442@dalsemi.com>

I'm pretty excited about Kroupware, so I started looking into migrating
from Sylpheed to Kmail, but Kmail won't read or import MH format, and
Sylpheed won't export to Maildir format, just mbox.  Does anyone
know of mail folder translation tools that might help me move?

Second, a bit of an install report.  I put RH 8.0 on my laptop and as
advertised by others, it was the smoothest install I've ever done.  RH
still uses the in-kernel PCMCIA drivers, so people with ToPIC PCMCIA to
PCI bridges are still screwed.  After finishing the install and going
through the initial configuration, I was presented with a beautiful
Blue Curve (TM) desktop environment and fonts that were about 3 pixels
high.  I had to manually kill X to get to a console, since the Alt-F7
console is apparently disabled by default now, and found that ORBit was
creating a 5 Mb/second .Xsession-error file in my home directory.

It was hosed, so I re-installed 7.3 last night.

Colin

?? to get to a console from X, ctrl+alt+fn. By default there are six consoles 
available, F1- F6. Alt+F7 brings you back from the console to the default X 
session. Just like it's always been.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Oct 31 10:39:43 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 31 Oct 2002 10:39:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and BackupExec (running on Windows server) Re:
	Samba + Windows question: can act as admin locally, but not when logged
	into the domain
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGNLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEGNLMAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1036089589.25572.481.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-10-30 at 15:23, Michael J. Luevane wrote:
> Ya, I know :)  The S96agent.be is there, I started it manually, it shows in
> the ps -A listing, but the Windoze box doesn't see it. Of course, this
> windows box has the problem as stated in the original subject line here.

This problem sounds like the BE services aren't running with a user
account from the domain.  The properties of the BE services should show
you what user the service are running under.  The linux box should also
be a member of the domain.

Good Luck

Derek
> 
> /===========================================================\
> | Michael Luevane      +                                    |
> | System Administrator +       mikel @ quantec llc . com    |
> | Quantec, LLC         +       www.quantecllc.com           |

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 31 10:41:26 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 10:41:26 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Hint on upgrading postfix on Red Hat boxes
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311033540.6690-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Yesterday, Simon Mudd released postfix-1.1.11-11.rpm for RH 7.3 and I
grabbed it and freshened the existing -1.1.11-7 package. That's when postfix
wouldn't restart and it took me about a half-hour to figure out what went
wrong and how to fix it. Of course, I couldn't write for help as nothing was
moving in or out. Knowing that there are others running postfix and Red Hat,
I offer the following insight based on a dialog Simon and I carried out this
morning.

  Apparently, Red Hat upgrades the .db libraries with each distribution
release. The libraries each have a different file format and the new one is
incompatible with the old one. The -7 postfix rpm was built on RH 7.2 with
db3.2; the -11 postfix rpm was built on RH 7.3 with db3.3. Go figure.

  Anyway, if you upgrade postfix via rpm on a RH system, and it won't
restart, look at the contents of /etc/postfix/ and rebuild every hashed or
mangled *.db that's there. For most of them, running /usr/sbin/postmap
hash:<filename> does the job. For aliases, run /usr/sbin/postalias. Then
invoke /etc/rc.d/init.d/postfix stop followed by ... start.

  Next time, it won't take me a half-hour and you'll save a bunch of time,
too.

Rich




From derek at infotects.com  Thu Oct 31 10:53:14 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Thu Oct 31 11:11:06 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 11:11:06 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Hint on upgrading postfix on Red Hat boxes
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311033540.6690-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311108070.17921-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Anyway, if you upgrade postfix via rpm on a RH system, and it won't
>restart, look at the contents of /etc/postfix/ and rebuild every hashed or
>mangled *.db that's there. For most of them, running /usr/sbin/postmap
>hash:<filename> does the job. For aliases, run /usr/sbin/postalias. Then
>invoke /etc/rc.d/init.d/postfix stop followed by ... start.

Yeah, Berkley DB version incompatibilities can drive one crazy.

postmap & newaliases works for Postfix, but for other apps that use
Berkley DB there is a "upgrade" utility. If you want to upgrade foo.db
to version 3.2, for example, you could run:

	db32_upgrade foo.db

-Eric

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Thu Oct 31 13:23:04 2002

# mount
/dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
none on /proc type proc (rw)
/dev/hda1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda7 on /data1 type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda6 on /data2 type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda5 on /data3 type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hdb1 on /data4 type ext3 (rw)
none on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)
/dev/hda9 on /home type ext3 (rw)
none on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
/dev/hda10 on /tmp type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda8 on /usr type ext3 (rw)
/dev/hda11 on /var type ext3 (rw)
none on /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc type binfmt_misc (rw

and when I did I left hda3 unformatted thinking I'd save all data on
that partition. I used the same /user , same passwd, but RH wouldn't let
me into that user. I made a new user but I'd like to find out if my old
stuff is still sitting there. I couldn't backup my data first, lord
buddha knows I tried, because the way I had the disk set up I had no
room left that I could access. Thus the reinstall. How do I access hda3,
which is supposedly not formatted.
Thanks, Dirk






From plug at maneuveringspeed.com  Thu Oct 31 13:29:10 2002
From: plug at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 13:29:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] cannot receive mail locally
Message-ID: <004101c28124$8d0165c0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>

...even from another user on the same domain.

If you followed the "Changing hardware but keeping system intact"
thread, I should start off with saying I was successfully able to copy
all over to the new hard drive, and then reinstall Redhat 7.2 on the
existing system (install, not an upgrade, all packages, formatting only
the /boot and /swap partitions).

I had to modify /etc/sysconfig/network HOSTNAME setting from
localhost.localdomain to eagle.maneuveringspeed.com.  I rebooted (easier
than stopping and restarting individual services).

All users appear present and accounted for, I can su with ease, and
Apache, the mailman interface, vncserver, and basically everything works
as far as I can tell with the exception of mail:

local users cannot receive anything - even from local users.  Mail sends
just fine to other domains.  Thinking it might be a postfix problem, I
tried the fix posted earlier today in the PLUG mailing list.  Still no
go.  I su'ed to one user, and sent mail to another user on the same
system with PINE.  Still no go.  Mail sent from other domains bounces.
Root seems to wind up with the bounces sent from local users (see below)

To further explain:  "postfixer" is a user account I used for the
postfix mailing list.  It's not created by postfix or anything else.  I
run mail through spamassassin and anomy sanitizer.  Since mail runs
through these excellent tools and out to other domains, it seems quite
unlikely they are the culprit.  I *am* wondering where
"filter at localhost" comes from since I modified the hostname as mentioned
above.

I am, of course, running on the original maneuveringspeed box now.

Suggestions?  When this is all done, I'll draw up some formal document
and add this to the knowledge base!

---Greg

From lemming at attbi.com  Thu Oct 31 13:40:11 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 21:40:11 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Reinstall
Message-ID: <20021031214012.KAKA29857.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>

> Hello all. I've reinstalled my RH 7.3 system as ;
> 
> /dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda1 on /boot type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda7 on /data1 type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda6 on /data2 type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda5 on /data3 type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hdb1 on /data4 type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda9 on /home type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda10 on /tmp type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda8 on /usr type ext3 (rw)
> /dev/hda11 on /var type ext3 (rw)

> and when I did I left hda3 unformatted thinking I'd
> save all data on that partition. I used the
> same /user , same passwd, but RH wouldn't let
> me into that user. I made a new user but I'd like
> to find out if my old stuff is still sitting
> there. I How do I access hda3,
> which is supposedly not formatted.

I slightly editted.

The reason the password was changed is because an 
install will overwrite older files.  Formatting just 
means formatting the partition.  If your user had the 
usual place for their data, it would be in /dev/hda9 
or /home.  If you formatted that, then the data is gone. 
(well, except for expensive disk recovery services)





From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Oct 31 13:47:56 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 13:47:56 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] cannot receive mail locally
In-Reply-To: <004101c28124$8d0165c0$6401a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311342170.14666-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

Greg,

The first thing I'd do is compare your /etc/postfix/main.cf with your 
backup from before your hardware move. The reinstall might have saved the 
old main.cf file as main.cf.orig or .rpmsave.

Other than that, do the logs give any more hints as to whats up? Are the 
permissions and ownership set up like they were on the /var/spool/mail 
files?

HTH,
Keith

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Oct 31 14:38:45 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 14:38:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SAMBA 2.0.? and WinXP

can

figure

else and get connected to the internet on any machine but the one
just 
behind the cable modem.
    The box behind the modem is set for dhcp on eth0 for AT&T and
eth1 
one is set static. The other two boxes are set with static IP
addresses 
and the gateway to the IP of eth1 for the first box. It seemed like
such 
a great thing to be able to ping to the outside. I just seem to be 
missing something or just not sure which step is next to take.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Oct 31 15:21:24 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 15:21:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SAMBA 2.0.? and WinXP
References: <000601c2812e$eba19870$6b0aa8c0@diesallotxp>
Message-ID: <3DC1BAF4.5090905@sun.com>

You don't need to hack the registry if you use encrypted passwords.

I setup Samba on my fileserver at home with encrypted passwords - when 
we got a laptop that had XP preinstalled on it, as soon as I set it up 
to get on the network, sharing worked fine.

Samba was at least at v2.2ish however, I couldn't tell you about older 
versions.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Oct 31 16:01:26 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Anyone know this spammer?

Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Here is a supposedly valid phone number for a spammer hawking software to
> stop spam.
<...>
>   Whoever it is also does not accept IP-blocked calls and I don't feel like
> revealing my number.

Maybe it's someone building a valid phone number directory with a "you
called me" excuse for when you claim to have put yourself on the "don't
call" list. Just the way some spammers have a "remove from list" button
that is really a way to validate your e-mail address, this guy is trying
to get valid phone numbers, and won't bother taking the call if you
block your number from his caller id machine.

 >Folks,

 >Could someone please verify this for me before I
 >check it into 2.2?   Thanks.

 >

 >
 >---------cut here-----------------------------------------------
 >;
 >; This registry key (gathered from the Samba-tng lists) is needed
 >; for a Windows XP client to join and logon to a Samba domain
 >;
 >HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\netlogon\parameters
 >"RequireSignOrSeal"=dword:00000000
 >---------cut here-----------------------------------------------

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Thu Oct 31 16:27:22 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 16:27:22 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Reinstall
In-Reply-To: <3DC19F38.6000501@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311619550.12474-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Hello all. I've reinstalled my RH 7.3 system as ;
> 
> # mount
> /dev/hda3 on / type ext3 (rw)
> 
> and when I did I left hda3 unformatted thinking I'd save all data on
> that partition. I used the same /user , same passwd, but RH wouldn't let
> me into that user. I made a new user but I'd like to find out if my old
> stuff is still sitting there. I couldn't backup my data first, lord
> buddha knows I tried, because the way I had the disk set up I had no
> room left that I could access. Thus the reinstall. How do I access hda3,
> which is supposedly not formatted.
> Thanks, Dirk


It appears to me, that system is using hda3 as your root (/) partition and 
presumably it was used during the reinstallation.  I've never given 
installers the trust to "do the right thing" with regards to saving backup 
copies of configuration files such as /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to name 
two.  Classically, a RedHat install will create a filename.rpmsave when it 
finds a filename already in place when it wants to install filename from 
an rpm package.  Take a look in /etc for files with a ".rpmsave" attached 
to their names and you may find your original configuration files.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Oct 31 17:19:36 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 17:19:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Uh-oh! Upgrade breaks application
In-Reply-To: <200211010057.gA10v2205804@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311634300.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200211010057.gA10v2205804@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <20021101011936.GC15032@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> [2002-10-31 16:58]:
> >   Earlier today I grabbed the rpms to upgrade mozilla to 1.0.1. Now it won't
> > load. I've not had this happy experience before.
> > 
> >   First I had freshened the existing 1.0.0 version and I noticed that I
> > could not type anything in the URL box that opens when one presses
> > ctrl-shift-l. Then I tried accessing google and the URL entry box didn't
> > appear there either. So, I shut down mozilla.
> > 
> >   Second attempt involved removing all mozilla packages and re-installing.
> > Still cannot load the application. Even typing '/usr/bin/mozilla' at the
> > comand line doesn't fire it up or give me some useful feedback. The prompt
> > goes away for a few seconds, comes back and no mozilla is running.
> > 
> >   Anyone have some idea what might have broken?
> 
> Are you certain that all of your old mozilla processes are gone?  Do
> a 'ps aux' and check the output closely.  When my browser won't start,
> this is the first thing I check.

And then, try it as a different user, or move your ~/.mozilla directory.
If it works after moving your .mozilla directory, something in there is
corrupted. Copy things back, one at a time and test. When you copy
something, and then mozilla won't start, you've found what's corrupted.
Remove the offending item, and it should work again. 

I've had mozilla corrupt my prefs.js file a couple of times. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

"It is often easier to fight for principles than to live up to them." - Adlai Stevenson

Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 18:08:07 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Uh-oh! Upgrade breaks application
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311729400.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311759460.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   So, I'll go through by hand and remove all references to mozilla, then
> re-install the rpms.

  Russ, you did so well with the last suggestion, perhaps you'll do as well
with the next one.

  Letting mozilla create a new ~/.mozilla tree worked. It comes up now. But,
... there's a rather major problem: I cannot get it to accept the old
bookmarks.html file.

  I copy the bookmarks from the backup directory but as soon as I start
mozilla, the old (netscape version) bookmark list overwrites what I copied
there. I cannot figure out why. I've added a bunch of bookmarks to the new
one and reorganized the list. Each other time I upgraded mozilla I was able
to copy and keep my latest bookmark file.

  Very puzzling. Any ideas?

Thanks,

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 31 18:22:28 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 18:22:28 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Uh-oh! Upgrade breaks application
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311759460.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311818110.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I copy the bookmarks from the backup directory but as soon as I start
> mozilla, the old (netscape version) bookmark list overwrites what I copied
> there. I cannot figure out why. I've added a bunch of bookmarks to the new
> one and reorganized the list. Each other time I upgraded mozilla I was able
> to copy and keep my latest bookmark file.
> 
>   Very puzzling. Any ideas?

  I'll answer my own question by explaining how I fooled mozilla into
behaving properly.

  chmod 400 the new bookmarks.html file copied from the backup directory.
Exited mozilla. Restarted mozilla. Ta-da! The correct bookmark file was not
overwritten this time. Exited mozilla. Restarted mozilla. The proper
bookmarks are _still_ there.

  It must be stored in a prefs file and instantly overwrites the existing
bookmarks file as the program loads. And this now explains the problem I've
been having the past few weeks: saved bookmarks disappear the next time I
start mozilla. Don't know what to do about this other than post the
information somewhere the developers may see it.

Rich

From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 20:07:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] New directory size
Message-ID: <3DC1FDF9.1050705@attbi.com>

When I mkdir in RH 7.3, what size directory is made? This particular 
partition is 20,000M.Does the directory fill up the partition and if I 
make a new directory in that same partition, does the new directory take 
1/2 the partition?
Dirk




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Oct 31 20:16:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 20:16:21 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] New directory size
In-Reply-To: <3DC1FDF9.1050705@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210312015090.8783-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> When I mkdir in RH 7.3, what size directory is made? This particular 
> partition is 20,000M.Does the directory fill up the partition and if I 
> make a new directory in that same partition, does the new directory take 
> 1/2 the partition?

Dirk,

  I believe that the default size of a directory itself is 2048 bytes;
perhaps 4096 on a very large drive. What you put in that directory is
limited only by disk space.

Rich




From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Thu Oct 31 20:53:23 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 20:53:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] New directory size
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210312015090.8783-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210312015090.8783-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200210312053.23833.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Thursday 31 October 2002 20:16, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 31 Oct 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> > When I mkdir in RH 7.3, what size directory is made? This particular
> > partition is 20,000M.Does the directory fill up the partition and if I
> > make a new directory in that same partition, does the new directory
> > take 1/2 the partition?
>
> Dirk,
>
>   I believe that the default size of a directory itself is 2048 bytes;
> perhaps 4096 on a very large drive. What you put in that directory is
> limited only by disk space.

It depends on what filesystem you use.  Since this is RH, I'd probably 
guess either ext2 or ext3.  Either way, you probably allocated a full 
block which is often 4096 bytes.  As you add files to the directory, it 
will grow to take up the first block that was allocated.   Eventually it 
will get another block etc.  On ext2/3 filesystems, I often check the 
directory size just make sure that I'm not about to do an 'ls' on a 
directory with 300,000 files or something.

If you've got ReiserFS, then the directory size is likely very small. I've 
seen empty directories that take just a few bites because ReiserFS 
allocates disk space is ways completely different from ext2/3.

Best,
Kyle




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Thu Oct 31 21:00:03 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 21:00:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C
Message-ID: <200210312100.03361.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Okay, smarter persons, who can explain what LANG=C means? The context is using 
it as a pre-command to running a program, for example:

env LANG=C abiword

The effect is to set the locale of Abiword to US English ASCII- I want to know 
what C itself stands for. 

If you run 
env LANG=en_EN abiword

it generates an error message:
Gdk-WARNING **: locale not supported by C library

Abiword runs fine anyway.

thanks ever so,
Carla who is tired and wants to know, dammit, and Google has been only 
marginally helpful

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Thu Oct 31 21:17:32 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 21:17:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Yahoo! goes with PHP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210310802220.12438-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0210310802220.12438-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <200210312117.32266.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Thursday 31 October 2002 08:08, Matt Alexander wrote:
> On 31 Oct 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> > One of the people on the mod_perl list is an insider working at Yahoo,
> > and has just confessed that the presentation is a bit of smoke and
> > mirrors.  Apparently, the real reason was as we suspect: "politics".
>
> Bah.  PHP will work great for them.  It's a nice language that's
> improving very rapidly with a large development community.  No matter
> what language they chose, I'm sure someone would cry "foul play!" and
> "politics!"  I'm just happy that they're using more Open Source software
> because it makes my job easier when approaching management to do the
> same.

The foul play I see is not in what language they chose, but in the  
disregard for the cost of that choice.  Hmm, Perl shows as more performant 
in their own tests on the slide.  Hmm, they have a lot of people with Perl 
experience.  Hmm, they have all their business logic in Perl. 

It doesn't matter if it was Perl or Visual Basic.  They have a large 
investment in a language and they are choosing to ignore that asset.   It 
isn't as if the Perl code and all their special stuff will magically turn 
into PHP over night.  For a very long time, they are going to be 
maintaining and extending code in the systems they had before and PHP.  
Ask a COBOL programmer how long code lives.  

Anyone who thinks that management at Yahoo is going to say, "Oh sure, put 
off these fourteen revenue generating projects while you convert all that 
nasty old Perl code to PHP" is smoking crack.  New stuff in PHP, possibly, 
but forget about converting anything.  All that Yahoo seems to have done 
is make the burden on their development group even larger.

Best,
Kyle

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Oct 31 22:25:57 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 22:25:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding new ethernet card to Sun20 running debian 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 31 Oct 2002 21:49:51 PST."
             <20021101054952.31356C5CE@max.seansdomain.org> 
Message-ID: <200211010625.gA16Pv206898@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

sean at fork.com said:
> What really concerns me with the two cards that you have so far, is
> that they  seem to be displaying the same MAC address. 

I believe this is normal for Sun systems.  The MAC address is stored 
separate from the ethernet card, at least for non-PCI systems.  I'm 
guessing the logic is that multiple interfaces would never be on the
same net.  No doubt a google search would get you a better explaination.

galen





From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Oct 31 22:48:00 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 22:48:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C
References: <mailman.1036126803.17076.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4vxke.hqs@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Carla Schroder wrote:

> Okay, smarter persons, who can explain what LANG=C means? The context is
> using it as a pre-command to running a program, for example:
> 
> env LANG=C abiword
> 
> The effect is to set the locale of Abiword to US English ASCII- I want to
> know what C itself stands for.
> 
> If you run
> env LANG=en_EN abiword
> 
> it generates an error message:
> Gdk-WARNING **: locale not supported by C library
> 
> Abiword runs fine anyway.
> 
> thanks ever so,
> Carla who is tired and wants to know, dammit, and Google has been only
> marginally helpful

The C programming language.  Setting 'LANG' to 'C' reverts a few behaviours 
to "quirky" original UNIX ones, like 'B' being ordered before 'a' (unless 
you set 'LC_COLLATE'), high-bit characters not displaying (since true ASCII 
is only 7-bits), and a few other things.  Remember that UNIX and C are 
historically intertwined.

Wil
- -- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Oct 31 22:50:33 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 22:50:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Two NIC's in one box
References: <mailman.1036128843.19927.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4vxo9.ht8@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Hello Linux folkz,
> Is it possible to widen network bandwidth by using two NIC's in one box
> assigned to the same IP?
> 
> Thanks in advance for any suggestions.

It's not quite that easy, but yes, it can be done.  Google for 'channel 
bonding' and 'Fast Ether Channel'.  (Hint: You need an Ethernet switch that 
supports it.)
 
Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Oct 31 23:01:57 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 31 Oct 2002 23:01:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Potpourri of questions this morning
References: <mailman.1036083217.10185.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4vy7c.ihp@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Colin Kuskie wrote:

> I'm pretty excited about Kroupware, so I started looking into migrating
> from Sylpheed to Kmail, but Kmail won't read or import MH format, and
> Sylpheed won't export to Maildir format, just mbox.  Does anyone
> know of mail folder translation tools that might help me move?

Access your mail through IMAP and let the IMAP server manage the message 
store, not your mail client.  It's also a lot better when using new clients 
that might otherwise corrupt your mailbox.  If you want a fun evening, I've 
got RPMS for Cyrus IMAP at ftp://ftp.nakedape.cc/pub/contrib/cyrus-imap.  
Check out the on-line free chapter from the O'Reilly book "Managing IMAP" 
for information about importing mbox files into the Cyrus IMAP server 
store.  (I've got replacement Perl scripts for the couple Tcl scripts he 
uses that don't work any more, but I need to find them again and upload 
them.)

Wil
- -- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *
